HEADLINE: Albany Leaders, in Budget Push, Agree on Sales Tax for Services

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 30

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and legislative leaders have tentatively agreed to extend New York State's sales tax into a broad new area - the service industry.
The sales tax is also expected to be applied to magazines, which now enjoy special exemption, and to telephone calls made to 900 numbers.
But under the agreement, the details of which were still being worked out today, the bulk of the new revenue would come from extending the sales tax for the first time to services like custom computer programming, management consulting, public relations and cleaning services. $500 Million in New Taxes The new sales taxes, it is estimated, would be worth almost $500 million a year. The budget is expected to total $50 billion, and legislators are looking for ways to fill a budget gap that is estimated to be as high as $4 billion. 
Business lobbyists, who have bitterly opposed the plan to expand the sales tax, say it represents a major departure from the state's longstanding policy of limiting the tax to tangible goods and to services that result in tangible goods, like film developing. They say they are concerned that the new sales taxes could crimp New York's service industry, which has been the fastest growing segment of the state's economy.
''For the first time in New York, we're going to be putting taxes on intangible property,'' said Daniel Walsh, president of the Business Council of New York State, the state's largest business lobby. ''It sets tax policy in a very disadvantageous way.''
The tax package appeared to be one of the few elements of the state budget still under negotiation today, four weeks after the legal deadline. The talks have been proceeding almost line by line through the budget.
After a round of late-night talks on Sunday, officials said they had resolved many of the outstanding issues and had already begun to print parts of the budget. It was still unclear, however, when the Legislature would act.
''It's down to two things: the tax package and school aid,'' said one legislative budget analyst. The distribution of state school aid totaling more than $8 billion is traditionally the last budget issue to be resolved. #32 New Judgeships Under an agreement reached Sunday night, the budget would include provisions to create 32 new judgeships across the state. The agreement would end a four-year political impasse that held the number of judges in the state constant while the number of criminal cases soared. [Page B2.] The sales-tax package is just one piece of a broad array of new taxes and fees that are expected to be imposed as part of the budget. All told, the increases are expected to total more than $1 billion. State officials say the increases are needed to counteract a slump in state income and business tax collections.
Officials plan to close the rest of the estimated $4 billion budget gap by making cuts and using one-time revenues like reserve funds and the proceeds from refinancing of bonds.
Maintaining the silence that has surrounded state budget talks, Governor Cuomo and the legislative leaders have refused to discuss details of the new sales taxes.
Under New York's current sales-tax laws, a 4 percent state tax is added to almost all consumer goods except food. On top of this, counties add an additional 3 or 4 percent sales tax - New York City imposes 4 1/4 percent - to all goods subject to the state tax.
Some personal services are subject to the sales tax now, including car repairs and appliance installations. New York City imposes additional sales taxes on parking fees, haircuts, private protection services and detective services.
 
Broadening the Base
Some of the changes in the state sales tax would simply extend taxes already imposed in New York City to the entire state. For example, state leaders have tentatively agreed to extend the state sales tax to cover parking, protection services and detectives.
Many of the new taxes, however, would bring the sales tax into a realm that has traditionally been avoided by both New York City and New York State. These are some of the services that would be taxed:
* Custom-designed computer software, which includes computer programs specifically designed for use by a single corporation.
* Management consulting and public relations services.
* Janitorial services provided by independent cleaning agencies.
By broadening the base of its sales tax, the state would simultaneously expand the base of the tax for counties and cities. Budget analysts said today that the new sales tax could provide as much as $100 million in new revenues to New York City, the center of the state's service industry.
 
Crucial to Balance the Budget
Budget analysts in the State Capitol were working today to draft legislation expanding the sales tax. They said that crafting the legislation so that it would effect only the services intended was proving difficult. But they said the taxes were considered crucial to a balanced budget.
In moving to tax a broader range of services, New York is following an increasingly well-trod but still controversial path, tax experts say.
''Our economy is moving away from tangible personal property to services,'' said Laird Graeser, a research associate with the Federation of Tax Administrators in Washington. ''That's where the money is. But for lots of folks in the business community, it's the camel's nose in the tent.''
Groups like the Business Council say they fear it is only a small step from taxing management consulting to taxing services like legal advice or advertising. Only three states, Mr. Graeser said, currently tax such services: Hawaii, South Dakota and New Mexico.
Three years ago Florida acted to impose a tax on a wide spectrum of services including advertising. But the tax was repealed after out-of-state businesses that advertised in Florida objected to paying it.

HEADLINE: Bush Assails Congress for Delay Of $420 Million in Aid to Panama

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 30

 BODY:
As President Bush welcomed President Guillermo Endara of Panama to the White House, he used the occasion today to criticize Congress for delaying a bill that includes $420 million to help rebuild the Panamanian economy.
''It's embarrassing,'' Mr. Bush told the United States Chamber of Commerce before his meeting with the Panamanian leader. ''I've asked the Senate and the House to move on that legislation over a month ago, and they haven't done it. It's frustrating.'' 
 
Senate Approves Compromise
After President Bush's heated criticism, the Senate approved a compromise tonight that removed a major obstacle to the legislation, which also includes $300 million in aid to Nicaragua.
Senate action on the bill had been stalled over a series of unrelated amendments, including one that would have allowed the District of Columbia to pay for abortions for poor women and another imposing the death penalty in the district for certain drug-related crimes.
Mr. Bush had threatened to veto the measure if the provision on money for abortion was not removed. But Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican minority leader, said that the President had interrupted a meeting with him this morning to call Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Democratic majority Leader, and implore him to enact the bill.
Negotiations among the senators produced an agreement to pass the abortion and death penalty amendments and move the battle over those issues to a House-Senate conference committee. The House version of the bill on Panama aid does not address abortion or the death penalty.
Mr. Endara's visit to Washington is his first since American forces invaded Panama on Dec. 20 and ousted the country's military leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. Mr. Bush, speaking to reporters after his talks with Mr. Endara, said the United States has a responsibility to see that Panama's shattered economy is repaired.
 
Meeting Expectations
''Unemployment in Panama remains unacceptably high, and we want to help President Endara reduce it to and meet the rising expectations of a liberated Panamanian people,'' Mr. Bush said, adding that trade and credit guarantees approved by Congress this year are only half the job.
While there is virtually no dispute in Congress that the United States has an obligation to assist Panama, some lawmakers have argued that the money in the aid package is more than can be effectively used now.
Mr. Endara, who had hoped for as much as $1 billion from the United States, made no public reference to the aid package today. He expressed general appreciation, saying: ''We are grateful for the American people. Everybody in Panama loves President Bush.''
Mr. Endara was installed as President by United States invasion forces in December. In May of last year, he was the opposition presidential candidate in elections. General Noriega claimed victory, but international observers said the election was a fraud; days later, the Noriega Government declared the elections void.

HEADLINE: German Unification Is Outrunning the Diplomats

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST BERLIN, April 30

 BODY:
Representatives of the four victorious powers of World War II convened in a castle here today with East and West German Government specialists to discuss an agenda leading to a unified German state.
But even as the experts began their discussions, the German Democratic Republic created by the Communists is melting away piece by piece, hour by hour as West German companies and products move into the East German market and Bonn officials take the upper hand here.
Diplomats are already making jokes about the ''four plus two'' formula that brought specialists of the Soviet Union, United States, Britain, France and the two German Governments to the round glass-topped table in East Berlin's Niederschonhausen Castle.
 
Unification Arithmetic
''Four plus two. That equals five,'' says one current aphorism making the point that East Germany simply does not count any more as an international player. 
The experts are supposed to prepare talking points for the full scale four-plus-two meetings of their Foreign Ministers beginning Saturday in Bonn.
But the changes taking place in the lives of East Germans seem to be outpacing the deliberations in the castle. Already hundreds of West German entrepreneurs have set up businesses in East Berlin and other East German areas. An East German car owner was astounded the other day to find the People's Own Chemicals Factory tire store that he was accustomed to patronize was now labeled Kroning, a West German concern. Inside were products from the British company Dunlop and the French giant Michelin.
''Is this now a private shop?'' the driver asked a workman.
''I don't know,,'' the employee replied. ''It doesn't interest me. The main thing is the pay envelope.''
 
Quick Film Developing
Down the street a camera shop has announced that its customers can now have one-day service for developing and printing their films instead of the of two to three weeks that had been customary. The proprietor has begun sending film to a West Berlin firm for processing.
Such services, of course, cost more than the East German ones they are replacing and with East German wages scaled at roughly one-third those of West Germany, the new prices concern many people here.
More worrisome for the bulk of the East Germans is that as soon as a treaty between East Berlin and Bonn initiating a currency union goes into effect on July 1, rents, public transport prices and other items kept low by heavy subsidies all the years of Socialism will go sky-high.
''I've already started planning to move to a smaller apartment,'' said Hans Gerd Protsch, a Foreign Ministry official who has a four-room flat facing Karl-Marx-Allee.
 
Property Claims
Other East German householders have become anxious that many of the more than three million people who fled this country since it was founded in 1949 will now demand their properties back.
Recently West Germany's Central Association of House, Apartment and Property Owners calculated that as many as 500,000 citizens will raise such claims.
In addition claims are being made for properties confiscated by the Communist authorities after they took power. One such claim has been filed by a citizen of Switzerland who owned the land near Alexanderplatz where a huge television tower now stands. ''I don't want a television tower,'' the former Berliner told an interviewer.
The rapid approach of German unity on the practical level brought about by the March 18 Parliamentary vote in favor of East Germany's Christian Democratic Union Party has created elements of chaos here. The uncertainties have also prompted another increase in migration of East Germans to West Germany with 4,000 making the journey last week, a figure that is almost twice the low point that was recorded after the March elections.
 
Western Products
On the one hand, the stores filling up with West German goods have on the one hand, pleased shoppers, but on the other, led retailers to refuse to order from East German wholesalers on the premise that the goods were unsalable. A walk past the stores of Friedrichstrasse makes the point: French perfumes, Italian sunglasses and American cigarettes are on display, crowding out East German products.
Supermarkets carry West German eggs, beer and bread at three times the price but hardly three times the quality of East German eggs, beer or bread -yet East Germans are paying the premium for the Western products.
Because of these buying patterns, a surplus of three million eggs has accumulated in East Germany.
Over the weekend, hundreds of East German farmers mounted demonstrations with tractor convoys to protest the invasion of West German farm products, which have forced them to suspend deliveries of their own goods and put off slaughtering of animals for meat.
 
Prospect of Unemployment
A further concern of the East Germans is the prospect of mass unemployment as large numbers of state enterprises close down and others trim their work forces. Already 10,000 are officially registered as jobless in East Berlin and probably another 10,000 who have no work but have not declared themselves. The unemployed receive 70 percent of their wages.
Among the unemployed are many senior figures of East Germany's former Communist Party, including Egon Krenz, who was briefly First Secretary last Autumn and Gunter Schabowski, the Politburo member who declared the opening of the Berlin Wall on television on Nov. 9.
Mr. Schabowski, who is in his early 50's, told a party comrade last week that he had applied to the City Waterworks for a job as inspector of fountains. He explained that East Berlin had over 1,000 fountains and that water purity was often a problem. He was refused the post because of his membership in the Party of Democratic Socialism, the successor of the Communist Party.

HEADLINE: Move to Suburbs Spurs The Poor to Seek Work

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EVANSTON, Ill., April 30

 BODY:
Poor black women who have moved from Chicago public housing projects to the suburbs are more likely to find jobs than are women who moved to another neighborhood within the city, researchers at Northwestern University say.
The researchers found that many women had been hampered in pursuing jobs because of fear of crime around the housing projects. In large part, the suburban women told the researchers, they now felt free to pursue jobs because they felt safe to be outside. 
''Many of the women talked about how liberating it was to be able to go out at night and not feel danger,'' said James Rosenbaum, a sociologist who headed the study. ''They also talked about the availability of jobs in the suburbs.''
The women in the study were helped to move from Chicago Housing Authority complexes to subsidized housing units in mostly white suburbs or to more racially mixed parts of the city, as part of a settlement in a Federal suit over segregation in Chicago public housing. It is the choice of the families whether to move to a suburb or to another location in the city.
 
Motivation in Suburbia
The study, released last Tuesday, looked at 230 women, all of them mothers, who had moved to the suburbs and 112 who had moved within the city from 1982 to 1987. It found that the suburban women were far more likely to find jobs than were their counterparts in the city. The employment rate for those in the city was 50.9 percent; for those in the suburbs, 63.8 percent.
''Some women reported feeling a lot more motivated in the suburbs,'' Mr. Rosenbaum said. ''They saw all of their neighbors working. And the parents of their children's friends were working, and some women said this gave them incentive to get jobs.''
The study also found that women who moved to the suburbs were just as integrated socially with their neighbors as were the women who relocated in the city, a finding that the researchers said was unexpected. The researchers had expected that poor black women in more affluent, white suburbs might feel isolated.
But 75 percent of suburban and city women reported making friends, and both groups reported making the same number of friends. In the city, those friends were more often black; in the suburbs, they were more often white.
 
Rebutting the Critics
On average, the women in the study were 35 years old, had 2.5 children and had been receiving welfare payments for more than five years. The demographics of the women in the study largely resemble those of the population in the housing projects.
The researchers said the study showed that relocating poor people into suburban areas could be effective. Critics of the program had predicted that poor black women would not adapt in the suburbs or would not be accepted. In the 14 years since the program was started, about 3,500 poor black families have been helped to move from the public housing projects.
''People remarked repeatedly how oppressive it was to live in the projects,'' Mr. Rosenbaum said. ''They felt they couldn't get a job, because it wasn't safe to be out after dark. And they didn't want to leave their kids alone after school, because they were frightened they would be lured into the gangs.''

HEADLINE: The Perils of Bashing Junk Bonds

 BODY:
Michael Milken is a convicted felon. But he is also a financial genius who transformed high-risk bonds - junk bonds - into a lifeline of credit for hundreds of emerging companies. Snubbed by the banks, these businesses would otherwise have shriveled.
In other words, the Milken case presents issues far more important than one person's slide from the financial pinnacle. There is no condoning Mr. Milken's criminality. But if overzealous Government regulators overreact by indiscriminately dismantling his junk bond legacy, they will wind up crushing the most dynamic parts of the economy. 
Junk bonds are securities that pay high interest because they are issued by companies with little collateral, as is true of new businesses. After the credit crunch of the 1970's, banks retreated from lending to such concerns. So Mr. Milken came to their rescue, raising billions for upstarts like MCI, Turner Broadcasting and the Hovnanian home-building enterprise. About half the money was for capital investment and other internal needs. Used in this way, junk bonds promote economic growth.
The controversy surrounds the use of junk bonds to buy other businesses. And even these acquisitions were mostly non-hostile and non-controversial. Only one in twenty involved a takeover of a large company, and in these, the pressure of large debt impelled new management to improve operations. The mere threat of takeover forced greater efficiency even in non-target companies.
Mr. Milken reminds his audiences that only 5 percent of American corporations have high credit ratings. Cutting off junk bonds means cutting off vital credit for the remaining 95 percent, including nearly every company run by a minority member or a woman. Mr. Milken feathered the financial nest of many fat cats through dubious, even illegal practices. Still, his image as some sort of financial Robin Hood isn't entirely off the mark.
Some junk bond takeovers did harm, ringing up so much debt that even well-run companies like Bloomingdale's were driven into bankruptcy. The takeover binge saddled businesses with debt that creates a cloud of potential bankruptcies. Junk bond takeovers also paved the way for low blows. Raiders threatened managers of target companies with greenmail, a huge payoff at shareholder expense. Over all, however, the final verdict on junk bond takeovers isn't in. Meanwhile, the important need is to stop reacting hysterically to the fraud and excess of the Milken revolution.
First, Congress overreacted to the rash of savings and loan bankruptcies by requiring thrifts to shed all their junk bonds by 1994. This was done even though junk bonds contributed very little to S & L losses, according to Prof. Larry White of New York University and a member of the former Federal Home Loan Bank Board.
Now, state and Federal regulators are pressuring pension funds and mutual funds to divest their junk bonds. The group representing state regulators is considering further limits on junk bond holdings of insurance companies, even though these make up a small percentage of the assets of most companies. And bank regulators are raising their standards, penalizing higher-risk commercial loans.
The danger of crimping so much capital flow is obvious; a fifth of all new corporate debt issues involve junk bonds. There's a chilling message here for small businesses without valuable assets: Don't look to the banks for capital. Don't look to insurance companies or pension funds. Don't look to Wall Street. In short, don't look. Unless your name is Exxon or I.B.M., prepare to wither.
What's needed is not vindictive junk bond bashing; it's prudent financial regulation. For example, it makes sense to outlaw greenmail. It makes sense to help regulatory authorities by requiring that pension funds, insurance companies and banks provide updated figures for the market value of their junk bonds and other assets.
But a frenzied attack on all junk bonds makes no sense. If that continues, the nation will wind up transforming Michael Milken's downfall into an economic catastrophe.

HEADLINE: TOPICS OF THE TIMES;
Squeezing the Slorc

 BODY:
Since the army shot down a democratic revolution in Myanmar, formerly Burma, 19 months ago, that nation's 40 million people have been helpless victims of a capricious military regime. Washington has suspended official aid. But Myanmar's ruling State Law and Order Restoration Council, or Slorc, has found a new way to pay for its brutal military operations. It recently opened Myanmar's long-closed economy to foreign commerce.
Teak, fish, seafood, petroleum and minerals are Myanmar's main legal exports. Myanmar is also the source for roughly half the world's heroin. The leading drug lord is Khun Sa, whose private army fights alongside Slorc troops against non-Burmese ethnic tribes at Myanmar's borders. Their aim is to make it easier to ship drugs and other exports abroad. The U.S., unfortunately, is a big market for both legal and illegal commodities.
But thanks largely to Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, American consumers may soon stop subsidizing repression. Mr. Moynihan has attached a provision banning U.S. imports from Myanmar to this year's mini-trade bill. By accepting the provision, the House would squeeze the Slorc - and perhaps hasten the fall of one of the world's least savory regimes.

HEADLINE: 20% Dropout Rate Found For Italian-Americans

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE

 BODY:
In movies, newspapers and best-selling novels, Italian-Americans say, they often find themselves depicted as killing, cooking or singing.
That biased view, experts said yesterday, has filtered through to classrooms in New York, where many Italian-American students suffer low self-esteem because of the stereotypes. A study released yesterday showed that 20.65 percent, or 1 in 5, will not finish high school.
Those figures are alarming to Italian-American leaders, who for the first time separated the statistics for Italian-American youths from those for whites in general. The dropout study, by City University researchers, showed that Italians, the largest white ethnic group in the city, have the third-highest dropout rate. 
Hispanic students have the highest rate, with 31.78 percent. Blacks are second, at 24.54. The rate for other whites is 18.55. Italians are one-third of the white students in the schools.
''Italian-American youth are highly influenced by popular culture, like all others,'' said Dr. Richard Gambino, director of Italian-American Studies at Queens College and a writer of books and studies of Italian-Americans.
''Hollywood has given an image over the years that Italian-Americans are inferior, physical, anti-intellectual,'' Dr. Gambino said. ''There is the criminal image of the Italian-American. This is not a healthy basis for a self-image to succeed in life or education.''
''The notion that we are all either bigots, bums or buffoons still lives,'' said Frank Arricale 2d, superintendent of Community School District 11 in the Bronx.
The dropout numbers and the reasons behind them were the focus of a daylong conference at the City University Graduate Center on West 42d Street. Held under the auspices of the state and the United Federation of Teachers, the session attracted 175 people.
 
'Driven by a Passion'
Matilda R. Cuomo, wife of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and honorary chairwoman of the State Council on Children and Families, was the leader.
''This is especially distressing, because Italians came to America driven by a passion to get a good education,'' Mrs. Cuomo said. The experts said the reasons for the high dropout rate included not only poor self-esteem and self-images, but also factors like peer pressure, parental ignorance about education and the belief that the benefits of education did not outweigh working.
The profile of Italian-American Educational Attainment, prepared by the John D. Calandra Italian-American Institute, showed Italian-American students in New York lagging behind those elsewhere in the country. Nationally, 15.5 percent of Italian-Americans have less than an eighth-grade education. In New York, the figure is 24.9 percent. Nationally, 18.7 percent have some college work, compared with 12.5 in New York.
 
Concern for 'White Underclass'
The director of the institute, Dr. Joseph V. Scelsa, said Italian-Americans in New York were simply suffering the same urban stresses that are so well documented for black and Hispanic youths, gangs, family dissolution and economic pressures.
''I personally think there is a white underclass in New York beyond Italians, and New York City needs to address that segment,'' Dr. Scelsa, a sociologist, said. ''When you look at the Bensonhurst situation you have to look at perception. There is the perception that Italian-American youths are not going to be given the same opportunities as those in affirmative-action categories. It creates an anger. Unfortunately black men become a symbol of the special treatment.''
The Bensonhurst incident, in which a black teen-ager, Yusuf K. Hawkins, was apparently slain at the hands of a group of white youths because of his race, was a topic throughout the conference. The killing and the press depictions of the predominantly Italian-American neighborhood in Brooklyn pointed up the need for education on the contributions of all groups, conference participants said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Negative stereotypes of Italian-Americans in the press have filtered through to New York schools, where Italian-Americans have a dropout rate higher than 20 percent. Dr. Joseph V. Scelsa, who gave a report to psychologists and education experts, talked with Matilda R. Cuomo. (Chester Higgins, Jr./The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Pricing the Priceless: Museums Resist, Accountants Insist

BYLINE: By ALISON LEIGH COWAN

 BODY:
Astronauts have risked their lives to lug chunks of moon rock back to Earth, where the museum-going public has been able to admire them. Now comes the hard part: figuring out what the rocks are worth.
The moon rocks are only the tip of a nasty accounting dispute that has museum executives livid. Until now, hardly any museums have put a dollar value for their collections on the financial statements they show lenders or donors. Most museums believe the information is hard to compute and irrelevant to day-to-day operations. They also see little benefit in flagging the enormous riches in their collections if it would deter donors and tempt thieves. As a result, many museums' most valuable assets, from moon rocks to Michelangelos, are nowhere on their books.
To the Financial Accounting Standards Board, the private seven-member group in Norwalk, Conn., that makes most of the nation's accounting rules, the omissions reflect poorly on the museums' financial statements. So the board is drafting tough new accounting rules that would require museums to state the value of their collections on their balance sheets to earn the unqualified approval of their auditors. 
Though the rules do not have the force of law, most museums are concerned about this proposed change because they have long found it useful to have audited financial statements for fund-raising and other purposes, and auditors will not certify books that do not comply with the profession's chief rule-making body. Guardians of Art or Bookkeepers? But just as Fasbee, as the keeper of the accounting rules is informally known, is offended by the mass oversight, many museums find the proposed solution offensive. To them, the thought of putting a dollar value on their collections is inconsistent with their mission as keepers of rare artworks and other historical treasures.
The clash comes at a time when the art world at large is already under pressure from lawmakers and others to be more accountable for the handling of the treasures in its care. Indeed, a similar argument erupted two years ago when New York City began requiring art galleries to post their prices conspicuously and art dealers derided the effort as crass. More recently, some New York State legislators have backed a bill that would force museums to make their records of sales and purchases available to the public, a reform that the museums have fought in the past.
Many museum officials also fear that the proposed accounting rules could bankrupt smaller institutions. A preliminary estimate by the American Association of Museums in Washington put the cost of compliance at $50 billion, assuming that it would cost an average of $50 to appraise each of the country's roughly one billion museum objects.
Considering that the new rules would cover some 7,000 nonprofit institutions ranging from art museums and historical societies to zoos and botanical gardens, that estimate may be less farfetched than it sounds. Even if the job could be done for less, many museums say they would still refuse to comply rather than spend scarce money on what they consider an absurd exercise.
Robert N. Anthony, a professor emeritus of the Harvard Business School who has written about nonprofit institutions' special accounting issues, said, ''If there ever was a bean-counting rule, this is it.''
 
More Professionalism a Goal
The Fasbee official in charge of the project, Ronald Bossio, concedes that few investors or donors are clamoring for new rules. Nonetheless, he said, the new standards will advance the board's goal of making the books of nonprofit institutions more like those of for-profit institutions and should improve the level of professionalism at the handful of museums that keep poor records of their collections.
''The real question,'' he said, ''is if you're going to present a balance sheet, why would you leave out an asset, particularly one as valuable as a van Gogh?''
Some museums retort that the objects they own are held in perpetuity and thus are not assets in the traditional sense - a difficult claim to make in light of the growing number of museums that deaccession, or sell, items from their ''permanent'' collections to raise money.
To demonstrate what they consider the impossibility of the task, the museums also argue that these items are hard to price, if not priceless. Brisk markets may exist for select works of art, they grant, but the bulk of collectibles either have thin markets or are one-of-a-kind objects whose price cannot be gleaned from the sale of comparable items.
How, for instance, would anyone appraise the American Museum of Natural History's Star of India, the world's largest known sapphire? What about George Washington's false teeth at the National Museum of American History in Washington, Babe Ruth's uniform at the Baseball Hall of Fame in Cooperstown, N.Y., or the giant pandas at the National Zoo in Washington?
 
Problems in Other Areas
Valuation problems, of course, plague other assets as well, from junk bonds to real estate, which suggests to some that the museums may have other motives for opposing the new rules.
''The arguments against doing so seem very strong,'' said William D. Grampp, a visiting economist at the University of Chicago who wrote ''Pricing the Priceless,'' a recent book that takes a dim view of government subsidies for art. ''But they actually are not, because they apply equally to the private enterprises, and private enterprises have managed to handle these problems.''
He believes that museums hate the idea because they want to spur gifts and deter theft. ''If the public knew what the value of museums' collections were, they would stop giving and start stealing,'' he said.
Aside from Professor Grampp, who calls the proposed new rules ''a very good idea,'' it is hard to find anyone with a kind word for the proposal -or for the accountants who dreamed it up. Even the appraisers, who stand to make millions in fees, are hard-pressed to defend it. ''Sure, I'd like to have the business, but I'm not sure what that's going to accomplish,'' said Ellen Epstein, a fine arts appraiser in Mount Kisco, N.Y.
And the debate is turning nasty. Edward H. Able, the executive director of the American Association of Museums, can barely conceal his impatience with ''Mr. Bossio and his near-sighted accountants.'' For his part, Mr. Bossio accused the museums of thinking they are above rules that are good enough for everyone else. ''They want to live in a different world and use different definitions of assets and liabilities,'' he said.
 
On a Field Trip
Nonetheless, many museums have urged members of their star-studded boards to write protest letters, and quite a few have done so. Several museums also volunteered to arrange field trips intended to make the accountants appreciate the mind-numbing ordeal ahead. Last month, William J. Moynihan, the director of the Amerian Museum of Natural History in New York, personally entertained a group of visitors from the standards board that included Dennis R. Beresford, the chairman.
The first stop was the entomology section, where the accountants got to see an eye-popping number of stink beetles and spiders, some suspended in jars and some ground up for experiments and some that had to be viewed under a microscope.
Inching their way to ichthyology, the guests admired shelf after shelf of dead fish, and capped their visit by passing around some 300-million-year-old fossils. Mr. Moynihan apologized for having to skip so many of the museum's other attractions. ''We only had one morning and you can imagine if you have 40 million objects, you can't get everywhere,'' he said, hoping they would take the hint.
Did they? Mr. Bossio said the show-and-tell session did persuade him that the natural history museums will have trouble meeting the proposed standards. He remains unconvinced that art museums share those problems. ''The art museums would like to use the problems of the natural history museums to get out of having to comply with this,'' he said.
Some accounting experts note that there are other businesses whose most important assets are nowhere on their books - the Coca-Cola Company's trademark is one example -and the standard setters have learned to live with it. ''Why are these assets any different?'' said Jean W. Horton, an audit partner at the accounting firm of Coopers & Lybrand.

HEADLINE: Bush's Tastes, Down Home to Less So

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 30

 BODY:
Barbara Bush has blown her husband's cultural cover.
Remember during the campaign, when everyone suspected that George Bush was just pretending to like motorboats and pork rinds and country music so he would not be labeled an elitist, when his true tastes probably ran more to sailing, cucumber sandwiches and Brahms?
Now, pentimento style, the real George Bush is showing through the exaggerated campaign persona. First, it leaked out that President Bush preferred popcorn, the current yuppie snack of choice, to the earthier pork rinds. Now, it turns out, he loves opera. 
The music wafting through the White House residence when the Bushes sit around in the evening is more likely to be Leontyne Price or Placido Domingo than Loretta Lynn or the Oak Ridge Boys.
 
Country, Yes, but Also Classical
''I don't want to ruin his myth,'' Barbara Bush said, smiling conspiratorially as she did just that. ''We go to sleep and we wake up to country music. I want that known.'' The Bushes keep their bedroom radio tuned to a Washington country music station.
''But we also do love to hear classical music. And we have it bellowing through the house.''
''Through the house, we do not make people listen to country music,'' she continued. ''Through the house, we put on just beautiful music. We love to hear Leontyne Price, she is just great, or Domingo, that's wonderful. He loves all that.''
The President also loves the recordings of Sandi Patti, and he even named the gospel singer to his new Presidential Drug Advisory Council.
Wearing an American flag broach on her royal-blue blazer, Mrs. Bush chatted about culture and the arts as she sat in the residence one recent morning with the family's English springer spaniel, Millie, snuggled on the rug. Now that Mr. Bush is no longer criticized as an out-of-touch patrician, the Bushes are willing to talk about tastes that might once have been denounced as highfalutin, as well as their more down-home preferences.
 
Giggles Instead of Weeping
The First Lady said that she and her husband sometimes tune in to the CBS News program ''60 Minutes'' on Sunday evenings, but now find themselves looking forward to ABC's new Sunday entry, ''America's Funniest Home Videos.''
While Ronald and Nancy Reagan liked to cry over ''Little House on the Prairie,'' the Bushes love to giggle over the videos of sleeping cats falling off television sets, children on sleds crashing into trees and houses, and bridegrooms fainting at the altar.
''Oh, gosh, it is funny,'' Mrs. Bush said. ''I would love to have the back tapes of that. This is terrible to watch people run into walls over and over again, but they are funny.''
Their other favorite program, she said, is ''Murder, She Wrote,'' also on Sunday on CBS. Now that ''America's Funniest Home Videos'' has settled into the same 8 P.M. time slot, the Bushes will have to choose between Angela Lansbury solving crimes and people crashing into walls, or use their VCR, which the President refers to as ''the V.''
 
No Solitary Filmgoing
Like the Reagans, the Bushes enjoy watching movies in the screening room at Camp David, the Presidential retreat in the Maryland mountains. Unlike the Reagans, they do not do their watching in romantic solitude.
''We had the Gatlin boys and Jimmy Dean up to Camp David for the weekend, and we saw a movie about three brothers who take a car trip,'' Mrs. Bush said. She was referring to the film ''Coupe de Ville,'' about three brothers who drive a vintage Cadillac south as a birthday present for their mother and argue all the way about the origin of the lyrics of the song ''Louie, Louie.''
''The Gatlin brothers kept saying, 'We relate to that, we relate to that,' and we related to it a little bit, too,'' laughed the First Lady, who has been on the road with her rambling husband as much as any country music star. ''I snoozed through a tiny bit, but it was cute.''
The President prefers action films, such as Chuck Norris and Arnold Schwarzenegger movies, to fantasy films like ''Field of Dreams.'' After watching the Kevin Costner baseball fantasy at the White House, the President shook his head and told his companions, ''If anybody figures that out, call me.'' What's Playing At Their Movies Mrs. Bush said that she and the President saw nearly all the Academy Award nominees for best picture: ''We saw 'Glory' up at Camp David. Wonderful. We saw 'Driving Miss Daisy.' We were sad Morgan Freeman didn't win, although we did see 'My Left Foot,' and we loved that, too.''
The Bushes are clearly movie fans. The films they have screened lately involve romance (''Pretty Woman'' ''The Fabulous Baker Boys''), farce (''Naked Gun'') the classics (''Henry V''), suspense (''Hunt for Red October'') and sentiment (''Stella''). There are also lots of films for the grandchildren (''The Little Mermaid,'' ''An American Tail'') and message movies, including one on Mrs. Bush's favorite project, literacy (''Stanley and Iris.'') Lately, the First Lady said, they have been watching tapes of a nine-part Civil War series produced for the Public Broadcasting Service.
Just as President Bush likes to pop out of the White House to buy bagels at Wagshall's, the local delicatessen, or to visit the Peking Gourmet Inn, his favorite Chinese restaurant, in suburban Virginia, so he likes to pop out to theatrical events on the spur of the moment.
In the recent past, Presidents did not go out to restaurants or theater much, fearing that it would create too much commotion. But Mr. Bush doesn't mind a little commotion.
While they usually take in the fare at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, Mrs. Bush said they were thinking of trying some of the smaller and less conventional theaters in the capital. ''George and I were just talking about it the other day and saying we really ought to scare the living daylights out of some of these other theaters,'' she said. ''They have wonderful things, too, and we could pop in on one.''
Conjuring up the image of the unwieldy Battleship Galactica, as one Secret Service agent calls the Presidential entourage, Mrs. Bush wryly noted, ''The trouble is, when we pop in, it's 17 seats or something.'' Relaxation Heaven: The One-Act Opera She said she tries to choose shows that will be ''relaxing and easy'' for her husband, after a long, hard day of dealing with world problems. ''My idea of heaven would be an opera that was one act,'' she said.
For their 45th wedding anniversary on Jan. 6, they went to the Kennedy Center to see ''A Tuna Christmas,'' a comedy about life in a small Texas town with Jaston Williams and Joe Sears. They liked it so much they brought the show to the White House to entertain at a dinner for the nation's governors.
Mr. Bush collects celebrities the way he collects friends: a wide and eclectic mix. Helen Hayes recently visited the White House, and Michael Jackson was at the President's side in the Rose Garden when Mr. Bush announced the Washington summit with Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Mr. Schwarzenegger, who campaigned for Mr. Bush and has visited the Bushes socially on several occasions, is the head of the President's Council on Physical Fitness. With the help of Vice President Quayle and President Bush, Mr. Schwarzenegger planned to show off the joys of excercise and sports with an exhibiton on the South Lawn Tuesday called ''The Great American Workout,'' featering stationary bicycles, golf, football, baseball and aerobics.
Entertainment for dinners has ranged from Ms. Price to Kenny Rogers to Maureen McGovern. Isaac Stern, the Boys Choir of Harlem, Simon Estes and Mstislav Rostropovich have also performed.
Playing President-as-groupie with enthusiasm, Mr. Bush extends his small gracious gestures to the stars. Elizabeth Taylor, who has been hospitalized with viral pneumonia, received a telephone call from the President. He also called Gloria Estefan several times after the singer's back was broken in a highway accident in Pennsylvania; when Pat Morita of the ''Karate Kid'' admired Mr. Bush's official navy-blue windbreaker, Mr. Bush took it off and gave it to him.
The First Lady says she loves to sneak out in the afternoons to art shows at the National Gallery or the Corcoran or the Phillips, or sometimes to smaller galleries. Although the President is not much of a museum buff, he knows he doesn't like ''filth,'' as he put it. Nonetheless, he pleased the arts community by rejecting government censorship of the arts, saying that artists ought to be able to paint or express themselves however they want. Books, Books, All of Them Open Mrs. Bush said that while she loved novels and nonfiction, she had been ''having trouble getting into books lately'' because of Graves disease, an immune system disorder that affects her eyesight. Although her difficulty with double vision has got better, she said that reading was not as pleasant as it once was.
''I can't read lying on my back at this moment, and that has an enormous amount to do with my eyes,'' she said. ''But I've got about 18 open books going, to tell you the truth. I'm not very proud of that. I just can't find one that I'm saying, 'Oh, I can't put this down at this moment.' ''
She said she has been ''fascinated'' by ''The Journalist and the Murderer'' (Alfred A. Knopf), by Janet Malcolm, an account of the uneasy relationship between the author Joe McGinniss and Jeffrey MacDonald, the Green Beret doctor convicted of murdering his family and the subject of a best-selling book by Mr. McGinniss. She also recently read ''What I Saw at the Revolution'' (Random House), the account by Peggy Noonan of her stints as as speechwriter for Mr. Reagan and Mr. Bush.
Although Mrs. Bush often picks out books she thinks her husband would like, she says that ''he's been fairly good about picking out his own books lately.
''He always has a book open. He always goes to bed with a book.''
Recent Presidential reading includes ''Liar's Poker'' (W. W. Norton), by Michael Lewis, a young broker's experiences on Wall Street in the greedy 80's, and ''Megatrends 2000'' (William Morrow & Company), by John Naisbitt and Patricia Aburdene, predictions about economic, political and social developments. Mr. Bush has also been reading ''Barbarians at the Gate'' (Harper & Row), by Bryan Burrough and John Helyar, an account of the RJR Nabisco takeover. On the lighter side, he has also been amusing himself with the spoof of American history ''Dave Barry Slept Here'' (Random House).
Mr. Bush confessed during the campaign that he is a ''terrible'' dancer and Mrs. Bush conceded that even with all the practice he is forced to get at state dinners, he still dislikes circling the floor. ''He'd rather do anything,'' she said.
She recalled that when her mother insisted that they dance at their wedding reception, her husband needled her by saying: ''I hope you're having a good time. Enjoy it. It's the last time I'll ever dance in public.''
''Little did he know,'' remarked the First Lady, with a mischievous smile.

HEADLINE: New U.S.-Soviet Trade Pact Stirs Criticism in Congress

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 30

 BODY:
The structure of a new Soviet-American trade agreement, as well as its timing in the midst of the Lithuania independence crisis, is raising opposition in Congress.
The agreement, which was reached in broad terms last Thursday among negotiators in Paris, was quickly criticized the next day by nine Republican Senators who called on the Administration to renounce the agreement because of Moscow's policies toward Lithuania.
But the accord is also raising concern because it makes extensive use of sideletters, which are documents signed by governments that traditionally elaborate points of a diplomatic text.
In this case, many Soviet concessions are contained in sideletters rather than in the main text. 
The reason, said a State Department official, is the United States' desire to accommodate the Soviet Union. ''They wanted it for optics on their side, and we went along,'' the official said, adding that any commitments in the sideletters carry the same weight as provisions in the main agreement.
The perception of some lawmakers, however, is that the sideletters represent a lesser degree of commitment on the concessions the United States wants from the Soviet Union. Those concessions are intended to help balance the lower tariffs on exports that the United States would grant to the Soviet Union under the pact.
A Congressional aide complained, ''This appears to be a jerry-builtquick fix, based on the desire of both sides to show progress on the economic issues before the summit and of the Bush Administration to show support for Gorbachev at this time of trial.''
The pact is expected to be ready for signature during the summit meeting in Washington May 30-June 3 between the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, and President Bush.
Under the agreement, the United States would provide so-called most-favored-nation tariff treatment, cutting tariffs on some Soviet items, like vodka, textiles and certain kinds of fertilizers and minerals, and putting Moscow in the same trade category as most other American partners for the first time in a half-century. Tariffs on some items could be cut by as much as 80 to 90 percent.
In addition to providing most-favored-nation treatment, the agreement contains these elements:
* Each side could open a trade office in the other country to advertise, meet with potential purchasers and otherwise promote commerce, although the office could not be used to make direct retail sales. They would also be able to have offices in their embassies to facilitate trade.
* Each country's commercial laws and regulations would be made readily available to the other. This information is already obtainable in the United States in public libraries, but it is closely held in the Soviet Union and tends to inhibit American business executives.
* The countries agreed to protect intellectual property and to abide by international conventions in this area. This is already done in the United States, but not in the Soviet Union.
* The negotiators established regulations involving the use of dollars, rubles and third-country currency in trade transactions. The precise rules have not been made public.
* They also agreed that if one country flooded the other's markets with a particular product, the other country had the right to stop those imports without endangering other trade agreements.
 
The American Demands
Some of the main American demands that have been met chiefly in the sideletters instead of in the central text are protection of patents, copyrights, trademarks and other intellectual property, full repatriation of profits for American companies with Soviet operations and improved working conditions for American business operators in the Soviet Union.
The pact has yet to be published, but the sideletters have drawn criticism because of what some see as previous bad experiences with the structure.
''We've had some bad experience with the Japanese and sideletters,'' said an aide to Senator Frank H. Murkowski, Republican of Alaska, who is usually supportive of Bush Administration foreign policy initiatives. ''The sideletters here are going to be looked at very closely.''
The reference was to a 1986 accord with Japan in which a sideletter, and not the main agreement, committed Japan to more than double American penetration of the Japanese computer chip market over five years.
For some time, the Tokyo authorities were unwilling to acknowledge even the existence of the sideletter. Only recently has Tokyo publicly accepted that the market penetration commitment exists.
 
Dispute Over FSX Recalled
The degree of commitment in a sideletter came up, also with Japan, in a dispute over the advanced jet fighter aircraft called the FSX that Japan and the United States have agreed to build together.
Many members of Congress last year wanted to rewrite the production agreement that the Defense Department had already concluded with Japan to provide better terms for the United States.
The Pentagon offered to deal with the Congressional complaints through a sideletter, but Congressional critics insisted on changes in the main text, which the Bush Administration then reluctantly agreed to and negotiated with Japan.
A Bush Administration trade official said there is ''absolutely no difference'' between a commitment in a sideletter and one in the main text, adding, ''They both have the same degree of commitment and legality.''
But the Administration does not speak with a single voice on this issue. A second Bush official from a different department termed the sideletters in this agreement ''chiefly statements of intentions by the Soviets.'' Both spoke only on condition that they not be identified.
While the Administration risks a fight with Congress on the degree of Soviet commitment, it has backed off from what could be an even bigger confrontation by keeping Export-Import Bank credits off limits.

HEADLINE: Income Rise Not Matched By Spending

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 30

 BODY:
The savings rate of Americans rose to 5.8 percent of their disposable income in March as consumer spending failed to match an increase in personal incomes, the Commerce Department reported today.
Consumer spending totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $3.66 trillion, slowing to an increase of four-tenths of 1 percent after a rise of six-tenths in February, the department said. It was the lowest increase since a three-tenths rise in October. 
The department said that personal income grew by eight-tenths of 1 percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $4.67 trillion. The rise followed revised increases of eight-tenths in both January and February. The rises were originally reported to have been seven-tenths in January and nine-tenths in February.
 
Strong Inflation Cited
But analysts blamed rising prices for the subdued spending and not intentions of consumers to increase their savings rate. ''For each of the months of the first quarter, we had very strong inflation that cut into purchasing power,'' said David Berson, chief economist for the Federal National Mortgage Association. It is likely to reverse itself in the second quarter, he added.
Stephen S. Roach, senior economist at Morgan Stanley & Company in New York, agreed, saying inflation remains the ''single biggest threat to the consumer support of this expansion'' although he too expects it to moderate in the current quarter. ''That will enable consumers to continue to expand their capacity to spend,'' he said.
Consumer spending is watched closely as a barometer of economic health because it accounts for about two-thirds of the nation's economic activity. It has been in the forefront of the economic expansion now in its eighth year following the 1981-82 recession.
''The March and February increases in personal income were boosted by increases in subsidy payments to farm proprietors,'' the Commerce Department said. ''Excluding these payments, personal income increased $24.6 billion, or five-tenths of 1 percent, in March and $28.9 billion, or six-tenths, in February.''
 
Largest Rise Since December
The income of Americans after taxes rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in March, the largest increase since a rise of nine-tenths in December, the department said.
The key component of the income category, wages and salaries, rose $14.1 billion at an annual rate after a $22 billion increase in February.
The rise in personal consumption, which includes everything except interest payments on debt, totaled $13.8 billion, down from $21.3 billion in February.
Purchases of durable goods, big-ticket items expected to last more than three years, fell by $6.8 billion. Purchases of nondurable goods also fell, down $2.5 billion, while services rose by $23.1 billion.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Con Edison's New Chief Comes From the Ranks

BYLINE: By DANIEL F. CUFF

 BODY:
The Consolidated Edison Company of New York yesterday named Eugene R. McGrath, who started with the utility 27 years ago as what was then called a cadet engineer, to be chief executive, effective Sept. 1.
Mr. McGrath, 48, was named president and chief operating officer a year ago January. As chief executive, he will succeed Arthur Hauspurg, who will retire at age 65 at the end of August. Mr. Hauspurg said he would recommend to the Con Ed board on May 22 that Mr. McGrath be elected chairman as of Sept. 1. 
''These actions will provide an orderly transition of executive responsibility,'' Mr. Hauspurg said in a statement.
Mr. McGrath said yesterday the question of whether he would keep the president's title or whether the board would designate someone else would be resolved between now and September. In the past, the top man has often carried the title of president as well as chairman and chief executive.
Con Ed serves 2.9 million customers in New York City and Westchester County.
''We'll be balancing various issues dealing with energy, the economy and the environment,'' Mr. McGrath said. The two main components of Con Ed's strategy, he said, will be to meet about half of the expected new demand for power through conservation and demand-side management, while obtaining the rest from independent power producers. This will be the case for the next 10 to 20 years, he said.
Mr. McGrath, born and raised in Yonkers, joined the New York utility in 1963 after graduating from Manhattan College. He started as a cadet engineer, a program in those days to introduce new graduates into various Con Ed departments. He holds an M.B.A. from Iona College, earned in 1980 and completed the advanced management program at the Harvard Business School.
Mr. McGrath is a director of Barnard College, the Regional Plan Association and the United Way of New York City, along with many other posts. ''Con Ed is literally rooted in the city streets,'' Mr. McGrath said, ''You couldn't pick up and leave even if you wanted to, and we need to be involved in the community.''

HEADLINE: COMPANY EARNINGS;
Unocal's Net Down 11.5%

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, April 30

 BODY:
The Unocal Corporation said today that its first-quarter earnings fell 11.5 percent, to $77 million, or 33 cents a share, from $87 million, or 37 cents a share, in the corresponding period a year ago.
Last year's results included a $46 million after-tax gain from a number of natural gas contract settlements. 
Revenues were $2.64 billion, almost identical to $2.63 billion last year.
Unocal said it enjoyed higher worldwide crude oil prices, lower interest rates and improved shale oil operations. But those positive factors were offset by lower chemical earnings.
Earnings from petroleum exploration and production declined 10.3 percent, to $130 million, but last year's period benefited from gas contract settlements.
Crude oil production fell partly because of the temporary suspension of oil production in the Cook Inlet area of Alaska as a result of eruptions from Mount Redoubt.
Unocal's refining, marketing and transportation segment recorded earnings of $11 million, more than double the $5 million reported a year ago. Chemicals operations earned $6 million, down 62.5 percent from $16 million a year ago.
Unocal's stock gained 25 cents today, to $28.25, on the New York stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Official Quits Futures Post

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 30

 BODY:
Robert R. Davis resigned today from his post as a member of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission to join the New York Mercantile Exchange as a senior vice president for planning and development.
Mr. Davis, who is 41 years old, is a specialist in financial markets and monetary policy. His resignation is effective immediately.
While at the C.F.T.C., Mr. Davis was an advocate of deregulation of the futures industry.
He also defended the C.F.T.C. and the futures industry from criticism in the wake of the October 1987 market crash. Mr. Davis said that there was no evidence that trading of stock index futures, which are traded on the futures markets, caused the decline.
In his resignation letter to President Bush, Mr. Davis said the C.F.T.C. was ''a model of good government that constructively channeled the invisible hand of the market and avoided laying on the dead hand of excessive regulation.''
He worked at the Joint Economic Committee of Congress before being selected by President Reagan to join the C.F.T.C. in the fall of 1984.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gold Continues Its Decline; Silver Prices Are Higher

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Gold futures fell moderately yesterday on the Commodity Exchange in New York, extending a slide spurred by rising interest rates on the Government bonds that compete with stocks, precious metals and other instruments for investors' funds.
On other commodity markets, grains, soybeans, oil futures, livestock and meat futures were mixed. Silver futures were 1.5 cents higher across the board, with May at $4.932 a troy ounce. 
Gold futures settled $2.60 to $2.70 lower, with the contract for delivery in May at $368.40 a troy ounce. Gold prices have fallen about $30 an ounce since mid-March, including a drop of more than $10 in the last week. Interest rates on 30-year United States Treasury bonds climbed to more than 9 percent during the period, their highest levels in nearly a year.
''It seems the market is under pressure from the economics of where to invest money,'' said Scott Hinton, a metals analyst with Elders Futures Inc.
 
Element of Risk
Gold continues to weaken, he said, because it ''is not as attractive a vehicle as risk-free Government securities.'' While Mr. Hinton said gold would likely remain under pressure, Bernard Savaiko, a senior metals analyst with Paine Webber Inc., said he believed the most aggressive selling had already occurred.
Soybean futures retreated on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday amid profit taking after last week's big gains. Wheat futures rose strongly, partly reflecting frost fears in the central plains, while corn futures ended mixed.
Soybean futures had surged more than 30 cents a bushel last week, partly on ideas that last week's hot, dry Midwestern weather might set the tone for the growing season.
Oil futures finished mixed on the New York Mercantile Exchange amid skepticism that OPEC could devise a way to curb its production.
Heating oil prices were bid sharply higher in trading tied to the expiration of the May contract, which finished 2.79 cents higher, at 56.53 cents a gallon.
Energy analysts said weakness yesterday in gasoline prices indicated the market was not expecting much from OPEC's emergency meeting scheduled for tomorrow.
Cattle futures settled mixed on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Pork futures ended mostly higher, led by the May pork-belly contract, which soared the permitted daily limit of 2 cents a pound in a rally largely inspired by technical factors.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Finishes Day Mixed In Shortened, Quiet Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended mixed yesterday against primary foreign currencies in thin, abbreviated worldwide trading.
Currency dealers said trading was quiet, with Japanese markets closed for a national holiday. Many European markets will be closed today for May Day, and some dealers took an early, extended break, they said. 
''With all the various holidays this week, there doesn't seem to be any reason to break from the trading ranges,'' said Trevor Woodland, chief corporate trader for Harris Trust and Company in Chicago. ''Everybody is in a bit of a wait-and-see mood.''
Mr. Woodland said the traders were marking time before several critical economic and political events occur later this week.
Today, the Federal Government plans to release figures on construction spending in March. Data on the index of leading economic indicators will be released tomorrow and those on April unemployment on Friday. The traders hope the figures will shed more light on the direction of the economy and interest rates.
Tomorrow, the Treasury also announces its quarterly debt refunding.
In West Germany, officials of the Bundesbank are to meet this week, although the traders said it was unlikely that they would move to raise interest rates in that country. Higher rates tend to support a currency.
In London, the dollar fell to a closing rate of 158.85 Japanese yen, from 159.08 yen on Friday in Tokyo. The dollar stood at 158.90 yen in New York, down from 159.30 yen on Friday.
The dollar was also weaker against the British pound. Sterling sold for $1.6390 in London, up from $1.6360 late on Friday, and for $1.6405 in New York, up from $1.6350.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with those of late Friday, included: 1.6795 West German marks, up from 1.6775; 1.4530 Swiss francs, unchanged; 5.6330 French francs, up from 5.6290; 1,230.50 Italian lire, up from 1,230.00, and 1.16435 Canadian dollars, up from 1.16375.

HEADLINE: Careers;
Learning To Manage A Race Track

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
''THE racing world will be here this week, and we will be busy taping interviews to be used in class,'' Dr. Robert Lawrence, a professor at the University of Louisville, said the other day. He heads its race track management program. Then, on Saturday he and many students are off to the races - the Kentucky Derby at nearby Churchill Downs.
The Kentucky Legislature has allotted a percentage of betting money for the program, which began in the fall of 1987 in the business school. ''We're getting about $600,000 out of the Kentucky betting dollar yearly, but perhaps it has slipped a little this year.'' he said last week. ''It goes up and down with parimutuel results.'' 
Being a horse lover is not enough to qualify a student for the program, Dr. Lawrence said, explaining that the industry needs better-trained personnel in accounting, financial management, marketing, computer science and public relations.
Dr. Lawrence said the program also conducted ''research and offers service seminars.'' One recent seminar was held to train race track stewards and another was for veterinarians.
The program has produced only four graduates, but about 60 are in the pipeline. Students are required to take two years of humanities and business courses before they can choose the major at the start of their junior year. For the final two years they take courses with titles like ''Introductory Horse Science,'' ''Legal Environment of the Equine Industry,'' ''Race Track Management'' and ''Breeding and Syndication Finance.'' They also do internships. The degree: bachelor of business administration with an equine major.
''I think the race track management field offers a good opportunity for younger people with the right training,'' Dr. Lawrence said, even though he acknowledges that ''racing has been losing out to casino and other types of gambling'' with regard to the share of the gambling dollar.
Dr. Lawrence cited the latest figures, compiled for 1987, that put racing and the non-racing show horse business at ''a very conservative total of $15 billion.''
''Racing will survive despite doom-and-gloom thinking,'' he said. ''It needs creative and forward-looking managers. Our graduates will have an impact.''
Dr. Lawrence plans to add an international equine course in the fall. In August he will attend a gaming and wagering conference in London to discuss the program. ''The British do not have such training,'' he said.
Although Britain and France have long been noted for famous horse races, Dr. Lawrence said the enthusiasm for racing in Australia and New Zealand was even greater. ''Australians bet 10 times as much money on horses as do Americans on a per-capita basis,'' he said.
Dr. Lawrence is searching for a few good professors. ''We have a position open for an economist,'' he said. ''It is hard to find Ph.D.'s with experience in the horse industry.''
Dr. Lawrence is an experienced horseman. At the time the university found him he was a professor of agricultural economics at the University of Maryland. A native of Calgary, Alberta, he graduated from the University of Oklahoma with a geology major and then added an M.B.A. Later, he received a doctorate from Texas A & M. There are many programs for horse enthusiasts, mostly stressing animal science, but the most notable competitor to emphasize management aspects is the University of Arizona, in Tucson.
''Don't call that competition,'' Dr. Lawrence said. ''Call them colleagues.''
Arizona's program is in its 17th year, and Dr. Lawrence does not know why Kentucky, the horse racing and breeding center of the nation, started one so much later.
The Arizona program has graduated more than 160 people, including some middle-aged career changers, said Lonny T. Powell, its coordinator and director. He holds a four-day symposium annually. Last December it was attended by more than 1,000 racing executives, giving students a chance to mingle.
Mr. Powell said starting salaries for his graduates were about $20,000, depending on the region of the country, but went up quite rapidly, with some soon earning $60,000 and more.
Meanwhile, the four graduates of the Louisville program have had plenty of job opportunities. One accepted a post at the Pimlico race track in Baltimore, another took a job with the Golden Gate Fields track in Oakland, Calif., and a third joined an Ohio bloodstock agency. The fourth has not yet decided between two breeding farms.

HEADLINE: Israel Reports an April Influx Of 10,000 Jews From U.S.S.R.

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, May 1

 BODY:
For the 16th month in a row, the number of Soviet Jews arriving in Israel increased sharply in April and for the first time exceeded 10,000, Israeli immigration officials said today.
The Government said 10,500 Soviet immigrants moved here last month, compared with 7,300 in March and 544 in April 1989.
The 44 percent increase in one month's time came despite continued Arab threats against the immigrants and resultant uncertainty about the continued willingness of third countries to serve as transit points for the emigrating Jews.
This month's figures also continue a trend started late last year that has seen nearly all the departing Soviet Jews choose to move to Israel and not the United States. In April of last year, for instance, when 544 Soviet Jews emigrated to Israel, 4,000 went to the United States. The change came largely because the Israeli mission in Moscow, re-established a few months ago after after a two-decade break in relations, welcomes the potential new citizens and pays their airfare as well as many living expenses on arrival in Israel. 
 
Longer Waits for Visas
To move to the United States, most Soviet Jews must wait months or years for a visa, a delay made longer in the last year when the Bush Administration effectively reduced the number of immigrants from the Soviet Union to be able to increase the number of Vietnamese and Cambodians admitted to this country. In addition, those coming from the Soviet Union get little economic help on departure or after arrival.
The flow of Soviet Jews has continued unabated because of several factors, experts here and in New York and Moscow said. One is the ease with which Soviet Jews can receive permission from the Soviet authorities to depart, with the concern of Soviet Jews that the open door might be suddenly closed. Other factors are the declining Soviet economy and the fear of renewed anti-Semitism, spawned by the increased freedom of speech in the Soviet Union.
In Israel, the ever-larger numbers of immigrants set off another round of recrimination and debate this afternoon as Israeli officials pointed fingers, each blaming the other because the Government still has not completed a single new apartment for the immigrants and has not created more than a handful of new jobs.
This morning, an Absorption Ministry official, Ida Ben-Shitrit, said, ''The data we have show that there is only enough rental housing for the next two or three months,'' if the immigrants continue arriving at the current rate. ''We have a real problem,'' she said. But Uri Gordon, head of immigration and absorption for the quasi-governmental Jewish Agency, said the state should count on continued increases in arrivals.
 
'Temporary Housing' Plan
''In the coming months, we are expecting close to 20,000 a month,'' he said. Immigration typically increases in the summer, when children get out of school.
Last week Rabbi Yitzhak Peretz, the Absorption Minister, said the Government might have to begin putting up ''temporary housing'' for the new arrivals. Mrs. Ben-Shitrit said the Government was investigating the purchase of several thousand prefabricated, temporary wooden structures to hold the new immigrants until permanent housing is built.
The Ministry of Housing, she said, has just begun to build 6,000 new apartments for immigrants. If they are completed on time, ''they will be finished in March of 1991,'' she said. ''But more than 100,000 are coming this year,'' she continued. ''So we are making emergency plans.''
Housing is just one of the immediate problems. At the weekly Cabinet meeting today, Labor Minister Roni Milo said that ''unless thousands of jobs are found, the state faces a tragedy that could endanger the future of immigration.''
 
Skilled Immigrants, Few Jobs
Most new immigrants from the Soviet Union are highly educated professionals. An average of 200 Soviet doctors arrive here each month, Rabbi Peretz said this evening.
Immigration aside, Israel's unemployment rate is about 9.5 percent.
For more than a year now, Israeli leaders from every party and all political outlooks have been warning that the immigrants are coming and that Israel should get ready.
In his annual state of the nation address on Sunday, President Chaim Herzog expressed the exasperation many of his compatriots also feel at the Government's failure to heed even its own warnings.
 
Dispute in Christian Quarter
''We are discovering shortcomings in our own ranks - unnecessary difficulties, defects, neglect,'' he said. ''Inevitably one wonders how we were not prepared for the massive wave of immigration we all knew to be imminent.''
But while a record number of immigrants was arriving last month and plans were being made to put up prefabricated, temporary homes, the Housing Ministry was secretly channeling $1.8 million through a Panamanian front company so 150 Jewish settlers could take up residence in the Christian Quarter of Jerusalem's Old City, setting off an international storm of protest.
''This is stupid in this situation,'' Mr. Gordon said. ''We need every spare pound for the newcomers to Israel.''
Absorption Ministry figures show that the Government spends about $3,666 during each new immigrant's first year of residence here.
 
Agency's Appeal for More Money
On Sunday the Absorption Ministry said it had run out of money and appealed to the Government for more. When the Government budget was written last fall, money was included for only 40,000 immigrants. More than 32,000 newcomers from all sources have already arrived.
The flow of Soviet refugees to Israel slowed slightly in late March, when the Hungarian airline Malev temporarily halted charter flights to Israel after threats from Arab terrorists against airlines ferrying Soviet Jews to Israel. Malev is now again bringing significant numbers of Jews through Hungary, and the Israeli airline, El Al, has almost daily charter flights from Budapest. An agreement in principle on direct flights from the Soviet Union to Israel has never been put into effect.
In April, the Government reported today, a total of 11,475 immigrants arrived from all sources, meaning that 975 came from countries other than the Soviet Union.
Most of the other immigrants came from Argentina and other Latin American countries, though a few were from Ethiopia, which recently reopened diplomatic relations with Israel, and a tiny number were from Iran.
