HEADLINE: WHITE HOUSE SEEKS A 'NEW LEADERSHIP' AT SAVINGS AGENCY

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 1

 BODY:
The outspoken head of the Federal savings and loan bailout came under White House pressure today, with the President's chief spokesman saying that ''we are interested in getting new leadership'' in the rescue effort.
The pressure on L. William Seidman, chairman of the Resolution Trust Corporation, comes as the cost of the bailout to the American taxpayer is growing, and the public appears to be more aware of the magnitude of the rescue. The agency is gearing up to spend almost $1 billion a day over the next two months to cover losses on the scores of insolvent savings and loan associations it is trying to sell.
For months, senior Administration officials have said privately that their battles with Mr. Seidman and his practice of publicly speaking out when he disagrees with the Adminstration have soured the relationship.
 
Preference for Own Team
They also point to a policy President Bush instituted at the start of his Administration to replace Reagan appointees with his own people. 
Mr. Bush, who is prevented by law from dismissing Mr. Seidman, is also said to want to exert more control over the day-to-day management of the rescue, which Mr. Seidman, a fiercely independent regulator, has prevented.
The White House press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater said at a news briefing today that at a meeting two weeks ago in the Oval Office, Mr. Seidman had not been asked to leave. But Mr. Fitzwater, in his comments,, implied that the White House would not resist if Mr. Seidman decided to go.
 
An 'Aggressive Program'
''Bill has indicated publicly that he would not like to serve out his entire term, which expires in 1991,'' Mr. Fitzwater said. ''And we are interested in getting new leadership there that will carry out an aggressive program when the time comes.''
The meeting with the President was first disclosed today in The Washington Post.
Many members of Congress and some banking experts said the pressure on Mr. Seidman, who is chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation as well as the bailout agency, could not come at a worse time.
After months of a sluggish start-up process, the Resolution Trust Corporation, which manages the day-to-day affairs of the bailout, is poised to spend $57 billion by the end of June to either liquidate or induce investors to take over 141 insolvent savings institutions. Eventually, it is expected to seize as many as 800 institutions, at a 30-year cost to the taxpayer and to the industry of between $300 billion and $500 billion.
This spring's initiative is the most ambitious since the rescue bill was passed last summer and one that would serve as a clear signal that the bailout was working. Banking experts and members of Congress said the pressure on Mr. Seidman now placed the plan under a cloud.
 
'Don't Need This Backbiting'
''This is a time when we all need to be pulling together as never before, and we don't need this backbiting,'' said William M. Isaac, a former chairman of the F.D.I.C. and now head of the Secura Group, a financial consulting firm. ''I see no reason to be trying to get him to leave. I would be trying to keep him in the Government, not run him out.''
But industry lobbyists and Administration officials also noted that the not so subtle pressure on Mr. Seidman was the product of months of tensions between him and the Bush Administration, dating back to when Mr. Bush first came into office.
Lawmakers and industry experts have said that both Mr. Seidman's independent style and the new regulatory structure set up under the bailThe chairman of the F.D.I.C. is also designated to oversee the management of the bailout - taking control of insolvent savings institutions, separating the good from the bad assets, selling the good assets and deposits to banks and other investors, and, eventually, selling billions of dollars in unwanted real estate assets.
 
Oversight Board Set Up
But the law also set up a Resolution Trust oversight board, headed by the Treasury Secretary, and in the bailout process the board sets broad policies and oversees management steps taken by the F.D.I.C., which until last year had been entirely independent. Now, insofar as its bailout role goes, it is answerable to the Treasury and by extension to the White House.
Attempts by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and Deputy Secretary John Robson to take more control rankled Mr. Seidman, and the two sides clashed repeatedly during the first months of the process.
Difficulties with the Treasury also led to the resignation in February of the oversight board's first president, Daniel P. Kearney. Since Mr. Kearney left, the working relationship betweeen the Treasury and Mr. Seidman has improved, both sides say. But both acknowledge that a lack of trust remains.
 
Possible Successors
While Administration officials say they have not decided who would succeed Mr. Seidman, William Taylor, the acting chief executive of the Resolution Trust Corporation's oversight board and head of bank regulation at the Federal Reserve Board, is the leading candidate, some officials say.
Robert L. Clarke, the Comptroller of the Currency and a member of both the F.D.I.C. and Resolution Trust boards, is also said to be a contender.
The White House cannot require Mr. Seidman to resign. Under the bailout law signed by the President last August, the President cannot remove the F.D.I.C. chairman, who is designated as an independent regulator.
And Mr. Seidman is not new to the political struggles of Washington. An accountant and lawyer by training, he was, as President Ford's chief economic policy adviser, considered one of the few power brokers in the Ford White House.
He then went on to be vice chairman of the Phelps Dodge Corporation, a mining company, and dean of the University of Arizona Business School. He was brought back to Washington by the Reagan Administration in October 1985.
The Treasury is not opposing Mr. Seidman's plan to dispose of the 141 institutions, even though it requires enormous sums of money and even though, at least for now, the budget deficit will increase by $57 billion.
But there are moves in Congress to dampen the budgetary effect of the bailout spending. A resolution introduced in the Senate would exempt a large amount of the financing Resolution Trust needs to close sick institutions from deficit calculations, in a process referred to as putting an expenditure off-budget.
 
Outrage in Congress
The reaction on Capitol Hill to the move to force out Mr. Seidman, especially among Democrats, was outrage. ''The Administration will be foolish to let the services of Bill Seidman slip away just because his straight talk ruffles some political feathers,'' said Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, the Texas Democrat who is chairman of the House Banking Committee. ''Seidman has great credibility with members of Congress and the American public. The Administration will be in dire need of all the credibility it can muster in coming months as the costs mount for taxpayers.''
A letter signed by 23 members of the House Banking Committee was sent to President Bush, warning him against trying to oust Mr. Seidman.
Mr. Seidman, when reached by telephone, said, ''I am not talking about my private conversations with the President.''
It is still uncertain whether Mr. Seidman will depart soon. Those who have worked closely with him said he had demonstrated such independence that he was not likely to leave before he felt he had the Resolution Trust Corporation up and running. That could be as early as this summer, but if his plan to dispose of the 141 institutions before July becomes a bureaucratic impossibility, he could well stay until later in the year.
 
One of Two Processes
The plan calls for one of two processes. Mr. Seidman has said the agency plans to liquidate at least 50 of the savings and loan associations. In that case, the agency would simply pay off depositors, take all the assets and warehouse them until it found buyers for them, which could take a number of years. Liquidation is often the most costly procedure.
A second option is called a ''clean-bank'' transaction, in which the Government takes a savings institution, removes the troubled assets, like loans in default, repossessed assets and dormant building projects, and sells both the deposits and good assets to a buyer.
In such transactions, the Government usually has to inject large amounts of cash - but not as much as in a liquidation - to cover the losses of depositors' money. For the right to take over these cleaned-up institutions, banks will pay a premium equal to between 1 and 2 percent more than the value of the deposits. For the bank buying a cleaned-up institution, the purchase can be a quick way to broaden its deposit base.
 
Goal Viewed as Difficult
Some banking experts warned that it would be almost impossible for Mr. Seidman to reach his goal. ''My own view is that selling off that many institutions under the present circumstances is impossible unless you are prepared to do an absolute fire sale,'' said Rodgin Cohen, a banking attorney for the New York law firm of Sullivan & Cromwell.
Mr. Cohen added that there was very little capacity in the banking industry to buy. ''There couldn't be a worse time to bring all these institutions to the market,'' he said.

LENGTH: 1426 words

HEADLINE: House Backs $24 Billion in Cuts From Bush's Plans for Pentagon

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 1

 BODY:
The House today narrowly approved the Democratic majority's $1.2 trillion budget for 1991, calling for $24 billion less for the military than President Bush proposed and $5.6 billion more for domestic programs.
The budget, approved on a 218-to-208 vote with no Republican support, is essentially a political blueprint that sets out Democratic priorities for where money should be spent in the 1991 fiscal year, which begins on Oct. 1. Even Democrats acknowledged that it was an early step in a process that would probably end in negotiations between Congress and the White House later this year. The Senate's budget proposal is deadlocked in a committee.
House Republican leaders had intended to offer the President's budget as an alternative but decided against it late Monday, partly to avoid an embarrassing defeat by the Democrats. And they conceded that the military spending levels at first sought by Mr. Bush had now been all but repudiated by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney. 
 
'Would Have Been Ludicrous'
''It would have been ludicrous given what Dick Cheney said last week to have brought that budget to the floor,'' said Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the Republican whip. He was referring to a Pentagon review of aircraft programs in which Mr. Cheney recommended substantial cuts in production of the Stealth bomber and delays in making fighter and attack planes.
As the House was voting, Mr. Cheney announced the extension of a freeze on military construction and said he had ordered a review of 207 construction projects for possible cancellation. ''The extent to which we can go forward on those projects is directly related to what kind of funding levels we're going to get out of Congress,'' Mr. Cheney said.
 
Home Ports Under Review
Leaving little doubt about the message he intended to convey to lawmakers whose states and districts benefit from the projects, Mr. Cheney said that if the military budget cuts being contemplated on Capitol Hill were adopted ''then there is no question that a large number of those projects on this list, plus additional ones, will have to be canceled.''
Among the projects being reviewed are four of six locations planned as home ports for major Navy ships when they are not on active duty: Ingleside Tex.; Mobile, Ala.; Pascagoula, Miss.; and Staten Island.
Before adopting the Democratic budget, the House rejected, 334 to 90, an alternative proposed by the Congressional Black Caucus that would have made even sharper cuts in military spending and redirected the savings to domestic programs, including education, job training, social services, housing and nutrition. The plan also called for tax increases aimed at the wealthiest Americans.
''In the real world, people want peace; they want nuclear disarmament,'' said Representative Ronald V. Dellums, a California Democrat who is a member of the House Armed Services Committee. He argued for the elimination of major strategic weapons systems, saying, ''If everybody says we're never going to use them, it's crazy; it sets logic on its head.''
Representative Patricia Schroeder, a Colorado Democratic who also serves on the Armed Services Committee, said it was wrong to spend billions of dollars on a program like the Stealth bomber and only a fraction of that on trying to control drug abuse. ''Substance abuse is much more important than building this plane that we don't know what we'll do with,'' she said.
 
Senate Is Struggling
With the House vote, the budget process remains in limbo until the Senate completes its own version of the fiscal blueprint.
The Senate Budget Committee has been struggling for weeks to come up with a measure it can bring to the Senate floor, but the lawmakers are stalled on issues like taxes and how much to cut military spending. There is no sign that agreement is near.
The Administration and House Republicans are hoping that the Senate deadlock will finally force the Democratic leaders there to agree that it is time for Congress and the White House to begin budget negotiations. The White House is eager for such negotiations, but Democrats are divided on whether to start the talks now or wait until later in the year.
The House plan calls for military budget authority of $283 billion, $24 billion less than Mr. Bush proposed. Budget authority is the amount of spending the Defense Department can commit for programs that may continue a number of years, like the purchase of an aircraft carrier. Limiting the figure would compel future military cuts.
The House plan calls for spending $224.3 billion on dozens of domestic programs like education, agriculture, grants to scientists and protecting abused children. That is $5.6 billion more than the White House proposed.
 
'Repudiation' of Bush Plan
House Speaker Thomas S. Foley of Washington joined a chorus of Democrats hoping to take advantage of the Republican decision to keep Mr. Bush's budget from a vote. ''This is, in effect, a quiet, if secret, repudiation of the President's proposals,'' he told reporters. ''A total abandonment.''
Representative Bill Frenzel of Minnesota, the senior Republican on the House Budget Committee, acknowledged that some Republicans were unhappy with Mr. Bush's proposals for cuts in Medicare, agriculture and retirement benefits for Federal workers, but he said Republicans had a larger point to make in not offering the plan.
''The blunt fact is that both the Democratic budget and the President's budget are hopelessly obsolete,'' he said, adding that Republicans want to avoid ''debating history'' and to hasten serious negotiations between the White House and Congress. Mr. Frenzel said officials at the Office of Management and Budget now believe the Federal deficit will be some $20 billion higher than projected in either budget because assumptions the Administration made about the interest rates have proven overly optimistic.
''What we are trying to tell the Democrats is that we are needlessly beating our gums,'' he said. ''This debate is irrelevant, ineffective and unecessary.''
 
Totals Are Nearly Identical
Both the budget approved today and Mr. Bush's plan included virtually identical figures for total spending: $1.23 trillion, with revenues of $1.17 trillion and a deficit of about $63 billion.
The Gramm-Rudman-Hollings balanced budget law requires that the deficit be held to $64 billion in the 1991 fiscal year and imposes automatic cuts in domestic and military programs if Congress does not agree to its own spending cuts or revenue increases to achieve that level.
But House Democrats rearranged the spending priorities within the overall budget, directing more money to domestic programs like housing and education and allowing room within the recommended foreign aid budget to provide $700 million to the new democracies in Eastern Europe, about twice the level suggested by the President.
The specifics of spending decisions will be made later this year by the Congressional committees that have jurisdiction over particular programs.
The budget measure that eventually emerges from Congress does not require the approval of President Bush, but the tax or spending bills that Congress passes to put the blueprint into effect do need the President's signature.
Although Mr. Bush has repeatedly said he opposes new taxes, his budget called for $13.9 billion in new revenue, including a variety of fees and an increase in the tax on airline tickets. The House adopted the same figure for new revenue, leaving it to the Ways and Means Committee to determine which taxes or fees would have to be raised.
 
Revenue Increases
As did the Administration, the House Democrats assumed that about $36 billion in spending cuts and revenue increases would be needed to meet the $64 billion deficit goal. But if new, more pessimistic economic forecasts by the Administration prove correct, Congress may have to find an additional $20 billion to keep the deficit at the prescribed level.
Mr. Frenzel said that prospect made immediate negotiations with the White House all the more crucial to avoid huge automatic spending cuts later in the year. ''If we don't,'' he said, ''a $56 billion train wreck lies ahead of us.''
Mr. Foley gave no indication of how quickly House Democrats might be willing to engage in such talks, noting that today's action was only the beginning of the process of agreeing to a budget. ''I think eventually there will be discussions with the Administration,'' he said, carefully avoiding the word negotiation.

HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe;
Baker Is Off to Europe, Ready to Sell Soviets on United Germany in NATO

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 1

 BODY:
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d leaves for Europe on Wednesday for the first six-nation talks about the future of a united Germany, carrying a briefcase full of ideas that he hopes will help the Soviets accept what the United States sees as inevitable: a unified Germany in NATO.
The ''two plus four'' negotiations, which were agreed upon last February at an East-West conference in Ottawa, call for West and East Germany to sit down with the four World War II Allies - the United States, Soviet Union, Britain and France - to resolve all of the external security issues raised by German reunification, and to dissolve the four powers' legal rights and responsibilities in Berlin and Germany as a whole.
Whatever the formal agenda, Administration officials and analysts predict the talks will quickly come down to the Soviets asking the Germans what economic and security incentives they will grant Moscow in return for the Soviets' expeditiously withdrawing their 380,000 troops from East Germany, allowing a united Germany to become a member of NATO and terminating their legal rights in Berlin along with the other Allies. 
 
Package of Initiatives
It is not that the Kremlin is expected to try to prevent German unification, say officials. It is far too late for that. But the Soviets can drag their feet -with bluff, bluster, blandishments and by endless haggling over the arcane legal issues involved in Berlin - until they are satisfied that arrangements for a united Germany will be militarily and politically acceptable.
The question for the West, said an Administration official, ''is how we make it digestible for the Soviets so they will accept this inevitable outcome sooner rather than later.''
Administration officials say they have in mind a package of initiatives that would not only make the establishment of a united Germany in NATO something palatable for the Soviets, but also acceptable to the other Europeans, many of whom are also nervous about German unification.
 
Informal Discussions
Most of the initiatives the Administration has in mind will be discussed only informally in the two-plus-four talks, which begin Saturday, and then parceled out to the relevant negotiating forums, where they will actually be addressed. The package includes these ideas:
* The Western Allies will suggest to the Soviets that if they are concerned about the size of the West German army, now 500,000 men, then Moscow and Bonn should work out a troop reduction arrangment as part of the ongoing Vienna talks limiting conventional forces in Europe. The Soviets will also be invited to station a limited number of troops in East Germany for a fixed transition period, as will the Allies in Berlin.
* The united Germany is expected to reaffirm West Germany's promise never to obtain nuclear, chemical or biological weapons, and formally confirm the Oder-Neisse line as its eastern border with Poland.
* In order to make a united Germany in NATO a less-threatening, more politically acceptable entity to the Soviets, negotiations are expected to begin soon that would result in the elimination of all, or most, United States-controlled, short-range nuclear missiles, and perhaps artillery shells, in Germany in exchange for the removal of the Soviet's short-range missiles and nuclear artillery from Europe. That would leave NATO with only air-delivered nuclear bombs in Germany.
* West Germany is expected to reassure the Soviets that all of the contracts that they have with East German industries will be assumed by a united Germany, and, say German officials, Bonn will strongly hint to Moscow that if it plays along on two-plus-four, generous economic aid will follow suit. The West Germans are also expected to offer to help subsidize the cost - as the East German Government used to do - of maintaining Soviet troops in East German territory for the transitional period.
* The 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe will be given a new, expanded and formalized role for conflict resolution and intra-European dialogue for its member states, say Administration officials, so that after a united Germany joins NATO - and the Warsaw Pact inevitably fades away - the Soviets, Poles, Czechs, Hungarians, Romanians and Bulgarians won't feel left out in the cold.
 
'In the Same Club'
''With C.S.C.E. everyone can feel that they are in the same club,'' said a senior Administration official. ''It won't really provide military or economic security, but psychological security, a place where everyone can feel at home talking about any European issues they want.''
This could prove to be the most difficult part of the package to sell, both to the Allies and the Soviets. The French would prefer to see the American-dominated NATO downgraded and the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe given a more formal security role that might eventually make it more of an alternative to NATO than a complement.
The same goes for the Soviets, who will find it hard to accept the notion of NATO emerging as the sole, dominating security structure in Europe. This could create the politically dangerous impression back in Moscow that while Stalin won World War II, Mikhail S. Gorbachev lost the peace.
There is a word that American officials say they have been hearing constantly of late from the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze: 'Synchronization.''
''What we think he means is that until they have a sense that all of their concerns and interests have been addressed - from the conventional forces negotiations to German unification - they will behave as though none of them have been addressed,'' a senior Administration official said. ''I think the Soviets are just now waking up to the monumental consequences of everything that has happened in Europe in the last year and this has introduced a kind of tentative and confused quality to their decision making.''

HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe;
Lithuanian Leader, on 'Private' Visit, to Meet Bush

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 1

 BODY:
President Bush will meet with the Lithuanian Prime Minister on Thursday, the White House announced today. It will be the first time that an American President has met with a leader of the Baltic republic since it was forcibly incorporated into the Soviet Union in 1940.
By the Administration's account, the meeting with Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene will also be the first direct contact between Mr. Bush and any Lithuanian official since Lithuania declared independence from Moscow on March 11.
The White House, aware of the diplomatic conundrum posed by the meeting, went out of its way today to portray Mrs. Prunskiene's visit to Washington and the White House talks as a private affair that did not signal a change in United States policy on Lithuania. 
 
Bush Decision Criticized
The announcement of the planned meeting came as Congress sharpened its criticism of Mr. Bush's decision last week not to retaliate for the Kremlin's economic sanctions against Lithuania.
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d became embroiled in a testy exchange with several prominent Senators during a committee hearing, and the full Senate voted 73 to 24 for a nonbinding resolution urging Mr. Bush not to submit legislation to increase trade with the Soviet Union unless Moscow lifts its trade sanctions and begins negotiating with the republic's elected leaders.
Trying to walk a thin line between refusal to recognize the incorporation of Lithuania into the Soviet Union and support for President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Bush Administration has not recognized the leadership of Lithuania as the government of an independent nation.
 
Letter Goes Unanswered
The White House has avoided direct contacts with Lithuanian officials during the crisis; Mr. Bush has not even responded to a letter from President Vytautas Landsbergis.
Mrs. Prunskiene has been quoted in news reports from Vilnius as saying that she was initially denied permission to visit Washington before the summit meeting between Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev, scheduled for May 30 to June 3.
But Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said today that Mrs. Prunskiene was never denied a visa and sought to portray Mr. Bush's decision to meet her in the White House as a routine matter without any greater policy implications.
Mr. Fitzwater said: ''The President feels that it's important to get an authoritative readout and description of events in Lithuania, hear first hand from her what is occuring there. And so she is in this country, and he thinks it's an important opportunity to hear her views.''
 
Reaction in Lithuania
The Reuters news agency quoted a spokesman for the legislature in Vilnius as saying that the meeting was a positive sign. After Mr. Bush declined to retaliate against Moscow for cutting off shipments of oil and natural gas to Lithuania, President Landsbergis charged that Mr. Bush had sold out Lithuania in a manner reminiscent of the appeasement of Hitler.
''At least this shows Bush has not taken his comments too personally,'' the spokesman, Edward Tuskenis, was quoted as saying.
Even with Mr. Fitzwater's careful formulation, the meeting posed some subtle diplomatic problems, since the point was to avoid any suggestion that the meeting was a tacit recognition of an independent Lithuania.
Mr. Fitzwater was asked, for example, if Mr. Bush was meeting with Mrs. Prunskiene as a private citizen, or as the Prime Minister of Lithuania.
 
'A Private Visit'
''He is meeting with her as an acknowledged and freely elected representative of the Lithuanian people,'' Mr. Fitzwater said. ''She is here on a private visit, as we've said.''
Mr. Fitzwater said Mr. Bush ''is not meeting with her as Prime Minister of an independent Lithuania. Just so there is no confusion.''
But what, Mr. Fitzwater was asked, will Mr. Bush call Mrs. Prunskiene? ''Prime Minister, I suppose,'' Mr. Fitzwater said.
Asked how that fit in with the Administration's position on Lithuania's independence, he said the ''title she carries is Prime Minister.''
''We'll be glad to call her that title,'' he said. ''We do not recognize Lithuania, and there's nothing changed about that.''
 
Message to the Kremlin
During a Senate hearing today, Senator Dennis DeConcini, Democrat of Arizona, told Mr. Baker that Mr. Bush's decision not to retaliate for the Kremlin's economic sanctions sent this message to the republic's leaders: ''Oh gosh, yeah, we want you free and we want to help, but you know, we're not going to do anything to upset Mr. Gorbachev.''
Mr. Baker listened with evident irritation and replied, ''I think that the President, frankly, Senator DeConcini, is in a better position to judge what might or might not be effective for the long run.''
The Senator said, ''I realize you guys are the masters here, and I'm just a little munchkin working around here, trying to express a view.'' But, he added, ''it seems to me that we're talking and that's all we're doing.''
Mr. Baker said, ''We have a lot of interests at stake here that are very important interests to the United States of America. One of these interests is to see the Soviets destroy 40,000 tanks as a part of a conventional forces agreement, and we want to lock that agreement in.''
''Another is to see them destroy 50 percent of their heavy strategic missiles which are targeted on United States cities. We want to see that agreement locked in. We want to see a continued approach by the Soviet Union that will permit us to hopefully bring freedom and democracy to other areas of the world.''
Mr. Baker said the Administration had to ''balance'' those concerns with pressure to push Mr. Gorbachev to allow Lithuania to secede. ''This is the way we see it for the time being,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Rich and Poor Lands Agree On Path to Economic Growth

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, May 1

 BODY:
Rich and poor countries reached agreement today on a declaration setting out new priorities for speeding up economic growth in the developing world in the 1990's after a difficult debate that ran longer than expected.
The declaration, unanimously adopted by a special session of the United Nations General Assembly, reflects the growing consensus on economic matters in the world since the majority of Eastern European countries abandoned Communism as an economic doctrine and recognized the importance of free markets and private initiative.
The declaration has no binding force on the nations that accepted it. But like all such United Nations agreements, it serves to record the shifting international consensus on what steps are needed to improve the third world's economic prospects after its generally disappointing preformance in the 1980's, when many poor countries grew poorer still. 
It emphasizes the importance of third world countries adopting sound domestic policies that reduce inflation, promote investment and make their economies more competitive. But it also acknowledges that democracy and the protection of human rights have a role in fostering the third world's economic growth.
 
Providing New Markets
In addition, the declaration recognizes that the political changes under way in Eastern Europe will help the developing world by providing it with new markets and sources of technology rather than absorbing Western assistance which it might otherwise have received. And it sees the safeguarding of the environment as a vital part of the development process.
Finally, it commits north and south to make a success of a series of international conferences dealing with specific international economic problems.
Those include the Paris meeting on the problems of the least developed nations in September, the Unicef world summit meeting on children's problems, also scheduled for September, the Uruguay Round of trade freeing negotiations and the 1992 United Nations Conference on Environment and Development, which will try to draft a new treaty combating climate change.
''Ideological conflict is yielding to a global approach to the real problems that beset the world,'' Boliva's representative, Hugo Navajas-Mogro, told the closing session on behalf of the Group of 77, as the third world calls itself at the United Nations.
 
The Need for New Policies
Speaking for the Bush Administration, Edward Marks, senior United States adviser to the special session, noted a ''fundamental rethinking'' of approaches to development and said, ''We are seeing a true convergence of views around the need for sound macroeconomic policies, enhanced competition and greater flexibility, creativity, innovation and openness.''
The consensus outcome came about only after delegates missed their original deadline of last Saturday for an agreement and carried on negotiations until late Monday night.
But the final consensus, diplomats say, also represents a personal triumph for the United States representative at the United Nations, Thomas R. Pickering, who opposed a skeptical United States Treasury, which originally wanted the United States to boycott the meeting.
Mr. Pickering said at a news conference before the meeting that the United States was taking part only with ''a lot of skepticism and a lot of reluctance'' in Washington because in the past such discussions often degenerated into quarrels between the industrial north and the developing south.
Nevertheless, despite the general climate of compromise, sharp conflicts of interest arose between north and south, particularly over debt and access to Western technology. And for the first time in any United Nations document approved by consensus, today's declaration raises the possibility of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund's granting relief to third-world debtors, something those institutions have refused to do in the past.

HEADLINE: Senate Approves $720 Million in Aid for Panama and Nicaragua

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 1

 BODY:
In a spur to the Bush Administration's Latin America policy, the Senate today approved giving $720 million in economic aid to Panama and Nicaragua after an impasse of several days over an assortment of unrelated amendments.
The assistance, which was approved by voice vote, was included in a $3.4 billion spending bill, mostly for domestic programs. The measure will now go to conference, where senators will work out a final bill with the House of Representatives, which had already passed a $2.4 billion version of the bill.
The action on Nicaragua and Panama came hours after the Administration signaled that it may become more restrictive in allocating aid to a third fragile Latin American democracy, El Salvador. 
Secretary of States James A. Baker 3d said at a Senate hearing and in meetings with lawmakers that the Administration may link future aid to that country's progress toward peace and human rights, and specifically in bringing to justice the killers of six Jesuit priests, their housekeeper and her daughter. Eight members of the Salvadoran armed forces, including a colonel, have been arrested in the case, but no further judicial action has been taken.
 
'A Turning Point'
''This case has got to become a turning point in the history of El Salvador,'' Mr. Baker told the foreign aid subcommittee of the Senate Appropriations Committee. ''I think it's fair to say that the sentiment being what it is, our assistance is going to be affected by the way this case is handled.''
Mr. Baker spoke a day after a task force of House Democrats issued a report saying the Salvadoran investigation had been at a standstill since January. Mr. Baker praised the work of the 19-member Democratic task force, saying it had raised substantial questions about the investigation and had conducted itself in a balanced and professional manner.
The path for Senate passage of the spending bill was cleared Monday night, after the Senate voted to allow the District of Columbia to use local funds to pay for abortions for poor women. Republicans had opposed that provision, but relented after Democrats agreed to another provision in the measure that would allow courts in the capital to impose the death penalty for drug-related murders.
President Bush has threatened to veto the bill if, in its final form, it contains the provision for the funds for abortion. Before the vote today, the President complained that Congress was moving too slowly in approving the aid to Panama and Nicaragua, and accused lawmakers of delaying passage by including their pet projects in the measure.
 
Endara at Press Club
But in a speech at the National Press Club, President Guillermo Endara of Panama did not echo the criticism. ''This is the price we pay for democracy,'' he said of the delays.
Despite the delays, the Bush Administration got most of what it wanted in the aid bill. Mr. Bush had requested $800 million for Panama and Nicaragua. Although there were efforts to greatly slash the funding, both the Senate and House versions provide for $720 million.
Panama will get $420 million, some of which will go to repair damage caused by the American sanctions against that country and the invasion by American troops last December that resulted in the ouster of the Panamanian leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega.
Mr. Endara, who was installed as President by the Americans, said Panama will not seek more aid next year because the country will use some of the money to pay off overdue loans to international banks. That, he said, would make Panama eligible for new development loans.
Most of the $300 million for Nicaragua will be for development projects and agricultural supplies. Money will also go for repatriation of the contra rebels and emergency employment programs.
The Senate, in the last day of consideration, passed several amendments to the bill, including more funds for an educational program for gifted students and for the United National Environment Program. Other unrelated provisions had already been attached to the bill, like more money for fighting forest fires and for the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The package also authorized $400 million in loan guarantees for Israel to build housing for new emigres from the Soviet Union. In a 73 to 24 vote, the Senate also approved a nonbinding provision urging Mr. Bush not to send to Congress a trade agreement with the Soviet Union until Moscow rescinds sanctions against Lithuania.
 
Salvadorans Comment
SAN SALVADOR, May 1 (Reuters) - Reacting to the possibility of deep cuts in United States military aid, the Salvadoran Government said today that its much-criticized inquiry into the murder of six priests could lead to a trial within 90 days.
The Salvadoran armed forces said cutting military aid would strengthen the hand of leftist rebels in the country's 10-year-long civil war, which has cost tens of thousands of lives.
''It hurts us that a cut in aid is being considered,'' said Maj. Mauricio Chaves Caceres, head of the armed forces press office.
Total American aid to El Salvador has been running at more than $1 million a day for the last decade. Military aid has totaled almost $900 million in that period, according to American Embassy figures.

HEADLINE: Berkeley Journal;
Finding the Right Dog For a Left-Leaning City

BYLINE: By KATHERINE BISHOP, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BERKELEY, Calif., April 26

 BODY:
In many cities, what comes to mind when people think of a police dog is the kind of animal that becomes the canine equivalent of the business end of a .357 magnum when it bares its teeth.
But this is Berkeley, a city that prides itself on its exquisite sense of doing the right thing on every question, from plastic foam food containers to peace trips to Nicaragua. So when faced with hiring its first police dog in decades to help combat a growing problem with crack, the city did what comes naturally here: it insisted on a politically correct pooch.
Translated more broadly, that means a dog that will not conjure up memories of the snarling beasts used to attack civil rights or antiwar demonstrators in the 1960's and 70's. While many cities with neighborhoods that are being torn apart by crack might welcome a lean, mean drug-fighting machine, the last thing Berkeley wants is a German shepherd with an attitude. 
After a talent search that lasted for months, the Berkeley Police Department has obtained Pepper, a 19-month-old Labrador that can sniff out stashes of crack even when drug dealers hide them outdoors under debris. And Pepper may be the prototype for the 1990's - a kinder, gentler police dog.
Gary A. Farwell, the executive assistant to Mayor Loni Hancock, said: ''This is not an aggressive dog. He does not instill fear by his presence alone.''
Over the years, this city has had an attitude about both the police and drug use that could be described as complex at best. In the late 1960's, it was as common to hear antiwar demonstrators refer to the guardians of public order as ''blue meanies'' as it was to see some police officers slapping their nightsticks against their open hands while begging their superiors to let them bust a few demonstrators' heads.
At the same time, marijuana gained widespread use, touted as a ''natural'' drug. In 1979 voters passed an ordinance that directed the police not to enforce laws against the personal use of marijuana and instructed the city to lobby for legalizing the drug.
Today, with crack destroying the city's poorer neighborhoods, many people here demanded stepped-up police activity, including drug-sniffing dogs, and are circulating petitions to place a measure on the November ballot that would repeal the 1979 law.
''That law is completely out of step with the times,'' said James W. Smith, a postal worker who heads the 300-member Berkeley Black Property Owners Association. ''It's like telling kids this is the one drug you can say yes to.''
The group argued for a well-trained police dog by holding a meeting at which a German shepherd demonstrated its drug-sniffing capabilities.
''The idea of a politically correct police dog is nonsense,'' Mr. Smith said, citing the ''heroic role'' played by German shepherds in looking for people trapped under rubble after the earthquake that struck the San Francisco Bay Area last October.
Once the city agreed to enlist a police dog, finding the right dog proved to be a challenging task. At first, the City Council specified a small breed, suggesting that perhaps the perfect beagle could be found.
There was a flurry of optimism late last year when Stride, an English cocker spaniel, trotted in from Berkeley's political antithesis to the south, Orange County, and instantly won everyone's heart. Alas, the canine crime-stopper was judged to be too emotionally attached to its owner.
A few months ago half a dozen dogs judged sufficiently mellow for the job were identified, and Pepper was selected by Charles E. Blake, general manager of Witmer-Tyson Imports Inc. of Menlo Park, which specializes in training dogs for law-enforcement agencies.
''He's a very nice dog from a personality standpoint,'' Mr. Blake said. ''One of their big concerns was that they did not want a fire-breathing beast that would be used for crowd control.''
But for some here, no police dog can pass muster. Maudelle Shirek, a member of the City Council since 1984 and a resident of Berkeley since 1943, helped lead the fight against German shepherds.
''I'm against any kind of dog,'' she said. ''People become confused and frustrated, so that's what they resort to. The drug problem is not a police issue. It's a social, economic and moral issue.''

SECTION: Section A; Page 18, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1731 words

HEADLINE: Washington at Work;
Two Unlikely Voices That Find Harmony On the Military Budget

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 1

 BODY:
It took Sam Nunn three months of research to pronounce the Bush Administration's 1991 military budget irrelevant. His series of carefully timed speeches on the Senate floor was front-page news.
It took Representative Les Aspin 24 hours to make virtually the same observation the day after the Pentagon announced the budget plans in January. His off-the-cuff remarks, delivered during a news conference on military-base closings, went largely unremarked upon.
The contrast speaks volumes about the two Democrats who as heads of the Armed Services Committees of Congress are as central to the debate about the United States role in the post-cold war world as their onetime colleague on Capital Hill, Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney. 
To the degree that ''new thinking'' on the nation's military programs emerges from Capitol Hill, it will almost certainly come from either Mr. Aspin or Mr. Nunn, partly because they are the members of Congress who think hardest about such issues and partly because their positions mean their thoughts and words will be heeded at the Pentagon, at the White House and in the press.
Sam Nunn is a small-town Georgia lawyer. Les Aspin is a Wisconsin economist with Ivy League credentials. For all their surface differences, they enter the military budget deliberations with a number of broad areas of agreement. (One of them is that they have both had their fill of odd-couple comparisons. ''You're going to say I'm owlish and he's effusive,'' grumped Mr. Nunn.) Different Routes Traveled Mr. Nunn is not just another go-along-get-along holder of a safe seat, Mr. Aspin is not merely a darling of the Northern liberal clique. And each has traveled a route that took him beyond the limitations of his political roots and his natural inclinations.
''We have very different backgrounds and a very different consultation process, but we often come out the same way,'' Mr. Aspin said. ''If you ask what's different between me and Sam Nunn, I tend to be more of a Congressional activist; my reaction is to do something, write it into a bill. Sam's reaction is to make a phone call or write a letter.''
Mr. Nunn's roots are the South -the tradition of patriotic responsibility and respect for authority, especially for the uniformed military. The ''Georgia heritage,'' as he calls it, virtually ordained his career path. He came to the Senate in 1972. His great-uncle, Carl Vinson, who ran the House Armed Services Committee, had left. But the Southern warlord tradition and influence - and the desire to perpetuate regional influence in Congress - was embodied in Senator John Stennis of Mississippi. Mr. Nunn was positioned for his chairmanship.
''I found out then, even though some people view manpower as boring, that this is the heart and soul of the military,'' Mr. Nunn said of his work as Mr. Stennis's cadet on the Senate armed services panel. ''I spent hundreds of hours in the manpower subcommittee; many times I was the only one there. But I learned an awful lot about personnel and people, promotion systems, numbers and generals and admirals - why that's such an emotional subject.''
Mr. Aspin's roots are a more complicated mixture of Midwestern populism and the Eastern establishment. His delight in challenging authority and his ready resort to a press release reflect his work as an intern and a campaign aide to William Proxmire, a Wisconsin Democrat who was a master at both while a Senator. But Mr. Aspin, who ran for Congress as an anti-Vietnam War Democrat, also had a stint at the Pentagon as one of Robert McNamara's whiz kids, in the early years of the Vietnam War.
''Informing and defining,'' he said when pressed to describe how that experience affected him. ''I at the time thought that gradual escalation was the right policy. In retrospect, that was not the right policy.'' As to what he learned in the Pentagon, he said, ''You learn the limitations on the political use of force.''
 
No Apologies From Aspin
The Aspin press releases are still pithy, if not quite as frequent as they were during his political adolescence. But even now he makes no apologies for the unabashed publicity seeking.
''You start out as a junior member of a committee,'' he said. ''How do you make an impact? One of the ways you do it is to call attention to problems. You kind of fall into it because it's one of the few outlets you have. As you get more seniority, you can move things without that device. You can get broader.''
In Mr. Aspin's case, getting broader meant disappointing the House liberals who in 1985 helped him leapfrog to the Armed Services chairmanship over half a dozen more senior committee members. By 1987, they were angry enough to win a no-confidence vote. He won the chair back two weeks later, and has spent two years trying to mend fences. He speaks of the abortive coup now as though it were some ancient tribal conflict rather than a reprimand for a nonconsulting style of operating.
''Every revolution sets up a counterrevolution,'' he said. ''It comes from a combination of people who don't think the original revolution went quite far enough and the people who think it went too far. If you survive the counterrevolution, then it's O.K.''
In the four years they have shared as chairmen, Mr. Nunn and Mr. Aspin have fundamentally agreed, brokering budget-driven compromises. Yet each year, politics and personality conspire to reinforce the typecasting: methodical Sam Nunn, a preeminent spokesman on defense because he finds bipartisan consensus; gadfly Les Aspin, with an academic's interest in arms control, driven to the middle by the tension between his committee's conservatives and the liberal House majority.
 
Uneasy With Interviews
''I hate this, I hate it,'' Mr. Nunn said, wincing at the prospect of having to talk about himself and adamant in his refusal to talk about any differences or similarities with Mr. Aspin. Mr. Aspin is no less uneasy with conversations that stray too far from the cerebral.
''I always have difficult problems with these interviews where I'm asked, 'Underneath, what do you really think?' '' he said with a sigh.
The clue to what Mr. Aspin thinks is the way he thinks - in big, analytical constructs and scenarios, as if the world were a gigantic puzzle and his job were to try the pieces in various combinations. Often he thinks out loud, a habit born of his years at Yale, Oxford and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, but one that leads some colleagues to complain that he is inconsistent.
''If I look at the Soviet Union now, in the spring of 1990, putting together the 1991 budget,'' he begins, ''what do I see?'' As he speaks, he is repositioning his gangling body sideways in his swivel chair so that his head is thrown back against one of its arms and his legs are dangling over the other. Staring up at the ceiling, he continues to spin out the arguments, pro and con - for cutting the Administration's military budget request.
But what does the chairman of the House Armed Services Committee believe?
''I say I want to hedge my bets,'' Mr. Aspin concludes, snapping back to an upright posture. ''I don't know whether the hawks are right or the doves are right, but it tells me that we probably ought not jump too much one way or the other until we see more evidence.''
 
The Body Language Clue
Mr. Aspin's body language should not be taken lightly, said Senator John Warner of Virginia, the senior Republican on Armed Services Committee, who has spent hours across the bargaining table from him.
''As the discussions go on, Les slides further and further down in his chair,'' said Mr. Warner, eagerly demonstrating the Aspin slouch. ''When he's slid almost to the floor, that's when you know he's going to cut his deal.''
Mr. Nunn gives away almost nothing with his body language and, 90 percent of the time, not a great deal more when he talks. The painstaking insistence on building a case before making it is a character trait that his colleagues find both admirable and irritating.
''If I know what I'm going to do, I don't mind telling people,'' he said, acknowledging that the more common impression is that he is simply avoiding a question until he has his political ducks in order. ''A lot of times, I really have not thought through it, or even if I know which way I'm going to lean, I don't have the clear rationale behind my answer at that stage.''
James Schlesinger, the former Defense Secretary and Central Intelligence director who is part of Mr. Nunn's kitchen cabinet, said, ''He is willing to reach judgments quickly in private, but unwilling to express them publicly until he has overwhelming evidence for them.''
Mr. Nunn did not spend a lifetime around Southern politicians without learning a few things about the grease that makes a legislature run. ''One of the great challenges around here is not just knowing the substance of something,'' he said, ''but knowing how to relate it to the timing and knowing how to relate it to other people's thoughts and ideas and knowing how to express it and knowing how many people and who you need to bounce it around with to get their input before you ever do it.''
For Sam Nunn, this is a proving time. His predecessor, Richard Russell of Georgia, decided to be a ''super-Senator'' after failing to win his party's Presidential nomination in 1952, and the conventional wisdom is that Mr. Nunn will take Mr. Russell's path.
Les Aspin's ambitions once included the Senate. But that flame has banked, and he is now busy doing what comes most naturally, tutoring. His latest pupils are the Russians, through an ad-hoc committee exchange program that brings Soviet military brass and legislators to his panel to observe the American brand of defense politics and policy making. ''Aspin was a self-proclaimed gadfly taking on the Pentagon powers, while Nunn was taking the role of uncle,'' said Norman Ornstein of the American Enterprise Institute. ''Now Aspin is taking positions where gadflies criticize him, and Nunn is taking positions where his traditional allies often look at him with bewilderment. As they have changed they've become more alike.''
Mr. Aspin acknowledges that perhaps the two have moved closer together. ''We can speak to each other in shorthand,'' the Representative said of the Senator. On Capitol Hill, the view is that they'll need to.

GRAPHIC: Photo: ''We have very different backgrounds and a very different consultation process, but we often come out the same way,'' Representative Les Aspin, left, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, said of his relationship with Senator Sam Nunn, chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee. (Andrea Mohin/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Warning on 'Risk-o-Phobia'

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 1

 BODY:
Budget Director Richard G. Darman said tonight that the United States should not abandon its market economy and economic growth to clean up the environment.
''Americans did not fight and win the wars of the 20th century to make the world safe for green vegetables,'' Mr. Darman said in a speech at Harvard University. ''If we were to regulate houses with the same principles we now apply to our food and air, for example, we would all have to live in single-story homes - for fear of falling down stairs.''
Mr. Darman and the White House chief of staff, John H. Sununu, are the two senior White House aides most skeptical of strengthening regulation of the environment. They have argued in support of diluting Presidental positions on global warming and other environmental issues.
The budget director said Americans ''must counter the tendency to become a risk-o-phobic society'' because prudent risk-taking is central to the American spirit and standard of living.
''It would be a regrettable irony if just as the values of the American romance were to triumph in the East-West struggle, they were to be lost in what some environmentalists like to term the struggle for 'global management,' '' Mr. Darman said.
''Because so many people are self-proclaimed 'environmentalists,' the label is no longer a meaningful characteristic. It is a green mask under which different faces of politico-economic ideology can hide,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Why So Slow on S & L Thieves?

 BODY:
The savings and loan bailout is already a mess. Why does the Bush Administration seem so determined to make the cleanup even slower? Now it is not so subtly nudging out the man who is managing the bailout. That comes hard on the heels of Congressional hearings showing Administration stinginess in prosecuting S & L thieves. 
An argument can at least be made for retiring William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and of the Resolution Trust Corporation. He's a holdover appointee who has said he intends to leave before his term expires next year. But there's no excuse for the insufficient prosecutorial effort.
S & L officers and owners who bled their institutions bankrupt are proving hard to catch. Most of the plunder has been squandered on bad investments and high living. That's the frustrating message from the latest of the House Banking Committee's useful hearings on the scandal.
F.B.I. Director William Sessions testified that though his agents had found ''pervasive'' fraud, the paper trail was so difficult to verify that it would take years to catch the thieves. Last year's S & L bailout legislation authorized $75 million a year for additional agents and Justice Department attorneys for three years. More than 200 have been added, but still more will be needed. Yet the Administration sought only $49 million in new enforcement funds for the first year and contends that $50 million will do for the second.
Fraud alone did not bring on the crisis, and could not have flourished without lax Federal regulation. Even so, the fraud was widespread and huge. Public anger at paying taxes to bail out thievery is fully justified. Moreover, unpunished fraud undermines confidence in financial institutions.
Henry Gonzales, the Texas Democrat who heads the House committee, has built a valuable record of what went wrong. The most electrifying hearings, on the Lincoln Savings and Loan case in California, spotlighted the Senate's ''Keating Five,'' who took large campaign contributions from Lincoln's chairman, Charles Keating.
Two of the five are the Senate Banking Committee's chairman, Donald Riegle of Michigan, and its ranking Democrat, Alan Cranston of California. That may help explain why the committee hasn't picked up Mr. Gonzales's lead. All five are under investigation by the Senate Ethics Committee.
The thrift industry's troubles turned into the biggest financial crisis in history while Congress -and the Reagan Administration - looked the other way. To keep looking away is to endorse fraud.

HEADLINE: Maybe the Key To Long-Term Care

BYLINE: By William A. O'Neill; William A. O'Neill is Governor of Connecticut.

DATELINE: HARTFORD

 BODY:
Solving the problem of financing long-term health care for the elderly is a pressing national priority. Connecticut has taken steps to address that problem, and is awaiting action by Congress that would help put its plan into action.
In 1986, I appointed a special commission to examine private and public responsibilities for financing long-term health care for the elderly.
In 1987, the commission reported that Connecticut was spending $274 million for that purpose. But, it said, with the growth in the elderly population and the projected rate of inflation of health care costs, that sum would grow to $1.4 billion by the year 2000 unless the state did something different. What could be done? There was substantial evidence that the private sector alone could not pay for long-term care. We realized that a publicly financed social-insurance program was equally unlikely, given America's national budget deficit and competing demands for Federal dollars. 
At this point, Connecticut realized that a public-and-private partnership offered the most promising alternative. The Robert Wood Johnson Foundation then gave the state a two-year $350,000 grant to develop such a partnership.
The projected plan, called the Connecticut Partnership for Long-Term Care, was worked out in 1988 and 1980 by the state's executive branch, legislators, insurers, consumers, health-care providers and employers.
It would provide individuals with a way to plan ahead to meet long-term needs for care while also constraining the growth of Federal and state Medicaid expenditures.
The state's primary goal is to enable individuals to receive necessary care without having to impoverish themselves. Under the plan, individuals are offered an incentive of guaranteed protection of assets to purchase private insurance for long-term care in amounts they can afford.
If individuals need such care in a nursing home or at home, they will first receive benefits under their private insurance policy. When that coverage runs out, they can apply for Medicaid and protect one dollar of their assets for every dollar their private policy has paid out in state-approved benefits.
These protected assets can spell the difference between dependence and independence. No longer will people need to go broke to get Medicaid.
Simply put, the partnership would do the following things:
First, it would allow individuals to protect assets equal to the sum their insurance has paid out in approved benefits. Second, it would establish stringent standards for private insurance policies that can offer such protection. Third, it would create a public consumer-information service to help individuals choose appropriate coverage.
Fourth, it would lead to much more affordable policies by encouraging insurers to develop a variety of policies for a wide market, including the poor as well as the affluent. Fifth, it would save state and Federal dollars by delaying enrollment in Medicaid.
By testing this approach, we can demonstrate how far private insurance can go in financing long-term care. It will then be possible to design public benefits that are feasible and cost-effective.
In June 1989, the General Assembly unanimously authorized the demonstration. The Robert Wood Johnson Foundation awarded the state $1.8 million to finance the first three years of a six-year demonstration.
However, since Medicaid is a joint Federal-state program, Federal legislation is needed for the demonstration to go forward. This legislation would waive the requirement that individuals can retain only a bare minimum of their assets before qualifying for Medicaid assistance. Such a measure unanimously passed the Senate last November but still awaits action in the House Energy and Commerce Committee.
We hope that the committee appreciates that the Connecticut partnership is a socially conscious, fiscally sound response to one of the most critical issues facing every state and the nation as a whole.
It offers a middle ground that is feasible, that will provide incentives to individuals to plan ahead and that will provide valuable information to guide a reasoned national solution.

HEADLINE: About New York;
Gay Dentists? Flirting Advice? Call the Hot Line

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

 BODY:
Things hummed along at the Gay and Lesbian Switchboard.
''How do you know you're gay?'' a nervous Long Island high school student asked. He had ridden his bicycle to a pay phone with a roll of quarters in his pocket.
A lesbian called to say she was lonely. A man called from London to ask about gay hotspots in Paris, his next stop. Someone wanted names of violent sex clubs and received a half dozen suggestions. Someone wanted and got a list of moving companies owned by gay people. An unemployed laborer asked about jobs. 
Nothing startles at this all-volunteer telephone counseling, referral and information service for gay people and those who are interested in gay people - be they parents, spouses or simply the curious. More than 30,000 people a year call to talk about everything from the suicide of a gay friend to where to find a gay dentist.
The premise is simple: people who aren't cut from a standard-issue cookie-cutter are O.K. too. And they need someone to talk to.
''It's all anonymous,'' said Brad Becker, the financial analyst who is president of the 18-year-old switchboard. ''It's a chance to talk to other gay people, to say something one has never been able to say to anybody before.''
The switchboard's first headquarters was literally in a closet at a bath house called ''Man's Country.'' Now at 648 Broadway, it receives no corporate or government support -but in 1985 it was granted nonprofit, tax-exempt status. Bills are paid through small donations.
Three phones are staffed daily from noon to midnight. A vast majority of calls are local, and all are anonymous. Volunteers punching computer keyboards can almost instantaneously pass on information about groups of gay bakers, lawyers or advertising professionals. Where to find the right kind of gay psychotherapist. The addresses and hours of gay saunas. A gay insurance broker. Gay philosophers. Scores of gay religious services. A rundown of gay plumbers.
''People want to put their money back in the community,'' Mr. Becker said.
This is not a $1-a-minute ''party'' line, though people sometimes discuss intimate things in a more or less analytical fashion. In this time of plague, just 7 percent of the calls concern AIDS. Mr. Becker explained that life must go on and that gay people, like everybody else, have many concerns. ''We don't want to equate gay with AIDS,'' he said.
The scene was frenetic. As soon as a receiver was back in its cradle, the phone seemed to ring. Susan P., a volunteer who works for an executive search firm, picked it up. A lesbian asking about bars. Susan said New York has a couple of hundred gay bars for men, but just five or 10 regularly catering to gay women. She gave names, suggesting which might be best tonight.
Some anonymous callers allowed a reporter to listen in on an extra phone. Some didn't. Switchboard members - who thought this article might be useful to fund raising and to public understanding - stressed that the privacy of calls is fiercely protected.
The phone rang. A man said he had been in a gay relationship for 15 years but was so attracted to a man at work that he would give all that up in a second. He said he loved the man -though they hadn't had sex, only flirtations -and needed advice on how to get to the next step. ''Meaning?'' a volunteer asked.
''I mean committing a little bit,'' was the answer.
The issue remained unresolved, but the caller seemed thankful for the chance to chat for more than a half an hour. Somebody called asking about sadomasochistic support groups. Somebody hung up on Susan as soon as he heard a woman's voice. Somebody listened to descriptions of bars, then voiced interest in ''a Western leather kind of place.'' ''A Texan,'' a laughing Susan reported. A very articulate man called to say he had met a man of whom he was enamored and didn't want to ''scare him off.'' He had no problem discussing things with a woman.
''This isn't a very unusual situation,'' Susan said, trying to help the man talk through his volatile feelings without imposing any ideas. ''I was warned by my friend, 'He's shy; take it slow,' '' the man said.
''Ah,'' said Susan. ''The great variable, the other human being.''
The calls continued. Yes, you must wear a condom during oral sex. Yes, tell your friend we take calls from the deaf.
A man said he was ''used and abused'' because he was so good-looking. He then wandered around a bit, concluding: ''It's nice to have other people to talk to.'' (212) 777-1800.

HEADLINE: Would-Be Payers Fight New York Sales Tax Plan

BYLINE: By DEIRDRE CARMODY

 BODY:
The tentative agreement between Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and legislative leaders to extend the New York State sales tax to magazines and a number of service industries was attacked by representatives of those industries yesterday. They said that it would drive many businesses out of the state.
Taxing magazines while excluding newspapers is similar to attempts that have been found unconstitutional in other states, magazine executives said yesterday.
''This kind of selective taxation of the press has been considered and rejected by the United States Supreme Court in two recent cases,'' said Peter Diamandis, chairman of the Magazine Publishers of America, in a letter to Governor Cuomo. ''Both cases involved sales taxes, singling out particular kinds of publications for taxation, and the Court ruled that such discrimination violated the free press clause of the First Amendment.'' 
 
Dry Cleaners Affected
The tentative agreement would also extend New York's sales tax for the first time to services like custom computer programming, management consulting, public relations, 900 telephone numbers and cleaning services.
''You couldn't ask for a worse time to burden the small business, when dry cleaning sales have been running 15 percent to 20 percent below last year,'' said Bill Seitz, executive director of the Neighborhood Cleaners Association, a regional association with 2,000 of its members in New York State. ''You also have a very large ethnic population in the dry cleaning industry who are trying desperately to survive, and they don't really need any more negatives.''
Harold Burson of Burson-Marsteller, the Young & Rubicam subsidiary that is the largest public relations firm in the state, said in a letter to Governor Cuomo that more than half of the firm's annual income of $50 million was derived from clients outside New York State. ''The work performed for these clients can easily be shifted to other Burson-Marsteller offices or, at the worst, to other public relations firms not subject to a state sales tax,'' he wrote.
 
Constitutional Implications
Although groups affected by the proposed tax generally reacted to what it would mean for them economically, the magazine industry was also concerned with constitutional implications.
Legally, some 15 states now tax magazine sales but not newspaper sales - as New York is proposing to do. But in most states these laws are not enforced, according to the Magazine Publishers of America. Whenever a state has tried to collect a tax on magazine subscriptions in one of these states, magazine publishers have challenged the tax in court and won, the publishers group said. Challenges have occurred in Texas, Arkansas, Louisiana, Tennessee, Florida and Missouri.
In March, for instance, Time Warner and its magazine Southern Living challenged Tennessee's sales tax, which exempted newspapers but not magazines. Newsweek brought a similar suit on the same law. The Supreme Court of Tennessee unanimously declared that the Tennessee sales tax, applicable to magazines but not to newspapers, was unconstitutional.
 
Newspapers Taxed in 22 States
In 22 states both magazines and newspapers are taxed, the publishers group said. Generally speaking, courts have upheld taxes that affect both magazines and newspapers, if they are just a small part of a general product tax.
Asked about the constitutionality of the proposed tax, Gary Fryer, a spokesman for Governor Cuomo, said he could not comment on the proposal because there has yet to be a final agreement on the budget's contents.
It is unclear whether the proposed New York tax would affect subscriptions or newsstand sales or both.
John Paluszek, immediate past president of the Public Relations Society of America and president of Ketchum Public Affairs, said that the legislation was being ''designed behind closed doors'' and expressed fears that it would be passed before the affected groups could express their concern.
 
Public Relations Counter-Effort
The Public Relations Society of America said that public relations activities generated about $554 million of business in New York State.
Michael Henning, managing partner of the New York office of Ernst & Young, certified public accountants, called the proposed tax a ''disservice tax.'' He said, ''If Mr. Cuomo wants to go after the industry that has really raised the revenues for the State of New York, I think there is the possibility that he will lose as much revenue as he will gain, because people will decide that this isn't the place to be based, and they will move their operations elsewhere.''
Throughout the state yesterday, an effort was under way to derail the proposal, as public relations executives with all the expertise at their command took on a cause dear to their own.
''As you can imagine, we're trying to mobilize everybody,'' said Donald D. Kummerfeld, president of the Magazine Publishers of America. ''We've got the New York State wholesalers involved as well.''

CORRECTION-DATE: May 3, 1990, Thursday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about a proposed New York State sales tax referred incorrectly to an industry that would be affected. It is janitorial cleaning services, not dry cleaning.
