HEADLINE: THE WINE REGIONS: CHILE;
Land of Promise Seizes the Moment

SERIES: Future articles will discuss Argentina, Portugal and the Napa Valley of California.

BYLINE: By FRANK J. PRIAL

DATELINE: SANTIAGO, Chile

 BODY:
THE highway runs down from Santiago toward Punta Arenas and, yes, the South Pole, but we weren't going that far, my leathery-faced driver and I. We were turning right near San Fernando, about three hours south of the capital, and heading into the Colchagua Valley to Peralillo. It was the fourth day of a weeklong trip through what is probably the most exciting wine region in the world right now.
As a wine-making country, Chile has a lot - some might say everything - going for it: a near-perfect climate, low land costs and low production costs, a long wine-making tradition, the complete absence of phylloxera, the aphid that can be fatal to vines elsewhere, and South America's only stable, export-oriented economy.
Add the fact that the seasons are reversed; the finest wine makers and viticulturists in the Northern Hemisphere, who might not dream of taking on extra work in their own territories, are eager to fly to Chile after their own wine is made. They can do an entire vintage and be back north just in time for spring. 
For the last six years, Chile has been busy capitalizing on these assets in an effort to become one of the world's important wine producing nations. And so, as I headed south in a pickup truck last month with the vineyard foreman who'd been sent to fetch me, it was the beginning of autumn, with orchards of gold, red and rust apple trees stretching off toward the Andes in the east. Chile's best wine region occupies the temperate middle of this 2,880-mile-long country, a region extending from Aconcagua Province near Santiago, through Colchagua Province and south to the towns of Sagrada Familia, Lontue and Molina.
Our first stop had been the Errazuriz Panquehue winery (pronounced eh-RAH-zoo-riz pan-KAY-way), north of Santiago in the Aconcagua Valley, where Augustin Huneeus, a Chilean who is president of Franciscan Vineyards in California, has an important financial interest. Then came Concha y Toro, by far the largest wine company in Chile, with 10 different wineries and vineyards spread through hundreds of miles of the fertile valleys of central Chile.
Last on this brief list, the place we were heading, was Vina los Vascos - Vineyard of the Basques - which has attracted considerable attention among wine lovers because it is half-owned by the owners of Chateau Lafite-Rothschild in Bordeaux.
Errazuriz Panquehue was founded near the beginning of the 19th century by Don Maximiliano Errazuriz, one of the first growers to plant French vinifera vines in Chile. The winery and its vineyards are relatively far north and thus, since this is the Southern Hemisphere, in one of the warmer growing regions. Each afternoon, however, the wind from the sea snakes through the mountains to cool the vines.
Errazuriz Panquehue is under the day-to-day direction of Eduardo Chadwick, the 30-year-old president who is a direct descendant of Don Maximiliano. He and his equally young staff work closely with the team from Franciscan in the Napa Valley and, in fact, have produced a line of wines, Caliterra, specifically for the American market.
The Caliterra line includes a cabernet made from grapes grown in the Maipo Valley south of Santiago, and both a chardonnay and a sauvignon blanc from a cooler new region nearly 200 miles south in Curico. The principal gem in the Errazuriz Panquehue diadem is the Don Maximiliano cabernet, made from grapes from the home vineyard.
Concha y Toro, founded in 1883 by Don Melchor de Concha y Toro, today is controlled by the Guilisasti family with a considerable interest held by several American banks. Longtime wine enthusiasts will remember Concha y Toros from the 1950's and before when its fat little bottles of Chilean riesling sold in the United States for under $1. For most of its life, Concha y Toro has concentrated on inexpensive wine. Its production is impressive: a projected 45 million liters or 5 million cases in 1990, more than double its 1988 production.
Even so, as the mass market has begun to slow down in Chile and elsewhere in the world, the company has moved resolutely into fine wines, especially for export. Its showcase vineyards are at Pirque, 30 minutes southeast of Santiago, but there are other plantings all over central Chile, including some experimental vineyards hundreds of miles to the south in cooler regions.
While much of that acreage is planted in common varieties for cheap wine, Concha y Toro makes almost all of the classic Bordeaux varieties, plus chardonnay, gewurztraminer and riesling. Its best-known premium wine is a cabernet sauvignon called Casillero del Diablo. More than half of all exported Chilean wine comes from Concha y Toros.
Los Vascos is far smaller than Concha Y Toro but its history is much longer. The resident owners of Los Vascos are Jorge Eyzaguirre and his wife, Maria Ignacia Echenique, both of Basque ancestry. The Echenique family have grown fruit in the Colchagua area since 1755, but the Eyzaguirre family acquired what is now Los Vascos only in the mid-1970's when the Government of Gen. Augusto Pinochet divested itself of lands appropriated by the state in the Presidency of Salvador Allende Gossens, who was deposed in 1973.
Mr. Eyzaguirre realized that he had acquired a dilapidated, obsolete winery that would would require major investment and expertise to bring back into production. He found what he needed four years ago at Vinexpo, a wine exposition held every two years in Bordeaux.
Eric de Rothschild, who was managing Lafite-Rothschild for the family group, Domaines des Barons Rothschild, had acquired several chateaus in the Bordeaux region and was looking for other investments. He liked everything he saw and heard about Los Vascos's potential, and in 1988 bought 50 percent of the winery.
Since then, the winery has been transformed. The first of two new buildings is up, and new fermenters, new presses and, most important, new French oak barrels for aging the red wines, have been installed. Most of the work has been supervised by Gilbert Rokvin, Lafite's chief wine maker. Before going to Bordeaux, Mr. Rokvin spent almost 20 years making wine in Spain, so he speaks fluent Spanish to the workers.
Los Vascos's problems mirrored those of most other Chilean wineries six years ago, when the push for export markets began. They had operated in a highly regulated economy, protected from foreign competition and cut off from foreign investment and ideas. With few exceptions, the wines were mediocre, made in vast quantities to be sold at the very lowest prices. Even now, standard table wine sells in Santiago supermarkets for around 80 cents a liter in a brick-shaped box called a tetra-pak.
The conversion to high-quality wine has been rapid but not without pain. Some workers still resist more exacting standards and there are holdouts, even at high corporate levels, who see no reason why overseas customers should not adapt their tastes to traditional Chilean wine styles.
And in fact, not even the best of the current crop of Chilean wines are always free of some of the old faults. Most serious among those faults is overproduction: making too much wine from a given plot of vineyard. When quantity is paramount, it doesn't matter if the wine is light and bland and lacking in the characteristics of the grape. What sets the best wines apart from the others is their intensity: the amount of taste and character packed into each mouthful.
The Chileans recognize this, and the most recent vintages of the best wines show remarkable improvement. But don't expect to find the concentration of a fine Bordeaux or California wine in the older vintages. Some of them, yes; most of them, no. That should all change with many of the 1989's and even more so with the 1990 vintage, which with the reversal in seasons is already in barrels.
Small oak barrels - the standard 60-gallon aging barrel of France and California - is new to Chile. The older wines were aged in much larger casks - and aged and aged. Consequently, they taste oxydized to Americans. They taste oxydized to the Chileans, too, but they like them that way. Every winery is busily acquiring small oak barrels now and, in a few years oxydization should be a thing of the past.
White wines used to taste oxydized, too, but modern wine-making techniques, which keep the wine fresh and lively are now widely used.
This visit concentrated on three wineries, one with a strong degree of American influence, one with French, and the third, the country's largest, has had some French help, too: Emile Peynaud, the famous Bordeaux enologist was a consultant until he retired two years ago. While these three are among the outstanding Chilean wineries, they are hardly the only oustanding ones among Chile's hundreds of wineries.
 
Other Labels To Consider
CONCHA y TORO, Errazuriz Panquehue and Los Vascos don't have a lock on the best Chilean wines. Here are a few others to consider.
Among the cabernets are Santa Rita Medalla Real, 1986; Cousino Macul, Antiguas Reservas, 1986; Miguel Torres, 1987 Curico; Undurraga, 1987 Santa Ana, and Canepa 1987 Finissimo. Of the three featured wineries, look for Caliterra 1987, Maipo; Los Vascos 1987, and Concha y Toro's 1987 Private Reserve, Puenta Alto.
Sauvignon blanc may be Chile's best wine at the moment. The better versions have that leanness and touch of acidity that distinguishes the best sauvignon blancs in Europe and so often seems lacking in California versions of the wine. Some Chilean sauvignons are a bit dull but most are more than drinkable. Santa Rita's is excellent; Miguel Torres and Undurraga make delicious sauvignon blanc, as do Caliterra and Canepa.
Santa Rita's 1987 Reserva chardonnay is outstanding. The 1989's from Cousino Macul and Santa Carolina are worth seeking out as well.
That's the good news. The even better news is that the prices of these wines are all remarkably low. Most of them are $6 or less. But they will not remain that way. Nothing brings a glow to a Chilean wine maker's eyes quicker than the mention of higher prices. They'd all like to go to around $10, which is fine if the quality continues to increase as well. Stay tuned.

HEADLINE: F.D.A. Approves the Irradiation of Poultry

BYLINE: By MARIAN BURROS

 BODY:
THE Food and Drug Administration yesterday approved the irradiation of poultry to control salmonella and other bacteria that are responsible for an increase in food-borne illnesses in this country.
Most of the poultry industry, however, said it had no plans to use the technology because of strong consumer resistance to irradiated foods. Over the last 30 years, the F.D.A. has approved irradiation of fruits, vegetables, pork, wheat, and herbs and spices, but opposition has blocked the widespread use of the procedure.
As far as the agency knows, only small amounts of herbs and spices are being irradiated. New York, New Jersey and Maine have banned the sale of irradiated foods. 
The food and drug agency said the process, which does not make the food radioactive, would ''greatly reduce but does not eliminate all the bacteria'' in poultry. Irradiation is a process in which foods are exposed to gamma rays, X-rays or electron bombardment to kill insects, molds or bacteria that can lead to spoilage or disease. The F.D.A allows irradiation of up to 300,000 rads or 3 kiloGrays.
Foods that are to be irradiated are placed on a conveyor belt, which travels into a chamber protected by thick concrete walls. A radioactive source such as cobalt 60 or cesium 137, a waste product of the nuclear power industry, emits the radioactive rays.
As many as half of the chickens in this country may be contaminated with salmonella, which causes gastrointestinal illness, generally with mild flu-like symptoms. But among the elderly and those with compromised immune systems such as cancer patients and people with AIDS, salmonellosis can cause death. In 1987 there were 44,609 reported cases of salmonellosis, but the Centers for Disease Control say the actual number is more like 4.5 million.
In addition to salmonella, radiation could also be used to control camplylobacter jejuni, bacteria that cause 2 to 4 million cases a year of gastrointestinal illness.
Whether or not irradiated food is safe may be moot. The National Broiler Council and the Turkey Federation said today that they have no intention of irradiating their products. William Roenigk, an economist with the National Broiler Council, an association representing 90 percent of the companies that produce and process chicken in the United States, said the membership believed that the effort to convince the public that irradiated chicken is safe ''would be much too costly and time consuming because most people have made up their minds. They are not neutral about it.''
Mr. Roenigk added, ''Most consumers are not willing to make the tradeoff and they are aware that proper cooking will kill the salmonella and that seems to be a much better trade off than going to irradation.''
Stuart Proctor, the executive vice president of the Turkey Federation, which represents about 95 percent of the growers and processors, said that because of a lack of consumer acceptance, his members were not planning to irradiate their products. Approving irradiation for poultry ''is a step in the right direction,'' he said, ''but we are not going to go out and do a consumer education campaign.''
The approval of irradiation for poultry was sought by the United States Department of Agriculture, which regulates meat and poultry products, and Radiation Technology Inc. of Rockaway, N.J., a concern that irradiates food.
There are more than 1,200 scientific studies dealing with the safety of food irradiation, many of them hotly contested.
''As far as we are concerned, we found overwhelming evidence there was no safety concern,'' said Dr. Laura Tarantino, consumer safety officer of the agency's division of food and color additives.
But Dr. David C. Dodson, assistant clinical professor of medicine at Boston University, said the agency ''has not done the appropriate testing.''
''With food irradiation, you create new chemicals in the food, radiolytic products, and that is what should be tested,'' he said. A radiolytic product is a chemical that is potentially toxic. Some may be carcinogenic.
Dr. Dodson went on: ''There is vast literature which has shown adverse effects and an equal amount of literature that shows no harmful effects in animals. There is one published study on humans that was reported in the American Journal of Clinical Nutrition in 1985 which showed chromosomal damage'' from eating irradiated wheat.
In 1986 Richard Ronk, who was the deputy director of the F.D.A.'s Center for Food Safety and Applied Nutrition, said the agency would continue to permit low-level radiation of food without further animal studies because after interacting with the molecules in food, ''energy from low-level radiation is not capable of forming radiolytic products, which might be carcinogenic.''
Dr. Ronk added, ''There is no way to test the effects of irradiated foods in animal systems.''

HEADLINE: Personal Ecology

 BODY:
To The Living Section:
Regarding ''How Do You Fix a Broken Planet?'' by Dena Kleiman [April 25]: Many of us who grew up during the Depression practiced conservation for reasons of economy. Here are some of the unwritten rules at our house in the 30's:
* Turn off lights that are not in use. 
* Shampoo hair once a week.
* Wear clothes until soiled.
* Use napkin until soiled, keeping in napkin ring.
* Use hot water sparingly (a hot tub means three or four inches of bath water).
* Mend clothes; darn socks.
* Use paper cups, plates and napkins only for picnics.
While these measures seem drastic, perhaps they can be adopted in modified form. We would do well to heed the old New England wisdom:
Use it up, wear it out, Make it do, do without.
 
MARY ANN HYDE
Weston, Conn.

HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook;
In Philadelphia, 3 Arts Centers, 2 or One?

BYLINE: By PAUL GOLDBERGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA

 BODY:
For the last half-century, Philadelphia has had only one major downtown performing-arts center, the venerable Academy of Music, but now the city is struggling over the fate of two others.
The first is a new hall planned for the Philadelphia Orchestra that is designed by Robert Venturi, a Philadelphian who is one of the world's most celebrated architects. The second is the old Metropolitan Opera House, a crumbling wreck of a theater in north central Philadelphia, which a local foundation wants to restore as the centerpiece of a major urban-renewal project.
While proponents of both projects insist that the two halls have nothing to do with each other and say publicly that they are fully in favor of both projects moving ahead, they express private doubts that the city will have the economic means to make both happen.
Although the halls would not be directly competitive - the orchestra hall would replace the 134-year-old Academy of Music as the setting for the Philadelphia Orchestra's concerts, while the restored opera house would mainly be used for popular music and touring shows - each project would cost upward of $100 million, a considerable amount of money for an old city that has traditionally turned up its nose at the splashy big-money spending on the arts characteristic of many newer cities. 
Behind the question of whether Philadelphia will build the Venturi building, restore the old opera house, do both or do neither, is a tale of cultural politics intertwined with architecture and urban sociology.
Each project has been promoted as providing a unique mix of urban elements offering the city not only cultural benefits, but social and economic ones as well. The new orchestra hall holds out the allure not only of an improved building for the city's most cherished cultural institution, the Philadelphia Orchestra, but also of the possibility of giving Philadelphia its first major public building by its greatest living architect.
While perhaps Philadelphia's most beloved cultural entity, the Academy of Music was originally built as an opera house, and it has never been considered ideal for symphonic concerts. But since the new hall would be diagonally across the street from the Academy of Music, which would remain as a secondary hall, and would be close to the Shubert Theater and a planned new repertory theater, the orchestra has promoted the project as the centerpiece of a new Avenue of the Arts, which would concentrate cultural activity on South Broad Street.
But the likelihood that the hall will be built anytime soon is slim, given a lackluster fund-raising campaign, which after several years has yielded only $19 million, a tiny fraction of its $110 million goal. The effort to build the hall is expected to be further crippled by the recent decision of Riccardo Muti, the orchestra's popular conductor, to return to Italy after the 1991-92 season.
A restored Metropolitan Opera House offers the city something quite different: not significant new architecture, but the prospect of bringing a palatial, landmark-quality theater back to life as a dramatic centerpiece for a renewed north central Philadelphia, a neighborhood now ridden with drugs and crime.
The proposal to restore the 3,400-seat opera house, which was built by Oscar Hammerstein in 1908 but has been used over the years for everything from gospel services to boxing and is now almost completely abandoned, envisions the huge old building as the anchor of a broader effort to build housing and new commercial buildings amid the dilapidation of the area.
The effort is at least as much of a long shot as the new orchestra hall, not only because the old opera house is in appalling condition - its elaborate plaster ornamentation is largely ruined, and much of the orchestra pit was filled in with concrete years ago - but because it would also require the cooperation of a daunting coalition of government officials, private developers, community leaders and the major foundation that has expressed interest in acting as a catalyst.
Officially, no one in Philadelphia sees the two projects as an either-or proposition. But the new orchestra hall has been estimated to cost $110 million, with construction costs rising continually. Restoring the old opera house and providing community improvements along with it would cost at least $100 million. While it is possible that money could be found for both in the next couple of years, it is unlikely.
Complicating the political situation is the role of Philadelphia's largest foundation, and one of the wealthiest in the country, the Pew Charitable Trust. The Pew Trust is the instigator of the Metropolitan Opera House project; it has acquired an option to buy the property and it has also hired economic development, architectural and theater-management consultants to study the opera-house project.
Its board has said it would put $20 million into the project if the right combination of Federal and state funds and private investments could be found to assure that the project would move ahead.
The $20 million figure rankles the Philadelphia Orchestra since that is precisely the amount the Pew Trust informally pledged to the orchestra's building project several years ago, when the planning for the Venturi hall began. Since then, the foundation, traditionally Philadelphia's charitable leader, has shifted its priorities from old-line Philadelphia philanthropies to seek innovative projects with major social impact.
The director of the Pew Trust, Rebecca Rimel, has a particular interest in inner-city problems, and she and her colleagues saw the opera-house project as a means of showing the foundation's commitment to creative ideas in philanthropy and to helping its home city at the same time.
 
The Complications Of Finding Money
The trust has made only a token grant to the orchestra project, although its board has said it will consider a larger grant later. But the foundation has told the orchestra not to rely on it as the core of its fund-raising effort. And some people close to the foundation have expressed irritation with the orchestra's expectation that it could rely on traditional charitable sources to pay for its new building, and have urged that it be more aggressive in building bridges to other potential donors.
The Pew Trust's reluctance to play a major role in financing the new hall has in turn affected other gifts, since the trust, which has total assets of roughly $3.2 billion spread out over several related foundations, has generally set the pace for philanthropic giving in Philadelphia. So far, the orchestra has found no other donor willing to come forth with the major gift necessary to assure that the building will go ahead. And the $19 million it has raised is far short of the $50 million it says it must have in hand before it can start construction on the Venturi building.
Architectural issues are far from the fore here, but they are not irrelevant, either. For the Venturi design, if it does get built, holds the potential of being a civic building of some consequence. As with much of Mr. Venturi's work, it is best described as a modern building based on old-fashioned models: a building that attempts to combine the thin, flat forms of modernism with traditional, decorative imagery.
The best thing about the overall form is the way in which Mr. Venturi has managed to shape a building that manages to have a strong and traditional presence on the street and at the same time to defer to the demands of the automobile.
The hall would appear from South Broad Street to be a large, formal and nearly symmetrical palazzo, with big windows facing the street; on the side, the mass of the building would be slightly scooped out to permit a large automobile approach and a second entrance. So this is a truly urban building, but one that acknowledges the reality of life at the end of the 20th century, in its very shape celebrating the pedestrian-oriented cityscape and yet symbolizing the way in which it is forced to accommodate the needs of the automobile.
The facade of the new orchestra hall is a bit flatter than it might be, hardly sleek but more blunt and plain than so important a civic building probably should be on South Broad Street. The interior of the 2,700-seat hall, to the extent that its designs - which are still developing - are any guide, is inventively decorative, with intricately patterned balcony fronts joining to create an overall geometric pattern.
Russell Johnson, the acoustical consultant who worked with I. M. Pei on the design of the recently completed Meyerson Symphony Center in Dallas, is working with Mr. Venturi here. As in Dallas, Mr. Johnson has led the architect to a long, narrow auditorium, with lots of architectural detail and few flat surfaces. If some of the ornamental themes of this auditorium could make their way onto the too-blunt facade, the hall would be a much stronger building.
The Metropolitan Opera House is neither as gracious a jewel box as the old Academy of Music nor as intriguing an architectural possibility as the new orchestra hall. As a building, it more resembles the great movie palaces, though it predates them; it is vast, a quirky combination of the ornate and the barnlike. Its acoustics, however, are said to be superb, and for some years it was used by the Philadelphia Orchestra as a recording studio.
 
Beneath It All, A Commitment
Can the two projects be combined and the opera-house project made the orchestra's new home? Neither side likes that alternative. The orchestra, cognizant of the slow speed with which Philadelphians give up their sentimental attachments, made a point of saying it wanted to stay close to the old Academy of Music on South Broad Street. Orchestra spokesmen say the orchestra's patrons do not want to go to the neighborhood of the old opera house on North Broad Street.
The Pew Trust dislikes a combination because its consultants warned against letting the restored opera house be the home of a nonprofit company. In their study on the viability of the opera-house project, the consultants told the trust that the hall's financial success depends on its being booked with profit-making musical events.
What ties the thinking underlying both projects together, however, is the commitment of both sponsors to downtown Philadelphia, and to the idea that a major arts building can become a kind of symbolic base on which other kinds of community improvements can be built. While the Venturi orchestra project offers much greater architectural potential, the old opera-house restoration is a much more innovative piece of urban planning. The unfortunate thing is that Philadelphia may have to choose between them.

HEADLINE: Purchasers' Economic Index Rises

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
After an 11-month decline, the nation's manufacturing economy expanded in April, stimulated by strong levels of new orders, particularly from foreign customers, the nation's purchasing managers reported yesterday.
The National Association of Purchasing Management said that its index of economic activity rose to 50.2 percent in April from 48.8 percent in March. The index is at its highest level since April 1989.
A reading below 50 percent indicates that the manufacturing sector of the economy is in a decline, while a reading above 50 percent indicates an expansion. A reading below 44 percent indicates a decline in real gross national product. 
Analysts said that the figures suggested the economy was beginning to rebound following a lackluster fourth quarter. However, some cautioned that it was too soon to tell whether the expansion would be sustained through the rest of the year.
''This indicated that the economy is growing at a rate of about 2 percent in real gross national product,'' said Wayne C. Stevens, chief economist with Duff & Phelps Inc. ''To run above that level, you need a stimulus, like lower taxes or lower interest rates. It's too soon to tell whether the economy will continue to grow beyond that level.''
 
Report Is Hailed by Analysts
Still, many analysts hailed the purchasing managers' report as a harbinger of more robust economic growth for the remainder of the year. ''The figures are very positive, because they show that the economy is leaving the danger zone of recession and embarking on a path of moderate growth,'' said Lawrence A. Kudlow, chief economist at Bear, Stearns & Company.
Mr. Kudlow added that the reports earlier this week on higher levels of new orders for machine tools offered further evidence that the economy was entering a period of expansion and that capital spending was increasing. ''These figures tell us that the United States economy is far more resilient than its critics have suggested,'' he said.
The purchasing managers' report is considered an important economic indicator because it is compiled from information supplied by managers from a range of industrial companies throughout the country.
The report showed that the index for new orders for export rose one percentage point, to its highest level since September of last year. It climbed to 60.5 percent in April from 59.5 percent in March.
The level of new orders generally increased in April, the report said, with the index for new orders rising to 55.5 percent in April from 50.4 percent in March. Analysts said that the increase in export orders contributed significantly to that increase.
At the same time, the level of imports remained essentially unchanged in April, with the import index holding at 50.5 percent. ''This apparent stabilization in growth of imports coupled with the increasing growth in exports bodes well for the continued decline in the United States trade deficit,'' the report said.
Production in April expanded, although at a slower pace than in March. The production index dropped to 53 percent in April from 54.4 percent in March, the report said. The report said that it was unlikely that production would decline in the rest of the second quarter because of the surge in new orders in April.
The purchasing managers also reported that prices increased in April. Their price index rose to 50.8 percent, from 48.2 percent in March. The managers surveyed said 17 commodities had risen in price, up from 11 in March. Those items included a number of metals - aluminum, copper, nickel and zinc - as well as several chemical products like methanol, Freon and polypropylene.
The employment index slipped slightly in April, to 45.1 percent, from 45.2 percent in March. Some members continued to report hiring temporary workers and working overtime to handle inreasing production activity, rather than hiring new employees.

SECTION: Section D; Page 2, Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 789 words

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Capital Squeeze: Guess Who Pays

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
IT has never been much fun at the bottom of the third world's economic pecking order, and for millions in Latin America, Africa and the backwaters of Asia, it is grimmer than ever. Cut off by private lenders in the 1980's, most poor countries have been forced to make ends meet without much help from the industrialized economies. The flow of capital actually reversed direction in the last decade, with rich countries reabsorbing $20 billion to $40 billion in resources each year from their impoverished neighbors.
For the relatively affluent debtors like Brazil and Mexico, the resulting squeeze on imports has increased social friction and delayed a likely leap into modernity. For many others it has meant a cut in living standards for people who were already obliged to make every calorie count. 
Since the mid-1980's liberal advocates have been pressing the case for a better deal for the debtors. Now there is a freshly issued report on the global dimensions of the capital scarcity problem, complete with an estimate of how much it would cost to jump-start growth in 40 low-income nations.
The analysis, which was sponsored by the United Nations' World Institute for Development Economics and written by Lance Taylor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, is in one sense upbeat: A mere $40 billion in capital each year, just one-third of 1 percent of the affluent world's income, could raise annual growth rates in poor countries by more than one percentage point.
The catch, however, is that the $40 billion would almost certainly have to come from American savers, who do not seem to be in a particularly thrifty mood these days. What is more, it comes when competing demands for capital - for rebuilding Eastern Europe and for environmental cleanups, among other needs - are on the rise.
Most poor countries cushioned the oil shocks of the 1970's with money borrowed from Western banks. The world recession of the early 1980's savaged the markets for their raw-material exports, forcing them to borrow more merely to stay in place. And high interest rates, driven by America's newly whetted appetite for foreign capital, made it more difficult to service their foreign borrowings.
When the dust settled, most poor countries were hopelessly in debt, and capital from foreign banks had dried up. Indeed, the tight supply of funds to meet foreign obligations was made even tighter by domestic capital flight: The middle and upper classes of Latin America, no fools, had stashed as much as they could manage in banks from Miami to Milan.
This reversal of capital flows typically added up to about 5 percent of national income. But the impact on output, Mr. Taylor notes, was often two or three times as great because the ability to use existing economic capacity was sharply reduced by the scarcity of imports. Farmers in the Philippines, for example, might be forced to cut grain production by $1 million for want of imported fertilizer costing $100,000.
Separate econometric models, constructed for individual countries by the U.N. consultants, made it possible to measure the cost of the capital squeeze. Mr. Taylor then used the equations to calculate the amount of cash it would take to undo the damage.
A $40 billion annual fix, he estimates, would go a long way, unclogging a lot of bottlenecks, allowing a lot of capital already in place to operate more efficiently. Such a fix, one might think, would hardly be beyond the means of lending countries with combined incomes of some $12 trillion a year.
But as Jeffrey Sachs of Harvard and Warwick McKibbin of the Brookings Institution have argued, the macroeconomic effects of the transfer could wash out part of the benefits absent a corresponding cut in consumption or investment in developed countries. Without a little belt-tightening north of the Equator, interest rates might actually rise enough (or third world export prices fall enough) to send the debtors back to square one.
West Germany and Japan already do most of the savings for the industrialized nations, and they are not about to save more. And America, which now absorbs most of those savings to cover its trade deficit, does not seem inclined to change its profligate ways. Even if the rich countries chose to make the effort, it seems likely that any extra capital freed in the process would end up in, say, new auto plants in Budapest or in new flue-gas scrubbers for power plants in Illinois.
In the global economy, it has often been argued, no nation is an island: Poverty is everyone's problem because the fate of the winners is inextricably linked to the fate of the losers.
Maybe. But for the moment the rich nations are doing a pretty good job of ignoring the linkages.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Ex-Merrill Executive To Head Reuters Unit

BYLINE: By Daniel F. Cuff

 BODY:
Michael O. Sanderson, a former chief of Merrill Lynch-Canada, has been named president and chief executive of the Instinet Corporation, an electronic equities trading operation owned by Reuters Holdings P.L.C. of London.
Mr. Sanderson, 47, succeeds Robert H. Reid, 61, who has managed Instinet since 1988. Mr. Reid will remain as executive vice presdient, reporting to Mr. Sanderson, who in turn reports to John S. Hull, executive vice president of Reuters America Inc., Reuters provides news and financial information worldwide. 
The screen-to-screen trading system was purchased by Reuters in 1987 and became profitable for the first time in 1989. Under Mr. Reid, Reuters said, Instinet's annual shares-traded volume increased 78 percent, to 2.56 billion shares at the end of 1989 from 1.44 billion shares at the end of 1987.
''Electronic equity transactions continue to grow in the marketplace in North America and other equity centers around the world,'' Mr. Sanderson said. The company, which now trades in United States and British stocks, plans to expand in Europe and elsewhere, he added.
Mr. Sanderson plans to travel extensively from his New York base to sell the system. ''I plan to cover the world,'' he said, ''with a very extensive customer calling program.''
After graduating from Brown University, Mr. Sanderson did his graduate work in politics, philosophy and economics at Oxford. He joined Merrill Lynch in London as an investment executive in 1967.
After a series of moves and promotions, Mr. Sanderson went to Toronto in 1984 to become president and chief operating officer of Merrill Lynch-Canada. He was named chief executive two years later.

HEADLINE: Dow Surprises Some by Rising 12.16 Points

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stock prices rose yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average gaining 12.16 points, to 2,668.92.
The gain came despite some expectation among traders that prices would fall after figures from the National Association of Purchasing Management showed that the manufacturing economy was expanding. That situation can be bad for the stock and bond markets because it suggests that interest rates may be increased to curb inflation. Bond prices did decline on the day. 
Volume on the Big Board, however, while relatively light because of a holiday in much of Western Europe, rose to 149 million shares, from 122.8 million Monday. Advances outnumbered declines by 820 to 679.
''The stock market's up despite the fact that bonds are down,'' said Hildegard Zagorski, market analyst for Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. ''Maybe there's some perception that interest rates have peaked.''
 
Index Up to 50.2%
Stock prices would normally decline in the wake of a report like yesterday's from the purchasing group. Its manufacturing index rose to 50.2 percent in April - enough to strengthen investor sentiment that the Federal Reserve might raise interest rates soon to cool off the economy.
After the close, Robert T. Parry, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, said he expected the nation's real interest rates to remain high.
''Stocks sold off for a while'' when the inflation figures came out, said Robert G. Freedman, chief portfolio manager for John Hancock Advisers. But then, he said, the market ''didn't pay any attention to the figures.''
''Maybe we're getting to the point where we can move up,'' he argued. ''But I don't see any tremendous rally.''
Expressing more a hope than a conviction, the John Hancock executive said, ''Maybe we can get to 2,700'' on the Dow, ''and if we get there, maybe we can get a little higher.''
 
Active Boeing Trading
The solid market standout, particularly among the blue chips, was Boeing, the Seattle-based aircraft company, which jumped 2 1/2, to 72 1/4, with 1.49 million shares changing hands. It was the Big Board's eighth-most-active stock.
The company said on Monday that because of an accounting change, its first-quarter profits fell by 34.2 percent, but that without the change, its profits would have jumped by 87 percent. The company also raised its dividend to 37.5 cents a share, from 30 cents and announced a 3-for-2 stock split. Analysts subsequently beefed up their recommendations of the stock.
In another strong move, Tosco, the oil company, plunged 5 1/4, to 17 1/4, after it said it had abandoned plans to sell the company or its refinery operations because of unsatifactory offers. The company, based in Santa Monica, Calif., also reported on Monday that it had lost $6.9 million in its first quarter, down from a loss of $8.03 million in the comparable period a year earlier. Tosco was the Big Board's third-most-active issue, with 2.4 million shares changing hands.
Chrysler rose 3/4, to 15 1/4, on 1.1 million shares, after reporting better-than-expected results for the first quarter. Many analysts forecast a loss, but Chrysler showed a profit of $71 million, against $351 million a year earlier.
 
American General Up
American General, the insurer, rose 1 1/8, to 40 1/8. Analysts voiced optimism that Torchmark, another insurer, could win a proxy vote scheduled for today to install its team and take over the Houston-based company. A Federal court in Nashville yesterday granted Torchmark a temporary order that prevents Tennessee insurance officials from blocking the battle.
MGM/UA, which Pathe Communications has agreed to buy for $20 a share, or $1.2 billion, fell 1 1/8, to 17 1/2, after it gave only vague details about the financing. It said on Monday that it had access to the last $450 million it needed, but gave scant information on how it would raise the money.
Unocal, the oil company, rose 7/8, to 29 1/8, in heavy trading, although it reported on Monday that its first-quarter profits fell by 11.5 percent. Richard J. Stegemeier, the chairman, told stockholders at the its annual meeting that he expected demand for natural gas - and prices - to rise steadily over the long term.
 
Slight Changes in Blue Chips
Most other blue-chip industrial stocks changed only slightly, except for I.B.M., which fell a point, to 108, in heavy trading; Texaco, which rose a point, to 58 5/8, and Procter & Gamble, which also rose a point, to 71 5/8.
The Dow transportation index advanced 6.93 points, to 1,136.91, with Airborne Freight up 1 5/8, to 42 3/8; UAL up 1 1/2, to 153 1/4, and Federal Express up a point, to 55 3/4.
Oracle, the computer company, topped the over-the-counter active list, falling 1 1/8, to 14 3/4, on 2.7 million shares. Hilton Hotels, an occasional takeover stock, rose 3 1/8, to 49 1/2, in strong trading.
Among the indexes, the Standard & Poor's 500 rose 1.45, to 332.25; the Nasdaq composite was up 1.78, to 421.85, and the Amex market-value gained 0.22, to 343.32.

HEADLINE: Fed Official On Inflation

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: BOCA RATON, Fla., May 1

 BODY:
A Federal Reserve governor, John P. LaWare, said today that the nation's high inflation rate in the first quarter might have been an aberration.
''Food, energy and apparel had up-blips and shouldn't continue,'' Mr. LaWare said in an interview at a meeting here of the Bankers Association for Foreign Trade. ''The labor cost increase was a little worrisome.''
The Government previously reported that consumer prices rose five-tenths of a percent in March, which translated to an 8.5 percent gain in the first quarter.
Mr. LaWare said he hoped inflation would be almost unchanged in 1990, ''but the signals are mixed.'' Last year, consumer prices rose 4.6 percent, after a 4.4 percent gain in 1988.
A report by the Commerce Department showed that the economy grew at an annual rate of 2.1 percent in the first quarter. ''I think we will see a continuation of slow, steady growth,'' Mr. LaWare said. ''I think this slow, steady growth is very healthy under the circumstances.''

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Mixed in Light Day; Gold Prices Mostly Higher

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended mixed yesterday in light trading as many European markets were closed for the May Day holiday. Gold prices rose.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for May delivery settled at $370 a troy ounce, up $1.60 from late Monday. The Republic National Bank of New York also quoted a late bid for gold at $370 an ounce, up $1.30. 
The dollar gained after the release of the monthly index figure from the National Association of Purchasing Management, which indicated the United States industrial sector expanded slightly in April for the first time in 11 months.
News of an upturn in economic activity is good for the dollar since it makes it more likely that interest rates will rise. Higher interest rates make the dollar more valuable relative to other currencies.
 
Gains Given Up
But the dollar was not able to sustain its gains yesterday and soon gave them up, Bob Morrissey, a trader with the Bank of Boston, said.
Many European markets were closed for May Day, and trading in the United States was thin, he said.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell to 158.90 Japanese yen, from 159.08 yen on Friday. Japanese markets were closed Monday for a holiday. Later yesterday, in London, the dollar fell to 158.80 yen. In New York, the dollar bought 158.85 yen, down from 158.90 late Monday.
In London, the dollar rose against the British pound. It cost $1.6385 to buy one pound, cheaper than $1.6390 late Monday. In New York, the dollar lost ground, with the pound trading at $1.6445, more expensive than $1.6405 late Monday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday quotes, included: 1.6805 West German marks, up from 1.6795; 1.4555 Swiss francs, up from 1.4530; 5.6370 French francs, up from 5.6330; 1,231.75 Italian lire, up from 1,230.50, and 1.1646 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1644.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Monday rates, included: 1.6785 West German marks, down from 1.6787; 1.4562 Swiss francs, up from 1.4512; 5.6450 French francs, up from 5.6335; 1.8927 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8884; 1,232.50 Italian lire, up from 1,230.50, and 1.1645 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1649.
Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $368.50 a troy ounce, up from $367.75 bid late Monday. Zurich gold markets were closed for the holiday. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold fell $1.72 to close at a bid of $370.83 an ounce.

HEADLINE: Outlook for G.O.P.: Senate Gains in '90, A Showdown in '92

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 2

 BODY:
As Senate races shape up around the country, officials in both parties say Republicans are bucking the usual trend in midterm elections: they are in good position to pick up several seats this fall and narrow the gap with Democrats.
Some Republicans are even hoping and some Democrats are worrying that Republicans have a chance to retake the Senate, where Democrats hold 55 seats to the Republicans' 45. But most analysts predict a gain of two or three seats by Republicans this year, with the showdown for control coming in 1992.
''It is possible we can get a majority of Republicans back in the Senate this year,'' Vice President Dan Quayle told a group of Republican state chairmen the other day. ''The Democrats are talking about holding down their losses. If we don't get a majority, perhaps we can get a 50-50 split. And I wouldn't mind spending the next two years of my life casting every tie-breaking vote for President Bush.'' 
Less partisan analysts predict less sweeping, but still important, changes. Two well-known monitors of Congressional races, Charles E. Cook Jr. and Stewart Rothenberg, each of whom edits a political newsletter, both predict Republican gains in the Senate of one to four seats, in large part because of the party's unusually successful recruiting of strong candidates.
Such gains could have an important impact on the Senate, where Senator George J. Mitchell, the Democratic leader, already has to operate with a margin that is less than overwhelming.
The most vulnerable Democratic Senators, politicians generally believe, are Claiborne Pell of Rhode Island, the chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, Paul Simon of Illinois, Tom Harkin of Iowa, Carl Levin of Michigan and Jim Exon of Nebraska.
 
White House Looks to Hawaii
In addition, the death of Spark M. Matsunaga, Democratic Senator from Hawaii, last month has created another opportunity for Republicans. One of the state's most popular Republicans, Representative Patricia Saiki of Honolulu, is expected to run for the seat this fall and is given a good chance, despite the state's Democratic leanings. Representative Daniel K. Akaka has been named the interim Senator and is expected to be the party's candidate this fall to serve the full four years remaining in Mr. Matsunaga's term.
To emphasize the importance the Republican Party places on the push for the Senate, President Bush invited Ms. Saiki to the White House this afternoon, urged her to run and promised to help.
Democrats concede that they are on the defensive and that their goal now is simply to hold their current majority. They insist there are several states where Republicans are vulnerable, although independent analysts say that so far none seems as threatened as the Democrats.
The three Republicans most often cited as vulnerable are Jesse Helms of North Carolina, Mitch McConnell of Kentucky and Larry Pressler of South Dakota. The Democrats, still locked in primary fights, have yet to pick their candidates in Kentucky and North Carolina.
 
Attention on North Carolina
But national attention is already focusing on North Carolina. Well-known artists, including Roy Lichtenstein and Robert Rauschenberg, have contributed to a Democratic contender, Michael Easley, a county district attorney, hoping he will be the best challenger to Mr. Helms, who has sponsored legislation to bar Federal support for works deemed to be obscene.
In South Dakota, Ted Muenster is challenging Mr. Pressler, who is best known in Washington for voting against President Bush more than any other Republican senator. Democrats say that in a year when an anti-Washington mood is rife, Mr. Muenster, a businessman and an aide to a former governor, is an ideal candidate.
No great national issue has caused the Democratic vulnerability. President Bush's popularity is of some modest help to Republican candidates, politicians say, and the improved farm economy is making it easier for Republicans in places like Iowa and Illinois, two of this year's battlegrounds.
But many of this year's main topics - abortion, the environment and the peace dividend - tend to give an advantage to Democrats.
 
Good Recruiting by Republicans
Instead of using issues, the Republicans have achieved their advantage this year largely through a mundane but crucial bit of politics: They have done a better job of recruiting Republican candidates to challenge Democratic incumbents than the Democrats have done at finding candidates to challenge Republican incumbents.
''We've probably had our best recruiting season ever for these midterm elections,'' said Wendy deMocker, communications director for the National Republican Senatorial Committee, which raises money for and provides services and advice to Republican Senate candidates.
Republican Party officials persuaded eight members of the House to give up their seats and run for the Senate. Democrats see an irony in this: the Republican failure to dislodge Democrats from control of the House has left many Republican members so frustrated that they are willing to walk away from a safe House seat for a shot at a Senate seat.
''Republican members of the House do not have a lot to lose by running for the U.S. Senate,'' said Anita Dunn, communications director for the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee. ''They have no power in the House and no future. If they actually felt Republicans would regain control any time in their lifetime it would have been worth staying.''
Moreover, with a Republican Administration, Ms. Dunn said, Republicans can be confident that the White House will find them a job if they lose.
 
Abortion Rights Republicans
In Iowa, Illinois and Rhode Island, Republican members of the House are challenging incumbent Democratic Senators. In Michigan, Representative Bill Schuette is favored to win the Republican nomination to challenge Senator Levin. In Colorado and Idaho Republican House members are running for seats left vacant by the retirement of Republican Senators, increasing the party's chances of holding those seats.
One important change has occurred in the type of candidate recruited by the Republicans - women who support legal abortion. This description applies to Ms. Saiki in Hawaii and to the Republican candidates for the Senate in Rhode Island, Representative Claudine Schneider, and in Illinois, Representative Lynn Martin.
By contrast not a single Democrat in the House is seeking a Senate seat this year. In both Indiana and Oregon, members of the House delegations, including Representatives Lee H. Hamilton of Indiana and Ron Wyden of Oregon, resisted pleas from their party that they challenge the Republican Senators, Mark O. Hatfield of Oregon and Daniel R. Coats of Indiana.
''Democratic congressman were in a position where they felt they had established some strength in the House,'' said Ms. Dunn. ''They did not feel like leaving that for a risky Senate race.''
A number of prominent Democrats outside the House also declined entreaties to seek Senate seats. Former Gov. Gerald Baliles of Virginia declined to challenge Senator John W. Warner and former Vice President Walter Mondale turned down requests that he challenge Minnesota Senator Rudy Boschwitz.
So even though there are actually more Republican-held seats up for election this year, 18 as against 16 Democratic-held seats, more Democrats than Republicans face tough races.
Senator John B. Breaux of Louisiana, chairman of the Senate Democratic Campaign Committee, said that Republicans may be overrating the value of recruiting so many House members. ''In a period when I detect a lot of anti-Washington sentiment, I don't think it's a help being from Washington. They can't make a good case in this atmopshere that it's time to get new blood in Washington. They're just getting new blood from the other side of the dome.''
So while his contenders are not as well known as some Republican candidates, Mr. Breaux said, they are in better position to wage an outsider-style campaign.
There has been a virtually ironclad rule that the President's party loses ground in the House in midterm elections. It has been broken only once since the Civil War, in the Depression year of 1934. In the smaller electoral world of the Senate, the pattern is not as predictable. But on average, said Ms. deMocker of the Republican Senatorial Campaign Committee, the party in control of the White House has lost 3.7 Senate seats in midterm elections.

HEADLINE: U.S. SEEKS TO EASE TECHNOLOGY SALES IN EASTERN EUROPE

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 2

 BODY:
The Bush Administration today proposed a relaxation of restrictions on the export of advanced technological products to the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe, including computers, precision machine tools and telecommunications equipment.
As cold war tensions ease, America's allies have sought more liberal trading rules, and the business community has expressed concern that what it considers excessive control of exports is denying markets to the United States. The change was opposed by conservatives in the Pentagon.
The White House press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater, said the idea was to ''build higher fences around fewer goods.'' 
 
Seeking Allies' Approval
The proposals, which have been considered by an interagency group since early this year, are to be submitted in Paris on June 7-8 to a high-level meeting of the Coordinating Committee on Multilateral Export Controls, or Cocom, an adjunct of NATO formed 41 years ago to keep militarily sensitive technology out of Soviet hands. Debate is expected over whether the Administration plan goes far enough.
While the reaction from American business was generally favorable, many executives said the moves, which could expand exports by hundreds of millions of dollars, were inadequate. Similar views were expressed in Congress.
Some Congressional aides saw more than just a coincidence in the fact that today's announcement came just a day before the House Foreign Affairs Committee is scheduled to draft legislation that would mandate even greater liberalization of export controls than the Administration now contemplates.
''The proposal is better than what we've seen before, but falls short in areas critical to the United States,'' said Representative Sam Gejdenson, Democrat of Connnecticut, who is chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Subcommittee on International Economic Policy and Trade, which is initiating that legislation.
Under the Administration proposal, restrictions would be eliminated on 30 of the 120 categories of products now on the export-control list and there would be a partial lifting of the controls in 13 categories.
The plan would treat exports destined for Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union differently.
Virtually all personal computers used in office automation, word processing and light industry would be decontrolled. In addition, computers used in banking, travel reservations and publishing would get favoravble consideration for export to four Eastern European countries that have begun moves toward democratic reform: East Germany, Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia.
The European allies of the United States are expected to push for even more liberalization. As Germany nears unification, some Europen officials see Cocom as an anomaly. Cocom has 17 member nations - all the countries in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization except for Iceland, plus Japan and Australia.
No one has been more outspoken about the export restrictions than the Foreign Minister of West Germany, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, who said in a speech last week, ''The Cocom wall through Europe must be dismantled.''
A spokesman for the West German Embassy here, Hans-Henning Horstmann, declined to speculate on whether the June talks might be heated, confining his reaction to saying, ''We welcome every step that facilitates the transfer of technology to Eastern and Central Europe.''
On the other hand, there are American conservatives both in and out of Congress who want the restrictions kept. They said they were distressed that the move to make advanced technology available to the Soviet Union has come at a time of tensions over Lithuanian independence.
The Center for Security Policy, a Washington-based policy research institute, expressed its ''disbelief'' that the Administration had ''rewarded Moscow for its economic crackdown'' on Lithuania.
The institute said this was the second such move recently. Last week the Administration announced that it was near concluding a trade agreeement with Moscow that would lead to sharply lower American tariffs on imports from the Soviet Union.
 
The Administration's View
Mr. Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said the timing was related to ''the status of events in Eastern Europe, the changes we see in the Soviet Union, the changes in Allied attitudes towards sales, changes in our assessment done by the Defense Department and others.''
''Timing is dictated by the process itself and its impact,'' he said.
Although Defense Secretary Dick Cheney went along with the proposal, officials said that strong opposition had come from the Pentagon's Defense Technology Security Administration, which plays a major role in export-license approvals.
Asked about these divisions today, Mr. Fitzwater said the Defense Department had done the basic analysis and had joined other security agencies in a ''unanimous'' recommendation to the President. Officials said the deliberations were the most exhaustive and comprehensive export-control review ever.
Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher termed it a ''quantum leap'' from earlier positions. He said in an interview that the United States would now be having ''informal discussions'' with Cocom allies to try to establish as much common ground as possible before the June meeting in Paris.
At a Cocom meeting in February, the United States found itself isolated. Anticipating tough negotiations in June, Mr. Mosbacher acknowledged that there ''may be some flexibility, depending on the area.''
 
Raising the Limits on Computers
In technical terms, the plan calls for complete decontrol of computers that can process up to 275 megabits of data a second. That processing rate is about four times the current limit on computers allowed to be exported to restricted countries. One megabit is a million bits.
On computers for civilian uses, the limit would be extended to the so-called China Green Line - a processing rate of 550 megabits a second, the current limit on computers that are shipped to China.
For machine tools the changes would result in decontrol of many tools with a positioning accuracy of plus or minus two or three microns. This would still bar exports of the kind of milling equipment that the Toshiba Machine Corporation of Japan and Kongsberg Vaapenfabrikk of Norway sold illegally to the Soviet Union in the 1980's. That equipment could be used to make advanced submarine propellers, and the discovery of the sales caused a furor in Washington in 1987.
In telecommunications, the United States proposed relaxation of some cellular communications systems and some satellite ground stations. For Eastern European destinations, there would be greater access to fiber-optic equipment and some microwave telecommunications systems. But access to the more advanced technology would be dependent on adoption of safeguards against diversion to the Soviet Union.

HEADLINE: Former Official Says Bush Aides Swayed $500,000 H.U.D. Grant

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 2

 BODY:
A former senior Federal housing official testified today that staff aides to Vice President George Bush intervened with the Department of Housing and Urban Development to win a $500,000 grant for a Kansas City developer in 1985.
The witness, DuBois L. Gilliam, told a House panel that he was directed to arrange the grant for the developer, Hector Barreto, the founder of the United States Hispanic Chamber of Commerce and a longtime supporter of Mr. Bush, even though the project did not qualify for Federal assistance.
Mr. Gilliam did not suggest that Mr. Bush had personally ordered the grant, and White House aides said today that they had no knowledge about the project, a study of the feasibility of an international trade center in Kansas City. ''I never heard of Hector Barreto,'' said Marlin Fitzwater, the chief White House spokesman. 
But Mr. Barreto said at a news conference this afternoon that he had lobbied Mr. Bush and former Housing Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. on behalf of the project.
None of the actions mentioned in the testimony today would amount to a crime by Vice President Bush or his staff. But the testimony was further indication of a pattern of widespread political favoritism at the housing department during Ronald Reagan's Administration. The testimony also offered the clearest example to date of how Mr. Bush's name may have been invoked in the distribution of politically desirable H.U.D. awards.
Mr. Gilliam, a former Deputy Assistant Secretary of Housing who is now serving an 18-month prison sentence resulting from his actions at the housing agency, has emerged as a central witness in the year-old Congressional investigation of favoritism and corruption at the Department of Housing and Urban Development.
In his second day of testimony on Capitol Hill, Mr. Gilliam, appearing under a grant of immunity from further prosecution, said the Kansas City project did not quality for Federal assistance, and that the grant was eventually approved as part of an unusual arrangement with officials in Kansas City.
Under the arrangement, Kansas City paid for the study out of the city's Community Development Block Grant funds, which are provided by H.U.D. In turn, Mr. Gilliam arranged a $500,000 special grant for Kansas City from one of Mr. Pierce's discretionary funds. ''In other words, let's make a deal -you do this and I'll do this,'' Mr. Gilliam said.
James I. Threatt, a Kansas City official, confirmed Mr. Gilliam's account in an interview today, saying he was told by Mr. Gilliam at the time that ''Vice President Bush's office was interested in having this project funded.'' The trade center is under development. At his news conference, in Kansas City, Mr. Barreto, a trade consultant who was a member of President Reagan's 1980 White House transition team, said he recalled discussing the project with Mr. Bush at two or three meetings in the mid-1980's.
''I mentioned that we were very actively'' pursuing the grant, he said of his conversations with the Vice President. Mr. Barreto said one of the conversations occurred during a ''very private meeting'' with Mr. Bush on Sept. 21, 1985, at a gathering in Puerto Rico of the Hispanic Chamber of Commerce.
News reports show the $500,000 grant was announced in Kansas City in early October 1985.
In his appearance before the House Government Operations Subcommittee on Employment and Housing, Mr. Gilliam did not identify which aides to Mr. Bush may have contacted the housing department on behalf of the project. He said the White House discussed the grant with Deborah Gore Dean, Mr. Pierce's executive assistant, and that Ms. Dean had relayed the information to him.
 
He Tells of Call From Dean
''I received a call from Deborah Dean,'' Mr. Gilliam recalled. ''Deborah Dean said she had been over visiting with the Vice President and she indicated that she had received a call from the Vice President's staff asking about the grant and indicating their desire to try to help to get this project funded.''
Earlier that same day, Mr. Gilliam said, he had been visited at his H.U.D. office by Mr. Barreto.
At that meeting, ''I shared with Mr. Barreto that we could not fund'' the Kansas City project because it did not qualify under the department's technical assistance program, Mr. Gilliam said, adding: ''He then indicated to me that he was going to go to the Vice President's office to visit with him and his staff people. He then left my office in that direction.''
Ms. Dean has refused to talk with reporters in recent months. A lawyer for Ms. Dean, Charles Leeper, would not comment on today's testimony.
Despite his criminal record and his acknowledgement this week that he received more than $100,000 in illegal payoffs while at H.U.D., lawmakers have presented Mr. Gilliam as someone whose testimony could be believed even though he has engaged in illegal conduct. Much of his information, they say, has been corroborated through documents and other witnesses.
 
'Admitted Cheat and Liar'
A statement issued by Mr. Pierce's lawyers said, ''Mr. Pierce denies all allegations of wrongdoing and improper conduct. It is inconceivable that the subcommittee has accepted at face value the unsubstantiated testimony of an admitted cheat and liar who repeatedly violated the public's trust while at H.U.D.''
''By granting him immunity,'' the statement said, ''this subcommittee has provided Gilliam with a free ride, virtually assuring that Gilliam will never spend another day in prison for these multiple criminal acts. Under the circumstances, it is impossible to imagine how this subcommittee can vouch for Mr. Gilliam's credibility.''
In his testimony, Mr. Gilliam said he resigned from H.U.D. in 1987 after an internal investigation had turned up evidence of the illegal payoffs he now acknowledges that he received from H.U.D. contractors. Mr. Gilliam said he met with Mr. Pierce, who was aware of the inquiry.
''He thought it would be best for me to go ahead and leave,'' Mr. Gilliam testified. ''And I told him I would leave, but I'd need some help from him. He told me he would help me in any way he could.''
Working through Ms. Dean, Mr. Gilliam said, he obtained a promise from Mr. Pierce of housing grants that could have been worth more than $2 million.
The grants, he said, were to be in the form of rent subsidies for the rehabilitation of 250 low-income apartments. Mr. Gilliam left H.U.D. to become a housing consultant and, under the arrangement described at today's hearing, he could have sold rights to the subsidies to developers or other housing consultants.
Mr. Gilliam said he originally asked for H.U.D. subsidies for 400 apartments. ''Deborah went and spoke to the Secretary,'' he said. ''She came back and told me I had 250 units. I couldn't have the 400 units because I was being greedy.''
''She indicated to me that Secretary Pierce thought I was being a little greedy,'' Mr. Gilliam added.
Representative Tom Lantos, the chairman of the House subcommittee, described the arrangement as ''a multimillion-dollar severance package,'' a ''golden parachute'' offered by Mr. Pierce to a corrupt aide.
''That's a fair statement,'' Mr. Gilliam replied.

HEADLINE: Burmese Rights Abuses Are Said to Continue

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE

 BODY:
Amnesty International has charged in a report that ''severe human rights violations'' have continued to be frequent in Myanmar, formerly Burma, under the current military Government.
The report, made public Tuesday, was criticized yesterday by a Burmese diplomat in Washington as containing untrue allegations. Parliamentary elections are to be held in Myanmar on May 27. 
The report said these rights violations had kept on occurring ''at a very high level'' in Myanmar since September 1988, when its Armed Forces Chief of Staff, Gen. Saw Maung, led a military coup that ended the 26-year rule of the Burma Socialist Program Party of Gen. Ne Win.
The report said that months of pro-democracy demonstrations and ''the deaths of thousands of mostly peaceful demonstrators as a result of shootings by the army'' preceded the coup.
The study said that ''recent testimonies obtained by Amnesty International'' described the rights abuses under the current government and said they have included ''mass arrests of prisoners of conscience and possible prisoners of conscience, widespread torture, summary trials, and extrajudicial executions.''
Asked to comment, Soe Win, a first secretary in the Burmese Embassy in Washington, said yesterday that he had not read the report, but that ''these allegations are not true.''
''The torture of detainees, inhuman and cruel treatment of prisoners, etc., are unknown to us, except when we were under foreign domination,'' he said, referring to colonial rule by Britain, which ended in 1948.
Mr. Soe Win, who said he was not related to Mr. Ne Win, said more detailed comment would be forthcoming later.
The Amnesty International report said that the testimony it had obtained ''indicates that real or imputed critics of Myanmar's military Government run a high risk of being imprisoned, interrogated, and tortured for the peaceful expression of their politial views,'' although it noted that the Government had ''pledged political and economic reforms that appeared to go some way toward meeting the demands of pro-democracy protesters.''
The study also said, ''Evidence based on interviews conducted in November and December 1989 by Amnesty International from recently released political prisoners and refugees who have fled the country suggests not only that torture and unlawful killings of civilians in ethnic minority areas continue to be widespread, but that torture of political suspects occurs in other parts of the country.''

HEADLINE: World's Legislators Urge 'Marshall Plan' For the Environment

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHABECOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 2

 BODY:
Legislators from 42 countries called today for a ''global Marshall plan'' under which industrial nations would help less developed countries grow economically while still protecting the environment.
The three-day conference, presided over by Senator Al Gore, Democrat of Tennessee, ended here today. It did not specify how much such an effort might cost, but urged the richer countries to help finance environmentally benign growth in the third world.
Delegates agreed to immediately begin steps to reduce the air pollution that many scientists believe triggers the process of global warming.
The legislators who took part are not empowered to set policy for their Governments. Many of them said they would bring the proposals adopted by the meeting to their Parliaments and seek legislation.
 
Some Specific Proposals
These were among the specific proposals for legislative action:
* Setting a worldwide target of reducing by half over the next 20 years the emission of industrial gases that are building up in the atmosphere.
* Establishing national goals of achieving economic growth in ways that can be sustained without long-term damage to the world and national environments. The conference called for the creation of a ''green common market'' and proposed ''a bank for sustainable development'' to help finance growth in the third world without harming the environment.
* Instituting a world strategy that links population growth with poverty and environmental degradation, and seeks to stabilize global population, now just over 5 billion, at 10 billion people.
* Creating an ''international convention for the protection of all the world's forests,'' in both temperate and tropical regions.

HEADLINE: All Forgiven, Jamaican Will See Bush Today

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KINGSTON, Jamaica, April 28

 BODY:
When he visits the White House on Thursday, Prime Minister Michael N. Manley will be welcomed as a friend of Vice President Dan Quayle and a partner of the Bush Administration.
Such a visit by a Caribbean leader would be fairly unremarkable were it not for Mr. Manley's not-so-distant past as a sometimes strident advocate of socialism in the third world.
But in a turnabout that anticipated the move toward capitalism in Eastern Europe, Mr. Manley was reborn before the elections that returned him to power early last year as an advocate of free markets, privatization, global economic integration and competition.
''It was just a matter of time before these highly bureaucratic and centralized states yielded to more democratic processes,'' Mr. Manley said of Eastern Europe's political changes. ''I cannot claim to be surprised.'' 
When in office during most of the 1970's, Mr. Manley was more often perceived as a thorn in Washington's side than as a partner. After a visit to Cuba, he declared that he would accompany Fidel Castro ''to the mountaintop.''
The Reagan Administration openly rejoiced at Mr. Manley's defeat in 1980 at the hands of Edward P. G. Seaga, a conservative whose friendship with Washington was cemented when he strongly supported the United States invasion of Grenada in 1983.
Returned to office by an electorate disillusioned with growing economic hardship, Mr. Manley has courted the United States, conscious that from tourists to investments in the bauxite industry his large neighbor's attitude toward his Government can profoundly affect the economic climate here.
One of Mr. Manley's first gestures was to insure cooperation with the United States anti-drug efforts.
''This time he started out by making all the right noises,'' said a Western diplomat in Kingston, who suggested that for a canny politician like Mr. Manley more than the right noises were needed to soothe some doubters.
But after observing the leader since his return tp power, even skeptics with sour memories of Mr. Manley's policies of two decades ago have come to agree that the change is real, the diplomat said.
Wycliffe Bennett, a Jamaica scholar who headed the National Broadcasting Services under both the Manley and Seaga Governments, said, ''Manley is now rather centrist, I would say.''
The actions that have persuaded doubters include raising interest rates, ending subsidies for some basic commodities and devaluing the Jamaican dollar. These and other austerity measures were included in an agreement the Government recently signed with the International Monetary Fund.
Despite such unpopular measures, the People's National Party of Mr. Manley defeated Mr. Seaga's Jamaica Labor Party in local elections in March, a testament to his enduring support among the country's poor.
Mr. Manley has replaced many of the social programs and promises of the past with a call to hard work. ''There are economic problems and they are deep,'' he now warns, adding that the country's salvation will come about only through ''a great national effort.''
But Mr. Manley emphasized in an interview in his airy colonial-style offices that he was not merely seeking to placate an outside neighbor but hoping to initiate an era of more meaningful cooperation between the two countries and with others in the Caribbean Basin. ''I'm hoping to use my visit to strengthen the impression in Washington of the huge problems facing the developing world,'' he said, placing particular emphasis on the imposing sums owed to Western governments and multinational financal institutions like the World Bank and the I.M.F.
Still championing third-world development, Mr. Manley says he also hopes to impress upon the White House a concern that haunts many developing countries: that the dissolution of political blocs in Europe will lead the West to completely forget them.
''It is a shortsighted error of the greatest magnitude and it is amoral to support the development of Eastern Europe at the expense of places like the Caribbean, where many of us have long been in the trenches of democracy,'' he said.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

STATE: NEW YORK, USA (92%);
