LENGTH: 1019 words

HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe;
Europe Seeking Greater Unity by '93

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, May 2

 BODY:
With plans to create a single trading market already well advanced, the 12 nations of the European Community have set themselves the task of achieving still greater economic and political unity by Jan. 1, 1993.
Yet as they move toward such vague goals as ''economic and monetary union'' and ''political union,'' mobilized this time by the revolution sweeping Eastern Europe, the 12 are facing mounting difficulties in defining just what they mean.
Their long-term objective remains unchanged: to create an economic and political unit that will enable Western Europe to compete for influence on the world stage with the United States, Japan and Soviet Union.
But in the coming year they must decide how this is to be achieved and, more specifically, how much additional national sovereignty must be surrendered to the community's various supranational bodies. And on this, they are still far from agreement. 
 
Conflicting Views
The British Government is strongly opposed to giving any extra power to what it refers to scornfully as the ''bureaucrats'' at the community headquarters in Brussels, while even advocates of regional unity, like France and West Germany, hold conflicting views on how power should be redistributed.
Further, despite the acceleration in the process of integration over the last five years, no government believes that the proposed changes will bring the community much closer to becoming a federation of European states, with a single president, government and parliament.
Nonetheless, moves toward greater economic and political unity, which began when six countries signed the Treaty of Rome establishing a common market in 1957, were given significant new momentum by community leaders at a special summit in Dublin last Saturday.
Overriding British objections, they endorsed a plan to achieve ''economic and monetary union,'' which could include creation of a common currency and regional central bank, and ''political union,'' which remains a nebulous concept, by the time the single market goes into effect in 1993.
 
Conferences in December
To make the necessary changes in the Treaty of Rome, all but Britain also favor the idea of holding parallel inter-governmental conferences dealing with each aspect of integration. To allow time for national parliaments to consider the measures, the conferences should open in December this year.
One reason for confusion about the community's aims stems from the fact that the new drive toward European union has been inspired not by a new surge of regional solidarity but by fear of the impact of the collapse of Communism in Eastern Europe and the rush towards German unification.
France in particular argued for speeding the community's integration as a way of tying a united Germany to the West and of strengthening European stability at a time of uncertainty throughout the Continent. And Italy, Spain, Belgium, the Netherlands and, eventually, West Germany agreed.
While East Germany will automatically join the community when it is absorbed by West Germany, other Eastern European countries will be offered loose association agreements rather than membership. In the language of European experts, the decision was to ''deepen'' rather than ''widen'' the community.
 
Deadline of Jan. 1, 1993
As a result, the Dublin meeting ruled that economic and monetary union, which had been expected to go into effect in the mid-1990's, should be achieved by Jan. 1, 1993. And political union, originally planned as a follow-up to economic and monetary union, was provisionally given the same deadline.
Community leaders felt emboldened to take on this new challenge by progress toward a single market. For example, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain, who remains deeply suspicious of such notions as political union, supports the single market as a way of freeing businesses and banks from the shackles of government intervention.
Even this, though, has involved a steady erosion of national sovereignties. Almost weekly, the community issues ''directives'' that affect everything from subsidies to state enterprises to company merger policies. These are routinely approved by national parliaments, including Britain's Intended to permit the free movement of people, goods, services and capital, the single market will also bring the removal of internal borders within the 12-nation region. And here, the community has to work out rules to control terrorists, drug traffickers, illegal migrants and refugees.
 
Agreement Could Be Elusive
Agreement on future stages of integration, though, may prove more elusive. A commission headed by Jacques Delors, the President of the European Commission, has defined economic and monetary union as harmonizing policies through creation of a regional central bank and a common currency. Its report has been endorsed by all governments except Britain.
It anticipates that the European currency unit, or ECU, which already exists as a reference mark, would become legal tender throughout the community. The central bank, or Eurofed, would be independent, although its power to impose policies on individual governments is still subject to debate.
But Britain, which has so far refused to tie the pound to other community currencies, has made it clear that it is unwilling to transfer decisions on interest rates, exchange rates and even gov ernment spending to any regional body. And it hopes to block the required community consensus for such radical changes.
It is already clear that ''political union'' will not mean a single European government. Rather, the European Commission, the European Parliament and the Council of Ministers will assume some powers currently exercised by national governments and parliaments. The central question, then, is what powers should go to which bodies.
The 12 Foreign Ministers are to prepare a report on different concepts of political unity for the next community summit in Dublin on June 25 and 26. The leaders are then expected to formalize their call for an intergovernmental conference on the subject this December.

HEADLINE: Timid, and Destructive, in Albany

 BODY:
In a year rich with examples of poor judgment in Albany, for New York's political leaders to agree on a patchwork of nuisance taxes offers the most disappointing and dangerous news yet.
There's no question about the need for more tax revenue. The state faces a deficit that could reach $4 billion. But Gov. Mario Cuomo and legislative leaders could not bring themselves to raise money the right way, from a broad-based tax. Instead they have concocted a package that extends the state sales tax to a spectrum of goods and services. They don't seem to understand the message that conveys to the business community, already antsy: Leave town. 
The tentative agreement, part of a $1 billion tax plan, extends the 4 percent sales tax to all manner of new targets - magazines, 900 telephone numbers, custom-designed computer software, public relations services. Imposing sales taxes on the service industry is particularly troubling, because that's the healthiest, fastest-growing segment of the state's generally flagging economy.
New York already imposes sales taxes on nearly every consumer item except food. With the new tax on services, little short of a handshake will go untaxed.
Also troubling is that even now, with the budget already a month late and the deficit mounting, Senate Republicans are playing politics. Led by Ralph Marino of Long Island, the majority leader, they're resisting efforts by Mr. Cuomo and the Assembly Democrats to distribute school aid equitably and reasonably. They're pushing for inflated school spending, especially in wealthy suburban districts.
The tax package is even more of an offense against sensible government because the state has reasonable options. One is a corporate surcharge higher than already planned, which would be temporary and affect all businesses, not just the service industry. Another option is a higher gasoline tax. New York's 8-cent-a-gallon tax is among the lowest in the country. For one day Mr. Cuomo floated the idea of an increase, then quickly retreated when it drew opposition. Nobody else has gone even that far.
Politicians don't like to make unpopular decisions - particularly in an election year. This year, that timidity will hurt the constituents they're trying to placate, by damaging the state's fragile economy.

HEADLINE: U.S. Can Only Suffer From Failure to Join 1992 Fair in Seville

 BODY:
To the Editor:
You report that Congress has ''approved only $2.9 million of the $15 million seed money needed for the United States to officially guarantee its attendance'' at Expo 92, the Seville World's Fair (news article, April 17).
However, Congress has not appropriated any money for United States participation in the Seville World's Fair. Since President Reagan committed the United States to participate in the fair, and President Bush endorsed that commitment, the United States Information Agency (the Federal agency that oversees American participation in world's fairs overseas) has been working to persuade the Senate and House Appropriations subcommittees to come up with $15 million in Federal funds to match the $15 million the U.S.I.A. expects to raise from states and corporations. 
In a Feb. 5 news article, you reported Representative Neal Smith, chairman of the House Appropriations Subcommitte as saying: ''I doubt there will be any Federal Government money. We shouldn't put world's fairs as a higher priority than housing for State Department personnel or broadcasting for the Voice of America.''
Representative Smith obviously believes that Expo 92 is just another fair and not the proper subject of Government expenditure. But more than 100 nations are attending, including all other North Atlantic Treaty Organization members, and virtually every Western Hemisphere nation. Puerto Rico will spend more than our Government is asked to spend! France, Britain, Germany, Japan and Italy are each spending more than triple the United States budget. As I understand it, without Congressional approval of $2.9 million for the Seville Expo, our participation in the fair may be a dead issue by May, as architectural, engineering and design deadlines remain unmet.
While the United States stands back and lets Western Europe prospectively bear the main financial burden of rebuilding Eastern Europe, the failure of the United States to be present at Seville during the most important world's fair ever held, coinciding with the integration of the European Economic Community and the 500th anniversary of Columbus's voyage, could raise in Europe's mind the specter of a new isolationism. At the very least the world will wonder about America's behavior.
Perhaps deciding in 1990 to spend money on a fair that will take place in 1992 seems frivolous. Worrying about the United States image in Europe and Latin America may not seem compelling at this date, but I predict that when the fair opens April 20, 1992, were the United States not to be present, our absence will have great repercussions.
 
ERIC M. JAVITS
New York, April 18, 1990
 The writer is former chairman of the Spanish Institute.

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
Six, the Magic Number

BYLINE: By Tom Wicker

 BODY:
In the unlikely but not impossible event that the Democrats lose control of the Senate this year, they'd do well if they gave up only five seats, no more, no less. That would result in a party tie at 50-50, and give the Republicans control only by virtue of Vice President Quayle's tie-breaking vote.
For the next two years, in that case, Mr. Quayle would have to decide personally and visibly all the numerous divisive issues on which neither party could muster 51 votes. He must be kidding if he says he wouldn't mind. 
It isn't likely to happen and the Republicans aren't likely to get control of the Senate in that or any way -though their chances are a lot better than the Democrats' 10-seat edge might suggest. Republicans need to win at least six Democratic seats, while losing none of their own, to produce a 51-to-49 majority.
If that happened, those six seats changing hands probably would come from among the following:
* Illinois: Senator Paul Simon, a liberal and an unsuccessful Democratic Presidential candidate in 1988, is being sharply challenged by Representative Lynn Martin, for whom both George and Barbara Bush already have campaigned.
* Iowa: Senator Tom Harkin, a Democratic freshman in a state where no Democratic senator ever has won re-election, faces Representative Tom Tauke, who - Republicans say - has raised $2.1 million from more than 20,000 contributors.
* Michigan: Senator Carl Levin, a Democrat, won by only about 52 percent of the vote in 1978 and 1984 in a state that's been losing Democratic strength. The Republicans will pick a candidate, probably Representative Bill Schuette, in a September primary.
* Rhode Island: Claiborne Pell, a Democrat and chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, has been around a long time. Democrats note that both he and his popular opponent, Representative Claudine Schneider, are pro-choice and equally liberal -''so why replace Pell with Schneider?''
* Montana: Two years ago, Senator John Melcher, a Democrat, was beaten, as were all incumbents in statewide races. This year, Senator Max Baucus, another Democrat, faces a primary and Republicans think him vulnerable; but four Republican contenders have entered a possibly divisive primary of their own.
* Nebraska: Republicans believe that Representative Hal Daub can beat Senator Jim Exon, a conservative Democrat, because the Senator got only 52 percent of the vote in 1984. But that was 24 points more than Walter Mondale, the Democratic Presidential nominee.
* Hawaii: After Spark Matsunaga's death, Gov. John Waihee, a Democrat, appointed Representative Daniel Akaka, also Democratic, to fill the seat. Republicans think they can win a special election this fall, even in a Democratic state, if they can persuade Representative Patricia Saiki to run; and she doesn't seem reluctant.
Even Republicans concede that winning six, much less all of these seven seats, would be remarkable; Democratic sources scoff at the idea, though conceding that all these races are close. Democrats claim also to be ''competitive'' in Kentucky, where the Republican freshman, Mitch McConnell, won by fewer than 6,000 votes in 1984. Harvey Sloane, the former Mayor of Louisville, is the probable Democratic nominee.
Three G.O.P. Senators (Humphrey of New Hampshire, Armstrong of Colorado and McClure of Idaho) are retiring, but Republican officials see ''no contest'' for their seats. Democrats contend they have decent chances in Colorado and New Hampshire (which they consider a strong pro-choice state) and even hope to win Mr. Quayle's old seat in Indiana.
That supposedly Republican state has a Democratic Governor and seven Democratic representatives (out of ten), including Jill Long. Last year she won the House seat from which Mr. Quayle and his appointed successor, Dan Coats, moved up to the Senate; Democrats cautiously hope State Representative Baron Hill, a former basketball star, can beat Mr. Coats.
Republicans are squirming and Democrats chuckling - for now - at the special case of Louisiana. The seat of Senator Bennett Johnston, a Democrat, is at stake and the Republicans want State Senator Ben Bagert for his opponent. They may be embarrassed with David Duke instead; the former Ku Klux Klansman is running in Louisiana's nonpartisan primary as a self-anointed Republican and might well win the right to face the Senator in a runoff.
Neither party would laugh about that. To avoid a runoff, Mr. Johnston needs to win over 50 percent in the primary - a tall order in a state with the nation's highest unemployment.

HEADLINE: Hartford Shifts Revenue in Move to Adopt Budget

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, May 2

 BODY:
The General Assembly today moved toward adoption of a $7.05 billion budget that would solve the state's financial problems for the next year by using a series of short-term infusions of tax revenue, postponed payments to the state pension plan and shifts in budget accounting.
The proposal, part of which was approved on Tuesday night by the House of Representatives, avoids what lawmakers had dreaded: a tax increase or layoffs of state workers in an election year. It also allows budget increases for some of the most pressing needs like Medicaid payments, state employee health insurance and staffing for prisons.
But the route used by the Assembly in getting to that point has troubled lawmakers in both parties. For example, the budget would take $102 million from the state's rainy-day reserve fund to help erase the $246 million deficit projected for the fiscal year that ends on June 30. That leaves the reserve fund almost empty. 
The proposal would also push an additional $90 million in one-time accelerated payments from mostly corporate and inheritance taxes into the budget for the fiscal year that begins on July 1; that money then could not be used next year. A $76 million quarterly payment to the state's pension plan, which is to be skipped next year, will also likely have to be made up in the following budget.
 
Bond Rating Lowered
Almost $200 million in expense items that had previously been paid from the state's general fund, using regular tax revenue, are shifted off the budget and are to be paid in the future through the sale of bonds or other special accounts.
Standard & Poor's, the bond-rating agency, recently lowered the state's bond rating from AA-plus to AA because of the anticipated depletion of the reserve fund and the increase in borrowing.
The items shifted off the budget, which include $111 million in grants to local municipalities are not in the budget bill and will have to be approved later with bond authorizations or other legislation. Combined with $7.05 billion in the main budget proposal, total state spending would be $7.38 billion, up 6.12 percent from the year that ends on June 30.
The co-chairman of the Finance, Revenue and Bonding Committee, Representative William J. Cibes Jr., Democrat from New London and a candidate for governor, has publicly denounced the plan he helped construct, saying he believes it is not a responsible budget in the long run. Republican minority members in the Assembly have been even more to the point. $500 Million Deficit Expected ''They're just gimmicks,'' said Representative Robert G. Jaekle, Republican of Stratford and the House minority leader. ''When you add up all the non-recurring sources of revenue, there's a big hole for next year.''
The combination of postponed payments and one-time revenue sources, Mr. Jaekle said, would give the state a guaranteed $500 million deficit for the year beginning July 1, 1991, if the economy did not significantly change.
The Assembly's Office of Fiscal Analyis, a nonpartisan research arm of the legislature, projected an even larger gap of more than $600 million earlier this year, based on the budget plan proposed in February by Gov. William A. O'Neill. And while no new projections have been made based on the changes in Mr. O'Neill's budget that were adopted in the Assembly, the tax-revenue stream has clearly worsened.
In the three months since Mr. O'Neill presented his budget, for example, the projected size of the deficit grew to $246 million from $90 million for the year ending in June, according to estimates from the State Comptroller, mainly because of corporate tax revenues that were weaker than expected.
Those declining tax-revenue numbers helped make up the backdrop as lawmakers struggled to write a budget that would be accepted by the Democratic majority.
The resulting document cuts $150.8 million from the $7.2 billion budget proposed by Mr. O'Neill, said the House Speaker, Richard J. Balducci, Democrat of Newington.
As the House debated the budget bill for almost eight hours before approving it 84 to 60 along party lines, the question on Tuesday was what was properly labeled a cut.
''Some of the things we're doing are one-shot items,'' said Deputy Speaker Janet Polinsky, Democrat of Waterford. ''What do we do for an encore?''

HEADLINE: Growing Soviet Export: Military Technology

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
A high-ranking Soviet scientist came to Capitol Hill recently to lecture members of Congress on why the United States should buy technology developed for the Soviet Union's military and space programs.
Such an address would have been unthinkable only a few years ago. But economic pressures in the Soviet Union are forcing the nation to market its hard-won expertise in the West, in return for hard currency.
Among the products of Soviet research that have already found their way into the American market are metal-forming techniques, coatings that greatly extend the life of cutting tools and a new way to track radiation dosages.
That the Soviet Union is willing to offer technology even with military applications was evident in a recent deal involving a consortium including the Soviet Institute for Structural Macrokinetics, which the visiting scientist, Dr. Aleksandr G. Merzhanov, directs. The institute, situated near Moscow, studies materials fabrication. The consortium agreed to supply Soviet-made high-temperature superconducting powders to a small American company that would seek markets in this country. 
Superconducting powders have no resistance to electricity and can be formed into valuable components in electric motors, power transformers and the like. They remain on United States lists of products that cannot be exported to Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union without special permits.
 
Company 'Pretty Impressed'
''I don't think Dr. Merzhanov and his process would have been in the United States three or four years ago,'' said Peter Walsh, vice president of Project Development International Inc., based in New York, which helps market Soviet products and technology in this country. ''The Soviet Government is actively promoting defense-related technology.''
Robert D. DeLuca, the chief executive of HiTc Superconco Inc., the small research company near Philadelphia that is buying the superconducting powders, said his company was ''pretty impressed'' by them. He said the Soviet material, like other high-temperature superconductors a synthetic compound of copper oxide, yttrium and barium, is purer than the powders his company makes internally. And the Soviet fabrication process is much faster, taking place in seconds rather than the several days required for conventional processing.
The Soviet research establishment is vast, amounting to 1.5 million people working in thousands of institutes and industrial establishments, Soviet officials say. But while in the past it was supported completely by the state, such financing is now being cut back, so the scientists and engineers employed there are trying to find new sources of revenue. Most of the deals being signed now are small and largely experimental in nature.
''We have to organize our work so we are not depending so much on Government support,'' Dr. Merzhanov said. ''This includes broader sources of financing.''
More deals are likely as Soviet research institutes forge links with marketing organizations in this country.
In recent weeks Genesis Technology Group in Cambridge, Mass., formed a partnership with Biogen, a group of 26 Soviet biological institutes. The partnership will try to market such products as amino-acid food supplements and drugs to treat alcoholism. It will also try to interest Western pharmaceutical companies in sponsoring research at the institutes in return for rights to the results.
 
'World-Class Technology'
Arthur D. Little Inc., a consulting firm also situated in Cambridge, signed an agreement with the Soviet Academy of Sciences to evaluate a wide variety of technologies and to market them in the West. The two are to form a company called E'West Managers, which will have its headquarters in Geneva and Moscow.
''There are some fields where Soviet research institutes are known to have world-class technology and science,'' said Theodore P. Heuchling, a senior vice president at Little. Among them: nuclear fusion, which is both the basic mechanism of the hydrogen bomb and a potential source of cheap electric power; high-energy lasers, and gallium-arsenide solar-power cells.
''Some of the technologies involved were clearly developed for military defense reasons,'' said Alfred E. Wechsler, another Little official. ''The attitude is that now they should be moved into the commercial area.''
John Kiser, the president of Kiser Research Inc. of Washington, which represents Dr. Merzhanov's institute in this country, said the Soviet Union had long been more willing to market advanced technology in the West than Western governments had been to permit technology to flow the other way. In the book ''Communist Entrepreneurs,'' he notes that technologies as diverse as surgical stapling, magnetic casting of aluminum and synthesis of polycarbonates originated in the Soviet Union.
 
Metal-Coating Process
Joseph H. Filner, the president of Project Development International, said a metal-coating process now being marketed in the United States by Multi-Arc Vacuum Systems Inc. of St. Paul had originally been developed for the Soviet nuclear program. The process increases the life of cutting tools like drills and mills as much as sixfold by depositing a thin layer of titanium nitride on the surface.
Researchers in the United States knew the advantages of titanium nitride, but the temperature of the process they had developed, more than 1,800 degrees Fahrenheit, was so high that many of the tools became deformed, limiting their usefulness. Meanwhile, Soviet scientists had found a way to apply the coating at 800 to 900 degrees. ''We found they had better technology, so we bought it and brought it back to this country,'' Mr. Filner said. The treated tools, recognizable by the golden coating, are now widely used in American industry, including in military plants, and are beginning to turn up in consumer markets, Product Development officials said.
More recently, Mr. Filner found that scientists at the Riga Medical Institute in Latvia had developed a radiation detector - a crystal that has been treated with selected impurities - that is 50 times more sensitive than the one commonly used in the United States.
The Soviet aluminum-oxide crystal detector can measure one-tenth of a millirem of radiation, compared with a maximum sensitivity of five millirems for a standard lithium fluoride detector, said Arthur C. Lucas, vice president for technology at Victoreen Inc., in Cleveland.
 
Questions of Origin Not Asked
Mr. Lucas said the devices ''may have been developed for the Soviet nuclear navy, but they are not saying and we are not going to ask.'' He said the quality of Soviet materials science was very good.
''All they need is an economic structure that can take advantage of the advances they have made,'' he said.
The detectors are being made in a Soviet-American joint venture in Riga as Victoreen attempts to build a market in the United States. Mr. Lucas said the company estimated it could sell 300,000 to 500,000 of the detector crystals a year.
Because the Soviet Government allocated resources to military and space programs rather than consumer goods, it stands to reason that military-derived developments are among its most marketable products, Mr. Kiser of Kiser Research said. ''The closer something is to a military application, the less likely it is they need help from us,'' he added.
 
Freedom From Profit Pressure
The lack of commercial markets for much of the technology developed by researchers in the Soviet Union has been a big economic drag on the nation. Then again, Soviet scientists, free of the pressure to push technology into applications that improve quarterly profits, have been able to pursue projects for decades. The process that produces the superconducting powders and other materials has been developed over 20 years by Dr. Merzhanov, a physicist, and his wife, Dr. Inna Borovinskaya, a chemist.
Lacking commercial interests to protect, Soviet scientists are also eager to license their technologies so they can gain access to Western computers and analytic instruments.
Mr. Filner cautioned, however, that the quality of Soviet finished goods remained uneven and that some Soviet scientific claims tended to be exaggerated. ''They are converting a missile plant in the Urals to produce videocassette recorders,'' he said. ''I don't think we will be able to sell many Soviet VCR's over here soon. For the next 10 years their best exports will be brains and semifinished goods.''

HEADLINE: Economy Improving, Data Show

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 2

 BODY:
Having avoided recession, the economy is gradually picking up strength, with the long-suppressed industrial sector setting the pace, private analysts said today after publication of another batch of Government economic data.
The Commerce Department reported that factory orders climbed 3.8 percent in March and that its predictive index for overall economic activity rose nine-tenths of 1 percent for that month. Both figures were a bit stronger than expected and represented the biggest monthly gains since 1988.
Consistent with this picture of modest rebound was the Federal Reserve's periodic survey of business conditions throughout its 12 districts. The survey found that ''overall economic activity continues to expand slowly.'' Six districts reported that industry was on the rebound. 
 
No Credit Crunch Seen
The Fed's report, prepared before the mid-May meeting of the central bank committee that sets monetary policy, also cited little evidence of a credit crunch and scant expression of inflation fears.
While the report, known as ''the beige book,'' consists largely of anecdotal evidence, the findings appeared consistent with other recent indicators of the economy's performance and suggested, among other things, that recent worrisome inflation figures were probably temporary.
''The trend is toward a stronger manufacturing and goods-producing sector,'' said Lincoln F. Anderson, an economist at Bear, Stearns & Company. Inflation, he added, appears to be concentrated in the service area, where consumers are resisting attempts by companies to pass along their higher costs for health care and other benefits.
The Columbia Business School's Center for International Business Cycle Research said on Tuesday that its leading index of service-sector activity rose five-tenths of 1 percent in March, suggesting ''a more subdued pace'' of growth than in recent years.
 
Fed's View on Prices
Various Federal Reserve officials have in recent days declared first-quarter inflation - at an 8 1/2 percent annual rate on the Consumer Price Index and a 6 1/2 percent annual rate on the fixed-weighted gross national product index - to be unacceptably high. But analysts caution that it is not at all clear that the Federal Open Market Committee will decide to tighten policy at its next meeting because much of the increase resulted from weather-related jumps in food and energy and those prices have begun to ease.
The gain of 3.8 percent in factory orders for March followed a 1.8 percent increase in February. Together they offset a January plunge. The latest gain, the largest since December 1988, was heavily affected by gains for aircraft and motor vehicles.
The nine-tenths of 1 percent rise in the index of leading indicators, which is intended to forecast the economy's path, about offset February's decline. Still, it was the seventh gain in the last nine months and the biggest since June 1988.
Six of the index's 11 components contributed to the advance, led by a rise in contracts and orders for new plant and equipment. The other gainers were the change in the price of materials especially sensitive to the business cycle, manufacturers' orders for consumer goods and materials, stock prices as measured by the Standard & Poor's stock index, the speed of deliveries from suppliers and initial claims for state unemployment insurance.
 
Three Lagging Categories
Three categories held the index back: building permits, the change in manufacturers' unfilled orders and the M-2 money supply.
The length of the average workweek and the University of Michigan's index of consumer expectations were unchanged.
Two companion gauges, the coincident index for current economic activity and the lagging index, the components of which tend to move only after a turning point has occurred, rose two-tenths of 1 percent and eight-tenths of 1 percent, respectively, the department also reported. The coincident-to-lagging ratio - an alternative predictor - eased to 1.115 from 1.121.
A private forecasting index compiled by Safian Investment Research rose six-tenths of 1 percent in March, with 12 components rising and 11 falling. On the other hand, a subindex that excludes stock market and monetary elements fell two-tenths of 1 percent, its fourth straight decline.
The Federal Reserve's survey, compiled this time by its Philadelphia district for the period up to April 20, reported that manufacturing activity had risen in Cleveland, Richmond, Atlanta, Chicago, Dallas and San Francisco. St. Louis continued weak, while Boston and Philadelphia reported conditions in their districts as ''mixed.''
 
Real Estate 'Generally Weak'
Residential real estate was described as remaining ''generally weak'' but with pockets of strength in upstate New York, parts of California and in the Minneapolis-St. Paul area. Retail spending was ''growing slowly,'' and loan demand varied but was ''flat'' over all.
Despite complaints from business people about tightening access to credit, the Fed survey suggested that this was not a serious problem.
''There is little evidence that a general 'credit crunch' is developing; the majority of businesses say they have not seen any change in credit terms and have had no trouble getting credit,'' the report said. ''Where credit tightening by banks and thrift institutions has been noted, however, it has mainly affected newer small businesses and the real estate industry.''
Retail sales were said to be strongest in Cleveland, Richmond, Minneapolis and San Francisco and weakest in St. Louis and Dallas.
The report made remarkably little mention of inflation, although the respondents in Cleveland said there was concern that ''commodity prices continue to firm gradually and service prices have been accelerating.'' But it was widely expected that inflation would moderate this spring.

HEADLINE: Mexico Plans To Privatize Bank System

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, May 2

 BODY:
President Carlos Salinas de Gortari sent the Mexican Congress a constitutional amendment today that would reprivatize the country's banking system, which has been in state hands since 1982, and allow private interests to set up new financial institutions.
The proposal, if passed by both houses of Congress, would authorize the Mexican Government to sell off its 66 percent share in the nation's 18 commercial banks, a stake that is worth several billion dollars on the open market.
Government officials said it was still unclear whether foreign investors would be allowed to acquire a voting share in existing banks or in new ones expected to be formed.
''Circumstances have changed'' since 1982, Mr. Salinas argued in the amendment proposal made public today. He said that while the nationalization of the banking system eight years ago may have been justified at the time, privatization was the only way now for Mexico to ''respond to the challenges of the last decade of the 20th century'' and ''confront with sovereignty a world that is transformed, more competitive and technologically revolutionized.'' 
The sweeping bank privatization plan is the latest in a series of Government moves intended to open the Mexican economy to competition and make it more efficient. Since taking office in December 1988, Mr. Salinas has liberalized the foreign investment code, greatly lowered tariffs, put state-owned companies like Mexicana Airlines and the telephone company Telmex up for auction and begun discussions with the United States about the possibility of negotiating a free trade agreement.
 
Move Was Expected Eventually
A liberalization of bank ownership rules was expected to come eventually but not soon. Many believed that Mr. Salinas would wait until after next year's midterm elections to take this step.
The measure is also in line with a more recent policy of looking to the Mexican private sector, rather than abroad, for the bulk of the investment needed to fuel economic growth. The Mexican government had hoped that the signing of a foreign debt accord last summer would bring a flood of foreign investment, but those hopes have been dashed by the sudden interest of Western investors in Eastern Europe after the end of Commmunism there.
''This is one of a series of policy announcements aimed at keeping the Mexican private sector interested in investing in Mexico,'' said Rogelio Ramirez de la O, a leading independent economist here. ''The emphasis was on foreign investment before Salinas visited Europe in January, but now the main target is the Mexican private sector.''
A Government official said that one of the objectives of Mr. Salinas's proposal was ''the democratization of credit and bank service.'' He predicted that bank customers would benefit from lower interest rates and more competitive loan policies.
Mr. Salinas said that even though the Government ''does not intend to be the majority shareholder in each and every banking institution, it will retain a participation in the commercial bank system.'' Government officials said they did not yet know what percentage of which banks Mr. Salinas wanted to keep in state hands, but suggested that the Government might keep a small stake in the three banks that together dominate Mexican banking - Banamex, Bancomer and Banca Serfin.
Mexico's commercial banks were nationalized on Sept. 1, 1982, at the height of a fiscal and foreign debt crisis, by then-President Jose Lopez Portillo as punishment for what he called their role in the ''looting'' of Mexico through capital flight. Early in 1987, the Government began allowing Mexican private investors to buy up to 34 percent of shares in commercial banks, but the private sector has long clamored for a total withdrawal of the Government from the banking system.
Whether foreign banks and investors will also be able to take advantage of the opportunities created by banking privatization is unclear. The revised foreign investment code announced last May reserves virtually all financial activities except leasing for Mexican nationals, but new legislation approved by Congress in December appears to permit foreign investors to buy nonvoting shares in Mexican banks.
''The precise amount and conditions for foreign participation in the process of privatizing Mexican banks would be a matter of discussion and debate within the Mexican Congress,'' one Government official said today. ''That is likely to happen, but nothing is definite and there is clearly going to be a lot of debate on the issue.''
According to Banamex, 87 foreign banks maintained representative offices in Mexico at the end of last year, including 27 banks from the United States. But only Citibank, which was also one of only two banks to escape nationalization in 1982, functions as a commercial bank.
 
Battle in Congress Expected
The President's proposal is certain to face a struggle in the Mexican Congress, where it must be passed with a two-thirds majority to become law. Mr. Salinas's Institutional Revolutionary Party has 263 seats out of 500 in the lower house, and while he can probably count on the support of the 100 representatives of the right-of-center National Action Party, the left-nationalist Democratic Revolutionary Party has strongly opposed other measures to reduce state ownership or control of the economy and is sure to fight this one.
Anticipating that debate, Mr. Salinas said that selling off state-owned bank shares ''will contribute to the strengthening of the country's economic stability, broaden the perspectives for long-term development and meet the most urgent demands of those who have the least.'' He said he would use such an infusion of funds to improve ''basic services such as drinking water, sewers, electricity, schools, housing, health centers and sports facilities.''

HEADLINE: Orders to Factories Rose 3.8% in March

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 2

 BODY:
Orders to factories for manufactured goods rose in March for the second straight month, the Government said today in a report that analysts interpreted as another sign that the industrial sector is recovering from months of weakness.
The Commerce Department said orders rose 3.8 percent in March, to a seasonally adjusted $240.4 billion, after advancing 1.8 percent in February. Orders had dropped 5.5 percent in January, the worst decline in 16 years. 
The January decline was the steepest since a 7 percent drop in December 1974. The March increase was the largest since a 4.7 percent gain in December 1988.
 
Supported by Other Reports
Also yesterday the Government reported that its index of leading indicators rose nine-tenths of a percent in March, the largest rise in more than a year. The orders report coincides with statistics from purchasing managers that indicate the manufacturing sector is expanding and follows a Government report last week that the gross national product grew at an annual rate of 2.1 percent in the first quarter.
Robert G. Dederick, chief economist with the Northern Trust Company in Chicago, said a spell of weakness ''is behind us and we now have a flat, slightly upward bias.''
Allen Sinai, chief economist for the Boston Company, said: ''I think the worst is over. The question now is what kind of rebound and whether the interest spike over the last month or so will abort what appears to be a recovery.''
The department said most of the overall March increase was in durable goods, up 6.6 percent, to $128.7 billion, after a 2.4 percent increase the previous month.
Durable goods are relatively expensive items expected to last more than three years. Many buyers must take out loans to purchase them, and their sales have been hurt by high interest rates.
 
Jump in Transportation Orders
Most of the increase in durable-goods orders was concentrated in the transportation category. It was up 22.4 percent, to $36.6 billion, largely because of a 63.2 percent increase in aircraft orders. Transportation orders rose 10.1 percent in February.
Excluding transportation, orders were up 1 percent.
Orders for primary metals were up 7.3 percent, to $11.7 billion, after a 4.2 percent decline in February, and nonelectrical machinery was up 1.2 percent, to $22.6 billion, after falling six-tenths of a percent in February.
Electrical machinery orders fell 1.6 percent, to $19.6 billion, after rising 2.8 percent in February.
Orders for nondurable goods rose eight-tenths of a percent in March, to $111.7 billion, after a 1.1 percent gain in February. Food and chemicals accounted for most of the rise.
 
A Crucial Category
In the category of nonmilitary capital goods, considered a barometer of business investment plans, orders rose 14.4 percent, to $41.3 billion, after declines of 5.9 percent in February and 13.6 percent in January.
But military orders dropped 3.9 percent, to $7.4 billion, after jumping 18.3 percent in February. Excluding the military, orders gained 4 percent, the largest such increase since a similar advance in April 1989.
The Commerce Department also said shipments were up 1.1 percent in March, to $236.8 billion, after gaining 3.4 percent a month earlier.
Inventories fell three-tenths of a percent, to $371.9 billion, their third decline in four months.

HEADLINE: Oil Outlook Is More Confused Than Usual

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOULDER, Colo., May 2

 BODY:
Unusual complications in predicting oil supply and demand - including uncertainty about the economies of the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe and the effects of the environmental movement - are making producers reluctant to invest in new wells and pipelines, experts at an international conference here say.
The reluctance comes even as spare capacity is rapidly disappearing and as many producers appear eager to avoid the kind of capacity shortage that has twice caused convulsions in the oil markets in the last two decades.
Fewer new investments in production capacity could result in shortages and price increases, and eventually crash development of new capacity that would then depress prices, the experts said.
Elaborating on the increased difficulty of making investment decisions based on predictions about supply and demand, Thad Grundy Jr., a Deputy Assistant Secretary of Energy, said, ''It's always been a moving target, but there are so many variables now.'' 
William L. Liscom, publisher of Energy Listener, a newsletter, cited a prediction by a Chevron Corporation economist at the conference that oil prices would vary between $15 and $25 in the rest of the decade, a huge range. ''The only certainty is it's going to be volatile,'' he said. ''That's going to bring a lot of investment to a halt.
''I'm not sure who is going to put money into Algeria or Nigeria on the basis of those prices,'' he added.
Experts say they cannot even tell whether some of the factors causing uncertainty would raise or lower demand. The increased emphasis on the environment, for example, could bring new requirements for efficiency and conservation, meaning less demand, but also a call for cleaner fuels, which require more crude oil to produce. Similarly, the opening of Eastern Europe to the West could bring economic stimulus or an economic slump.
Another pending change, the restructuring of the Soviet economy, could also raise or lower the demand for oil, depending on the country's economic progress, and raise or lower the worldwide supply of oil. The Soviet Union is the world's largest producer of oil and gas and the third-largest producer of coal, and small changes in the health of those industries could be reflected quickly in Soviet exports of fuels.
Internal upheavals threaten Soviet production, experts say, as do pressures to invest in the production of consumer goods instead of oil and gas. Domestic demand could also grow. But both the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe could consume less because of efforts at modernization or efficiency or because of recessions brought on by the restructurings.
Technical changes also loom, in the long term at least. ''Superconductivity is a huge and present threat to oil demand in the future,'' said Charles T. Maxwell, vice chairman of C. J. Lawrence, Morgan Grenfell Inc., although he said the threat was probably 20 to 25 years away. The development of superconductive materials, which have vastly lower resistance to electricity, would allow more efficient energy use.
Other changes will come sooner, in Europe and East Asia, he said. He cited co-generation, the burning of fuel to obtain not only electricity but also industrial steam, lowering fuel requirements.
Significant progress in solar cells would make them more suitable for displacing oil for electricity generation late in this decade, he added. Current solar cells would be a feasible replacement for oil priced at $60 to $100 a barrel, he said, and that range is falling fast as the cells are improved. And many experts expect the average price of oil, now under $20 a barrel, to rise.
Oil prices tend to respond rapidly to very small shortages or surpluses. How close the world is to shortage is not clear, as several conference participants noted, because the capacity to produce and even the actual amount produced are often unclear. But a steady growth in worldwide demand in recent years, combined with a precipitous decline in production in the United States and other non-OPEC producers, appears to have put about 82 percent of OPEC's capacity in service.
The conference was sponsored by the International Research Center for Energy and Economic Development, an autonomous research center at the University of Colorado.

HEADLINE: Brazil and Argentina Seeking Aid

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Despite a backlog of more than $11 billion in interest owed to commercial bankers, Brazil and Argentina will be negotiating for new official aid when the International Monetary Fund and World Bank meet in Washington next week.
And both countries are likely to win approval of aid in the next several months, underscoring one of the major changes in third world debt policy since the announcement of the Bush Administration's new approach just over a year ago.
The new strategy, in addition to calling for the voluntary reduction of debt, also allows for continuing negotiations and financial support from the international financial institutions, even when the countries are far behind in their commercial-loan payments. Bank loans make up the major portion of third world debt. 
 
Debate Over Policy Change
There has been strong support for this change in policy within the I.M.F and the Bush Administration and among some experts on the debt crisis. But it also worries others, especially the bankers who are owed the interest.
The Institute for International Finance, which was established by commercial banks, is expected to criticize the policy in a report to be released today. The report, which says the payment backlog now totals $18 billion, with more than half of it owed by Brazil and Argentina, will conclude that the policy is an incentive for countries to miss their loan payments. The practice, the report says, could become a habit and, even more importantly, spread to international institutions like the I.M.F. and the World Bank.
Because of this policy, said one official familiar with the institute report, ''it seems that countries are using arrears'' as a way to ease pressure on their economies.
 
No Other Option
But in the case of Brazil, with arrears of $5.1 billion, and Argentina, with $6.1 billion, some officials and bankers see no way to deal with the problems before the countries get aid from the I.M.F., or before they begin debt-reduction negotiations with their commercial bankers.
To refuse the aid, as long as the countries are taking approved steps to restructure their economies, would just aggravate the problems in each of the countries, officials said, and would favor the banks in debt negotiations.
A precedent for this kind of negotiation - with countries still in arrears - has been established in some of the deals already reached under the debt strategy named for Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady.
Venezuela was $600 million behind in loan payments while negotiating with its commercial bankers. As part of the agreement reached in March, Venezuela paid off these arrears. Costa Rica, which also negotiated while in arrears, agreed to pay off 20 percent of its backlog at the time of its agreement and the rest over several years.
 
'Bankers Were Very Unhappy'
''It is true that bankers were very unhappy with this change in policy,'' said one banker who will be involved in negotiations with Brazil. ''But it is also true that it is probably necessary for the I.M.F. to have negotiations with Brazil because the arrears are so large.''
If the I.M.F. refused aid outright to countries in arrears, added John Williamson, a senior fellow at the Institute for International Economics in Washington, ''the bargaining advantage is too heavily with the commercial banks. By standing pat they could bring all assistance to a country to a halt.''
But Mr. Williamson and the banker insisted that the policy would get out of hand if the I.M.F. didn't insist on strong economic reform programs and some prompt payments to the commerical banks.
 
Argentina Exemplifies the Risks
Argentina is an example of the risks of the arrears policy. Argentina won a standby agreement with the I.M.F. last September and received one payment of $240 million from its $1.4 billion allotment. This agreement came soon after the inauguration of Argentina's new President, Carlos Saul Menem, and amid hope that he would be able to make the changes necessary to bring down rampant inflation and open the economy to foreign investment. But the program has run into serious problems since then, and the I.M.F. has stopped any further aid.
Argentine officials have submitted a new economic program to the I.M.F. and are hoping to get the standby loan reactivated. One official said that ''it's a strong possibility'' the request would be granted.
Brazil can make a stronger case to the I.M.F. for aid. However, even if the I.M.F. approves a standby aid program for Brazil, the arrears problem could still make negotiations with its commerical bankers on debt reduction difficult.
 
Brazil Seeking Debt Reductions
Brazilian officials have said the country would not make payments of more than $5 billion a year on its foreign loans, including those from the international institutions and commerical banks. The Brazilian Ambassador in Washington, Marcilio Marques Moreira, said the Government had not yet decided on its strategy for debt negotiations, except that it will seek substantial debt reductions.
He said that the Government wanted to work out a deal with I.M.F. first so that it could have a ''basic agreement'' before negotiating with the commerical lenders. Such an agreement, which would include I.M.F. approval of the Government's new economic policy, would give Brazil extra support in its negotiations with its bankers.
Another banker who will be involved in negotiaitons with Brazil said he was not too concerned about the $5 billion limit on loan payments. He thinks it is a negotiating position. But, he added, ''No doubt it is going to be a tough negotiation.''
He said that Brazil had more economic potential than Mexico or Venezuela, which have already reached debt agreements under the Brady plan. But President Fernando Collor de Mello must prove that his radical economic program can halt hyper-inflation in Brazil, where prices rose 48-fold in the 12 months through March. The heart of the program is a freeze for 18 months on about 75 percent of the country's bank deposits.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Fund Yields Are Mixed

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields on money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were mixed for the week ended yesterday.
Donoghue's average seven-day compounded yield for a taxable money market fund declined 3 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 7.96 percent, while the 30-day average yield slipped a basis point, to 7.98 percent. The decline is only temporary, analysts say. Indeed, yields on tax-exempt funds rose. 
Walter S. Frank, chief economist at Donoghue's, said the financial markets were exerting some pressure on the Fed to signal some awareness that rates had risen.
Assets of taxable funds declined by $3.5 billion for the week, to a total of $378.1 billion. Assets of institutional funds rose $948 million, to a total of $79.4 billion, while assets of consumer funds fell $4.4 billion, to $298.7 billion.
 
Effect of Tax Filings
Money managers said the decline in consumer assets could be attributed to the tax-filing season, during which many investors paid their taxes by writing checks against their money market funds, and to rising interest rates that have made one-year certificates of deposit and one-year and two-year Treasury securities more attractive.
The average maturity of securities held in managers' portfolios is 44 days. ''If they were worried about higher rates, then the number of days would decline more than where they are now,'' an analyst at Donoghue's said.
Among the general-purpose money market funds with assets of more than $100 million that are surveyed by IBC/Donoghue's, Dreyfus World Wide Dollar Money Market Fund, distributed by the Dreyfus Service Corporation in Garden City, L.I., posted the best return for the week, with a yield of 8.91 percent.
Although yields of tax-exempt funds were up for the week ended yesterday, assets declined by $1.2 billion, to total $75.4 billion. The average seven-day compounded yield rose 5 basis points, to 5.79 percent, for an equivalent yield of 8.04 percent for investors in a 28 percent tax bracket and 8.64 percent for those in a 33 percent bracket.
 
Best Tax-Exempt Yield
Donoghue's said the Calvert Tax Free Reserve California portfolio, distributed by the Calvert Group, Washington, had the best yield for the week. The return was 6.67 percent, about 88 basis points points better than the seven-day average.
By comparison, The Bank Rate Monitor's national index shows bank money market accounts down a basis point, to 6.24 percent, while certificates of deposit were up.

HEADLINE: Dow Rises 20.72 Points in Brisk Trading

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stocks advanced briskly yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average rising 20.72 points, to 2,689.64.
Prices rose despite growing sentiment that the Federal Reserve may raise interest rates to cool off the economy. Program traders, moreover, were noticeably absent. 
Volume fell to 141.6 million shares, from 149 million on Tuesday, with 864 issues rising and 612 declining.
If the Fed increases rates, that will almost certainly lure investors instantly away from the stock market to the higher returns of bonds and money market funds. The bellwether 30-year Treasury bonds, meanwhile, remained steady at 9.02 percent.
The traders said many investors largely ignored new data showing that the economy was expanding because many had already adjusted to the strong possibility that interest rates would be going up.
When asked why the market was so strong, one trader noted that ''The 1990 Stock Traders Almanac,'' published by Yale Hirsch in Old Tappan, N.J., said that for the last 40 years, stock prices have risen 72.2 percent of the time on May 2 - the highest percentage in May.
In Old Tappan, Mr. Hirsch said, ''The market tends to be strongest on the last, first, second, third and fourth days of the month.''
The market could advance again today, the analysts said.
In an announcement that came as a relief to stock and bond traders, the Treasury said well after the end of the trading day that it would raise $30.5 billion next week.
The analysts said that they had expected the total to be that high but that the markets would have been under pressure if the refinancing had been much higher.
In one of the biggest developments of the day, American General, the big Houston insurer, jumped 7 1/2, to 47 5/8, with 7.1 million shares changing hands - by far the most active issue on the New York Stock Exchange. The company said it would put itself on the block.
Among the Dow industrials, I.B.M. rose 1 1/8, to 109 1/8; Primerica 1 1/8, to 30 1/8; USX 7/8, to 34, and Westinghouse a point, to 73 5/8 - all in strong trading. Chevron rose 5/8, to 66 1/8, and Texaco 3/8, to 59. Other oil stocks gained, with Royal Dutch/ Shell up 7/8, to 73 3/4; British Petroleum a point, to 61 1/4, and Amerada Hess 7/8, to 47 1/4.
The Dow transportation stocks rose only 1.78, to 1,138.69, with Union Pacific up a point, to 68 7/8, but UAL down 2 1/4, to 151.
In a move that generally follows the end of an offer to buy a company's stock, Rorer, the drug company, fell 5 1/4, to 64 1/2, with Rhone-Poulenc's offer expiring tomorrow.
Among the indexes, the Standard & Poor's 500 gained 2.23, to 334.48; the Nasdaq composite 1.73, to 423.58, and the American Stock Exchange's market-value 0.91, to 344.23.

HEADLINE: Diamond Sales Outlook

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, May 2

 BODY:
Diamonds are headed for an eighth consecutive year of record sales, the world's biggest producer, De Beers Consolidated Mines Ltd., said today. The South African-based company's chairman, Julian Ogilvie Thompson, said that world retail sales rose 4 percent in 1989 in terms of United States dollars. Growth was particularly strong last year in Europe, where economies were buoyant, and in Japan, where a tax concession on jewelry purchases helped to increase sales. In the United States, the world's largest market for polished diamonds, growth was modest because of an easing in economic activity, Mr. Ogilvie Thompson told thr De Beers shareholders.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mostly Higher; Gold Prices Down Slightly

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended mostly higher yesterday in quiet trading following a mixed performance overseas. Gold prices were slightly lower.
Currency dealers said the markets had little reaction to Government economic reports that pointed to continued strength in the economy. 
The Commerce Department said its index of leading economic indicators rose nine-tenths of 1 percent in March, nearly offsetting a 1 percent drop the previous month. It was the steepest rise since a 1.6 percent gain in June 1988. In another report, the department said factory orders rose 3.8 percent in March, rebounding from January's worst decline in 16 years.
''The numbers were within expectations,'' said Gabriele Schmitt, a corporate trader for the Bank of New York. ''Most of the figures were pretty much priced in.''
She said traders also shrugged off news that East and West Germany had agreed on key terms of their July 2 monetary union, since that announcement was also within expectations.
 
Declines Against Yen
In Tokyo, where global trading begins, the dollar eased to 158.55 yen, from 158.90 yen late Tuesday. The dollar traded at 158.25 yen in London, and at 158.015 yen in New York, down from 158.845.
The dollar was mixed against the British pound from late Tuesday. Sterling sold for $1.6435 in London, up from $1.6385, and for $1.6425 in New York, down from $1.6445.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's quotes, included: 1.6848 West German marks, up from 1.6805; 1.4550 Swiss francs, down from 1.4555; 5.6530 French francs, up from 5.6370; 1,234.75 Italian lire, up from 1,231.75, and 1.16715 Canadian dollars, up from 1.16455.
Late European dollar rates, compared with Tuesday, were: 1.6823 West German marks, up from 1.6785; 1.4535 Swiss francs, down from 1.4545; 5.6425 French francs, up from 5.6365; 1.8910 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8892; 1,232.25 Italian lire, up from 1,231.25, and 1.1672 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1635.
Gold prices fell slightly in New York after rising overseas. On the Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $369.50 a troy ounce, down 50 cents from late Tuesday. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $369.70 an ounce, off 30 cents.

HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe;
Europe Picks Its Lodestar

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, May 3

 BODY:
The NATO alliance and the European Community are now making all their major decisions about the future in the shadow of German strength and Soviet weakness.
The alliance's agreement today to hold a NATO summit meeting in London early this summer to discuss future strategy, the need for nuclear weapons, and its political role in light of impending German unification and continuing Soviet collapse is only the latest example.
The American decision to forgo the modernization of short-range nuclear missiles that both the United States and Britain were insisting on until a year ago, and to cancel plans to modernize nuclear artillery systems stationed in Germany, is another striking illustration. It was warmly welcomed by the West Germans at the NATO foreign ministers' meeting here. 
 
A Respect for Bonn
Here and at a meeting last weekend of European Community leaders in Dublin, the other Europeans - even Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain - have shown a respect for West German positions on political and strategic issues that simply did not exist a year ago.
But a year ago nobody seriously anticipated the possibility of German reunification. Nor did anyone foresee such a rapid decline in Soviet economic and political conditions that, as Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd of Britain put it today, there is ''a serious possibility that the whole thing will crumble'' at a Communist Party conference in Moscow scheduled about the same time as the NATO summit.
''What we're doing,'' a NATO diplomat said, ''is trying to define a vision of the future that both the Germans and the Soviet Union will feel is clearly in their interests.''
 
A Unanimous Affirmation
In line with that approach was the unanimous affirmation by NATO foreign ministers of the idea that a united Germany should remain a full member of the Western alliance, with security guarantees for the Soviet Union and provisions for Soviet troops to remain stationed in eastern Germany for a transitional period.
''A stable, united Germany within secure borders is a loss for no one,'' Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said. And NATO's Secretary General, Manfred Worner, said, ''We have no intention of strengthening the balance in Europe to the detriment of the Soviet Union.''
But to make that clear, diplomats here say, the alliance must seek in the months ahead to redefine itself and reassess the fundamentals that have guided its strategy for 20 years.
The questions range from whether NATO should continue to rely on forward-based nuclear weapons to how many conventional troops the alliance will need to defend itself against the incoherent, ever less threatening, but still sizable military potential of the Soviet Union.
 
Keeping Germans in the Ranks
Any reassessment will also have to produce results acceptable to the Germans. The West German Foreign Minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, warmly welcomed the decision to cancel the modernization of short-range missiles. He and Chancellor Helmut Kohl had long resisted plans to upgrade the missile force. But over coming months and years, NATO diplomats say, the alliance will have to persuade the Germans that they should stay with NATO rather than follow the Soviet Union's call for vaguely defined pan-European security arrangements springing from the framework of the 35-nation Conference for Security and Cooperation in Europe.
To head off the pan-European drive without frightening the Soviets, NATO and the European Community have suggested discussing other roles for the security organization at a 35-nation meeting in Paris this year if the United States and the Soviet Union have reached an agreement on troop reductions. Indeed, NATO ministers were making uncharacteristically solicitous remarks today about President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, no longer the enemy.
In a speech before Mr. Kohl and other German Government officials in Cambridge, England, in March, Mrs. Thatcher suggested that the Conference for Security and Cooperation in Europe could play a mediating role in disputes between member states, hold foreign ministers' meetings twice a year, and institutionalize commitments to free elections, private property and the rule of law.
 
French-German Cooperation
Within the European Community, after a period of nervousness last winter about how rapidly the Germans would proceed toward unification and what they would do to their borders, the postwar pattern of French-German cooperation is again emerging as the core - and perhaps even most of what there is - of the slow progress toward European unity.
Viewed in this light, the sonorous call last month by President Francois Mitterrand of France and Chancellor Kohl for a new drive toward European political unity was simply another way of eliciting a German profession of loyalty and commitment to common Western European values, in the tradition of Adenauer and de Gaulle, or of Helmut Schmidt and Valery Giscard d'Estaing a generation later.
Even Mrs. Thatcher, who said she suspected deeper pan-European political designs that would rob the British Parliament of its hard-won political sovereignty, went along with the call by Paris and Bonn, to the extent of agreeing to commission foreign ministers to study the question of whether the community's charter should be amended to strengthen the commitment to unity by 1993.
 
Eye on Local Politics
The aim of political union, the 12 leaders agreed in Dublin, would be to enable the European Community and its institutions ''to respond efficiently and effectively to the demands of the new situation,'' meaning partly the collapse of communism in Eastern Europe but mostly the reunification of Germany.
For the moment, European politics are still, and perhaps always will be, local politics. Part of the reason for Mr. Kohl's new influence is the respect other leaders have for his success in leading East Germany's Christian Democrats to power there in the March elections, and for the strong showing they expect him to have in the West German elections, possibly the last, set for December.
Mrs. Thatcher, whose party has fared disastrously in opinion polls conducted in the run-up to municipal elections today, was feisty as usual on Saturday at the Dublin meeting. But she was not obstructive about what the Germans clearly wanted: the endorsement of German unity, and some warm words about European unity to go along with it.
 
'Never More at Stake'
What is at issue in all this, as one statesman here observed, is the shape of the Western economic and political community, based on trans-Atlantic partnership and shared cultural values - and the commitment of a united Germany to that Western community.
''There's never been more at stake,'' the official said, ''and the Germans have never been more important to its success than they are now.''
Diplomats and ministers will clearly keep a worried eye on developments in the Soviet Union as they try to chart a course. ''The ambitious goals we have set before us can only be achieved with the success of Gorbachev's proposals for change in the Soviet Union,'' Mr. Genscher said today.

HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe;
Lithuania Premier Sees Bush, But There's No Red Carpet

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 3

 BODY:
Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene of Lithuania was not expecting the White House driveway to be lined with her nation's gold, green and red flags. She was not expecting an honor guard or an Oval Office lunch or a joint departure statement with President Bush on the South Lawn.
She knew there would be no diplomatic fillips because the Bush Administration does not recognize Lithuania's declaration of independence, and because the White House did not want to trumpet the visit for fear of offending the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
But the Prime Minister never expected to have her Lincoln sedan stopped at the White House gate. She did not expect to have to get out of the car, show her red Soviet passport to a security guard, go through a metal detector and walk up the long driveway to the White House on her own. 
White House officials put the best face on the embarrassing do-it-yourself reception, asserting that the driveway gate was broken. But they had no excuse about why there was no one there to greet the Prime Minister until after the party had spent 10 minutes trying to get inside, for what turned out to be a 45-minute meeting with the President.
Mrs. Prunskiene is nothing if not unflappable. If President Vytautas Landsbergis took the hot emotional route in recent remarks, saying that President Bush had sold away Lithuania just as the Allies appeased Hitler in 1938 by allowing Nazi Germany to claim the German-speaking part of Czechoslavakia, Prime Minister Prunskiene took the cool, reasonable approach today as she pleaded her nation's cause with members of Congress, the President and the press.
''Even the world's darling does not have the monopolistic right to decide the fate of other nations,'' she said on Capitol Hill, in a scathing reference to Mr. Gorbachev.
Talking through a translator, she calmly warned that too much sympathy for Mr. Gorbachev soon ''degenerates into toadyism, and the latter gives birth to a cult.''
The Prime Minister's meeting with President Bush, the first direct contact between the White House and a representative of the Vilnius government, was hastily arranged by the White House just two days ago, after Bush officials realized she had a highly visible schedule on Capitol Hill.
She told Mr. Bush that her country would never revoke its declaration of independence, but that it was willing to suspend new laws passed by the Lithuanian Parliament to put into effect the declaration of independence if she received international guarantees. The guarantees would consist of international recognition of the government, of Lithuania's sovereignty and of its boundaries.
President Bush reminded Mrs. Prunskiene of Hungary in 1956, when the Western powers encouraged a rebellion against Soviet domination and then watched helplessly as Soviet Army tanks rolled into Budapest.
''The message was, 'You can't face down the Soviet Union if they don't want to be faced down,' '' said a senior Administration official. ''He told her that the U.S. wants dialogue - talk, talk, talk.''
The official also said the President told the Prime Minister that a compromise proposal on suspending Lithuania's independence laws, recently suggested by President Francois Mitterrand of France and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany, ''had merit.'' The Bush Administration, the official said, had ''privately and earlier suggested something similar.''
 
'Very Impressive Lady'
President Bush found Mrs. Prunskiene ''a very impressive lady, very articulate, very balanced,'' said the official. For her part, the Lithuanian leader was cautiously happy with the meeting. Unlike some members of Congress, who said the summit meeting scheduled for later this month should be postponed, she said she wanted it to go forward, and hoped both leaders would listen ''not only to the voice of the strong but also to the voice of those who are not quite strong.''
She said she told President Bush that she hoped that at the summit meeting, the United States could find a way to take a formal role as a mediator in the dispute between the Soviet Union and Lithuania.
As though he were afraid of letting the self-possessed Lithuanian Prime Minister have the Washington stage to herself, only weeks before the summit is to begin here on May 30, the President held one of his impromptu news conferences this morning and offered his most lavish praise yet of Mr. Gorbachev.
''I salute the man for what he has done,'' Mr. Bush said. ''I think he's under extraordinary pressure at home, particularly on the economy. I do, from time to time, worry about a takeover that will set back the whole process.''
But Mrs. Prunskiene argued that Mr. Gorbachev would become stronger if Lithuania were democratic because it would aid him on overcoming ''the reactionary forces'' who oppose Baltic independence and his program of change.
The President said reports that the Soviet military was pressing Mr. Gorbachev to take a harder line on some arms-control issues were ''a matter of some concern.''
He also cast doubt on the Prime Minister's notion that the United States could mediate the Lithuania dispute. ''If there was a constructive role for the United States, of course, we should fulfill that, but there's not,'' he said.
In an interview in her car, as she drove from the Hill to an appointment with Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger, the Prime Minister warned President Bush and the American people against pursuing a policy that is too dependent on Mr. Gorbachev's future.
''Freedom, like a genie that's been let out of the bottle, doesn't necessarily want to listen to the dictates of the person who uncorked the bottle,'' she said, explaining Lithuania's defiance of Mr. Gorbachev.
She spoke only in passing, and without emotion, of her country's ''difficult times, deprived of oil, most of her gas, metal and other important products.'' She recast the case for her country in logical terms, saying that the United States did not need to choose between helping Lithuania and helping Mr. Gorbachev.
''The solution is this: Gorbachev together with a breakthrough for democracy in the Soviet Union and an independent Lithuania,'' she told the members of Congress on the Helsinki Commission.''
At a dinner tonight, with journalists at the house of Christopher Matthews, a columnist for The San Francisco Examiner, Mrs. Prunskiene was asked why Lithuania had not waited a year to declare its independence.
She smiled and said, ''We felt we had to do it quickly, like a karate chop, if it was to work.''
Mrs. Prunskiene, a 47-year-old economist and former Communist Party official, had a small entourage, no security guards and she rode in a dark-blue sedan paid for by a private person in the Lithuanian-American community. As a translator, she used the head of a Lithuanian-American organization based in Washington.
Even so, she showed a natural aptitude for American politics. When the Prime Minister settled in her room at the Embassy Row hotel here on Wednesday night, her friends and advisers gathered around to counsel her on how to handle the American politicians she would be meeting.
They told her that each politician would think he was more important than the last.
''And my job,'' she said, smiling knowingly, ''is to confirm that.''
