HEADLINE: Developers Offer a Garden to Sell the Kitchen Sink

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
With huge inventories of unsold homes in the New York region and New England, home hunters this spring are being offered an array of offbeat incentives and promotions.
Select the right house and the sellers will throw in the cost of commuting to Manhattan for a year, or a fully landscaped English garden, or a 1984 Mercedes-Benz or an all-expenses-paid vacation to Disney World.
''Price cutting is too commonplace,'' said one developer, Steve Maun. ''We are trying to be creative.''
Mr. Maun is the developer of Horizon Farms, a subdivision in Warwick, N.Y., about 40 miles northwest of New York City, and he thinks one of the top priorities of young home buyers is saving for their children's college expenses. So a buyer at Horizon Farms, at prices from $299,000 to $389,000, gets up to $20,000 in United States Treasury bonds. At their maturity in the year 2008, the bonds will be worth more than $100,000 for college bills. ''It's a natural,'' Mr. Maun said. Other promotions, lacking some of the flair of Mr. Maun's, involve complex negotiations. In some new projects, buyers can sell their old homes to the developer at a guaranteed price. Or they can get reduced-rate mortgage financing. Or they may be given the option of renting for a year and then buying at a pre-established price, with part of the rent going toward the down payment. 
Financial experts say some of the incentives really do reduce buyers' costs or add to the value of homes. But others, they warn, are no more than frivolous prizes in expensive boxes of Cracker Jack.
''Any time a seller is giving something away, it should probably tell you there is room left to negotiate the price,'' said Lowrey Nabb, a broker and president of the Association of Realtors in Houston, where an even deeper real-estate slump led to many promotional giveaways and deep price reductions in the mid-1980's.
In the Northeast, most of the aggressive incentives have cropped up since January and apply to a fraction of the houses on sale. Sellers say it is too early to tell how many buyers will take the promotional bait. Mr. Maun, who began offering his Treasury bonds in March, said two families have been won over so far, signing contracts to buy in his Orange County subdivision. But skeptics are not hard to find. Big Price Cuts ''Any developer who thinks a trip to the Caribbean is going to sell a house is in fantasy land; he should take the trip himself,'' said Jon Gollinger, president of the Collaborative Companies, a Boston concern that is marketing hundreds of homes for struggling developers and banks that have foreclosed on property in the weak New England market.
Mr. Gollinger's approach to selling houses is straightforward: he has cut prices sharply, in some cases 40 percent below what is being asked for comparable houses on the market.
Aggressive marketing and unusual incentives are nothing new to the real-estate market.
During a slump between 1978 and 1982, when interest rates on mortgage loans climbed to more than 15 percent, the catch-all phrase for real-estate promotion was ''creative financing.'' Lenders and sellers concocted a flurry of strategies, taking out second or third mortgages, offering low-rate loans that came fully due in a ''balloon payment'' after five or 10 years and employing even more complex financial acrobatics to keep interest charges down, at least temporarily.
 
Builders and Lenders
But the biggest problems facing sellers in 1990 are not high interest rates. Instead, with 30-year fixed-rate mortgages available at slightly over 10.5 percent, the sluggish sales around New York City and in the Northeast reflect broader problems: a downturn in employment growth, home prices that remain beyond the reach of most potential buyers and a change in buyer psychology that has kept others out of the market because they believe home values will increase little, if at all, during the early 1990's.
Home builders are in a financial squeeze, often putting them in a precarious position with their lenders. In most development financing, the builders stipulate before they begin construction a minimum price that they expect to receive for each home; if they wish to sell at prices below the stipulated amount, they must receive the lender's approval.
That means some are struggling to prop up selling prices, even if it means throwing expensive giveaways into the bargain.
 
'A Very Tough Market'
Still, some real-estate executives say aggressive promotions are less an indication of developers in trouble than of sellers hoping to receive special attention.
''This is a very tough market, and you need a red flag to make a property stand out,'' said Bill Higgins, owner of Higgins Real Estate, a brokerage in Hillsdale, N.J.
Mr. Higgins has persuaded one of his clients, Hill Top Construction, to offer trips to Disney World to buyers of six houses it has been unable to sell in subdivisions in Mahwah, Saddle River and Hillsdale, all priced between $350,000 and $600,000.
Another of his clients, East Crescent Developers, is offering to build, plant and landscape an English garden costing $5,000 for the purchaser of a large five-bedroom house in Mahwah, priced at $589,000.
 
Selling the Old House
''Maybe the cost of the vacation or the garden will simply be reduced from the selling price, but these things draw attention,'' Mr. Higgins said.
Perhaps most unusual in the weak markets of the region are offers by many developers to help buyers sell the homes they are leaving. Large development concerns that have their own brokerage offices are offering to market the homes at a discounted brokerage fee, while others are offering to buy them outright.
''The worst fear among buyers is that they are going to wake up one day owning two homes,'' said Hal Knopf, the broker for Lion Estates, a subdivision of 30 homes priced at $389,000 to $560,000 in Rockville Centre, L.I.
The developer for the subdivision, Joel Chinman, is offering a ''guaranteed sale'' to those who want to buy in Lion Estates but must first sell their present houses. Although people taking advantage of the offer may not be thrilled by the price they receive, Mr. Knopf said, the promotion ''gives them a safety net.'' He said half the Lion Estates houses have been sold, and two of the buyers have taken up his offer to buy their old houses.
 
Renting With Option
Another strategy becoming widespread in the Northeast is the ''rent to buy'' option offered by many sellers. One is John Wallice, president of the Glen Hudson Development Corporation of Huntington, L.I. He is trying to sell 22 units at Indian Trace, a town house condominium complex in Smithtown. The prices range from $185,000 to $200,000.
Other, more unusual incentives have been tried but failed.
Since September, the AmeriFederal Savings Bank of Lawrenceville, N.J., has been trying to sell new three-story town houses at New Colony, a project designed in part to spur an economic rebirth in its neighborhood, the Mill Hill district of downtown Trenton.
One promotion is AmeriFederal's offer to cover commutation costs for a year for buyers who work in Philadelphia or in Manhattan. So far, no big-city commuters have taken the bait.
The biggest incentive is cut-rate financing, which the bank said it was able to provide because it received $1 million in cut-rate loans from the State of New Jersey. Thirty-year fixed-rate mortgages are being offered to buyers at 8.375 percent interest.
The bank has received tax abatements for the Colony Hill buyers, reducing their bills by 50 percent for 15 years. Monthly common charges on the town houses, which are operated as condominiums, have been reduced to $77, from $100 a month.
The bank has also cut prices, from between $148,000 and $162,000 to between $118,000 and $132,000. Ten of the 19 town houses have been sold.
One determined family is the Ansorges of West Windsor, N.J. In a sequence of events not unlike those affecting other anxious sellers in the region, the Ansorges have come under pressure to sell their house because Harry Ansorge, a senior copyright lawyer for Bristol-Myers Squibb, has been transferred.
With their 3-year-old son, they have signed a contract to buy a cooperative apartment on the East Side of Manhattan, close to Mr. Ansorge's new office, and they plan to move by July.
In addition to reducing the asking price, the Ansorges are now offering to throw in a symbol of suburban affluence - their blue 1984 Mercedes-Benz, which they say is worth more than $20,000.
''A lot of people might dream of a Mercedes but never take the initiative,'' Mr. Ansorge said, sounding more like a television pitch man than a corporate lawyer. ''Here is their chance.''

HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe;
Excerpts From Session By Bush on Arms Talks

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Bush's White House news conference yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:
 
OPENING STATEMENT
The revolutions of '89, 1989, that have brought democracy to Eastern Europe, the prospect of German unification, and my hope for rapid conclusion of a C.F.E. agreement bring us close to a peaceful and more stable Europe, whole and free. . . .
We've arrived at this historic point by maintaining a strong partnership with our European allies. NATO will remain vital to America's place in Europe. It is a proven structure upon which to base our security and from which to promote a stable, cooperative European order. The alliance is now ready to take on new challenges, and in order to set a new Western strategy for these times, and after consulting personally with my allied colleagues - a consultation completed by Secretary Baker in Brussels today - I'm calling for a NATO summit in early -in early summer, late June or early July, probably.
A fundamental purpose of this summit should be to launch a wide-ranging NATO strategy review for the transformed Europe of the 1990's. To provide direction for this, I suggest that this summit should address first the future political mission of the alliance, reaffirming its crucial role in managing and stabilizing the transformation of Europe. 
Second, the alliance's conventional defenses for the future, and next steps for conventional arms control. While we're still in a period of transition, as Soviet forces leave Eastern Europe and our arms-control works move forward, we need to develop a new strategy for the period ahead. And third, the role of U.S. nuclear forces in Europe. As democracy comes to Eastern Europe and Soviet troops return home, there is less need for nuclear systems of the shortest range.
 
Short-Range Misslile Talks
And in response to these new conditions, I've decided to terminate the follow-on to Lance program, and cancel any further modernization of U.S. nuclear artillery shells deployed in Europe. The NATO summit should agree on broad objectives for future negotiations between the United States and the Soviet Union on the current short-range nuclear missile forces in Europe, which should begin shortly after a C.F.E. treaty has been signed.
Fourth, the future of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, C.S.C.E., to give it and especially its Eastern European member states a more active part in shaping Europe's future. The C.S.C.E. can help to build free societies and provide a forum for political dialogue in a united Europe. My allied colleagues and I should agree to take up these ideas at the C.S.C.E. summit this fall, to be held around the signing of a C.F.E. treaty.
The future of the United States cannot be separated from the future of Europe, and so along with our allies we must prepare for the magnificent opportunities that lie ahead. In these times of uncertainty and hope, NATO will continue to be vital to America's place in Europe and a bulwark of democratic values and security. So this is what I'll be talking about tomorrow, and it has been discussed by Jim Baker with our allies in Brussels yesterday and today. . . .
 
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
Q. Mr. President, you said that things were moving on the hostage front, and can I ask you what are the prospects of getting all the hostages out? They may sometimes feel like sacrificial lambs as the U.S. stands and waits. What good-will gesture do you have in mind to facilitate this and expedite their release?
A. I would have in mind any gesture that wouldn't be perceived as negotiating for the release of hostages. We have a policy. I'm going to stay with that policy. But let me give you an example, Helen. One of the things that the Iranians are interested in is the fate of -I believe it was four? - four Iranians that were taken, I think, back in '82. Now if there's some way that we can go back and get any information that would relieve the anxieties of the loved ones of those four people, we ought to do that.
And it is our view - and I have said this, made this clear - that it is the best information we have that these people are not alive. But just as we'd like a full accounting for Higgins, our heroic Marine that apparently has been killed, I can understand the Iranians wanting a full accounting, even though they know we have nothing to do with this.
So here's an area where they have said they'd like some information and if we can get it, I think we ought to get it, and we're trying. So if that is good will, so be it. I hope it is. That's the way I would intend it. And there may be other things we can do. But look, I understand the anxiety of the hostage families and I can understand the broken hearts, and that's why I'm not going to shift and act like everything is normal.
Q. Are you passing this word to Iran, and also in terms of the frozen assets?
A. Well, that's been going on, as you know, some discussion on frozen assets. Abe Sofaer's been over there. So, and if they view that as good will, fine. And if that can continue now in some way, fine. But that we've already discussed and opened, and I'm not sure they would view that as enough, you know?
Q. Is it brighter, though?
A. . . . Look, I have tried very hard not to raise the hopes of the hostage families only to have them dashed. And there's a certain cruelty in this process. When you flash a picture of a person that's held hostage and then another person appears in freedom. I welcome the release of Polhill and Reed, but I can't rejoice and say that my heart is full of great good will as long as six others are held hostage. . . .
 
Penalties for Moscow
Q. Mr. President, within the last few weeks you've been considering penalties against Moscow for its treatment of Lithuania. Now, however, you're liberalizing sales of computers and other hard technology to Moscow. Senator D'Amato, among others, says that now is not the time to be nice to the Soviet Union. Why have you decided on this course of reward rather than punishment?
A. Well, I don't consider the COCOM re-evaluation as a policy of reward. I'll have to discuss that with Al D'Amato to see that he understands the facts, because what we're doing is putting up tighter walls around needed items that are in the national security interest. And then where there aren't - when the other items that are not on the list for pure national security now, they're going to come off. And I don't view this as giving something to the Soviets at all.
 
Gorbachev's Future
Q. The May Day parade where Mr. Gorbachev was heckled - your Defense Secretary says that he doesn't think that Mr. Gorbachev can succeed with his reforms. Do you?
A. The May Day parade? He ought to come join some of the parades I go to around here. . . . That's the fruits of democracy. He's just learning. He's just learning. So, I wouldn't read too much into that. Yes, there's some discontent. And a lot of it relates to the economy. And some of it relates, by Lithuanians inside the Soviet Union, to the handling of Lithuania. But that's what's, there's a good side to all of this. I sometimes ask myself if that's true. But it is. Because that's the way, you know, fledgling democracies are beginning to work. And that's the way our system has worked. And I don't suppose, if everybody - anytime anyone points to a vi - a demonstration that gets rambunctious in the United States and points to 'that means instability in the United States system,' there's got to be something crazy. Because that isn't the way it works.
 
Foreign-Aid Review
Q. What about a full-scale review of American's foreign aid requirements? Are you interested in doing one of those or not?
A. Well, I'd be interested in a full-scale review. I mean, we've heard a lot - you know, a lot of our percentage of aid goes to a handful of countries. And here we have a man coming in here today, Prime Minister of Jamaica, Mr. Manley, who has just done a first-class job in trying to move Jamaica forward in many, many ways. And I salute him for that. But his aid was a small amount and I believe it's been just lined out because of insufficient resources, or failure to reallocate. I've suggested that the President be given a discretionary fund out of all this foreign aid so we can accommodate a person that is trying to take his small country and firm up its democracy.
 
Policy on Beijing
Q. Mr. President, it's been nearly a year since the Tiananman Square massacre. Can you point to anything in the last year in your policies there - improve the situation there after a year of trying to head off severe sanctions and keep the rhetoric down?
A. Several things. I've already mentioned them, and I'd repeat - you know, Fulbright and Peace Corps and some of these matters. But I'm disappointed. I've said that publicly before, and I am. Because I would like to think there would be a more vigorous response. I was pleased that they lifted martial law in Tibet the other day, so there are some things that are happening that are going in the right direction. But overall, I'm disappointed.
And yet, preserving a relationship with the People's Republic of China in the broad, global context is important. And so I've no apologies, I have no feeling that I took the wrong path. I mean, we did, by Executive action, what - everything that the Congress would have done by legislative action. Everything. And so there wasn't any substantive difference with the Congress on this. And so - but look, I'll express a certain disappointment because I'd like to see more action, more things happen that really move the whole process forward.
 
Nuclear-Arms Talks
Q. Mr. President, do you think your proposal on nuclear weapons in Europe will be enough for the Soviet Union to accept a reunified Germany within NATO?
A. Our policy on what?
Q. Your change on nuclear weapons in Europe.
A. You mean on the Lance follow-on?
Q. Will that be enough for the Soviet Union to accept a unified Germany?
A. I think they're going to accept it because that's the right thing to have happened. And I want to see that determined by the alliance, and keep the solid alliance position. And I want to see the Soviet understand that it is in their interest for a U.S. presence, in their interest for an expanded NATO, in their interest on a united Germany to be inside that expanded NATO. . . .
Q. Mr. President, the Soviets seem to be backpedaling on both Start, on the cruise missiles, and some of the things we think they agreed to on troop levels and C.F.E. Are you concerned about this? And what's your assessment now of the prospects for both a Start treaty and a C.F.E. treaty this year?
A. We're going to have to hustle, we're going to have to hustle. And they're going to have to come forward. I don't want to say we're not going to get a C.F.E. agreement and I don't want to say we're not going to get the principles of a Start agreement locked in. And that's what I'd like to see happen. And the summit that's coming up serves as some incentive for that to take place.
 
Relations With Mexico
Q. Mr. President, do you think that the relations with Mexico have been damaged by the Machain case and can the United States pay bounty to foreigners to abduct people in other countries?
A. I, you know the United States has had a system of, official system of rewards, you remember at the time of Noriega and stuff, there were some rewards out. But I don't, I hope the relations haven't been damaged. The Vice President, incidentally, did a very, very good job in explaining the policy to President Salinas himself. Our Attorney General has worked very closely with the Mexicans. We have had superb cooperation from Mexico in fighting drugs, outstanding. And so I salute them. But yes, there were some misunderstanding here and I've told our key people eliminate the misunderstanding. We don't want misunderstanding with Mexico. We don't need it. We need continued cooperation and we're getting continued --
Q. But in the future, are they going to continue going into Mexico, the agents of the --
A. That's a matter for Mexico to decide. And if Mexico wanted to have some people work with our people here, and that could help the fight against narcotics, I would be very open to that if it fit into our fight against drugs.
 
U.S. Troops and Peru
Q. I want to know if you're going to ask permission from Congress to send U.S. troops into Peru and take $35 million of our much needed money right now and build a military installation down there for us to train their troops to fight drug cartels.
A. To send U.S. troops in there to do that?
Q. Are you going to ask Congress for permission to do that?
A. I have not considered asking Congress for that. But, if Peru, if there's some training role that will facilitate the fight against drugs I would be willing to consider it. But I have no intention of asking Congress at this moment for anything of that nature.
Q. Do you feel now that you have the authority to send, to build this installation, which has been reported that you were planning to build down there in Peru.
A. Just a minute. I need expert advice on that.
You're talking about building a facility. We'll have to get back to you. You see the kind of advice I'm getting here. No, really, I'm sorry, but I just don't know about any facility. But I do know that the concept of training is a very valid concept. I don't think it requires approval from the United States Congress, but if the law requires me ask if we do something that's going to require that along the lines here, then I'd, I would ask. We're not trying to get around Congress. We work very cooperatively with them. . . .
 
Iranian Hostages
Q. Earlier you dropped a hint about the United States helping obtain the release of some Iranian hostages. Who's got them and how could you help?
A. These were diplomats, these were four Iranian diplomats that were taken in Lebanon in 1982. And they, the Iranians don't feel that they've had a full accounting of these people. In fact, I think they still hope that those people are alive. The best information we have as an outside party to all of this is that they are not still alive. But my point is, if Iran feels that way and the families of these four people feel that way, this is something where we should use every, every asset we have to, to disperse the lack of information, to bring them the facts, if we can. And see, this is something they feel strongly about. They've mentioned it to us several different times. And here's something we can do without there being any, violating our policy. It's something I'd like to do. And I think they would consider this a gesture of good will. So we're trying very hard again. I wish I felt that the answer we gave them would be different than the one. Because there's a human equation here. There is some suffering here on families in Iran, and so it's you know.

HEADLINE: Stutter-Step Democracy in Korea

 BODY:
Thousands of riot police storm the world's largest shipyard, at Ulsan, South Korea, to break up a strike and sit-in by workers. Two days later, they club strikers at the Government-run Korean Broadcasting System. Is this the new democratic South Korea? 
Yes, and democracy is an important factor in how the U.S. should respond. It is for Korean voters, not Washington, to pass judgment on how their freely elected Government conducts domestic affairs. Still, in light of the importance of U.S. economic and military ties with Korea, any threat of a return by Seoul to the discredited repressive ways of the past is a legitimate cause for U.S. concern.
President Roh Tae Woo deserves great credit for his role in peacefully moving South Korea to a democratic path. His efforts made free, fair presidential elections possible in 1988. After his election, he worked with opposition parties when they controlled the legislature, proposing useful, though incomplete, social and economic reforms.
But democratization is not yet secure. President Roh's own mandate rests on less than an absolute majority. And while the merger he recently engineered with former opposition parties is legal, it has stifled democratic give-and-take. Steady progress has now given way to a stutter-step.
President Roh has yielded to big-business pressure and pulled back from some of his bolder proposals for financial reform. With Korea's annual growth rate down from an astonishing 12 percent to a merely robust 6.5 percent, he has grown nervous about anything that might threaten business confidence. That nervousness explains the Government's violent assaults on labor. Repression has brought a dose of confidence to a shaky stock market. But it also risks setting off a dangerous backlash.
For generations, rural Koreans deferred to authority, according to Confucian tradition. Today's urbanized, educated population is less docile. Koreans, as they showed in 1988, insist on a significant say in their own affairs. So long as the authorities are facing down relatively isolated labor militants or student radicals, they will likely prevail. But when, as in 1988, wider sections of society conclude that the Government is acting unjustly, the tables can abruptly turn.
President Roh has, until now, shown himself astute enough to keep his balance. But neither he, nor Korean democracy, can afford to rest on past achievements.

HEADLINE: U.S. Aid to Peru Military Is Blow to Democracy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The Bush Administration's new $35 million program to aid the Peruvian military (front page, April 22) in fighting guerrillas involved in the drug trade carries the risk of exacerbating human rights violations in Peru.
The announcement could not have been worse timed. The first round of presidential elections was held in Peru in April, and the two top candidates, Mario Vargas Llosa and Alberto Fujimori, face a runoff in May. By announcing the new aid program in the midst of these presidential elections, the United States has signaled the irrelevance of civilian leadership in Peru and has strengthened the military against the new president. The result could be the weakening of democracy in Peru and the deterioration of Peru's human rights record, one of the worst in Latin America. 
Democracy is a fragile institution in Peru. The country has been dominated by military dictators for most of its history. The 1985 election of President Alan Garcia was one of the rare times since the country became independent in 1821 that power was transferred from one democratically elected leader to another.
Even under civilian rule, the military has retained a large measure of independence. About two-thirds of Peru is under emergency law. In these parts of the country, all power has been ceded to the military, leading to increasing human rights violations in the fight against the leftist Shining Path guerrillas.
Since the guerrillas first became active in 1980, more than 18,000 people have died in fighting or disappeared. Of these, roughly half are attributable to the military, in a dirty war beginning to look more and more like the situation in Argentina in the early 1980's. In some instances, the military has slaughtered entire male populations in the desperately poor Andean villages where the guerrillas derive most of their support.
Although President Garcia took office amid pledges to respect human rights, his authority has been severely weakened by Peru's economic crisis, and he has virtually no power to control human rights violations by the military. So complete is the military control in emergency zones that army officers have been able to prohibit Peruvian governmental commissions created to investigate human rights abuses from even entering the areas where violations are said to have taken place.
The last thing the United States Government should do is bypass Peru's civilian government and deal directly with the military. Yet by signing the new aid agreement before the new president is even chosen, that is essentially what the United States has done.
Although the agreement apparently contains promises that the Peruvian Government will improve its human rights record, promises by the military are worthless. The best way to improve Peru's rights record is to strengthen the authority of the new president. Instead, the Bush Administration has chosen to bolster the independence of the often brutal Peruvian military.
 
LAUREN K. SAUNDERS
Los Angeles, April 26, 1990
 The writer, a public interest lawyer, spent two months in 1988 in Peru under Harvard Law School's Human Rights Program.

HEADLINE: The Unscientific Charm of the Big Bang

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It is playing to the grandstand or ignoring direct observation to try and rationalize the superconducting supercollider project by claiming it will illuminate the first few femtoseconds following the big bang (letter by Sidney D. Drell et al., April 4).
The big bang is a charming literary conception, but is it science? What this means can be clarified by a classic story about Wolfgang Pauli, the late, great, sometimes irascible physicist. Dunned for his report on an article he was supposed to referee, he replied: ''That paper isn't even good enough to be wrong!'' In Pauli's sense, the big bang may be just barely good enough to be wrong, but there is no positive support for it in clearly disinterested direct observation. 
Indeed, of its two pillars, the Hubble Law and the cosmic microwave background, the first is supported only by data gathered largely assuming the Hubble Law, and indulging in other elementary statistical improprieties.
It is rejected by efficient statistical analysis of the clearly disinterested galaxy samples now available. The observed black-body form of the cosmic microwave background is simply the most likely disposition of remnants of light on a purely random basis, assuming the classic principle of the conservation of energy, and is not at all uniquely indicative of a big bang. In any event it is consistent with the big bang only in conjunction with the ingenious but contrived hypothesis called inflation, which is not testable by practical direct observations.
The scientific case for the superconducting supercollider is seriously weakened by representing it as a handmaiden to the big bang. I hope it can be built, but it is important to discuss it in a scientifically responsible and equitable way.
 
I. E. SEGAL
Cambridge, Mass., April 11, 1990
 The writer is professor of mathematics emeritus at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

HEADLINE: Baruch College, Proud of Its Record, Seeks Minority Faculty

 BODY:
To the Editor:
We, department chairmen of the School of Business and Public Administration of Baruch College of the City University of New York, wish to respond to your April 5 and April 18 articles about minority representation in our faculty and administration.
We are proud to belong to the long tradition of public education that began with the establishment of the Free Academy in 1847. The mission of this college has always been the superior education of students from diverse ethnic and racial origins, training them to be the skilled professionals required by the city's economy. The school provides access to career opportunities and social advancement that our students would not otherwise have; for example, within a year after graduation many of our students are the principal wage earners of their families. The path of upward mobility is open to all who would take advantage of it, and we take pride in enrolling more black and Hispanic students in business-degree programs than any other college in the country. 
The programs of our business school are accredited by the American Assembly of Collegiate Schools of Business, the Accrediting Commission on Education for Health Services Administration and the National Association of Schools of Public Administration. These accreditations signal international recognition of quality and achievement. Baruch graduate students had the highest pass rate in the country on the November 1988 certified public accountant exams, and CUNY-Baruch ranks eighth nationally among colleges whose graduates are partners in the big six accounting firms.
Among masters-degree-granting economics and finance departments, ours ranked first nationally in the frequency with which their articles are cited in the professional literature. This record of achievement grows out of the commitment to excellence in teaching and research that attracts more than 350 companies and government agencies to recruit our students.
Our recruitment of faculty and administration is blind to color, ethnicity and gender. It is distressing but a fact of life that some minorities are woefully underrepresented in the doctoral programs from which we draw our faculty. We will continue to seek out qualified minorities, and call upon the community - government, business and alumni - to provide the resources to further our responsibilities.
 
STEVEN B. LILIEN
HOWARD N. ROSS, E. S. SAVAS
New York, April 19, 1990
 The letter was signed also by five other Baruch department chairmen.

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
Iraq's U.S. Support

BYLINE: By William Safire

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
At 4:15 on a recent Friday afternoon - which, in the nation's capital, is the news equivalent of the dead of night - the Department of Agriculture put out a short release: a team of its officials had left for Iraq to look into ''possible irregularities'' in our Government guarantees of bank loans to finance purchase of U.S. commodities.
When a bureaucracy protects itself with a phrase like ''possible irregularities,'' look out.
Officials are now doing their best to put together a report that will not displease President Saddam Hussein, but there is this problem:
Thanks to our generous loan guarantees (now up to a billion dollars a year to Iraq), Baghdad has been buying U.S. farm products - but at considerably above world prices. In some cases - corn, for example -Iraq has often paid 10 to 15 percent above the market. 
Why? The Iraqis are not babes in the woods when it comes to bargaining, and the sales are risk-free; payment to our exporters is guaranteed by the U.S. One possibility: something about doing business with Iraq limits the field of sellers and makes possible the high pricing.
Another possible reason for the whopping difference in price is called ''excess markup diverted for an improper purpose.'' This translates to what Middle East traders call baksheesh - kickbacks to Iraqi Government officials or businessmen, which the American taxpayer is not supposed to guarantee.
Moreover, from 1985 through 1987, a period during the Iran-Iraq war in which a billion dollars in U.S. guarantees went to our preferred warriors, the cost of freight was not included in our guarantee. The full guarantee was supposed to help U.S. farmers, not foreign shippers.
However, Department of Agriculture officials - prodded by hints of wrongdoing in this space and from the U.S. Attorney's office in Atlanta - have stumbled over some funny business in the files.
The cost of freight to Iraq can amount to one-fourth of the price of a ton of corn, and it seems that - contrary to law at the time - freight was being underwritten by the American taxpayer. We'll get some of the details when Paul Dickerson's report is made available to the Congress.
That's where Senators Daniel Inouye and Bob Kasten of Senate Appropriations, and Representative Howard Berman of House Foreign Affairs, have put forward bills to stop all aid and technology transfer to the nation that gasses its Kurds, develops missiles to deliver binary poison gas warheads, and hangs a newsman who dared investigate a mysterious explosion.
Will the abuse of the loan guarantee appropriation in 1987, and the suspected skimming of ''excess markups'' by corrupt Iraqis and middlemen, help these legislators put through the Iraqi Sanctions Act of 1990?
Second question: Will the Justice Department and Federal Reserve investigations of Iraq's abuse of the U.S. banking system - running a billion in secret financing through the Atlanta branch of Italy's Lavoro bank - lead to indictments in coming weeks, adding to the urgency of the need for sanctions?
You might think so, but do not overlook the relentlessly pro-Iraq tilt of the Bush White House or Saddam Hussein's new supporter, Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole of corn-producing Kansas.
What's with the New Dole? It's as if a combination of his Armenian defeat, old anti-Israeli resentments and Kansas corn interests suddenly let the dark out.
Nowhere can the mind-set of Senator Dole better be seen than in the transcript of the meeting he and four other senators held with Saddam Hussein in Baghdad on April 12. (Somebody should put that complete transcript, proudly broadcast by Baghdad radio as evidence of the dictator's clout with U.S. leaders, into the Congressional Record.) Senator Dole assured the Iraqi strongman that the Voice of America had taken action against the staffer who had offended him recently: ''That person was fired.'' (Wholly untrue: the writer of the pro-human-rights editorial is still on the job.) Senator Dole also hastened to remind Mr. Hussein that ''we condemned the Israeli attack in 1981'' (a point he did not remind Americans of when running for President) and shared his assessment of pending legislation: ''I assume Bush will object to the sanctions. He may veto them, unless something provocative occurs.''
Suspicion of scandal is minor provocation, not on a scale with gassings and hangings, but if serious investigations develop - 'tis enough, 'twill do.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

CITY: BAGHDAD, IRAQ (78%); 

COMPANY: MIDDLE EAST TRADERS LLC (54%); VOICE OF AMERICA (59%); VOICE OF AMERICA (59%);

HEADLINE: Newark's New Image Buoys Mayor on Eve of Election

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWARK, May 3

 BODY:
Every city has its symbol, and Newark's may still be the 1967 riots that scorched the city and left 23 people dead. But Sharpe James, a believer in the strength of symbols, has spent as much time over his four years as mayor trying to change that image as he has trying to solve the most serious problems.
Mr. James spent $100,000 to install 775 nylon banners printed with flags or civic messages on downtown lampposts. Changing the banners every six months costs $30,000. He knows the banners may not help the 100,000 residents on public assistance nor shelter the 16,000 homeless people nor reduce the 50 percent high-school dropout rate. But he said he believed they were absolutely necessary.
''What they are is like the eagle somebody puts over a garage,'' he said. ''It just says: 'I live here. I care.' '' 
 
Bond Rating Upgraded to BBB+
As Mr. James approaches the election next Tuesday unopposed for a second term, business and community leaders give him high marks for image building and say there is substance behind the symbols.
The state's largest home builder is putting up 1,100 residences in the Central Ward. For the first time in 20 years the city's bond rating has been upgraded, to BBB+ from BBB, saving the city millions in interest.
Business leaders say the plans of Blue Cross-Blue Shield of New Jersey to move 2,500 workers from the suburbs to a new office tower downtown show that Newark is bouncing back.
No one, not even Mr. James, believes all the problems have been solved. Crime and drug abuse are still out of control. Much of the housing is substandard, and rents are still climbing. Schools are old and often wild, and children born here have a 1-in-5 chance of dying before reaching their first birthday. Still, using his energy and the talents of newly hired employees, as well as big corporations, Mr. James has managed to keep many of the promises he made in 1986, when he turned out his solidly entrenched predecessor, Kenneth A. Gibson, the first black mayor of a major Northeastern city. Mr. James has gained national attention as a second-generation black mayor in a city where members of minority groups are no longer satisfied just to have one of their own in City Hall. Having severely criticized Mr. Gibson in the campaign, Mr. James has had to deliver a combination of economic development, municipal services and fiscal accountability downtown and in the neighborhoods.
In a city that once seemed to have lost hope, many of Mr. James's initiatives have been symbolic, like the banners on Broad Street, the newly organized mounted police, the hundreds of new trees and a new law that requires security gates on downtown stores to be open meshed, so the city does not appear to be under seige.
Residents and community leaders said the biggest change in this city of 315,000, founded in 1666 by a band of Puritans searching for a heaven-on-earth, may be a can-do attitude, personified by the Mayor's unstoppable image.
''He has uplifted the spirit of the city,'' E. James Ferland, chairman of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company, which has its headquarters in Newark, said at a recent gathering of executives at the newly refurbished Newark Museum. ''He has changed the way Newark thinks about itself and the way others think about Newark.''
Much of the turnabout is a spillover from the state's economic vigor of the 80's. Newark was late in reaping the benefits of that expansion, but now it remains active while the suburbs have grown quieter.
Richard W. Roper, director of the program for New Jersey affairs at the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs at Princeton University, said Mr. James's personal energy and enthusiasm for leadership suited Newark's needs in the mid-80's in much the same way that the low-key style of Mr. Gibson fit the need for calm in the contentious days of the 1970's.
There are other differences between the two men that reflect their contrasting styles and differing challenges.
 
Changes in Circumstances
''Gibson focused at the beginning on direct delivery of social and human services,'' Mr. Roper said. But as the 80's began, the Federal assistance supporting such programs evaporated, and ''it was clear that by Gibson's third-term economic development was what he should have been attempting to secure for the community.''
The people of Newark had observed Mr. James from 1970 to 1986 as a maverick City Council member, with independent ideas and humorous barbs as his trademark, but lacking a clear agenda. By the time he took over at City Hall, the people were demanding safe streets and affordable housing and they wanted them at once.
''Ken Gibson was a hero,'' Mr. James said in a recent interview. ''I'm supposed to be a miracle worker.''
Mr. James spends as much time in the streets as in City Hall and said he felt the impatience keenly. ''I got elected by criticizing an entrenched black leader,'' he said. ''The day I took over, the people wanted me to solve all the problems.''
 
Administrator From Atlanta
His first priority was to avoid the mistakes of other black mayors who, after winning City Hall, had rewarded supporters by giving them jobs without regard to ability.
Mr. James conducted a national search for staff members. His most important appointment was Richard A. Monteilh as business administrator. Mr. Monteilh was administrative and financial officer of Atlanta and had earned a national reputation for an efficient, responsible style.
Mr. James and Mr. Monteilh began by hiring the accounting firm of Coopers & Lybrand to study management; 700 recommendations came out of the study. The most important dealt with improving the 80 percent rate for collecting taxes, water bills, parking tickets and other fees. The city became tough, putting liens on properties, turning off water and towing scofflaws' cars. The collection rate is up to 95 percent, and revenues have risen $30 million.
 
Conflict With School Board
Although many lots remain, more than $3 billion in commercial development has been completed or proposed since 1986, and 2,000 houses and apartments have been built. The city also won state support for a proposed $200 million performing-arts center.
Despite the general smoothness of his first term, Mr. James has had setbacks. He has engaged in a running battle with the Board of Education over patronage, accountability and its $421 million budget. By comparison, the city budget is $346 million. Last week voters approved a budget for the next school year despite his opposition.
 
Jump in Infant Mortality
Poverty and unemployment rates remain significantly higher than the state average, the incidence of AIDS is among the highest of any major city in the nation, and recently there has been a troubling rise in infant mortality, which jumped from 15.5 percent in 1987 to 19.3 percent in 1988, according to the latest available figures. The state average is 9.8 percent.
City officials said drug abuse, in particular crack, is at the root of many of those problems.
Mr. James also fought for control of the Housing Authority. This year he won the power to appoint its members, but he has been stymied in his plan to demolish most of the hellish high-rise projects until the units to be destroyed are replaced one for one.
Critics fault the Mayor for being too eager to promote the city and offer tax abatements to developers. ''If the city is going to give abatements and land, it should get something more in return,'' said Victor DeLuca, executive director of the Ironbound Community Corporation and a candidate for councilman-at-large. Mr. James said it was the abatements that kept developers interested in Newark when they abandoned the suburbs.
 
Impatience With Small Details
In an interview at City Hall, Mr. James said he had grown more cooperative in four years and he conceded one longstanding fault, an impatience with the small details of government.
''I hate meetings just for meetings' sake,'' he said. ''I'm a problem solver. I'm not a numbers person. I don't sit down and play with slide rules and calculators. I have a hard time reading my telephone bill.''
Though he professes to not being a fiscal expert, Mr. James said the two accomplishments he is proudest of are the upgrading of the bond rating and keeping administrative budget increases to below 4 percent every year.
In his next term he plans to focus on adding police officers, building rental housing and improving schools.
Bettering the image also remains high on his list, even if many of the efforts are purely symbolic. He recently decided not to replace his 1986 Lincoln with a new car. But he did have the license plates changed, from NWK 86 to NWK 90.
''If you can't buy a new suit, you buy new shoes,'' he said. ''Putting 90 on there makes it feel new.''

CORRECTION-DATE: May 9, 1990, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article on Friday about Sharpe James's first term as Mayor of Newark misstated the infant mortality rates for Newark and New Jersey. In 1988, the last year for which figures are available, the city's rate was 19.3 per 1,000 births, and the state's was 9.8 per 1,000.

HEADLINE: LAW;
The fleecing of the client, a cautionary report about the lawyer's conflict of interest.

BYLINE: By David Margolick

 BODY:
''Tell me a man is dishonest, and I will answer he is no lawyer,'' Daniel Webster told the Charleston, S.C., bar in 1847. ''He cannot be, because he is careless and reckless of justice; the law is not in his heart, is not the standard and rule of his conduct.''
It is a lofty ideal. But Lisa Lerman, a law professor at Catholic University in Washington, reports that it is also a self-serving myth. That, at least, is what is suggested by her interviews with 20 lawyers. Once promised anonymity, they spoke with her with a candor and contrition more appropriate to a confessional than a scholarly journal. 
All lawyers face a fundamental conflict of interest, between clients and careers, Professor Lerman writes in the current issue of University of Pennsylvania Law Review. The latter usually prevails, particularly in times of cutthroat competition and straitened economics. But never, never is the client to know.
What results is a House of Games, a panoply of deceits: padding bills, puffing expertise, ducking responsibility, meter-running, posterior-covering. Lying to clients, she writes, is ''a serious and pervasive problem'' in law firms, whose subculture ''does not put much emphasis on truthfulness.'' Or, as she paraphrases Nietzsche, for some lawyers, ''lies are necessary in order to live.''
Professor Lerman concedes her survey is not scientific. What she did, essentially, was turn over 20 rocks at random, and with great delicacy.
The lawyers who spoke with her -most of them youngish and in private practice - were given comic strip pseudonyms like ''Miles Marcus,'' ''Beth Forrester,'' ''Martin Richards,'' and ''Alison Price,'' with a ''Deborah Greenberg'' and ''Arthur Katz'' thrown in for flavor. No locales are mentioned; presumably they work in Metropolis and Gotham City. Once she got her quotations, all interview tapes were promptly destroyed.
Some of these lawyers practice in the personal injury bar, which tony lawyers have always loved to hate. One, ''David Larsen,'' tells of a defense lawyer who settled a $100,000 case for $4,700 because he was short of cash. But the professor's examples suggest that cheating may be even more rife in the ostensibly impeccable large firms, whose clients have deeper pockets and, often, less of a ringside seat.
The lawyers describe a world in which clients can be charged just about anything. There is the tale of a client who farmed out similar assignments to two firms, and got bills of $100,000 from one and $5,000 from the other.
''Winston Hall,'' described as ''an associate at a large firm,'' tells of how his employer updated Robin Hood to the Boesky era, regularly bilking the mega-rich, often foreigners. He put the prevailing attitude this way: ''They've got so much money in these countries where there is nothing to buy, they might as well give it to me.''
Then there is ''Mary Helen Murphy,'' an associate at a ''middle-sized firm'' who recalls her futile efforts to blow the whistle on a senior associate who, under pressure to get his billable hours up, routinely charged a couple of clients for 12 to 16 hours of labor a day when he averaged only two. When the lawyer discovered her snitching, he came into her office.
'' 'You're not going to get away with this,' he said,'' she recalled. ''And he closed the door and he started gesturing. His face was splotchy. I said 'Get out!' and I started to scream. One of the senior partners came down and said, 'We'll have to up his dose of lithium again' and then the partner said to me, 'Don't leave your scissors on that side of the desk.' That was their response to what this man had done.'' She later quit the firm in disgust.
The only clients smart enough to see through the make-work, double-billing and other assorted rip-offs, ''Winston Hall'' said, are people who presumably used to do it themselves. ''The worst clients from the point of view of a lawyer are the ex-partners, who know damn well that lawyers do work to run up the meter,'' he explained. He tells of a time when a client paid an inspection call on his firm, and saw how little the eight lawyers he was bankrolling were producing. ''It was like a customer going into the kitchen of a restaurant,'' he said. ''They were utterly horrified.''
What clients also don't know, the interviewees said, is that lawyers routinely blame secretaries for their own foul-ups, take credit for the work of underlings, exaggerate their expertise, say work they still haven't started is off ''in word processing,'' and forever duck phone calls.
The article has already provoked its share of curmudgeonly criticism. ''One gathers that Professor Lerman does not like lawyers,'' Edmund B. Spaeth Jr. wrote in a comment in the same issue of the publication.
Professor Lerman, a graduate of New York University Law School, denies the charge. ''I work with lawyers all day,'' she said. ''And I'm also married to one.''

HEADLINE: Review/Theater;
2 Caryl Churchill Plays Show Dark Side of 80's

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH

 BODY:
Attending a Caryl Churchill play is asking to get one's face slapped, repeatedly, frequently and with vicious force. ''Ice Cream With Hot Fudge,'' as the English writer calls her new pair of one-act comedies at the Public Theater, is short in length but bottomless in its cynicism about citizens of the Thatcher-Reagan 1980's on both sides of the Atlantic. Ms. Churchill doesn't like Americans very much. She may like the English less. ''Ice Cream With Hot Fudge'' is a livid, nasty piece of work.
Even at its most intellectually vapid, the evening is usually charged with the black humor and esthetic adventurousness one expects from the author of ''Cloud 9,'' ''Top Girls,'' ''Fen'' and ''Serious Money.'' In past plays, Ms. Churchill has scrambled chronology, allowed overlapping dialogue to erupt into cacophony and asked actors to ricochet between sexes and roles. Some of these techniques resurface here, but so does a new, Mametesque (or Pinteresque) spareness. ''Ice Cream,'' the bill's hourlong main event, and ''Hot Fudge,'' its 20-odd-minute curtain raiser, hurtle forward in mysterious, strobe-bright, snapshot-quick vignettes of acidic verbal wit and oblique events. The larger dramatic twists - three grisly deaths in one play alone - are often confined to the shadows offstage. 
''Ice Cream'' at least begins on familiar ground, as another ugly-Americans-abroad play. Lance (James Rebhorn) and Vera (Jane Kaczmarek) are a chatty, Anglophilic middle-aged suburban couple slobbering over castles and pubs while searching for familial roots in the British countryside. They find those roots in Lance's two English third cousins, but the relatives, Phil (Robert Knepper) and his sister, Jaq (Julianne Moore), are themselves rootless. They're alienated, amoral punks living at the dank fringes of the Thatcher economic miracle.
''I completely loathe the United States of America,'' says the thuggish Phil, who nonetheless wouldn't mind having his way with his American cousin's preppy wife. He darkly adds that Americans, having exported so much cultural and imperialistic ''filth'' to the rest of the world, should be prepared to have some of it ''thrown back.'' As if to prove the point, he and Jaq lead the square Lance and Vera into a real-life, Ramboesque crime that gives the first half of ''Ice Cream'' the narrative shape of Alfred Hitchcock's ''Man Who Knew Too Much.''
In the play's later scenes, the action switches to the United States, with Phil and Jaq becoming the tourists. En route to Yosemite and perhaps Disneyland, they discover a country no less ''violent and stupid'' than their own England. But the American horrors Ms. Churchill subjects the visitors to - lecherous men, dreary surburbanites, doomsday-fixated evangelicals, all firmly caricatured by John Pankow and Margaret Whitton - seem to have been culled from old Dennis Hopper road movies and television reruns. Ms. Churchill's writing flattens out, a sure sign that her observations are secondhand, and her visions of a poisoned Middle America seem embarrassingly dated and quaint when stacked up against ''Twin Peaks.''
Until it melts, ''Ice Cream'' is very funny, especially once the previously chipper Mr. Rebhorn and Ms. Kaczmarek sink into panic after unearthing the grotesque England beneath the picturesque tourist vistas. Even in the dud stateside episodes, Ms. Churchill does effectively limn one American trait - the compulsion to confess, whether to shrinks or officemates - and, as ever, she finds sick laughter in her menacing young British drifters, chillingly embodied by the cruel-eyed Mr. Knepper and the affectless Ms. Moore.
While the title of ''Ice Cream'' refers to its characters' cultural and linguistic differences, that of ''Hot Fudge'' is more elusive. Suffice it to say that the characters in this brief, explosive work are on the gravy train. In three dense, fast-talking scenes, set in a pub, wine bar and private club on the same night, Ms. Churchill captures present-day hustlers of several classes and nationalities. The rackets may involve old-fashioned theft, sophisticated credit-card fraud, real-estate speculation or faddish tennis instruction, but to this playwright, they are all part of the same bankrupt new Anglo-American empire of multi-national corporations, ''random walks,'' currency shifts, ecological vandalism and disingenuous corporate public relations.
As is explained in one hilarious speech, even the once-romantic calling of travel agents can now be rationalized in cold market terms because everyone in the world is either ''a potential customer'' or, as part of a tourist spot's ambiance, ''a potential commodity.'' While Ms. Churchill's rage at greed is familiar from ''Serious Money,'' her stock-exchange comedy, ''Hot Fudge'' resembles ''Top Girls'' when it suddenly shifts its setting from the economic arena to the private world where its money grubbers actually live. The play's fourth scene, set in a living room, exposes the sad people shouldering the pyramid schemes of compulsive mercenary success. As harrowingly acted by Ms. Moore and Mr. Pankow, each in a different state of psychological unravelment, this denouement is a nauseating glimpse into a most contemporary void.
The director, Les Waters, gives both plays a production as jolting as the writing. Annie Smart's distorted sets, as lighted by Stephen Strawbridge, have the imposing colors and stark, unsettling angularity of Alex Katz paintings. The six fine actors make fierce impressions in a total of 23 scurvy roles. One doesn't have to swallow all of Ms. Churchill's at times knee-jerk didacticism to find ''Ice Cream With Hot Fudge'' rich in bracing theatrical bile.
 
ICE CREAM WITH HOT FUDGE - Two one-act plays by Caryl Churchill; directed by Les Waters; sets and costumes by Annie Smart; lighting by Stephen Strawbridge; fight staged by B. H. Barry; associate producer, Jason Steven Cohen. Presented by Joseph Papp. At the Public/Newman Theater, 425 Lafayette Street.
WITH: Margaret Whitton, John Pankow, Jane Kaczmarek, James Rebhorn, Julianne Moore and Robert Knepper

HEADLINE: Review/Art;
Images of Third-World Dislocation

BYLINE: By ANDY GRUNDBERG

 BODY:
What is called political art has achieved a renewed currency of late, for reasons that are not difficult to grasp. The controversy over Robert Mapplethorpe's photographs and attempts to restrict the latitude of the National Endowment for the Arts have left artists feeling more embattled than usual. The controversies have also raised awareness of the political possibilities of art.
Today the ''deconstructive'' photographic strategies used by post-modernist artists in the 1980's, such as appropriating the images of others, no longer seem entirely sufficient. In their place, one finds a return to Conceptual practices of the late 1960's and early 70's - especially involving installations. Artists like Hans Haacke, Dennis Adams and Christian Boltanski all use photographs, to be sure, but the meanings of their images are determined by the objects and environments that the artists carefully construct to house them.
One of the most promising young practitioners of this sort of polemical installation art is Alfredo Jaar, a 34-year-old Chilean-born artist. His subject is the dislocation suffered by nonindustrialized cultures in the face of Western economics and technology. He addresses his subject by creating room-size environments that are partly sculptural and partly photographic. 
Since 1986, Mr. Jaar's work has been seen at the Venice Biennale, the Sao Paulo Bienal, ''Documenta 8'' in Kassel, West Germany, and the ''Magiciens de la Terre'' exhibition organized by the Pompidou Center in Paris last year. But despite this exhibition record, and a currently traveling retrospective organized by the La Jolla (Calif.) Museum of Contemporary Art, Mr. Jaar still has something of an underground reputation in New York. (The La Jolla retrospective will end its tour here next year at the New Museum of Contemporary Art in SoHo.) Mr. Jaar's most recent politically charged installation, ''Geography War,'' is now on view at the Diane Brown Gallery in SoHo, in what is said to be his first one-man gallery show in New York. The work links two nominally distinct issues: the disposal of toxic industrial wastes and the tradition of Western imperialism. Focusing on a well-publicized incident in which barrels of carcinogenic chemical by-products were shipped from Italy to a tiny town in Nigeria, where they contaminated the local populace, the artist has fashioned an evocative and psychologically charged atmosphere that, characteristically, is more poetic than dogmatic.
In the first of the gallery's two darkened rooms, six glowing, freestanding lightboxes are arranged in a slow arc, appearing much like graveyard headstones. On the sides facing the viewer are schematic maps of fragments of the Mediterranean and Atlantic Coasts, on which the route of the tainted barrels has been marked by vivid red dashes. On the opposite sides are color photographs taken by the artist in Nigeria, including images of a freighter at sea, stacked oil drums and children rooting through a vile-looking dump.
Because the lightboxes are arranged close to the wall, only a few of these photographs can be observed directly. The rest are visible only as reflections in small mirrors that Mr. Jaar has mounted behind the lightboxes. The mirrors play several roles: they stand in for the artist, who is trying to convey his concern for the state of the world; they imply that the attitude of industrialized nations toward third-world peoples has a psychological dimension, and, because some of them also reflect whoever is standing in front of them, they implicate the viewer in the tragedy they describe.
All this might remain obscure were it not for the second installation and the presence of a thick notebook, displayed on the gallery's sales counter, filled with newspaper clippings and other journalistic reports on the problem of toxic-waste dumping in Africa. The second installation, which consists of a single lightbox in front of a methodically fractured mirror, includes a single, coherent image of the chemicals' route from Italy to Nigeria and an image of the Nigerian farmer who was paid to store them on his land but was reportedly not told what they contained.
At a time when political art can be drearily doctrinaire, earnestly superficial or burdened by good intentions, Mr. Jaar's complex way of questioning the established order of things is especially welcome. True, to some it may seem too allusive to activate political consciousness, while to others it may seem too much concerned with matters extraneous to the domain of art. But like Mr. Haacke, the artist to whom he might best be compared, Mr. Jaar manages to address thorny social issues in ways that are visually innovative, intriguing and - dare one say it? - entertaining.
The Alfredo Jaar exhibition remains at the Diane Brown Gallery, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, through May 26. Frank Majore Josh Baer Gallery 270 Lafayette Street Through May 26 As one would expect of Frank Majore's work, the seven glossy large-scale color photographs that constitute this show combine elements of several genres: commercial still lifes, nocturnal cityscapes and glamour portraiture. But the emphasis here is less on worldly materialism than it is on a sense of evanescence and abstraction. This shift in Mr. Majore's career can be gauged by comparing ''Interior,'' a picture taken in 1989, with its companions, all of which date from this year.
''Interior'' depicts a glass brick on a coffee table in a luxurious (though patently faked) interior, with a red-orange vista of skyscrapers in the background. The 1990 images, by contrast, feature streaks and pools of light that suggest not only urban reflections, but also Surrealist drawings and experimental European photography of the 1930's. In works like ''Snake Eyes'' and ''Veil of Tears,'' women's faces are embedded in screens of blurry lights, like rain or theatrical scrims. These visages lend the pictures a sense of both depth and deja vu.
''Veil of Tears'' is characteristic of Mr. Majore's new approach. Instead of concentrating on the evocation of deluxe textures and surfaces in artificial, nonperspective space, the artist now seems focused on the boundary between ''pure'' abstraction and the insistent referentiality of photographs. The results are more festive than before and have less of a sense of loss and regret, although they can also seem almost pathologically hyperactive.
 
Hamish Fulton
John Weber Gallery
142 Greene Street
Through May 19
Since the 1970's, Hamish Fulton has made an art of walking, taking unaccompanied treks across France, Spain, Nepal, Japan, Mexico and his native England. These excursions -a kind of environmentally harmless Earth Art - have been rigorously documented by the artist, primarily in the form of black-and-white landscape photographs accompanied by terse, descriptive texts. In this show of recent works, however, only one photograph is on view; the rest consists of wall paintings and drawings on paper.
Mr. Fulton has long had to contend with being mistaken for a photographer, since his landscape photographs can be as gorgeous and well made as anything printed by the likes of Ansel Adams or Paul Caponigro. This may account for his decision to make drawings of the horizon lines he encountered on recent walks and, in the case of one wall painting, to use the outlined profile of Japan's Mount Fuji as the work's centerpiece. In the other large wall work, the words ''dead dogs'' in capital letters dominate, with his usual descriptive text underneath.
But while the drawings are enhanced by brown and gray streaks of soil, giving them an immediate, physical presence much like a Robert Smithson rock or salt sculpture, the paintings are cold and diagrammatic. As for the photo piece, a view of a rocky path that is cryptically labeled ''Magpie Leads the Way,'' it seems best to embody the artist's edgy balance of 19th-century romanticism and 20th-century self-consciousness. If Mr. Fulton's Conceptual concerns are still distance, duration and time, then photographs apparently remain his best means of expression.

GRAPHIC: photo: ''Geography War,'' 1990, part of a one-man show by Alfredo Jaar, at Diane Brown Gallery. (Diane Brown Gallery)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Review

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (86%); BRAZIL (79%); MEDITERRANEAN (79%); NIGERIA (79%); ITALY (79%); GERMANY (54%); FRANCE (54%);

HEADLINE: Auctions

BYLINE: By Rita Reif

 BODY:

Postwar Works
Contemporary artworks by the masters of the postwar period - including Willem de Kooning, Roy Lichtenstein, Francis Bacon, Sam Francis, Jackson Pollock and Jean Dubuffet - are to be offered next week at Sotheby's and Christie's in New York and are expected to bring the highest combined total of prices at such auctions in history.
These sales of Abstract Expressionist, Pop, Minimalist and Color Field art are estimated to total $190 million to $255 million. These figures are more than double last year's combined estimates of $86 million to $114.3 million for sales that actually totaled $139 million. And they are five times the projections of $37 million to $48 million for the May 1988 sales, which totaled $56 million. Over that time the number of lots has also increased, from 574 in 1988 to 893 last year and to 1,044 this year.
Leo Castelli, the SoHo art dealer, says some collectors and dealers are anxious about the prices because of recent international economic troubles, while others are optimistic. ''I think the good paintings will do well,'' Mr. Castelli said in a telephone interview. ''There are a lot of them in both houses. Perhaps less good ones will not do as well on their coattails.'' 
Most of the art styles that have emerged since World War II are represented in Christie's sale of 77 works at 7 P.M. Monday, a session estimated to total $50 million to $71.8 million. The sale continues at 10 A.M. and 1:30 P.M. on Tuesday with 425 additional works. The overall total for the two days is expected to be $66.5 million to $94.9 million.
One of the most important paintings at Christie's is Lichtenstein's ''Kiss II,'' a wordless, larger-than-life cartoon from 1962 in red, white, yellow, blue and black. The classic elements of comic-strip art are all there in the cliche image of a couple embracing, the impact of which is depicted as an explosion against the night sky. Mr. Castelli recalled this week that he sold ''Kiss II'' to a Swiss gallery for $1,000 the year it was painted. The presale estimate is $5 million to $7 million.
''People have offered $5 million for it when it was still in Switzerland, and they were refused,'' Mr. Castelli said. ''If it is to sell, it will probably have to go higher.''
Also in the Christie's sale is Dubuffet's equally colorful 1962 painting from his Paris circus series, a more mysterious study of a crowded street enlivened by nonsensical scatalogical references. The artist's New York dealer, Arnold Glimcher of Pace Galleries, described the painting this week as ''a celebration of the madness of Paris - of the awkward, the grotesque and the clumsy and the resuscitation of values discarded by society.'' The presale estimate is $2.5 million to $3.5 million.
Christie's is to offer two large works by Clyfford Still with titles that include the dates they were completed. ''1949-A No. 1'' is a dynamic study of swirling forms in black, red and white, about 8 feet by 6 1/2 feet. The presale estimate is $3.5 million to $4.5 million. ''1955-D'' is a more serene but intense study in red, about 10 feet by 9 feet. Christie's expects it to sell for $3 million to $5 million.
These estimates far exceed the auction record for a painting by Still, $797,500, which was paid for an untitled 1954 work at Sotheby's in 1985. Martha Baer, Christie's top specialist in contemporary art, explained: ''We haven't experienced a major Still painting in the boom market for contemporary art that began two years ago.''
The sale at Sotheby's at 7 P.M. on Tuesday offers 88 works, valued at $88 million to $114 million. The sale continues Wednesday at 10:15 A.M. and 2 P.M. with 454 additional artworks. The overall total is expected to be $123 million to $160.4 million.
Sotheby's two most important works are Abstract Expressionist paintings by Mr. de Kooning. His ''Woman as Landscape,'' from 1955, is a swirl of pink, red, green and blue that was acquired from the artist by Martha Jackson, a New York dealer, for $6,000 when the paint was still fresh. It is estimated to sell for $9 million to $12 million. Mr. de Kooning's ''Palisade,'' from 1957, one of a series of parkway landscapes depicted in broad strokes of blue, brown, yellow and white, was bought from the Sidney Janis Gallery in New York in 1959 for $14,000. The buyer was Milton A. Gordon, a New York financier and a co-producer of the ''Lassie'' television series in the 1950's. He was 82 years old at his death on Jan. 31. The painting, which is being sold by his estate, is expected to bring $8 million to $10 million.
Two chalk-on-blackboard paintings by Cy Twombly are estimated to bring prices well above $1.7 million, the record for the artist set last fall in a sale at Sotheby's in New York. The smaller and blacker of the two to be sold at Sotheby's is a painting about 5 feet by 7 feet from 1968 that is estimated to sell for $3.5 million to $4.5 million. The larger canvas, from 1971, is huge: about 10 feet by 16 feet. The price expected is $5 million to $6 million.
Lucy Mitchell-Innes, who heads contemporary art sales at Sotheby's, said the presale estimates exceed the record because several of Twombly's paintings recently have been sold privately for higher prices. One, she said, was sold for $3.5 million and another for $5 million.
''Traditionally, his market was based in Europe, but that has changed in the last three years,'' Ms. Mitchell-Innes said. ''The blackboard paintings are what everybody wants when they buy Twombly.''
Among the other major offerings are two portraits by Mr. Bacon, the more important of which is ''Study for a Portrait,'' a popelike image from 1957 shown seated on a throne, fists clenched. The presale estimate is $5 million to $7 million. Mr. Bacon's ''Study of Lucian Freud,'' from 1968, depicts the artist as a tightly swirled figure against broad stripes of lavender, gray and burgundy. The estimate is $2.5 million to $3 million.
Carroll Janis, who heads the Sidney Janis Gallery, said the sales should do well if owners are not greedy in setting reserves, the prices below which the artworks will not be sold by the auction house. ''Postwar art remains stronger than some of the older 20th-century art,'' he said. ''The sales will fare well if the reserve prices are reasonable.''
 
Soviet Art
A specialty sale of Soviet contemporary art, organized by Habsburg, Feldman, a Geneva-based house, is to be held at 3 P.M. tomorrow at the Puck Building in lower Manhattan. The 121 works by 31 Soviet artists are from the Kniga collection, owned by a group of Paris investors who have not been identified. The auction house estimates the sale will bring a total of $2.1 million to $2.8 million.
Acquired in the Soviet Union between 1984 and 1989 by Jose Alvarez, director of Editions du Regard, a Paris art-book publisher, the collection includes Ivan Chuikov's ''Grisaille,'' from 1988. It is a diptych in enamel on Masonite that is expected to bring $80,000 to $120,000. Also in the collection is Ilya Kabakov's ''Alley,'' from 1982, a landscape in enamel paint on cardboard with lines from 19th-century poetry covering part of the image. The presale estimate is $60,000 to $80,000.
 
SOTHEBY'S, York Avenue at 72d Street (606-7245). Viewing hours for contemporary art: 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. today and tomorrow; 1 to 5 P.M. Sunday; 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Monday; 10 A.M. to noon Tuesday.
CHRISTIE'S, Park Avenue at 59th Street (546-1010). Viewing hours for contemporary art: 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. today and tomorrow; 1 to 5 P.M. Sunday; 10 A.M. to noon Monday.
