LENGTH: 922 words

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
An Awful Time Living a Perfect Life

BYLINE: By MICHIKO KAKUTANI

 BODY:
Goodbye Without Leaving
By Laurie Colwin
253 pages. Poseidon Press. $18.95.
Geraldine Coleshares, the heroine of Laurie Colwin's new book, is a wife, mother and former backup singer with a rhythm-and-blues band. She describes herself as ''a person who craved the marginal,'' a ''nothing,'' who's ''alone in the middle of the universe,'' ''the harbinger of new life,'' ''the innocent American, making trouble right and left - a microcosm of imperialism.'' 
''I want to know,'' she says, ''how to be what I am.''
Geraldine's husband is her ''Boy Scout from Mars,'' her ''weirdo from Normalsville, who knew how to maneuver in the world,'' ''the golden mean,'' who ''managed to do good and make money at the same time.''
Her best friend, Mary, is her ''moral beacon.''
Her lover, Leo, is ''a school'' who would turn her ''into Hannah Arendt,'' someone who is ''more like a destination than a person.''
When we first meet Geraldine, she has just traded in her identity as a graduate student in English at the University of Chicago to join Ruby Shakely and the Shakettes - a Tina Turner-like group that's touring small towns around the country. Geraldine spends a lot of time on the tour bus ''blowing reefer and playing cards,'' while her friends from school pursue more conventional lives: ''getting married, having babies, being promoted, becoming White House Fellows or junior partners in their law firms.''
Actually, a similarly conventional life is in store for Geraldine. She meets a lawyer named Jonathan, quits the Shakettes, and after much agonizing is married and has a baby. Her family and Jonathan's family get along beautifully, no doubt because they share (like so many earlier Colwin characters) identical tastes and backgrounds. Geraldine's mother is a children's book illustrator and the head of a county art center; Jonathan's mother is on a local library committee and gives an annual cocktail party that ''was as regular an event as the bake sale, the Memorial Day parade or the Volunteer Fire Department chicken fry.''
In time, Geraldine takes a job as a researcher at the Race Music Foundation in Harlem - an obscure organization devoted to preserving the work of early black musicians. She and Jonathan move to a bigger apartment in some unidentified but gentrified neighborhood in Manhattan, and they go to dinner parties where Geraldine attacks the liberal hypocrisies of the other guests.
''They wore snappy clothes and owned small European cars. They worked hard and took interesting vacations in wilderness areas. They were healthy and hale and red-cheeked and they had never spent a minute of their lives worried about the essentials. The essentials had all been taken care of. Instead they had worried about grades, getting into college, law school. They worried when their cars didn't work and when cholera broke out in the some part of the world they had an impulse to go touring in. Later they had children and worried about early childhood development, what schools to send their children to. When they got together they talked about cooking equipment, and skiing, and gossiped about mutual friends. I was a total misfit.''
It doesn't take the reader long to discover that Geraldine isn't a misfit at all; she only thinks she is. Like the people she says she loathes, she leads a privileged existence in which the essentials are happily taken for granted. Her marriage is pleasant and fulfilling. Her child is healthy and bright. She and Jonathan have no economic worries, no worries about their families, their jobs or their futures. Even her love affair with Leo is completely painless, devoid of guilt, conflict or emotional trauma of any sort. While unsatisfactory dinner party conversations are enough to elicit a litany of complaints, Geraldine never seriously assesses her life or her values, never achieves anything even approaching self-knowledge.
Indeed, the reader quickly begins to suspect that Geraldine is one of those people who are constantly inventing things to worry about to pass the time. Although she has wanted to be a rock-and-roll singer all her life, she worries, once she's got a job as a Shakette, that it's not a proper lifetime occupation. Although she's madly in love with Jonathan, she worries that marriage is incompatible with her career. Although she says she loves being a mother, she worries that people will look down on her for not having a high-powered job. It never seems to occur to her that being a wife and mother doesn't preclude being a singer.
To make matters worse, Geraldine is constantly turning her identity crises into annoying little aphorisms: ''To be effortlessly yourself is a blessing, an ambrosia. It is like a few tiny little puffs of opium, which lift you ever so slightly off the hard surface of the world.'' Or: ''I mean, people who really do things have professions, and vocations. Maybe I'm one of those meandering types and being in the music business was a form of meandering.''
When Ms. Colwin steps away from Geraldine and her complacent, yuppified world, she succeeds in putting her eye for sociological detail to better use. Ruby Shakeley and some of Geraldine's other music-business friends are delineated briskly with a couple of lines of description, a couple of phrases of telling dialogue; and the European emigres she later meets in New York are also observantly defined. Unfortunately, these characters are no compensation, in the end, for Geraldine's self-absorption, her cute, self-conscious whining.

THE ECONOMY
 
Bush named his choice to succeed William Seidman when he steps down as the nation's top savings regulator. At the same time, trying to limit damage caused by the Administration's effort to push Seidman out, the President praised his work. [Page A1.] 
 
Sales of U.S.-made cars and light trucks rose 2.4 percent in the last 10 days of April, auto makers reported. [D2.]
 
Leveraged buyouts lowered tax receipts from corporations, Congress's chief economist testified. But an economist from the Bush Administration disagreed. [D20.]
 
COMPANIES
 
Bloomingdale's was formally taken off the auction block. The chain failed to attract a buyer willing to pay a high enough price, so Federated Stores will continue to operate it. [D1.] Apparel retailers got a much-needed sales spurt in April. [D5.]
 
G.M. and Ford posted sharply lower first-quarter profits. The declines were attributed to an industrywide production slowdown in January. [D1.]
 
The wife of Genentech's chief executive is the focus of an insider-trading investigation conducted by the S.E.C., the company disclosed. The investigation concerns trading shortly before Genentech said it would sell a 60 percent stake to Roche Holding. [D1.]
 
CBS will seek a ''better television measurement system'' because A. C. Nielsen was unable to explain the sudden decline in national TV viewing, a CBS executive said. [D1.]
 
Donald Trump is under fire from contractors on the Taj Mahal casino who say he has been slow to pay money he owes them, possibly because of a cash squeeze. Mr. Trump defended the delay and said he had ''a lot of money.'' [D6.]

INTERNATIONAL
 
OPEC members agreed to stop producing oil above their previously agreed upon quotas. [D1.]
 
The I.M.F. projected that world economic growth would slow to 2 1/4 percent in 1990, but it said ''no recession is in sight.'' [D6.]
 
MARKETS
 
Some traders use advance knowledge of customer plans to make profitable trades on the stock index futures market, Cigna's head of stock investments told Congress. [D8.]
 
Stocks advanced in cautious trading for the fourth day in a row, with the Dow rising 6.53, to 2,696.17. [D8.]
 
Treasury bond prices posted their best gains in nearly a month, as dealers awaited the release of April job data. [D14.]
 
Oil futures prices fell sharply despite an OPEC agreement to cut total crude-oil output by 1.45 million barrels a day. [D15.] The dollar finished mixed, and gold prices advanced modestly. [D15.]

HEADLINE: G.M. and Ford Profits Off Sharply for Quarter

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, May 3

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company, the nation's two biggest auto makers, each posted sharply lower first-quarter profits today.
The declines were attributed to an industrywide production slowdown in January, which was undertaken because of swollen inventories of cars and trucks in the United States. But Ford profits also plunged overseas.
Automotive analysts, having accounted for the production cuts, were not surprised by the size of the declines. G.M.'s shares closed at $45.125, up 37.5 cents, and Ford's shares closed at $45.625, up 12.5 cents, in New York Stock Exchange trading today. 
On Tuesday, the Chrysler Corporation also posted lower first-quarter profit.
General Motors' profit fell 54.3 percent on a 9.4 percent drop in revenue. The biggest auto maker earned $710 million, or $1.02 a share, compared with $1.55 billion, or $2.37 a share, in 1989's first quarter. Revenue dropped to $30.1 billion, from $33.2 billion for last year's period.
The company said earnings from overseas operations ''continued at a record level'' but did not elaborate. G.M. does not break out United States earnings, but David Healy, an analyst for Barclays Bank, said he thought the company was unprofitable in the United States for the quarter.
Ford posted a 69.1 percent decline in first-quarter earnings. The second-largest auto maker said net income for the period was $506.2 million, or $1.10 a share, compared with $1.64 billion, or $3.44 a share, a year earlier. First-quarter revenue was off 8.8 percent, to $23.6 billion, from $25.9 billion in the 1989 quarter..
Net income attributable to Ford's worldwide automotive operations dropped 78.9 percent, to $315 million, from $1.5 billion a year ago. United States automotive profits dropped 80 percent, to $160 million from $800 million. And unlike G.M., Ford suffered overseas: Profits fell 78 percent, to $155 million from $696 million. Ford said a strike at an assembly plant in Britain and economic changes in Brazil that have slowed vehicle sales and production depressed first-quarter profit and ''could continue to have a negative effect on Ford's future earnings.''
Net income from financial services, including the Ford Motor Credit Company and other lending activities, rose 35.2 percent, to $191.2 million, from $141.4 million a year earlier.
Retail sales of cars and trucks have been sluggish since last fall, and the auto companies do not expect a rebound from what they regard as a cyclical downturn before the latter part of this year. Because the companies book their profits and revenues when they ship new vehicles to dealers rather than when they are actually sold, the decision in January to reduce inventories by temporarily stopping some production directly affected earnings.
Vehicle sales at the end of last month improved marginally for both companies over results a year earlier, but analysts said the climate for sales remained generally sluggish.
 
General Motors
G.M. said it increased its share of the United States retail vehicle market to 35.2 percent in the first quarter, from 34.5 percent in the previous quarter.
But G.M.'s worldwide factory shipments of cars and trucks fell 13.7 percent, to 1.8 million, from 2.1 million in 1989's first quarter. The drop was caused by a 25.8 percent drop in production in the United States, where G.M. shipped 998,000 cars and trucks during the period, compared with about 1.4 million a year ago.
G.M. managers, in the midst of aggressive cost cutting, said they reduced the company's fixed expenses by $800 million in the period.
The per-share amounts on G.M.'s common stock, which declined 57 percent do not correspond to the $710 million in total consolidated G.M. earnings, which include profit from subsidiaries that have separate classes of stock. In financial results reported Wednesday, G.M.'s Electronic Data Systems posted an increase, and GM Hughes Electronics and the General Motors Acceptance Corporation posted declines.
G.M.'s cash and marketable securities at the end of the quarter dropped to $4.65 billion, from $5.35 billion at the end of 1989.
G.M.'s quarterly profit was improved by $75 million, or 12 cents a share, as a result of changes in actuarial assumptions affecting its pension plans. The company said it now assumes an 11 percent yield on pension assets, compared with a previous assumption of 10 percent; G.M. also reduced by two years its assumption on how long its retirees will live. But a spokesman said the actuarial assumptions remain conservative.
G.M. noted that it plans to offer several new or restyled cars and trucks in the coming months. G.M.'s Buick division will offer a four-door version of its Regal and a Park Avenue Ultra luxury car, a restyled Chevrolet Camaro and Pontiac Firebird, and a four-door utility vehicle that will be sold as the S-10 Blazer and GMC Jimmy.
 
Ford Motor
Ford's share of the United States vehicle market dropped half a percentage point in the quarter, to 21.8 percent, from the end of 1989, while its share of the truck market remained stable at 28.8 percent.
Weak sales in the United States forced Ford to offer steep discounts on most of its cars and trucks. In the first quarter cash rebates averaged $1,000 a vehicle, up from $800 a vehicle in the previous quarter. Rebates averaged $400 a vehicle during the first quarter of 1989.
Like G.M., Ford also improved profits by liberalizing its actuarial assumptions on pensions. The company said about $26 million of its quarterly net income was a result of its assuming a greater yield than previously on pension assets. A spokesman said the company now assumes a 9 percent return rather than an 8 percent return.
Ford's capital expenditures in the quarter rose 59.1 percent, to $1.62 billion, from $1 billion a year ago. David McCammon, Ford's treasurer, said the bulk of the outlays were for new product development, notably a new Escort model in Europe and its new Zeta engine, which will be sold worldwide.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Can U.S. Recover In Electronics?

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
THE Japanese Government's reported plan to organize an industrial effort to develop an advanced computer technology known as massively parallel processing, in which the United States now holds a substantial lead, heightens American anxieties. Some Americans already believe that Japan has a master strategy for achieving dominance in all areas of electronics technology and thereby becoming the world's greatest industrial power.
The Japanese strategy, according to Richard J. Elkus Jr., chairman of the Prometrix Corporation, a California-based manufacturer of semiconductor equipment, is based on the concept that products and markets become more and more interrelated during development. ''Every technology becomes the stepping stone for the next,'' he said. ''Every product becomes the basis for another. And the resulting efficiencies of scale are enormous.'' 
The heart of the Japanese strategy, he contends, is that capturing product markets is the key to technological supremacy. ''One often hears how we must improve our technological base,'' Mr. Elkus told a recent conference of the Center for Strategic and Industrial Studies in Williamsburg, Va., adding: ''Technology follows markets, not the other way around. If you own the technology, but lose the market, you will lose the technology.''
That, he said, is what has been happening to the United States electronics industry. Mr. Elkus was part of the team that developed the videocassette recorder at Ampex in the postwar years.
In 1970 Ampex was involved, through a joint venture partner, Toshiba, in discussions with other Japanese companies, including Sony and Matsushita, to develop a VCR standard. But Ampex, lacking adequate financial resources and seeking quicker returns elsewhere, decided not to pursue the VCR market, which was picked up by the Japanese. With that loss, Mr. Elkus said, went not only most of the video recording but also a major share of support technologies, including the design and manufacture of semiconductors.
The story permeates consumer electronics. American companies developed most of the original technology, but the Japanese now dominate or have a strong position in the markets for recorders, cameras, radios and television sets, digital watches, solar-powered calculators and a host of other products, as well as a growing share of the market for personal computers, work stations and laptop computers.
The linkages among all these products are crucial. Mr. Elkus stresses that at the highest levels of Government and industry, the United States must understand the importance of market and product ''infrastructure'' that results from those linkages.
Can the United States turn the tide in its favor? ''Absolutely,'' Mr. Elkus said. ''The U.S. computer industry is still dominant. America's position in mass media, software and transmission services is still solid. These markets can provide a basis for restoring America's competitive position.''
He contends that the United States must try to fight its way back into consumer electronics, display systems, audio and video recording, computer peripherals, components and related technologies. ''Otherwise,'' he said, the combination of developments in high-definition products and those markets America has lost will ''continue to encroach on remaining U.S. positions of strength.''
So, should the United States adopt an industrial policy? Or is the American system simply incompatible with Government efforts to direct or guide industry? As the Canadian economist Sylvia Ostry, former chief economist of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, observed, the United States, Japan, and Europe rely on three different models in their struggle for competiveness.
The American model ''is strongly consumer and short-term oriented,'' she said. ''Its strength is dynamism and flexibility.'' Business interest groups generate an implicit ''industrial policy'' response from Government in specific fields like military production and agriculture, while most industries insist Government leave them alone, she added.
By contrast, the Japanese model, she said, is a ''corporatist market economy,'' unique in its producer orientation, strategic use of cooperation and competition, and in the close and continuing interface of the state with business. She finds the continental European model, especially the German social-market economy, closer in some respects to Japan than the United States.
A world slump would worsen the conflict in these different national models. But other forces, as Mrs. Ostry suggests, may move them toward a convergent model.
One such force is the globalization of the world economy. Another force is the growing linkage among Japanese, American and European businesses. A third force, increasingly evident in the United States, is recognition of the need for Government support of education, research and development, and of cooperative efforts by businesses to create technologies crucial to all.
The competitiveness struggle can be a creative, not a destructive, force, if accompanied by open exchange among nations and businesses. But it will also involve what the late Prof. Joseph Schumpeter of Harvard called ''creative destruction.''

HEADLINE: Vehicle Sales Decline, Despite Late April Gain

BYLINE: By PAUL C. JUDGE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, May 3

 BODY:
Sales of domestically produced cars and light trucks rose 2.4 percent in the last 10 days of April, compared with a year earlier, the auto makers reported today.
But the better late-month results were not enough to offset poor results earlier in the month. Overall, vehicle sales declined 8.7 percent in April, and analysts said the sales climate remained generally sluggish. 
''The last 10 days doesn't mean anything. We're in a holding pattern, where we've been for the last three months,'' said Harvey Heinbach, automotive analyst for Merrill Lynch & Co.
 
G.M., Ford Gain
Thomas Webb, an economist for the National Automobile Dealers Association, said, ''Personal income grew in April, and consumer confidence was relatively high. Thus, the low level of auto sales implies to me underlying demand for new vehicles remains weak.''
The General Motors Corporation, however, posted a 4.1 percent increase in sales of its cars, which rose to 113,801 units. It was helped by a host of new models that arrived in showrooms in recent weeks. Sales of G.M.'s light trucks increased 7.6 percent, to 56,393 units.
The Ford Motor Company sold 64,851 cars in late April, an increase of 1.6 percent. Ford's light truck sales, aided by a new Explorer utility vehicle, were up 17.3 percent in late April, to 49,315 units.
But the Chrysler Corporation reported a significant decline in car and truck sales, which resulted in a steep loss of market share. Chysler's car sales fell 33.8 percent, to 21,866, units, while sales of its trucks and mini-vans declined 16.5 percent, to 26,114 units.
''Chrysler likes to say that its market share decline partly is deliberate because they phased out the Omni and Horizon and reduced fleet sales,'' said David Healy, automotive analyst for Barclays Bank, ''but I think the Toyota Camry and Honda Accord are eating their lunch.'' He was referring to Chrysler's compact cars, including the Plymouth Acclaim and Dodge Spirit.
Chrysler's combined market share in cars and light trucks fell to 10.7 percent in April, from 14.1 percent a year ago.
Ford's market share in cars declined to 21.9 percent last month, from 23.1 percent a year ago. By contrast, General Motors emerged from April with 36.2 percent of the market for cars, up from 35.7 percent a year ago.
 
Toyota Matches Honda
Toyota, which has been expanding its presence in the American market with increased production, matched Honda in market share. Both auto makers captured about 8.9 percent of the United States market, while the Nissan Motor Company's share declined to 4.4 percent, from 4.6 percent a year ago.
Other importers also registered sales declines for the month.
Eight auto companies operating plants in the United States sold 241,322 cars in late April, roughly equal to the 241,450 cars sold in the same period last year. Cars sold at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 7.1 million, an improvement over the pace of 6.8 million for the past 30 days, but lagging behind the annual rate of 7.7 million for the comparable period a year ago.
Dealers sold 138,924 light trucks and mini-vans in late April, up 7.2 percent over last year's sales.
For the month, domestic producers reported a sales decline of 10.6 percent, to 546,750, from 667,444 cars last April.

HEADLINE: I.M.F. Sees Slower Growth, but No Slump

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 3

 BODY:
In a less optimistic assessment than it made in October, the International Monetary Fund projected today that world economic growth would slow to 2 1/4 percent in 1990, but it said that ''no recession is in sight.''
In 1991, growth will rebound to 3 percent, the 1989 pace, the agency reported as officials of the I.M F. and the World Bank gathered here for five days of spring meetings that begin Friday. Last fall, the fund's economic staff projected world output would rise 2.9 percent this year. 
Despite the slower growth, which reflects a general tightening of monetary policy since mid-1988, inflation ''remains a major concern'' for many of the industrialized countries, and interest rates ''are likely to remain relatively high'' unless the United States and other countries with big budget deficits can bring them down, the I.M.F. said.
But even without fresh policy moves, the agency predicted that inflation in industrial countries would ease two-tenths of a point, to 4.2 percent, this year and then drop to 3.6 percent in 1991.
Inflation for developing countries is expected to run at 71 percent this year, down from 104 percent last year but about twice as high as the I.M.F. estimated last fall.
 
Trade Gains Seen
Raising its October estimate by nine-tenths of a point, agency analysts projected that world trade would expand by 6.6 percent this year, compared with 7.2 percent growth in 1989, and expressed some satisfaction that both Japan's trade surplus and the United States trade deficit had fallen to 2 percent of their gross national products.
West Germany's surplus rose to about 4 1/2 percent of G.N.P., but the movement toward German reunification could bring about ''sharp reduction,'' the I.M.F. said.
More broadly, the prospect of economic reforms in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union could bring about ''substantially'' improved performance in the medium term but economic activity is likely to be weak during the initial stages, the analysts declared. But Jacob Frenkel, research chief, stressed that each country needs to be appraised individually.
As for the global impact of the ''peace dividend,'' the agency was quite restrained. The budget savings in defense ''although not insignificant, may not be very large over the short to medium term,'' it said.
The I.M.F. analysts expect the United States economy to grow by only 1.7 percent this year, with consumer inflation at 4.6 percent, unemployment at 5.3 percent and the balance-of-payments deficit turning up, to $113 billion, after two years of decline that carried it down to $106 billion last year.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Bonds Stage Advance

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices posted their best gains in nearly a month yesterday, as dealers positioned themselves for the release this morning of April employment data.
''We have seen a certain amount of customer business, continuing what has been small amounts of buying all week,'' said James R. Capra, a senior vice president at Shearson Lehman Government Securities. ''The market has sold off a lot, and people don't want to get caught if the number turns out to be good.''
Despite the steep slide in prices recently, Mr. Capra and others said employment figures that are much stronger than expected could set off a further decline. These participants added that a strong report could possibly provoke the Federal Reserve Board to tighten monetary policy. 
But some traders disagreed. ''The worst possible number is priced into the market right now,'' one bond trader said. ''That means that any number that is even slightly tremendous could really send prices higher.''
In advance of the report, the consensus among most Wall Street economists was that non-farm payroll employment rose by 150,000 jobs last month. That excludes an estimated 230,000 workers hired by the Government to conduct the 1990 census.
''If the overall number comes in at anything under 400,000, the market will take off,'' the trader said.
 
Wage Figure Also Awaited
In addition to the payroll figures, analysts and traders are likely to look closely at the report's hourly wage figures to get an early sense of where inflation was trending as the second quarter began.
''The hourly earnings numbers are likely to be distorted by the increase in the minimum wage,'' said David Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, a primary dealer in Government securities. ''But the Fed governors have to be concerned with how much of a moderation in inflation they can expect to see from the rapid rise in the first quarter.''
Because of the distortions caused by the census workers and the increase in the minimum wage, Mr. Jones said, the Fed is not likely to put as much credence to the employment report as it normally does. Still, ''if payroll employment rose by more than 200,000 excluding the census workers, it would make the Fed take a second look'' at its current policy approach, he added.
Yesterday's price gains recorded in the bond market were the best since early April, but the rise was by no means enormous. By late in the day, the Treasury's 8 1/2 percent bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 95 1/8, up 13/32, to yield 8.97 percent. Late Wednesday the benchmark issue was offered at a price to yield 9.02 percent.
 
Notes Climb
Prices also improved in the secondary Treasury note market.
In late trading, the 8 1/2 percent five-year notes were offered at 98, up 1/4 of a point, to yield 8.98 percent. And the 8 7/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 99 29/32, up 1/8, to yield 8.92 percent.
Yields on the securities to be sold at next week's Treasury refunding auctions also fell.
The three-year notes to be sold on Tuesday were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 9.00 percent late yesterday, down from 9.06 percent late Wednesday. Meanwhile, the 10-year notes to be sold next Wednesday were offered at a price to yield 8.98 percent, down from 9.04 percent late Wednesday. And the 30-year bonds to be auctioned next Thursday were offered in when-issued trading at a price to yield 8.94 percent late yesterday, down from 9.00 percent on Wednesday.
The sharp run-up in short-term interest rates over the last month was reflected in the results of yesterday's one-year Treasury bill auction. The new bills were sold at an average discount rate of 8.05 percent, up from an average rate of 7.72 percent at the last auction on April 5. It is the highest rate on a one-year bill since the auction of June 2, 1989.
 
Corporate Issues
In the corporate bond market, Mountain States Bell Telephone and Northwestern Bell, two subsidiaries of U S West, priced a total of $98 million worth of deep-discount 40-year bonds under highly unusual circumstances. The bonds were sold publicly, but details of the pricing were withheld at the issuers' request.
Still, market participants said that Mountain Bell sold $55 million worth of 7 3/8 percent 40-year securities at a price of $76.18, to yield 9.749 percent.The $43 million Northwestern Bell offering carries a coupon of 7 3/4 percent, and was priced at $79.94, to yield 9.749 percent.
Morgan Stanley & Company acted as lead manager for the transaction. Both issues were rated AA-3 by Moody's Investors Services and AA-minus by Standard & Poor's.
Traders in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds said that prices of most issues rose by about 1/4 point. Similar price gains were recorded in the secondary market for tax-exempt bonds, participants said.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday that the narrowest and broadest measures of the nation's money supply, M-1 and M-3, fell in the week ended April 23. The third measure, M-2, rose by $1.2 billion. The report had no impact on prices in the credit markets.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Mixed, Gold Higher; British Election Is Watched

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished mixed against other primary foreign currencies yesterday as many traders stayed on the sidelines awaiting results from British elections and today's release of employment figures. Gold prices advanced modestly. Britons voted in local elections in the first comprehensive test of the Conservative Party's popularity since Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, now in deep political trouble, won a third term in 1987. 
The outcome of the balloting could affect the British pound, which declined yesterday. It fell in New York to $1.6410, from $1.6425 late on Wednesday. Sterling also lost ground in London, dropping to $1.6425, from $1.6435 late on Wednesday.
The traders played it safe while waiting for the results, analysts said.
The market was also cautious before the employment figures are released, especially because of possible changes in the non-farm payroll figures, an indicator of economic strength.
Robert Ryan, the senior trader with the Bank of New York, said the market was looking for a non-farm payroll increase of 150,000 to 200,000. A lower number could set off fears of a recession and send the dollar lower, he said.
Markets in Japan were closed yesterday for a holiday. In London, the dollar traded at 158.10 yen, down from Wednesday's close in Tokyo of 158.55 yen. In New York, the dollar rose to 158.045 yen, from late Wednesday's 158.015.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with those of late Wednesday, included: 1.6828 West German marks, down from 1.6848; 1.4550 Swiss francs, unchanged; 5.6450 French francs, down from 5.6530; 1,233.25 Italian lire, down from 1,234.75, and 1.16625 Canadian dollars, down from 1.16715.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold rose $1.90 an ounce, to $371.40. The Republic National Bank of New York later quoted a bid of $371.30, up $1.60 an ounce.
In London, gold rose to a late bid price of $370.65 an ounce, from $369.25 bid late on Wednesday. In Zurich, gold rose to a closing bid of $370.25 from $368.85.
Earlier in Hong Kong, gold fell $1.91 to close at a bid $370.07.
On the Comex, silver rose 1 cent an ounce, to $4.998.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Slower Rise In Costs of Commercials

BYLINE: By Randall Rothenberg

 BODY:
THE days of skyrocketing commercial production costs appear to be ending, as lavish song-and-dance ads, high production-company markups and competitive bidding among producers fade from view, according to a new study by the American Association of Advertising Agencies.
In its third annual ''Survey of Television Production Costs,'' the trade organization reported that the average tariff for a nationally broadcast television commercial rose only 8 percent in 1989 from the year before, to $190,000. In 1988, commercial costs rose 12 percent. Some agency executives say production expenses have tripled in the last decade. 
Among other things, the analysis of 2,498 commercials showed that on average commercial production costs for regional and local advertisers declined 6 percent, and the price for actors in national ads remained unchanged. From 1987 to 1988, the cost of creating a regional ad went up 29 percent, and talent costs rose 27 percent.
The advertising association hailed the study as proving ''the definitive end to the era of 'runaway' production costs.'' But independent commercial producers reacted more ambivalently, agreeing that agencies and producers were cooperating more to control costs, but maintaining that many commercial producers were being forced from the business.
''There's a depression in the production industry,'' said Barney Melsky, a founder and director of the Association of Independent Commercial Producers. ''The agencies have squeezed us into an unprofitable situation.''
Richard D. Hall, a past president of the independent producers association, said, ''Several companies have merged; several have gone out of business, and there are many more freelance directors out there.''
Within the advertising industry, production-cost control has been a divisive issue for years. Last year, Philip B. Dusenberry, the head of BBDO, New York, attributed the inflation to high directors' fees and the markup over costs charged by the production houses, which had conventionally been 35 percent. His comments drew widespread agency support, but were vigorously disputed by producers.
The 4A's findings show that the average producers' markup has slipped to 30 percent, a figure that several production representatives verified.
Executives at both agencies and production companies attributed last year's decline in the production inflation rate to a greater cost-consciousness at the ad agencies.
''The line of the year from agencies is, 'I've got a board to show, but I've got a dollar problem,' '' said Jay Kenny, an executive vice president of EUE/Screen Gems Ltd., a production company. (A board is a visual mockup of a commercial.) Mr. Kenny also said agencies were more willing to accept lesser-known and less-expensive directors. ''It used to be the better director always won,'' he said. ''That's not always the case today.''
Another factor apparently contributing to the lower inflation rate is the rise in noncompetitive bidding for production jobs. Conventional wisdom among agencies had it that pitting several production companies against each other would lead to a lower overall cost. But George Bragg, the head of production at Lintas U.S.A. and the chairman of the 4A's broadcast production committee, said that picking a single house, planning the job with it and negotiating the costs up front actually saved time and money.
The 4A's survey also indicated a slight shift in favor of simpler commercials. The total number of song-and-dance commercials declined to 31 last year, from 36 in 1988. Basic monologue spots increased to 259, from 144, and ads featuring consumer interviews or testimonials also increased to 134, from 79 in 1988.
But in the category of packaged-goods commercials - those for detergents, toothpastes and similar household products - production costs rose drastically. An average, nationally broadcast package-goods ad cost $144,000 last year, 13 percent more than in 1988. Advertising people say this reflects the paucity of creativity in the category.
''Package goods as a product category are catching up with the rest of the industry in terms of complexity of concepts,'' Mr. Bragg said. ''The Procter & Gamble commercial of five years ago is not the Procter & Gamble commercial of today.''

HEADLINE: Corporate-Tax Shortfall in Dispute

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 3

 BODY:
Congress's chief economist testified today that leveraged buyouts and other measures that increased corporate debt were an important factor in the Government's receiving less tax revenue from corporations than had been expected.
But an economist from the Bush Administration disagreed, saying the effect of buyouts was unclear and might have increased tax receipts.
The economists - Robert D. Reischauer, the director of the Congressional Budget Office, and Harvey S. Rosen, the Deputy Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for Tax Analysis - were asked by the Senate Finance Committee to explain why one of the main political selling points of the monumental Tax Reform Act of 1986 had been significantly overstated.
 
'A Mystery'
When the measure was enacted, lawmakers were told that the legislation, the most significant overhaul of the income tax system since World War II, would shift $120 billion in taxes from individuals to corporations in the first five years. 
In the three full years the law has been in effect, there has been a modest increase in corporate tax revenues, but the increase has been $20 billion to $30 billion below expectations. However, the total tax revenue from 1987 through 1989 was about as predicted, because receipts from individuals were higher than expected by approximately the same amount.
Referring to the shortfall in corporate tax payments, Senator Lloyd Bentsen, Democrat of Texas, who heads the Finance Committee, said: ''We've got a mystery on our hands. Well over $100 billion appears to be missing from the Federal Government's revenues, and we need to find out what the culprit is.''
Corporate lobbyists filled every seat in the hearing room today and stood against the walls. Some suggested that Mr. Bentsen was emphasizing the shortfall in corporate tax revenues as a prelude to trying to raise business taxes to meet budget goals this year.
Mr. Bentsen gave no specific indication that was his intention, but he has said it will be difficult to find the $14 billion in new taxes required for the next fiscal year by the budget resolution approved on Wednesday by the Senate Budget Committee.
Mr. Reischauer and Mr. Rosen agreed that the main reason corporations paid less in taxes than had been projected was that their overall profits were below projections. But they disagreed in some respects over why profits lagged.
Mr. Reischauer said that ''an important cause of lower-than-projected profits during the 1987 to 1989 period was further increased reliance by corporations on debt financing, instead of equity financing.''
Interest payments on debt directly reduce taxable profits. On the other hand, dividends are paid to shareholders after taxable profits are calculated.
In leveraged buyouts, the hottest trend on Wall Street in the late 1980's, investors using borrowed money, often raised by issuing high-yield ''junk bonds,'' buy up the stock of a company. In other cases, the managers of companies increased their debt to make their companies less attractive to hostile bidders.
 
'Profits to Bondholders'
Robert S. McIntyre, the director of Citizens for Tax Justice, a research organization sponsored by organized labor, told the senators he agreed with Mr. Reischauer's analysis. ''Corporations are sending their profits to bondholders rather than paying dividends to shareholders and taxes to the Treasury,'' he said.
Mr. Rosen said, however, that leveraged buyouts might actually have increased corporate profits, and thus tax payments, by leading to more efficient management. The data on tax payments collected so far, he said, are ''inadequate to make definitive statements.''
Mr. Reischauer and Mr. Rosen more or less agreed about other circumstances that had reduced corporate profits, including higher than anticipated interest rates and larger than expected increases in wages and salaries, which led to higher individual tax collections.

HEADLINE: Bush Asks Budget Talks With 4 Top Lawmakers

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 3

 BODY:
President Bush said today that he had invited the four top Congressional leaders to the White House on Sunday for discussions on the budget, a move lawmakers view as an effort by the President to regain control of a process on which Congressional Democrats seem to have the upper hand.
Some Democratic lawmakers also expressed the hope that Mr. Bush's move was a signal that he was ready to begin talking about raising taxes.
Mr. Bush, responding to questions at a White House news conference, brushed aside queries on that point, insisting the meeting would focus on the budget process, not its substance. ''I didn't say we're going to talk any substance,'' he said. ''We're not into a negotiation - we're talking process.'' 
Mr. Bush's move, on the heels of a House vote on Tuesday approving a Democratic-sponsored budget, seemed to be an attempt to short-circuit the process by proposing joint talks before the Senate acts on its own budget. If the talks are successful they would get the Republicans back in the game while avoiding a potential deadlock as the House and the Senate tried to resolve differences in their respective plans.
 
Congressional Leaders Named
The leaders in Congress who will attend the White House meeting are George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Senate majority leader; Bob Dole of Kansas, the Senate minority leader; Thomas S. Foley of Washington, the House Speaker, and Robert H. Michel of Illinois, the House minority leader.
While Democrats are divided about the wisdom of entering formal budget talks with the Administration, they agreed that the President's move appeared to be an attempt to regain control of a process that has taken on a life of its own in Congress.
''It looks to me like an effort to get a bridle on this horse before it gets out of the barn,'' said Senator James Sasser, the Tennessee Democrat who heads the Senate Budget Committee. The panel approved its version of the budget on Wednesday.
Mr. Bush acknowledged that ''nobody was too enthusastic'' about the budget he presented to Congress in January, but he said the budgets approved by the House and by the Senate Budget Committee had not been particularly well-received, either.
 
Budget Seen as Obsolete
After the House adopted a Democratic budget earlier this week Republicans chose not to offer the President's budget as an alternative, conceding that changing economic and political conditions had made it obsolete. That set in motion Mr. Bush's move today.
''What we have to do is start talking process and how we go forward,'' the President said. ''I'm not going to sit here and do nothing.''
Representative Dan Rostenkowski, an Illinois Democrat who is chairman of the the House Ways and Means Committee, said he was delighted that the President had initiated the meeting, and hinted that a discussion of ''process'' was merely the prelude to a more serious agenda that would ultimately include taxes.
''I understand that the President says the meeting is about procedure -that's what he's telling you,'' Mr. Rostenkowski said in an interview. ''I hope it's more than procedure.''
Earlier this year he pressed for a budget that called for tax increases. ''I've told the Presidenta big revenue increase won't hurt him politically, and I'd be most enthusiastic if we were talking about a big deal, not a small one,'' Mr. Rostenkowski said.
 
Some Are Wary of a Trap
But other Democrats, wary of a political trap, were clearly less enthusiastic about any immediate budget negotiations with the White House. Tempers flared when the subject came up at a meeting of the House Democratic whip organization this morning, and some members accused their leaders of ceding partisan advantage to the Administration by agreeing to any discussion before Congress had completed its own work on the budget.
Representative Leon E. Panetta, a Democrat from California who is chairman of the House Budget Committee and who has favored early negotiations, said he was encouraged that the Administration seemed to be ready to hasten the discussions. ''If you read all the signals and try to piece together all the quotes, on and off record, the implication is that we're moving in the direction of negotiating on all issues, including taxes,'' he said.
Mr. Panetta and other Democrats also agreed that Mr. Bush's invitation to the Congressional leaders was prompted by White House concern that the Federal deficit may be as much as $20 billion higher in the fiscal year 1991 than the Administration had estimated a few months ago.
This would require deeper spending cuts or larger revenue increases than envisioned in either the President's budget or the Congressional proposals to meet the deficit level set by the budget-balancing law for the next fiscal year, which begins on Oct. 1. The President acknowledged today that the Administration had been ''a little off'' on interest rates.

HEADLINE: Panel Urges Huge State Purchases To Save Adirondack Wilderness

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, May 4

 BODY:
A commission appointed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo to study the future of the Adirondack Park is recommending that New York buy more than 650,000 acres - more than 1,000 square miles - to preserve as wilderness and impose strong rules to limit development elsewhere in the park.
The panel, the Governor's Commission on the Adirondacks in the 21st Century, also plans to call for a one-year moratorium on all new construction on 90 percent of the park's privately held lands, and will urge permanent checks on most lakefront development.
 
A 'Last Clear Chance'
In a report scheduled for release next week, the commission concludes that the park has been overwhelmed by the pace of development, and that the state faces a ''last clear chance'' to preserve vast areas of Adirondack wilderness.
The report appears certain to set off an intense debate over the future of the park, an unusual combination of public and private land that includes some of the largest wilderness areas east of the Mississippi. 
Most of the commission's main proposals - including the moratorium -would require action by the State Legislature. Several lawmakers and other officials here said that for any of the proposals to become law this year, Mr. Cuomo would have to quickly embrace them and make them a priority in the closing months of the legislative session, expected to end in July.
Governor Cuomo said through a spokesman today that he had not read the report and would not comment on it. He created the commission last year after developers bought several tracts that had long been kept forested by logging companies.
The Adirondacks, the Governor said in his charge to the commission, are threatened by ''an era of unbridled land speculation and unwarranted development that may threaten the unique open space and wilderness character of the region.''
Zoning proposals advanced by the commission would sharply reduce the number of condominiums or other dwellings that could be constructed in nearly all of the park's back country, its most remote forest lands. The report said the action was urgently needed to stem pressures that mounted over the last few years as timber companies sold off their forest land to developers. More than 100,000 acres have been sold for subdivision in the last three years alone.
The land purchases sought by the commission would bring the total public ownership to over 50 percent of the park, from the present level of 42 percent. It also backs the purchase of so-called easements or conservation rights on other private lands, which would keep them private but prevent development.
The report even urged an expansion of the park itself, proposing that its ''blue line,'' as the park's boundary is known, be extended slightly at two places in the north.
While the zoning restrictions would head off second-home developments and other encroachment in Adirondack wilderness areas, they seemed likely to set off outrage among some park residents who say that such constraints make it difficult for many Adirondack natives to make a living there.
 
Some Residents Denounce Plan
One 800-member resident group, the Adirondack Fairness Coalition, which said it sought to balance park protection with economic growth, said today that the recommendations of the commission appeared to be ''preposterous in nature and scope.''
The group, which said it had seen a summary of the recommendations in a minority report prepared by one commission member, said the construction moratorium proposed by the commission would ''cripple the already weak economies of the 105 communities in the Adirondacks.''
The commission said that the state's Adirondack Park Agency, which oversees the park, had been overwhelmed by new development in the Adirondacks. The number of lots on subdivision proposals before the agency tripled in the last five years, and projections for 1990 show a 72 percent increase in lot proposals over last year.
The park agency should be replaced by two new agencies with broadly expanded powers to modify or even disapprove construction plans in the park, the commission concluded.
 
Costs of Plan Are Unclear
New York State ''must not let the park be overwhelmed by the short-sighted interests that would destroy the forest industry and treat the park as a mere piece of saleable real estate,'' the commission's chairman, Peter A. A. Berle, said in a letter to the Governor that accompanies the report. Mr. Berle, a former state Assemblyman and Environmental Conservation Commissioner, is president of the National Audubon Society.
The cost of the commission's recommendations will almost certainly be disputed. For instance, the panel projects a present cost of about $200 million for land acquisition, gauging the cost of land at $300 an acre. But the purchases would be spread over several years, and rising land prices could push the ultimate cost to many times that level.
Under the 10-year environmental bond act that is set to go before the voters this fall, the state would have $800 million to spend on land acquisition across the entire state.
It is uncertain how much The attention Albany will devote to the Adirondacks this year. The Governor and legislative leaders are at impasse over the state budget, now more than a month overdue. They are also expected to face revisions of the state's welfare system and a plan for rescuing the state's troubled hospitals.
 
Back Country Called Endangered
The commission said that the Adirondack Park Act, passed in the early 1970's, which was largely designed to counteract an explosion of second-home developments in and around the park's hamlets, had failed to anticipate the dangers to the park's back country.
That act divided the park's private lands into six land-use classes. The largest category, known as resource management, covers about half the park's private lands and includes the most remote areas of the Adirondacks.
Present regulations allow one house or other building for each 42.7 acres of land in that category. But under the zoning laws advocated by the commission, each private owner would be allowed only one building for each plot of land up to 2,000 acres, and one for each 2,000-acre plot after that.
The chief effect of such a rule would be to discourage timber companies from selling land for housing developments, although some critics are likely to argue that the rule could create a new market for construction of huge private estates in the back country that would price out all but the wealthy and still disturb the wilderness.
The report includes a total of 245 recommendations. Among them are creation of an Adirondack community development corporation with limited bonding authority to build affordable housing and water and sewage systems.
Aside from development, the commission attacks other human intrusions in the Adirondack wilderness. It proposes rules that would set noise limits for the first time on snowmobiles, boats and aircraft, and recommends new controls in the park on placement, size and color of commercial and roadway signs.

HEADLINE: Mohawks' Border World Of Violence and Tradition

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ST. REGIS INDIAN RESERVATION, N.Y., May 4

 BODY:
On a bluff overlooking the St. Lawrence River, a group of Indian men in jeans and Army fatigues were standing near a charred 20-foot-high mural of the Mohawk Tree of Peace. It was painted on the side of a burned-out building.
They explained that their enemies had lobbed a firebomb into the building last week, and they sounded almost casual. By current standards this qualified as a relatively minor annoyance. 
What impassioned them was a gunfight Tuesday morning that had consumed 1,500 rounds of ammunition, by their count, and left two men dead, by the police's. David George Jr., a beefy 42-year-old bricklayer who is part of a faction opposed to gambling on the reservation, told of a nine-hour siege Monday night at his home 100 yards from the Canadian border. He said his attackers fired from woods on the American side.
''We heard the first shots while we were sitting watching a movie - 'A Man Called Horse,' about some Indian with some kind of trouble,'' he said. ''They were trying to scare us off the reservation with submachine guns, and they probably thought we just had bolt-action rifles. But we fired back all night with our own automatics. When it got light outside, a dozen of us charged up the hill, and those guys ran into the woods.''
''Man,'' said David Francis, a 29-year-old ironworker who was there, ''you would have thought you were in Afghanistan.''
The violence is hardly comparable, and the situation remained calm today as New York and Canadian police patrolled. But the Mohawks' 14,000-acre reservation on the St. Lawrence River does share similarities with the land near the Khyber Pass: a tribal territory where teen-agers carry AK-47 rifles, a border region where smuggling is a routine part of the economy and a place where feuding religious and political factions are united only in their hostility to outside governments.
Matters of law and jurisdiction are fuzzy on the reservation, which straddles the Canadian border. The reservation's casinos, considered illegal by the Federal Government but legal by many of the Mohawks, are the immediate cause of the current tension.
Indians who regard gambling as inimical to their culture set up road-blocks last month to shut down the flow of casino patrons. The roadblocks were attacked by other Indians with guns and bats, and the feuding continued last weekend with arson and bursts of automatic gunfire at night.
More than 500 mourners marched today behind a green hearse carrying the coffin of Matthew (Ty) Pyke, a member of the anti-gambling faction who was shot on the road near Mr. George's house. His allies blamed the killing on the Warrior Society, a group of several hundred men associated with the pro-gambling faction since they set up roadblocks last year to stop the state police from raiding the casinos.
The Warriors have denied any involvement in the killing and accused the anti-gambling faction of starting the recent violence. They also denied accusations that they are financed by casino owners.
''We are neither for nor against gambling,'' Kakwirakeron, a spokesman for the Warriors, said today. ''Our position is that it is up to the community, not outsiders, to decide the gambling issue. We intervened only to protect our sovereignty.''
 
Splits Within Splits
Sovereignty is the perennial grievance among those Mohawks who consider themselves an independent nation, but who have to contend with demands from five bordering national, state and provincial governments. And there was widespread resentment this week when hundreds of police entered the reservation while Canadian military units waited outside.
But the sovereignty issue - whether the Mohawks should recognize the authority of New York State and the Federal Government on their reservation - is complicated by a long-standing dispute over who should govern the reservation.
There are three tribal governments claiming authority on the reservation, where population estimates range from 7,000 to 9,000. Some Mohawks, many of them Christians, favor the two existing Councils of Chiefs - one in Canada, and one in New York - which are chosen by popular vote. Others, who practice the Mohawk Longhouse religion, favor the traditional council of appointed chiefs. These camps are split within themselves on the issue of gambling, which is why staunch traditionalists are found defending institutions like Tony's Vegas International Casino.
The casino's owner, Anthony Laughing, sees the issue in economic terms.
''There are 700 to 800 jobs at the casinos,'' he said. ''My payroll is $100,000 a week, and this controversy has kept the public away for five weeks. Tony Laughing can survive this. But my people need paychecks, and there are no other jobs. What's going to happen to them if we shut the casinos?''
Tony's Vegas casino was attacked last summer by a mob of Indians who wrecked slot machines and caused an estimated $400,000 in damage.
The casino owner, a genial man with four gold rings, said he could understand why some Indians objected to the profits and the ambience of his 24-hour casino, which features a waterfall, chandeliers, 150 blackjack tables, 25 slot machines and other games.
 
'The Finer Things'
''If others want to go back to the traditional way of life, fine,'' he said. ''Let them go off on their own. But let the rest of us have the finer things in modern life. Maybe I'm being materialistic, but as long as I earn the money I don't see anything wrong with it.''
Nor did he have any apologies for the source of the money he said built his casino: an illicit practice known as ''buttlegging.'' American Indians buy Canadian cigarettes, but without having to pay the stiff Canadian taxes, then smuggle them back across the border to be sold at discount prices to non-Indians on another Mohawk reservation south of Montreal. The international border is generally regarded as artificial by reservation residents, many of whom cross it regularly in the course of daily life.
''Some people call it smuggling,'' the casino owner said. ''I say that we just happened to start the free-trade zone before the U.S. and Canada ever got around to it.''
While some of those who oppose gambling have talked of returning to a traditional economy, most take jobs off the reservation, often in construction. They resent the casinos, the cigarette trade, and what they see as an increasing level of drug smuggling as new activities that are corrupting young Indians. They speak of an ''Indian Mafia'' intimidating the reservation.
''They never work a day, and they Mr. George. ''I worked around their houses, and I've seen them bringing garbage bags home full of bills.''
''If you don't do what they say, they'll slash your tires, then they'll shoot at your car, and then go after you,'' said Mr. Francis, the veteran of Tuesday's shoot-out. ''They've got so much money coming in. You see these little creeps driving around brand new cars and trucks, building swimming pools, and it makes you mad.''

HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe;
Chief of Air Command Questions Bush Plan to Cut Nuclear Missiles

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 4

 BODY:
Challenging Administration policy on strategic weapons, the head of the Strategic Air Command expressed doubt today about the feasibility of President Bush's latest proposal to reduce long-range nuclear arms.
The official, Gen. John T. Chain, said he did not think that the Soviet Union would go along with Mr. Bush's proposal to ban land-based missiles with multiple warheads because Moscow relied on such weapons.
At the same time, General Chain questioned whether the United States had the money to carry out the Bush proposal. The President's plan would require the development of new single-warhead Midgetman missiles, and General Chain indicated that he did not think that the Air Force had enough money for such weapons. 
 
Rare Open Discord
It is rare for military officers to openly question policy directions set by the White House and Secretary of Defense. The comments by General Chain and some other recent remarks by senior officers suggest that budget cuts as well as the broad changes in military policy under discussion have produced anxiety in military circles.
General Chain said he did not understand the objection to intercontinental ballistic missiles that carry multiple warheads.
''I don't see where MIRV'ed ICBM's are destabilizing,'' he told reporters at a breakfast meeting, using the acronym for multiple independently targetable re-entry vehicles. His position was at variance with those of Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Brent Scowcroft, the President's national security adviser, who support Mr. Bush's plan.
 
Emphasizing 'Stealth' Bombers
General Chain was more supportive of Mr. Cheney's plan to put MX missiles on rail cars than he was of the costly Midgetman program. But he indicated that he did not believe the rail-car plan was vital, adding that his top priority was the purchase of the B-2, or Stealth, bombers.
Mr. Cheney said last week that he was cutting production plans for the new bomber from 132 to 75 planes. The general said that he supported that decision but that additional cuts in the B-2 program were unacceptable.
The general said keeping the 10-warhead MX missile ''in a silo does not bother me at all.''
Pentagon officials said General Chain's concerns that the cost of the Midgetman and MX programs would use money needed for new aircraft are broadly shared by Air Force leaders. The Air Force's long-range budget proposals include only limited funds for the two missile programs, enough to continue development of the systems but not enough to deploy the weapons, Pentagon officials say.
Both missile programs have been endorsed by the White House, which says that mobile MX and Midgetman missiles would reduce the vulnerability of American strategic weapons to Soviet attack.
Earlier this week, Vice Adm. Richard M. Dunleavy, assistant chief of naval operations, told Congress that the Navy was basing its aircraft purchase plans on the assumption that it will have 14 carrier battle groups, even though Mr. Cheney has indicated that his preliminary conclusion is that 12 are needed.
Mr. Cheney and the military services are preparing the Pentagon's spending request for 1992. The military services' spending preferences are being expressed as they enter long discussions with Mr. Cheney about what the 1992 budget request should be.
In his wide-ranging comments, General Chain indicated that he had not been consulted about Mr. Bush's proposal to ban land-based missiles with multiple warheads.
 
Second Round of Cuts Proposed
The President secretly proposed the ban in March, as part of a second round of arms reductions that would follow the strategic arms treaty to be signed this year. But President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union complained that Mr. Bush's plan focused exclusively on land-based missiles.
General Chainnoted that the Soviet Union has invested substantial sums in land-based multiple-warhead missiles, including the SS-18 and SS-24, which each carry 10 warheads.
''I can't personally imagine the Soviets giving up SS-18's and SS-24's,'' he said, adding that the weapons are the centerpiece of the Soviets' land-based missile force.
General Chain indicated that he did not see any particular need for the United States to give up multiple-warhead land-based missiles, either.
He complained that the Midgetman missile program to develop a new single warhead land-based missile cost $25 billion for 500 missiles, discounting for the effects of inflation.
 
May Testify Against Treaty
The general said he would testify against Senate approval of the strategic arms treaty if Congress did not approve money for nearly all 75 B-2 bombers sought by the Pentagon. But he added, ''My support of arms control is not contingent on ICBM modernization.''
A civilian Pentagon official said the goal of General Chain's approach seemed to be increasing the number of warheads that the American military would have for an attack on the Soviet Union while reducing spending on mobile attack. Such an approach, this Pentagon official said, would make the United States too dependent on a policy of launching missiles upon notice that an attack was under way, creating the possibility of miscalculation.
Former Defense Secretary Harold Brown proposed in a speech Thursday night that United States and the Soviet Union slash their strategic forces to 3,000 warheads as part of a second treaty that would follow the strategic arms treaty under negotiation.
But General Chain asserted that reductions of that magnitude would be unacceptable. ''I am not a fan of Start-2,'' he said, using a common reference to a second treaty.
Peter Williams, Mr. Cheney's spokesman, expressed reluctance to comment on the general's remarks, saying he had not seen a transcript of his comments. Mr. Williams added: ''If we came unglued every time somebody in the Pentagon expressed their views, we would not be able to function. We have become accustomed to it.''

HEADLINE: Unemployment Rate Rises to 5.4 Percent

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 4

 BODY:
The Labor Department reported today that the unemployment rate rose two-tenths of a point last month, to 5.4 percent, its highest level in more than a year, blunting fears of accelerated inflation and higher interest rates.
The latest data, which provided the first comprehensive view of economic performance in April, followed several recent reports indicating that both the economic pace and the inflation rate had quickened. The general reaction of economic analysts to today's figures was relief that the economy was in no near-term danger of overheating, thereby appearing to rule out any chance of a near-term tightening of monetary policy by the Federal Reserve.
The bond market soared on what was clearly good news for it, while the stock market posted a modest advance as it weighed the benefit of lower interest rates against the possibility that a slack economy would cause more erosion in corporate profits. 
There were sobering elements in today's report, including a decline in the number of jobs when temporary census workers were excluded and the 12th fall in the number of factory jobs in the last 13 months. But the figures did not revive serious fears of recession.
 
No Sign of a Slump
''I don't see any sign that the economy has slumped,'' declared Richard D. Rippe, a senior economist at Dean Witter Reynolds.
In interpreting the data before the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, Commissioner of Labor Statistics Janet L. Norwood said that while the job market was weak last month, the rise in the unemployment rate did not signal any fundamental change.
For one thing, she said, ''the April jobless rate follows a down tick in March and remains very close to the rate that has prevailed over the last year and a half.'' For another, she added, ''thus far we can discern no meaningful change in the measures that might signal a deteriorating unemployment situation.''
Dr. Norwood also said there was no rise in either the number of newly unemployed - those out of work for less than five weeks - or the number of people who lost their last jobs.
 
Scant Increase in Jobs
Probably the most startling figure in today's report was the scant rise of 64,000 jobs in nonfarm sectors, far below estimates that centered on about 375,000 and went to well above 400,000.
Those making the projections may have underestimated the degree to which hefty job gains in January and February, when relatively warm weather aided construction, borrowed strength from succeeding months. Construction jobs fell 99,000 last month after seasonal adjustment, showing the effects of a dearth of winter layoffs.
It also appeared that economists had expected too many new jobs from hiring by the Census Bureau.
Dr. Norwood may have caused some confusion when she said last month that more than 200,000 census takers were expected to ''be added in April.'' But she was referring to the cumulative total of monthly hiring of 22,000 in January, 5,000 in February, 90,000 in March and 78,000 in April - a total of 195,000 spread over four months.
 
Factory Jobs Fall Again
Factory jobs fell another 22,000 last month, with the weakness concentrated in durable goods, particularly machinery, the department said. Although output has been maintained, manufacturing remained clearly in the doldrums. Nevertheless, the ranks of production workers in factory jobs showed a small increase last month. Samuel D. Kahan, an economist at Fuji Securities Inc. in Chicago, said this implied the cutbacks were in support staff, a further sign that American industry has become leaner and more competitive.
Factory jobs have declined by 280,000 since March 1989, the report showed. Last month 46.5 percent of 141 manufacturing industries added to payrolls, up from 44 percent in March but down from 49.3 percent in February.
Over all, gains in service jobs were modest except in Government, which added about 50,000 positions, not including the 78,000 at the Census Bureau. Health services added 46,000 jobs and retail trade increased by 24,000 jobs. The total of 179,000 new service jobs was partly offset by a decline of 115,000 in goods-producing jobs to achieve the net advance of 64,000.
 
Modest Rise in Payroll Earnings
The length of the average work week in the private sector was unchanged, but the factory work week declined by 12 minutes, to 40.6 hours, and factory overtime fell by the same amount.
There were still other factors in today's report that helped prevent worry about an economic decline. One was an upward revision in jobs for March to a gain of 103,000 instead of the 26,000 increase initially reported.
Another was the disclosure that both hourly and weekly payroll earnings rose a modest three-tenths of 1 percent in April, slightly less than in March, despite a rise in the minimum wage that took effect at the beginning of the month. This was regarded as likely to reassure the Federal Reserve that wages are not producing worrisome inflation pressures that need to be quickly countered.
The survey of households, on which the overall unemployment rate of 6.8 million was based, showed a decline of 218,000 in civilian jobs and a 57,000 rise in the labor force, a combination that raised the ranks of the jobless by 275,000.
At 5.4 percent, the jobless rate is at the highest level since January 1989, and the April increase was the first change of more than one-tenth of a point - enough to be considered statistically significant - since a three-tenths increase, to 5.3 percent, in April 1989.
Nationally, the overall jobless rate. which includes people in the military, also rose two-tenths of a point last month, to 5.3 percent.

HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe;
Soviets, Saluting U.S., Harden German Stand

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, May 4

 BODY:
Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union today praised Washington's decision not to deploy advanced short-range nuclear weapons in Germany, but he said the move was not enough to make Moscow accept the membership of a united Germany in NATO.
In another indication of a general hardening of the Soviet position, Mr. Shevardnadze and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d failed to make any progress in three hours of talks toward resolving issues holding up completion of a treaty limiting long-range nuclear weapons.
The two sides had hoped to have such a treaty largely finished in time for the summit meeting on May 30 between President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Now they will have just one more chance to overcome their differences when Mr. Baker goes to Moscow on May 16. 
Administration officials said the Soviets, who last month suddenly took back some concessions they had already made at the arms control bargaining table, showed no inclination to soften their positions.
 
Facing a Lot of Issues
On both the German question and arms control, Administration officials described Mr. Shevardnadze as a man who was clearly wrestling with a lot of issues right now, all of which involve some reduction of Soviet power in Europe from what Moscow was used to over the last 40 years. This seems to have paralyzed him and his colleagues in some ways.
Mr. Shevardnadze arrived in Bonn, along with Mr. Baker, to join the Foreign Ministers of France, Britain and East and West Germany in Saturday's first ''two plus four'' negotiations on how a united Germany should be integrated militarily and politically into a new Europe.
While the talks are called two-plus-four, officials say they really will be five against one. The two Germanys and the three victorious World War II Allies are together on one side of the table and the Soviets alone on the other, and the only real question between them is, What will the West pay the Soviets to get their troops out of East Germany expeditiously and to allow a united Germany to join NATO?
On the eve of the talks, the bargaining has already begun. Through a series of bilateral meetings today between Mr. Shevardnadze and members of the five delegations, Germany and its Western allies dangled various economic and security incentives in front of the Soviet Minister. But judging from his arrival statement he intends to drive a hard bargain.
 
Seeks Neutral Status
Mr. Shevardnadze continued in both public and private discussions to refuse to even consider the idea of the united Germany in NATO, insisting instead that it be effectively neutral by becoming a member of both NATO and the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact.
While praising the Bush Administration's decision to halt deployment of new short-range nuclear weapons in Germany, Mr. Shevardnadze said of a united Germany joining NATO: ''For such a giant to belong to one bloc will not create conditions for stability. We think a united Germany should be a factor for peace and stability in Europe.''
For now American and NATO officials are treating this as little more than an opening bargaining position, and insist that because the Soviets have such a weak hand in Europe that they will sooner or later have to reconcile themselves to Germany's being in NATO only.
Indeed, the diplomatic talk of Bonn today was not about Mr. Shevardnadze's public remarks but rather about an article in the daily newspaper Berliner Zeitung written by a military adviser to the Soviet Communist Party Central Committee, Maj. Gen. Geli Batenin. General Batenin argued that a stable balance of power in Europe would best be insured by ''the incorporation of a unified Germany in the political organization of NATO.''
 
On Stationing of Forces
The Soviet general said NATO forces should not be extended into the eastern sector of a united Germany and that Soviet forces should remain there until a pan-European security system replaces both alliances.
The NATO position, agreed upon at a meeting of the alliance's Foreign Ministers in Brussels on Thursday, is that if the Soviets cooperate, NATO is prepared to offer Moscow a variety of security guarantees, including advancing the timetable for negotiations on the withdrawal of all American short-range nuclear weapons from Germany, including NATO guarantees not to deploy its forces in East Germany and NATO willingness to allow Soviet troops to remain in East Germany for a three- to five-year transition.
Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany followed up these military inducements to Moscow by holding out to Mr. Shevardnadze the prospect of a significant expansion in economic ties provided the Soviets cooperate on German unification, Mr. Kohl's spokesman Hans Klein said today.
Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany also said in a radio interview that there could be ''versatile economic relations that would not be disadvantageous to the Soviet Union after German unification.''
Nevertheless, if Mr. Gorbachev really tries to hold up the process of unification by refusing to remove his 380,000 troops unless a united Germany remains effectively neutral, American and NATO officials say they will not hesitate to use this to undermine his carefully cultivated image as the most forward-looking statesman in Europe.
This, NATO officials say, is not an inconsiderable threat for Mr. Gorbachev at a time when his program at home has little to show for itself. He has been able to point to his successful transformation of the Soviet image in the world arena as a reason his people should continue supporting him.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Meetings yesterday between Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, right, and Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union failed to resolve problems holding up a treaty limiting long-range nuclear weapons, which they had hoped to have completed by the end of this month. (Associated Press)
