LENGTH: 977 words

HEADLINE: Evolution on Europe;
Bush Sees Revamped NATO As Core of Europe's Power

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: STILLWATER, Okla., May 4

 BODY:
After opening the door for a revision of the Atlantic alliance, President Bush today gave a strong defense for using the North Atlantic Treaty Organization as the focus of Europe's security and for keeping the United States as the linchpin of the alliance in ''a new age of freedom.''
In a commencement speech at Oklahoma State University, Mr. Bush reaffirmed his commitment to cutting short-range nuclear missiles in Europe, negotiating larger cuts than currently planned in conventional forces, and moving NATO into a more political role.
But Mr. Bush insisted that American troops, nuclear weapons and political influence must remain on the Continent for the foreseeable future. He defended the need to maintain a unified military structure for the Atlantic alliance, even as the Warsaw Pact appears to be crumbling, by saying that Moscow's intentions remain unclear and that the Soviet Union will long remain a formidable military force in Europe. 
''President Gorbachev has made profound progress in his country, reforms so fundamental that the clock cannot be turned back,'' Mr. Bush said in a speech in which he seemed to be reaching for the vision of Europe's future that his critics have said was lacking from his foreign policy.
''Yet neither can we turn the clock ahead,'' he said, ''to know for sure what kind of country the Soviet Union will be in years to come.''
 
Emphasis on Europe
As he did on Thursday when he made his European arms control proposals, Mr. Bush said today that he wanted to broaden the role of the other, non-economic European group to which the United States belongs: the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, which includes neutral nations and current Warsaw Pact members and has focused primarily on human rights.
''The C.S.C.E. should offer new guidelines for building free societies,'' Mr. Bush said, ''including setting standards for truly free elections, adopting measures to strengthen the rule of law and pointing the way in the needed but painful transition from centralized, command economies to free markets.''
Mr. Bush said he supported proposals to have ''regular consultations among senior representatives of the C.S.C.E. countries'' and said members of the organization should ''consider whether new C.S.C.E. mechanisms can help mediate and settle disputes in Europe.''
 
Gesture Toward Thatcher
Mr. Bush echoed a proposal made by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain that seemed intended as a political gesture toward Mrs. Thatcher when she is suffering politically at home and has lost some battles in the struggle over the future of NATO. Mrs. Thatcher had been a strong advocate of plans to modernize the short-range American nuclear missiles in West Germany; Mr. Bush canceled that program on Thursday.
Mr. Bush also praised Mrs. Thatcher, alone among the allied leaders, as ''one of freedom's greatest champions of the last decade.''
Mr. Bush's comments about the security conference were also a gesture to President Francois Mitterrand of France, who has been looking toward the institution as a new forum for political and security dialogue in Europe.
But Mr. Bush made it clear that he did not want the conference to have a role in military affairs and said the purpose of an expanded security conference would be to ''reinforce'' NATO politically, not replace it.
 
NATO as the Foundation
''My European colleagues want the United States to be a part of Europe's future,'' he said. ''I believe they are right. The United States should remain a European power in the broadest sense, politically, militarily and economically. And as part of our global responsibilities, the foundation for America's engagement in Europe has been, and will continue to be, NATO.''
Mr. Bush's speech was the first in a series of commencement addresses this spring in which he plans to discuss national security. Although he sought to look to the future, Mr. Bush drew his vision today out of the chaos of the post-World War I years, the firestorm of World War II and the superpower confrontation of the cold war.
''Throughout our history,'' he said, ''great upheavals in Europe have forced the American people to respond, to make deep judgments about the part we should play in European affairs,'' he said. ''I believe that, now, we are poised at another such moment, a critical time in our strategic relationship with our neighbors across the Atlantic.''
Acknowledging that the threat of Soviet aggression has faded as a justification for NATO, Mr. Bush said: ''Our enemy today is uncertainty and instability. So the alliance will need to maintain a sound, collective military structure with forces in the field backed by larger forces that can be called upon in a crisis.''
 
'Enduring Compact'
Mr. Bush said that even with major cuts in conventional armed forces and nuclear weapons, ''militarily significant U.S. forces must remain on the other side of the Atlantic for as long as our allies want and need them.''
''These forces demonstrate, as no words can, the enduring political compact that binds America's fate with Europe's democracies,'' he said.
Mr. Bush used slightly cooler language than in recent weeks in talking about Soviet internal politics.
''It will be crucial,'' he said, ''to see whether Moscow chooses coercion or peaceful dialogue in responding to the aspirations of the Lithuanian people and nationalities within the Soviet Union. The only noble answer lies in a dialogue that results in unencumbered self-determination for Lithuania.''
The comments did not signal a change in Mr. Bush's policy of supporting Lithuanian independence in principle, while declining to take sides. The incrementally stronger tone also seemed to lack any political risk, since it followed signs of an emerging compromise between Moscow and Vilnius.

LENGTH: 956 words

HEADLINE: CONSUMER'S WORLD;
Views and Luxuries Draw Tourists to Trains

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
This summer, scenic and luxury train travel for comparatively modest prices will be unfurling the richness of the American landscape for thousands of vacationers. Travel agents say there are more choices for these trips than ever before, and more customers, too.
''Some of it is nostalgia, with people wanting to get back to the way things were before,'' said Dorothy Szymaszek, president of New Scotland Travel, a travel agency in Albany. ''Train rides are a very relaxed way to travel.'' 
''The big market is older people who have the time, plus the ones who don't like to fly,'' said Cynthia Newman, president of Waters Travel Service, a Washington travel agency.
It's a way to see the United States from a different perspective, said Clifford Black, a spokesman for Amtrak. ''You go through parts of the country that are virtually inaccessible by other means.''
And it can all be seen in comfort. Some observation cars have seats with large wraparound picture windows and translucent roofs that offer an unobstructed 360-degree view of the land during the day and the stars at night.
 
European Ambience
 Amtrak has a variety of scenic routes. Some travel companies are selling train trips with the ambience of European luxury trains like the Orient Express. Others are offering excursion trains on main lines or special tracks to provide a sense of how travelers moved around before automobiles and airplanes took over. Here are some of the trips being offered.
California Zephyr - This is the most popular of Amtrak's scenic routes. It's a 52-hour trip from Chicago to the San Francisco Bay Area. One-way coach fares are $196 for those who want to sleep in their seats. For more comfortable sleeping-car accommodations, with meals included, there are a variety of possibilities ranging in cost from an additional $280 (for an economy bedroom) to $589 (for a deluxe bedroom).
Coast Starlight - A 35-hour Amtrak ride from Los Angeles to Seattle costs $145 one-way in coach. To ride in a sleeper, add $159 to $330, meals included.
Adirondack - A 10-hour day trip aboard an Amtrak train from New York to Montreal by way of the Hudson River Valley and the shore of Lake Champlain costs $72. To ride in a custom-class car, with accommodations similar to those found in a parlor car, add $8 to the fare.
American-European Express - A new train company that began luxury-only service with a 17-hour run between Washington and Chicago last Nov. 15. A similar daily trip that takes 20 hours started Tuesday between New York and Chicago by way of Philadelphia. One-way fares range from about $500 in a compartment to about $1,500 in a presidential suite.
''We have a club car with a baby grand piano,'' said Barbara Schmidt, a vice president. ''And a paramount part of the trip is the food - a seven-course dinner, brunch, cocktail reception and tea.''
California Sun Express - This is a private rail car service from Los Angeles to Oakland. It was started about a month ago by Princess Railtours, a unit of Princess Cruises, at a cost of $179 one-way for two people. Along with the scenery, meals are a highlight of the 11-hour trip, with a number of seatings for dinner in the cruise-ship pattern.
Instead of using the trip for point-to-point rail transportation, travelers can take a mini-vacation package, stopping at San Luis Obispo, staying at the Inn at Morro Bay and touring the Hearst Castle for a total cost of $399 for two.
In addition to these trips, there are the scores of smaller tourist railroads across the country. They generally provide short trips, use historic equipment and run on small-town branch lines. Some of these trains are pulled by turn-of-the-century steam locomotives and others operate over narrow-gauge tracks.
Luxury train travel in the United States dates back to 1859 when the first Pullman service provided sleeping cars aboard railroads for long-distance travelers. In the early 1900's, trains like the Twentieth Century Limited provided pampered travel between New York and Chicago.
After World War II travelers took planes to speed things up. Passenger service became an albatross to the railroads, whose revenues and profits came from carrying freight, not people. And Americans who wanted to travel on their own schedule turned to the automobile.
 
'History Alive'
 In 1970 Congress created the National Railroad Passenger Corporation, known as Amtrak, to operate all regularly scheduled inter-city passenger train service in the continental United States. Since then its rail schedules and fares have been listed in the airline computer systems used by travel agents. And railroading has again attracted large numbers of travelers.
''More than four million passengers rode aboard historic or scenic trains in 1989,'' said Mark Smith, publisher of Locomotive & Railway Preservation Magazine. ''It's amazing what a chord railroading strikes in people. This is history alive.''
 
RAIL TRAVEL: WHO HAS WHAT
 Here are sources for information on scenic or luxury train travel in the United States.
 Amtrak - For travel throughout the continental states: Amtrak Distribution Center, P.O. Box 7717, Itasca, Ill. 60143. Phone: 800-USA-RAIL.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Posts Broad Decline; U.S. Report on Jobs Is Cited

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell yesterday against all major currencies except the Japanese yen after the Government said the United States unemployment rate for April rose to its highest level in more than a year.
The jobless rate rose to 5.4 percent in April from 5.2 percent in March.
''That seemed to be what set it off,'' Mike Ballow, a currency market analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said of the dollar's decline. 
Signs of economic weakness, like higher unemployment, might cause the Federal Reserve to ease interest rates. Lower rates would reduce the attractiveness of dollar-denominated investments, compared with those for other currencies.
Traders right now are ''only concentrating on interest rates,'' said Walter Simon, a vice president at Bank Julius Baer & Company in New York.
Also working against the dollar was a rise in bond prices, which sent bond yields lower, Mr. Simon said.
In addition, traders said the dollar's fall was hastened when the price crossed certain technical support levels in relation to other currencies.
Against the West German currency, the dollar fell in New York to 1.6660 marks from 1.6828.
The British pound was also more expensive, costing $1.6635 in New York, up from Thursday's $1.6410. Earlier in the day, the pound had moved higher in London, rising to $1.6595, from $1.6425 late Thursday.
The dollar also fell against the French franc, the Swiss franc, the Italian lira and the Canadian dollar.
Against the Japanese currency, however, the dollar bought 158.30 yen, up from 158.05 yen a day earlier. Markets in Japan were closed for a holiday, but earlier in London the dollar also gained, trading at 158.25 yen, up from 158.10 yen late Thursday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday, included: 1.4430 Swiss francs, down from 1.4550; 5.5930 French francs, down from 5.6450; 1,221 Italian lire, down from 1,233.25, and 1.1629 Canadian dollars, down from 1.16625.
Gold prices were mixed. Bullion fell 50 cents, to $370.90 an ounce, on the Commodity Exchange in New York. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $371.30 an ounce, unchanged from Thursday.
Gold rose in London to a late bid of $371.45, from $370.65 late Thursday. In Zurich, gold closed at $371, up from $370.25. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold rose $2.69 to close at $372.76 an ounce.
Silver for current delivery rose to $5 an ounce, from $4.998 late Thursday, on the Commodity Exchange. Silver in London had a late bid of $5.05 an ounce, up from $5.04 late Thursday.

HEADLINE: Norton's Net Down 36.4%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WORCESTER, Mass., May 4

 BODY:
The Norton Company, which spent many weeks fighting a hostile takeover bid, said today that its first-quarter profits fell 36.4 percent, mainly because of losses stemming from its operations in Brazil, which has been suffering from a recession.
Norton, a leading maker of abrasives and engineering materials, said its net income totaled $19.4 million, or $1.01 a share, compared with $30.5 million, or $1.45 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Revenues totaled $414.4 million, up 6.7 percent from $388.2 million a year earlier.
Last month Norton agreed to be acquired by Compagnie Saint-Gobain of France, one of the world's leading glass makers, for $90 a share, or $1.8 billion. The move staved off a $1.6 billion hostile bid by BTR P.L.C. of Britain.
Norton declined to comment on how the battle against BTR would affect earnings for the year.
Norton's stock was unchanged today at $88.875 on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Interest Rates Fall On Job Data

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Interest rates plunged yesterday, as prices of Treasury securities soared in response to news of an unexpectedly small increase in nonfarm employment in April. Only 64,000 non-farm jobs were added in April, and the unemployment rate rose by two-tenths of 1 percent, to 5.4 percent, its highest level in 15 months.
Those who invest in fixed-income debt viewed the jobs data as precluding any moves by the Federal Reserve to force up interest rates. This latest sign of a weakening economy was also seen as lessening inflationary pressures. Rising interest rates and inflation are the two major fears of investors in fixed-income securities. 
But the bond market's euphoria was tempered by fears that a weaker domestic economy would undermine the dollar, which fell after the employment figures were released. The sharp decline in interest rates also raised concerns that bidders at next week's Treasury auctions of $30.5 billion of notes and bonds might be less enthusiastic than they seemed to be earlier this week.
 
Explosion in Demand
 But yesterday demand for Treasury securities and other fixed-income issues exploded soon after the Government's monthly employment report was released at 8:30 A.M. As prices rose, many dealers and others who had sold Treasuries short earlier rushed to buy out of their positions, before their losses grew.
Despite some afternoon profit taking, late trading found the Treasury's benchmark long bonds, the 8.5 percent issue maturing in 2020, being offered at 96 21/32, up 1.5 points on the day, or $15 for each $1,000 of face value. As a result, the long bond's yield tumbled to 8.82 percent from 8.97 percent the day before and from 9.02 percent a week ago.
''Although the long end of the Treasury market posted strong gains, most investors were more interested in the shorter maturities, now that the surprisingly small growth in April jobs has virtually eliminated any possibility of credit tightening by the Fed,'' said William V. Sullivan Jr., senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds.
 
Increase Was Expected
 What stunned many market participants, Mr. Sullivan added, was that ''the consensus in the Street was that the recent hirings of census workers would result in a rise in April nonfarm employment by roughly 400,000 people. Moreover, the data show that non-farm payrolls were actually down by 14,000 or so last month.''
The lessening of fears that the Fed would tighten credit was one major reason for the strong interest in short-term Treasury issues. Any move by the central bank to tighten or loosen credit has an impact most immediately on the short end of the Treasury market.
For example, a week ago, when many expected the Fed to force up interest rates, the spread between 90-day Treasury bills and the long bond was 1.25 percentage points. Late yesterday, the spread had shrunk to one percentage point after the discount rate on the 90-day bills dropped 10 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 7.76 percent; six-month bills fell 16 basis points, to 7.82 percent, and the one-year bills plunged 22 basis points, to 7.83 percent.
Meanwhile, the yields plunged on the refunding issues, which traded on a when-issued basis. The yield on $10.5 billion of three-year notes, which are to be auctioned on Tuesday, dropped to 8.75 percent from 9 percent, while the outstanding 8 3/8's of 1993 climbed by 17/32, to 99 1/32, for a yield of 8.77 percent.
The $10 billion of 10-year notes slated for sale Wednesday fell to 8.80 percent from 8.98 percent in when-issued trading, while the outstanding 8 1/2's of the year 2000 jumped 1 2/32, to 97 26/32, for a yield of 8.83 percent. The yield on the new 30-year long bonds, which will be auctioned on Thursday, declined to 8.79 percent from 8.94 in when-issued trading, three basis points below the yield of 8.82 percent on the outstanding long bonds.
Mr. Sullivan and other credit market experts were unsure just how much of an impact the decline in Treasury yields would have on next week's pivotal quarterly refunding auctions. All Japanese markets were closed yesterday in observance of Children's Day, a national holiday. ''One thing in the Treasury's favor is that yields on West German and Japanese Government bonds have been falling,'' Mr. Sullivan said.
 
West German Yield Down
 The yield on the West German 10-year bonds dropped 29 basis points yesterday, to 8.51 percent, or 32 basis points below the yield on the Treasury's 10-year notes. The last quoted yield on 10-year Japanese bonds was 7.42 percent.
Another question that may be answered at next week's Treasury refunding, Mr. Sullivan said, was how much damage the April employment data did to the dollar. Many European foreign exchange houses had already closed for the weekend when Washington released the data.
The Fed did not intervene in the money market yesterday, largely because the bedrock cost of credit, the rate that banks charge each other for brief loans, eased slightly, to 8 1/8 percent from 8 3/16 percent. Dealers said the lower funds rate indirectly reflected the smaller-than-expected increase in Treasury balances from tax receipts. When these balances decline, as they invariably do, they tend to drain lendable reserves from the banking system.

HEADLINE: Seidman Vows to Set His Own Exit Date

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 4

 BODY:
The unusual public negotiations between L. William Seidman and the White House continued today, with the manager of the savings and loan bailout insisting that he would pick the time of his departure.
In his first extensive public comments on the question, Mr. Seidman said that President Bush ''did not ask me to leave'' and ''did not encourage me to leave'' and that the timing ''is truly my decision.''
The remarks, seen as an attempt by Mr. Seidman to maintain his dignity while not defying the President, capped a week in which comments by White House officials and President Bush himself made it clear that the Administration would like Mr. Seidman to leave well before his term ends in October 1991.
Mr. Seidman's comments came after his appearance before a House Banking Committee panel on the savings and loan bailout. As chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, he is also chairman of the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency created by Congress to administer the bailout and spend at least $50 billion over the next two years. 
The F.D.I.C. chief, who is highly regarded in Congress both for his skill as a banking regulator and his candor about the size of the savings crisis, has frequently clashed with top officials at the Treasury and John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff. Industry experts say Mr. Sununu and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady are leading the effort to force Mr. Seidman out.
Mr. Seidman has been a thorn in the side of the Administration for some time. During talks over the bailout legislation, Mr. Seidman broke with the Administration by seeking added powers for his agency. In addition, he persuaded Congress to approve a measure that would prevent the President from arbitrarily removing the head of the F.D.I.C. Mr. Seidman has also been outspoken in saying that the Administration's estimates of the bailout's costs are low and that Treasury officials have intervened excessively in the day-to-day running of the bailout.
On Thursday, President Bush, in an attempt to mute Congressional and industry criticism of the White House's increasing pressure on Mr. Seidman, both praised him and made his departure final by saying that he heartily agreed with Mr. Seidman's recommendation that his successor be the Federal Reserve Board's chief banking regulator, William Taylor. Mr. Taylor is on loan from the Fed to serve as chief executive of the oversight board of the Resolution Trust Corporation.
Mr. Seidman said today that he would remain at least until the end of June, a date he has set to complete a plan by the trust corporation to sell or liquidate 141 ailing institutions at a cost to the public of almost $57 billion. But Mr. Seidman left open the possibility that he might stay longer.
''President Bush did not speed up my decision,'' he said. ''I have been saying for several months that I planned to leave once the R.T.C. is up and running,'' but he added that he would decide when that time is.
Until the so-called June 30 project is completed, he said, ''I will not think about what I am going to do.''
 
Praise From Panel Members
 In Mr. Seidman's appearance before the House panel, which has in the past received him warmly, the tone was somber.
''One of the bright spots in this whole mess has been Mr. Seidman,'' said Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat from Brooklyn. ''The Administration should be on its hand and knees begging you to stay.''
Mr. Seidman cautioned the lawmakers against expecting quick results from the savings and loan rescue, saying that even a year from now the end will not be in sight.
''Don't be impatient,'' he told lawmakers with a hint of nostalgia. ''This is a long, hard job. It isn't going to be accomplished anytime soon.''
 
Warning on Interest Rates
 Mr. Seidman pointed to a recent rise in interest rates as a double threat.
First, the increased borrowings by the Treasury that are needed to finance the rescue push up interest rates, putting pressure on consumers and the economy. Then, higher interest rates generally translate into lower real estate values, which increases the bailout's cost to the taxpayer.
''The real pain of what is taking place, on everything from increased Government borrowing to the effect on real estate markets, is still being felt,'' Mr. Seidman said. ''I think it is very important that no one expect by this time next year we'll all feel great.''
As he has in the past, Mr. Seidman stressed that the losses in the savings and loan industry, which are increasing at a rate of $28 million a day, will not be stemmed until all the real estate acquired by Resolution Trust has been sold to the private sector.
 
Price Cutting Is Planned
 To speed up asset sales, the agency has significantly liberalized its sales guidelines to allow considerable markdowns on property that is not selling well.
He reiterated that the bailout was almost certain to cost more than the Bush Administration has predicted. He took exception, however, to the estimates by Comptroller General Charles A. Bowsher, who last month said the cost of the bailout, plus interest expenses on the borrowings, could be as much as $500 billion during a 30-year period.
''It's like buying a $100,000 house and saying that it really is $300,000 because you are taking out a mortgage on it,'' Mr. Seidman said.
At the hearing, lawmakers lavished praise on the F.D.I.C. chairman, gave cautious support to Mr. Taylor and asked Mr. Seidman what advice he had for Mr. Taylor.
''The first thing I'd say is take a hard look before accepting the job,'' he said. ''And don't expect a lot of praise.''

HEADLINE: Lagging African Economies Perplex Aid Organizations

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 4

 BODY:
Even though aid programs pump $15 billion a year into sub-Saharan Africa, the living standards of the region's 450 million people have declined in the 30-odd years since its independence.
Now the area, whose troubles have been frustrating global economic managers and challenging traditional thinking about development for some time, is competing with Eastern Europe for scarce world capital.
''I often hear Africans express a fear that they will be forgotten, or marginalized: this fear is not unreal,'' warns Michel Camdessus, managing director of the International Monetary Fund. Preliminary sessions of the spring meetings of the fund and the World Bank, the continent's main providers of money, started today. Among the subjects before the formal sessions, which open Monday, is: what to do with Africa. 
To avoid ''marginalization,'' the donors are calling for a much bigger effort by the Africans themselves, increasingly linking the flow of funds both to policy changes by African governments and to more governmental accountability to the governed. Under a proposal that is chiefly the idea of the Bush Administration, which the I.M.F. membership of more than 150 governments is expected to consider, countries that are in arrears - almost half of which are in Africa - risk losing their voting rights in the organization.
Some African leaders join the industrialized nations in supporting the linkage between aid and accountablity. One is President Abdou Diouf of Senegal, who said, ''Africa requires not just less government but better government.''
Along with such countries as the Central African Republic, Gambia, Ghana, Guinea and Mauretania, Senegal has started a comprehensive program of administrative changes. The programs aim at improving the civil service through competitive entrance examinations, regular staff appraisals and selective improvements in the pay structure.
''I fear that many of Africa's leaders have been more concerned about retaining power than about the long-term development interests of their people,'' said Barber B. Conable Jr., the World Bank's president, who criticized the region's autocratic political systems, as well as the ''nepotism'' and ''corruption'' that arise from them.
Conditions in Zaire illustrate the difficulties. Many African experts believe that President Mobutu Sese Seko has worsened Zaire's poverty by diverting well over $5 billion of state money into his personal accounts and assets abroad, including a 16th-century castle in Spain, a 32-room palace in Switzerland and estates in Portugal and Italy.
 
Voice for People Urged
 ''The only way to halt the continued impoverishment of the African people is to give them a voice in making decisions that affect their livelihood,'' said Kofi K. Apraku, a Ghanaian-born professor of economics at the University of North Carolina. Noting that Africans must do more to help themselves, Pierre Beregevoy, the French Finance Minister, said that in the competition for capital it was important to improve conditions for foreign investors. He added that the Africans should start by offering safe and remunerative savings for their own citizens.
Bush Administration officials also see much room for self-help. ''There's been capital flight, lack of performance, an unwillingness to change policies,'' a senior Treasury official said. ''I'm not saying it's all their fault, but theirs is an important part of the deficiency.''
On the list of policy changes sought by the World Bank and the I.M.F. are the phasing out of the more than 3,000 so-called ''parastatal'' or governmental enterprises, most of which lose money and fail to deliver adequate services; the simplification of customs procedures, legal systems and tax regimes; the deregulation of prices, interest rates and foreign exchange, and added scope for market mechanisms and the private sector.
 
Programs Are Criticized
 Many such measures are incorporated in so-called structural adjustment programs being put into effect by some 30 African countries under the guidance of the World Bank and the monetary fund, the two large lending organizations founded 45 years ago at Bretton Woods, N.H. But not all Africans are happy about the situation.
''Many Africans claim that the Bretton Woods institutions today exercise more power over Africa than the colonial authorities could ever have dreamt of during the colonial era,'' said Adebayo Adedeji, a Nigerian who is the executive secretary of the Economic Commission for Africa.
The proposal to cut off voting rights for countries in arrears illustrates the point. As of last Jan. 31, the monetary fund reported, arrears of more than six months amounted to $3.4 billion, more than $500 million of which was more than three years overdue.
 
Contributions Could Be Sold
 To get their voting rights restored, the governments would have to undertake even more closely supervised economic changes. Should they fail to live up to their obligations, the hard currency or gold that these countries had contributed to the monetary fund when they became members could be sold to satisfy the fund's claims against them.
Five of the 11 countries in arrears are African: Liberia, Sierra Leone, Somalia, the Sudan and Zambia. The other six are Guyana, Honduras, Kampuchea, Panama, Peru and Vietnam.
With a surge in debt in the last two decades, from $6 billion in 1970 to $134 billion in 1988, most experts agree that there is little likelihood that the African debt will be repaid.

HEADLINE: Jean S. Picker, 69; Delegate to the U.N. In the 60's and 70's

BYLINE: By JOAN COOK

 BODY:
Jean Sovatkin Picker, a former United States delegate to the United Nations, died yesterday at her home in Camden, Me., after a long illness. She was 69 years old. 
Mrs. Picker was appointed a delegate by President Johnson in 1968. She was reappointed special senior adviser to the delegations to six subsequent General Assemblies and to eight sessions of the Economic and Social Council under Presidents Nixon and Ford.
Mrs. Picker was born in Brooklyn and graduated from Smith College. She went to work for Life magazine as a researcher and became a member of the editorial board and a correspondent.
Her association with the United Nations began in 1953, when she became a volunteer lecturer with its Office of Public Information.
From 1958 to 1968, she was a member of the Committee of Correspondence, which trained women from poorer countries for leadership roles.
 
Friend of Eleanor Roosevelt
In 1978, Mrs. Picker became director of the United Nations Association of the United States, an independent group founded by Eleanor Roosevelt to educate others about the nature and function of the United Nations.
In 1955, she collaborated with Mrs. Roosevelt to write ''The United Nations: What You Should Know About It.'' The collaboration became a friendship, and in 1973, she wrote ''Eleanor Roosevelt: Her Day.''
In 1988, Mrs. Picker became the first recipient of the Eleanor Roosevelt Leadership Award for her commitment to international cooperation.
She is survived by her husband, Harvey Picker, dean emeritus of the School of International Affairs at Columbia University, and two daughters, Frances Mrachek of Newton, Mass., and Gale Picker of Falls Church, Va.

HEADLINE: The Talk of Little Italy;
A CHANGING LITTLE ITALY SAYS NO TO A HOTEL

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS

 BODY:
Squeezed between Chinatown, SoHo and the tip of the government zone of lower Manhattan, Little Italy has always fought to hold its distinctive head high, acknowledging that parking on its narrow streets is next to impossible but proud that its crime rate is low and that the neighbors still know one another, usually three or four generations back.
But the cultural and economic forces reshaping much of the city are changing Little Italy, too. While tourists still flock to the area for pasta and cappuccino, much of what was once Italian owned has been sold to Chinese investors over the last 15 years; many buildings named for places or families in Italy now bear signs painted in bold red Chinese characters.
In the northwest end of the neighborhood, spreading downtown chic has fostered condominiums and restaurants where pasta is a fashionable option instead of a staple.
Now comes a proposal for a seven-story 156-room hotel and residents are saying, enough. They say that the building would ruin the neighborhood, and that what should rise up instead is affordable housing for people who want to stay where they were born. 
''They should build an apartment house for people,'' said Freddy Landano, a retiree who sat inside Esposito Meats on Mulberry Street during the slow hours of a recent afternoon. ''A lot of people are looking for rooms.''
More than 100 residents showed up for a meeting last month to protest the hotel, said Anne A. Compoccia, who grew up in Little Italy and is the vice president of its Chamber of Commerce, even though she now lives in TriBeCa. ''We don't want it to become a den of iniquities for pimps, prostitutes, whatever,'' she said. ''We believe this hotel will be the destruction of the community, and we don't want it.''
The hotel, to be built at the southeast corner of Baxter and Hester Streets, is permitted under area zoning, said Martha Ritter, a spokeswoman for the Department of City By CONSTANCE L. HAYS The Talk of Little Italy Squeezed between Chinatown, SoHo and the tip of the government zone of lower Manhattan, Little Italy has always fought to hold its distinctive head high, acknowledging that parking on its narrow streets is next to impossible but proud that its crime rate is low and that the neighbors still know one another, usually three or four generations back.
But the cultural and economic forces reshaping much of the city are changing Little Italy, too. While tourists still flock to the area for pasta and cappuccino, much of what was once Italian owned has been sold to Chinese investors over the last 15 years; many buildings named for places or families in Italy now bear signs painted in bold red Chinese characters.
In the northwest end of the neighborhood, spreading downtown chic has fostered condominiums and restaurants where pasta is a fashionable option instead of a staple.
Now comes a proposal for a seven-story 156-room hotel and residents are saying, enough. They say that the building would ruin the neighborhood, and that what should rise up instead is affordable housing for people who want to stay where they were born.
''They should build an apartment house for people,'' said Freddy Landano, a retiree who sat inside Esposito Meats on Mulberry Street during the slow hours of a recent afternoon. ''A lot of people are looking for rooms.''
More than 100 residents showed up for a meeting last month to protest the hotel, said Anne A. Compoccia, who grew up in Little Italy and is the vice president of its Chamber of Commerce, even though she now lives in TriBeCa. ''We don't want it to become a den of inequities for pimps, prostitutes, whatever,'' she said. ''We believe this hotel will be the destruction of the community, and we don't want it.''
The hotel, to be built at the southeast corner of Baxter and Hester Streets, is permitted under area zoning, said Martha Ritter, a spokeswoman for the Department of City Planning. Frank Marino, a spokesman for Chatwal Hotels, the chain that plans to build the hotel, said construction is expected to begin later this year. Chatwal builds mid-range hotels sometimes affiliated with franchises like Days Inns.
''Our aim is to work with the community,'' said Barry S. Mann, the chain's president, who has attended neighborhood meetings about the hotel. ''We want to be part of the community. I told them I would like to give preference on employment to local residents. One gentleman said he doesn't expect anybody in Little Italy to be looking for a job as a maid.''
Some residents said the hotel might be an asset to the area. ''It would probably bring more people around spending money,'' said Dino Forzano, who owns Forzano's Italian Imports, where shoppers can buy manicotti makers, espresso machines, spaghetti-western soundtracks and socks decorated with maps of Italy. ''There are really no hotels around here, except those places on the Bowery.''
Others said they doubted any traveler would want to stay where the hotel is to be built. ''Baxter Street is garbage trucks all night long,'' said Sal Lapolla, a retired former proprieter of a Mulberry Street liquor store. He lives in an apartment that backs up on Baxter Street. ''Two o'clock in the morning they start, then every half-hour after that until 7. They're stationary for 15 minutes - clung-clung, clung-clung -then they race their motors to get the electricity back. It's unbearable.''
Noise will not be a problem, Mr. Mann said. ''We'll have double Thermopane soundproof windows,'' he said, ''similar to those found in airport hotels.''
 
'Really Little China'
 There have been links between China and Italy at least as far back as Marco Polo. But an increase in Chinese immigration and a flow of capital from Hong Kong, China and Taiwan has steadily widened the boundaries of Chinatown - at Little Italy's expense, some say.
''This is really Little China,'' said Anthony Luna, whose family has operated a neighborhood restaurant on Mulberry Street bearing the family name since 1878. ''I don't know why they call it Little Italy.''
Along Mulberry Street, Mr. Luna points out ghosts of former businesses. Outside one storefront, where ''Marconi 118'' is spelled in the sidewalk with what look like marbles, he said: ''This used to be an Italian restaurant. Now it's a Chinese beauty parlor.''
Gennaro's Grocery, on Mott Street, is one of the few Italian-owned businesses left there. ''We always had Chinese here,'' said Virginia Gennarao, the proprieter's wife, but ''not as many as after they lifted the immigration.''
''The Chinese have brought economy to the neighborhood,'' she said. ''That building over there was half empty. Now it's full of factories.'' The Italian neighborhood is getting smaller but it is not about to disappear, said Miss Compoccia, whose parents own a cafe there. ''It's shrinking, but it's coming back with a different face,'' she said. ''The Irish were here before the Italians. It's a process, and it's not such a terrible thing.''
Do the two most recent groups get along? It depends on who is talking. ''I don't think there are two ethnic communities that get along as well as the Chinese and the Italians,'' Miss Compoccia said.
But others express dissatisfaction. ''The Italians don't get nothing here,'' said an Italian woman who would not give her name but who said she had been in New York since 1910. ''We're left out. You know why? Because we don't cry and we don't complain.''
Mr. Luna said that not long ago a Chinese buyer offered his family several million dollars for a 19th century stable its owns in the neighborhood. The family sold to someone else, someone family members knew, he said. ''We stick together,'' Mr. Luna explained. ''We Italians don't want to sell anymore to the Chinese. We want to keep it Little Italy.''
 
Cigar-Smoking Retirees
 A daily arrival of tourists on its doorsteps is what keeps the neighborhood going. They come to sample Neapolitan cuisine, to sip small cups of coffee at sidewalk cafes and to search for the ultimate Italian dessert - sometimes after dining in Chinatown.
On a recent night along Mulberry Street several dozen teen-age girls from Half Hollow Hills East High School on Long Island surged into a restaurant, then a pastry shop. Limousines dropped off people on dates. Two neighborhood women sat on a stoop drinking cappuccino from big porcelain mugs as they kept an eye on a toddler. A Muslim family, the grandmother draped in white, perused menus in search of a prosciutto-free meal. A social club with religious statues in the window spilled cigar-smoking retirees out onto the sidewalk.
Richard Widenes, visiting from the Netherlands, said there were plenty of Italians in his native country but no Little Italy. ''We have a lot of pizzerias,'' he said.
 
Oh, That Al Brown
 It helps to be an insider in Little Italy. A cafe near the north end of Mulberry Street had a sign in the window advertising the place as the ''Shrine to Al Brown.''
Who was Al Brown? ''He's the brother of Jimmy Brown,'' said one of two men sitting inside the cafe one hot afternoon. Then he slammed the door.

HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;
SOVIETS UNYIELDING ON A NEW GERMANY IN WESTERN ORBIT

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, May 5

 BODY:
The major combatants of World War II opened formal talks on German reunification today with the Soviet Union emphasizing that it did not intend to let a united Germany slide easily into the Western orbit.
Moscow stated its disagreement with the West on several aspects of unification, but all participants agreed that German unity must not be hindered.
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d seemed to reflect this mood when he said, ''Today we engage in an act of reconciliation, of a people too long separated, of a Continent too long divided.''
 
Meetings Last Seven Hours
The Secretary spoke as he gathered with the foreign ministers of the two Germanys, the Soviet Union, Britain and France for the first full ministerial meeting of what have been dubbed the ''two plus four'' talks. The meetings lasted seven hours and were held at the Foreign Ministry in Bonn. 
From the outset, Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union signaled that Moscow, despite the disintegration of its Warsaw Pact and all its internal problems, would bargain hard for its views in the coming months.
Using some of the most categorical language on the issue to date, Mr. Shevardnadze rejected the idea of a single Germany joining the North Atlantic alliance, and he said the full gamut of military and political issues involved in unification had to be resolved before Moscow would sign any agreement.
 
Differences Played Down
At the same time, he seemed to take pains to indicate that Moscow did not intend to hold up the talks or German unity. At the news conference held by the six ministers on the end of their talks, Mr. Shevardnadze acknowledged that some ''serious differences'' had been aired, but he emphasized that these ''need not be dramatized,'' that ''this is usual for the negotiating process.''
''Happily, we have no problem with any sort of allergy to the wishes of the German nation to unity,'' Mr. Shevardnadze said in his opening comments, indirectly scoffing at reports that the notion of German unification was painful to the Soviets.
There was a sense among Western officials that some of Mr. Shevardnadze's tough talk may have been intended at least in part to assuage conservative critics in the Soviet Union, who have chafed at the idea of letting the Germanys unite and join the Western camp after the sacrifices made by the Soviet people in World War II. Mr. Shevardnadze explicitly noted the opposition in his opening statement, when he said German membership in NATO was also unacceptable for internal reasons. ''The population of our country, which sustained such frightening losses in the last war, cannot accept the idea of including Germany in NATO,'' he said.
More broadly, he appealed to the West to understand the difficulty that Soviet politicians faced on an issue that carried an enormous emotional burden. ''We are dealing here with an issue of special importance to Soviet people, to our whole society,'' he said. ''If an attempt is made to push us into a corner on matters touching our security, it will lead to a situation - I will say it candidly -in which our political flexibility would be severely curtailed, because emotions would boil up inside the country, shades of the past would rise to the surface, national complexes with roots in the tragic pages of our history would be revived.''
Mr. Shevardnadze's position confirmed expectations that the negotiations could in effect prove to be ''one plus five,'' with the Soviet Union using one of its last remaining levers in Europe - its victor's rights in Germany - to preserve whatever it could by way of political, military and economic influence on a Continent increasingly facing westward.
 
Balance of Power Stressed
German membership in NATO, Mr. Shevardnadze declared, ''would very concretely affect our security interests, it would mean an acute violation of the balance of power in Europe, it would create for us a dangerous military-strategic situation.''
Moscow has in the past resisted the Western plan to incorporate Germany in NATO. The Western position, expressed in opening comments by Foreign Minister Roland Dumas of France, is that it is not for the wartime Allies to decree what alliance a sovereign, united Germany could or could not join.
The broader disagreement between Moscow and the West that emerged from the opening statements was the scope of the ''two plus four'' talks. The Western position was that the allies were meeting only, as Mr. Baker put it, ''to arrive at a formula by which we will terminate and transfer all remaining four-power rights and responsibilities to a fully sovereign Germany.''
Other issues, such as the military and security structures in the Germany and the Europe of the future, could be discussed, but on these the ''two plus four'' should act only as a ''steering committee,'' channeling the various issues to appropriate forums or arms talks.
 
'Package Approach' Sought
The position staked out by Mr. Shevardnadze was that the ''two plus four'' must adopt what he described as a ''package approach.'' There would be no agreement, he said, until the participants had resolved all the ramifications of unification - including the military status and the military forces of the united Germany, the presence of foreign forces on German soil, German renunciation of atomic, bacteriological and chemical weapons and renunciation of fascist ideology.
''We believe that it would be in the interests of Germany itself if the termination of four-power rights would be the culminating step in German unification,'' Mr. Shevardnadze said.
Mr. Shevardnadze reiterated the Soviet position that Europe has to move toward broad new European security structures to replace the military blocs. To this end, he proposed the immediate creation of a ''pan-European center for the elimination of the military threat'' in Berlin, based in part on existing Allied institutions.
The center, he said, would serve as a control and observation post for all military activities on German soil, and the ''first block'' in the building of new security structures.
The proposal echoed Mr. Baker's idea of setting up a center for conflict resolution under the auspices of all-European Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. But the Soviet idea of a pan-European agency controlling all troops in Germany was certain to be rejected by the Western powers and Germany as a revival of special treatment for Germany.
 
Agenda Is Formulated
These differences, however, had not been unexpected at the opening session. Officials from all sides stressed that the ministers had found no disagreement on the principle business of the day, the agenda for their talks. This included:
* The borders of a future Germany, which all the participants agreed would be the territory of West Germany, East Germany and Berlin - ''no more, no less.''
* Political-military questions, an area likely to produce the most serious disagreements.
* Ending four-power authority over Berlin.
* Preparing a ''final settlement'' under international law under which the four Allied powers would terminate their rights and responsibilities for Germany. Moscow at one point had indicated it that might hold out for a formal peace treaty - which the Germans resist as a humiliating exercise that would have to involve the many other nations that formally declared war on the Third Reich - but Mr. Shevardnadze signaled that Moscow would settle for a less formal ''final settlement'' with the four allied powers.
 
Poland to Join Later Talks
The six ministers also agreed to allow Poland to take part in the third foreign ministers' meeting, scheduled for July in Paris, when its borders would be discussed. After initial resistance, Bonn agreed this year to let the Poles sit in on discussions of its western border.
Reading a statement agreed to by the ministers, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, the West German Foreign Minister and the host of the first round of ministerial talks, said, ''I can state that the talks have been taking place in a reasonable, constructive and trustful atmosphere and that they were dominated by the will for understanding.''
In his opening comments, however, Mr. Genscher and the East German Foreign Minister, Markus Meckel, cautiously stayed clear of the disagreements between Moscow and the Western powers.
Mr. Genscher did stress that relations with the Soviet Union ''will continue to be of primary importance,'' underscoring what has been an unstated theme of the talks. The sense in Bonn is that one of Moscow's aims in the unification process is to secure guarantees that a united Germany will honor all East German trade obligations, and that Germany will provide economic assistance to the Soviet Union.

LENGTH: 2949 words

HEADLINE: Life and Death On 129th Street
A special report.;
In Harlem, Death Is an Old and Busy Neighbor

BYLINE: By DON TERRY

 BODY:
Fred Quinn, a butcher when he can find work, has lost three brothers to the Harlem streets before they reached middle age.
The first, who was shooting drugs, died of heart failure when he was 34. ''He took a sip of wine and just dropped dead right on 130th Street.''
His youngest brother was 32 when he was shot twice in the head and dumped in a cemetery. His body lay in the morgue for three weeks, a John Doe tag around his toe. 
The third brother had cirrhosis and cancer; his 42-year-old heart simply gave out. ''Now it's just me and my sister left.''
Fred Quinn is 49 years old, accent on the ''old.''
Death comes early on his block - 129th Street between Park and Madison Avenues - this block of faded row houses and city-owned tenements, of abandoned buildings and vacant lots, of unemployment and dying dreams. Indeed, death comes earlier here in Harlem than anywhere else in New York City. According to a recent study by two doctors from Harlem Hospital, the death rate for blacks under the age of 65 in central Harlem was nearly three times that of American whites; in some of the hardest-hit pockets of the neighborhood, it was almost four times as high. On balance, life is longer in Bangladesh.
Death comes early here - and throughout America's Harlems -in complex ways.
Drugs and guns are common killers, though the leading causes of death in central Harlem are cancer, heart disease and cirrhosis of the liver. The causes can be found in the life of this block: in the unemployed men on the sidewalks, in the crumbling bathroom walls, in the prospering numbers parlors and in a psychology of survival where tomorrow is something to worry about only if it comes.
''The bottom-line problem is poverty,'' said Dr. Harold P. Freeman, a past president of the American Cancer Society and co-author of the study with Dr. Colin McCord. ''People who are intensely poor have other priorities. People think present tense. They don't think future. They think about making it through the day. People are fighting for their lives.''
They are people like Runette Carter, watching over her 6-year-old daughter as she plays on the stoop, and Woodrow Samuels, repairing his hot-dog truck and hoping it will be ready for the summer. They are people like Alana Crawford, heading for the numbers hole to keep her soup-kitchen meal out of the rain, and the sad-faced man over there, who, Mr. Samuels says, ''loves to drink too damn much.''
And they are people like Clarence Andrews, the man on the corner with the Yankees cap pulleddown against the sun. He has been out of work more than a year and spends the day riding a bicycle with a broken handlebar through the neighborhood where he grew up.
''When I was coming up it was old people dying,'' he said. ''It's changed. The oldest person who died that I remember, and she wasn't that old, was in her 40's. She was the only one who died around here who was up in age.''
 
Lots of Crack
Where Life Is Hard And Hope Is Scarce
When Ned O'Gorman, a poet and a teacher, first arrived in the neighborhood 25 years ago to open a small independent school, life was hard on the block, but there was still hope and there was still faith. Today, both are just about gone.
''The thing about this street is, you're never not aware of how difficult life is,'' he said. ''That must do something to the wear and tear on the fabric of your body and your spirit.''
Mr. O'Gorman was one of dozens of people interviewed in the neighborhood in recent weeks. From the steps of his school at No. 57, his thinning white hair tossed by the wind, he looked out over the street and talked about ''ghosts.''
''This used to be a self-contained community,'' he said. ''You never had to leave it. There used to be a fish market, a dry cleaners, a grocery store, a restaurant, a beauty shop, a funeral home. Now only the grocery and the funeral parlor are left.''
There is also the church, 110-year-old All Saints Roman Catholic, looming over the Madison Avenue end of the block, its glistening stained glass a stark contrast to the broken windows in the abandoned building across the street. These days the favorite sermons are about survival and beating the odds here on earth.
''The people don't want to hear any pie-in-the-sky stuff,'' said the priest, the Rev. John Meehan. ''These people want to know how to get through another day, how to get up for the 15th round.''
Father Meehan, a thin man with sandy hair, has lived in Harlem for 25 years, the last five on East 129th Street.
''People just exist here,'' he said. ''A lot of people are unemployed here. You name it and it's here. They're selling crack 24 hours a day.''
On 129th Street they peddle crack as openly as ice cream in Central Park. The price of a vial of crack and a pint of ice cream is similar: about $3.
And when the sun goes down the working people and the mothers and the children head inside and the crack dealers rule. The flames from a trash-can fire send shadows dancing over the faces of a half dozen people lined up on one side of the street. Across the way two more lines have formed, and people are running to join them.
In a few minutes the crack man will be open for business.
Roy Taylor has lived on the block for 20 of his 37 years and never, he says, has life been so hard and hope so scarce. ''I hate them,'' he said of the young crack dealers. ''They're killing my people.''
Mr. Taylor is a former boxer who works as a security guard in midtown Manhattan and, he said, ''when I go downtown, it's like I'm in a different country.''
In a small room in his apartment Mr. Taylor has rigged a heavy punching bag to a door frame. A photograph of him as a young junior featherweight, fists up, future bright, hangs on the wall. Now when he wants to forget the streets he pounds away at the bag, and the door frame shakes with each blow.
Sometimes he brings a couple of neighborhood children into his ''gym'' to hit the bag, ''because there ain't no recreation centers around here.''
''The kids don't have nothing and their parents don't have nothing,'' he said the other day, sitting in a jogging suit on his stoop. ''So they go for it. This drug stuff is about poor people trying to survive. But I get depressed and fed up with it. A friend told me his sister smokes crack with her daughter. What you going to do? All this stress gives people a sense, 'I don't care no more. I'm just going to quit.' ''
A young woman, her face a mask of makeup, walked down the block, a cigarette dangling from her mouth. Every few feet she stopped walking, stared at the sidewalk and weakly stomped her right foot.
''Every time she smokes crack,'' Mr. Taylor explained, ''she thinks she's killing roaches.''
 
Little Health Care
'When God's Ready, You're Gone'
 Preventive health care - regular visits to the doctor, AIDS education, a balanced diet, exercise - is rarely a priority here. Short of money and long on fear, willfully forgetting tomorrow or simply too tired to remember, people in Harlem increasingly rely on overcrowded hospital emergency rooms for their primary health care. Typically, they stay home until they are very sick.
''There ain't no such thing as a private doctor around here,'' said Leonard Woodson, a 58-year-old man in a red baseball jacket. ''I suffer from asthma. But I'm dealing with it myself. By the time you can see a doctor in the emergency room you're half dead.''
Private doctors practice in Harlem, but only half as many as are needed, according to a recent study by the Community Service Society. And while Harlem Hospital is ''a great place if you have a stab wound or a gunshot wound,'' Dr. Freeman explained, ''where we fall down a little bit is prevention. The system is not set up to provide preventive care for poor people. We see them when they're bleeding and in pain.''
Quite a few of the people on the block are employed, but when it comes to health care, they are often worse off than their jobless neighbors who qualify for Medicaid. Like millions of America's working poor, Mr. Taylor and several others on the block have jobs that pay them too much for Medicaid but provide little health insurance, if any.
''When I get sick, I go to the city hospital,'' Mr. Taylor said. ''Whichever doctor they got available, that's my doctor.''
When it comes to health care, denial is undeniable.
''People are simply afraid,'' said Dr. Muriel Petioni, who recently retired after 40 years of practicing medicine in Harlem. ''They don't want to hear about any more problems, so they ignore them for as long as they can.'' The denial is marked by fatalism and faith. A 39-year-old woman sat on the stairs of a row house near Park Avenue, smoking.
''I'm not convinced that cigarettes cause cancer,'' she said. ''Anyway, if I stop smoking, I'll get real fat and die of obesity. I like to smoke. It's one of the few pleasures I got.''
Across the street, Runette Carter, 45, watched over her playing children. She rattled off a list of friends and neighbors who had died in the last few years: her diabetic mother, Lila Carter, 62, ruptured appendix; Bernice Taylor, 57, cancer; a man named Keith, 32, heart attack.
''When God's ready, you're gone, whether you're 5 or 65,'' said Ms. Carter, a stocky woman with thick glasses who works as a school crossing guard. ''And you don't have to be sick a day in your life. The lady next door - we were talking Wednesday, and the next day they were putting her in a bag.''
 
Too Much Poverty
Unemployment, Worn Like a Shroud
 Forty-one percent of the people in the central Harlem health district live below the Federal poverty line. Unemployment shrouds the area.
The Saturday afternoon soup kitchen in the basement of No. 57 is always busy.
Alana Crawford, 27, stood under a porch, waiting for the kitchen to open. It was cold and it was raining and Ms. Crawford's stomach rumbled.
''You'll have to excuse me,'' she said. ''I'm hungry.''
Ms. Crawford said she had been homeless for two years. Relatives around the corner care for her daughter. Ms. Crawford, like her mother, who died of cancer in 1983, is diabetic.
''I'm often sickly because of being out here in all kinds of weather,'' she said. ''You keep a cold.''
At noon the kitchen opened its heavy gate and Ms. Crawford hurried in for a plate of tuna salad. The kitchen does not have room for people to sit down and eat, so plate in hand, Ms. Crawford walked out into the rain.
''I'm going to the numbers hole to eat,'' she said. ''It's warm in there.''
Woodrow Samuels, 55, is a self-employed television repairman, plumber and, if he can fix his gray truck in time, a summer hot-dog vendor. He has lived on the block for 45 years and has seen a lot of neighbors die early.
Standing in the doorway of his truck, Mr. Samuels gestured toward the thin man with the sad face, the man who ''loves to drink too damn much.''
''I think liquor is more dangerous than crack,'' Mr. Samuels said. ''Over all, more people get killed by liquor.''
The sad-faced man said he was 37 and had just been released from the hospital.
''I went and signed myself in,'' he said. ''It's real rough. This is my fourth time doing it. I don't know why I drink so much. Every time I had a problem I started drinking, but the problem would still be there.''
Central Harlem's leading killers - cancer, heart disease and cirrhosis - have roots in America's distilleries and tobacco fields.
''If you really want to address health problems in the black community you really must address the use of tobacco and alcohol,'' said David R. Williams, an assistant professor of sociology at Yale University.
''You also have to address the conditions that create the need in people to use them,'' he said. ''We know that alcohol consumption rises whenever there is an economic downturn and high unemployment.''
But whatever the reasons, black men smoke more than black women, and blacks more than any other racial group in the country. The consequences are clear: blacks have a higher incidence of lung cancer than whites, according to the American Cancer Society. And over all, the five-year cancer survival rate for black Americans is 38 percent, compared to 50 percent for whites.
In an article last year in a cancer society journal, Dr. Freeman wrote that there is ''no known genetic basis to explain the major racial differences in cancer incidence and outcome.'' On the contrary, he said, the causes appear to be largely environmental.
Many of Harlem's young men, though, do not live long enough to develop cancer or heart disease. Homicide, drugs and AIDS kill them first. Homicide is the leading cause of death for New Yorkers between 15 and 24; AIDS is the No. 1 killer for those between 25 and 44. In central Harlem, there were 122.1 AIDS-related deaths for each 100,000 people in 1988, the highest rate in the city after the lower West Side.
The Rev. Derrick Harkins, an assistant minister at the Abyssinian Baptist Church, said that in the last four years he had officiated at dozens of funerals for victims of AIDS, from prominent people to ''junkies whose grandmother's last loving thing they could do for them was to arrange their funerals.''
''I know one or two guys who died of AIDS,'' said Purvis Lucas, 36, leaning against his building near the end of the block. ''One died about two years ago. He was 30, 31. We used to hang out years ago. It was kept quiet when he died. The family didn't say anything to me. When people get AIDS around here, people keep it quiet. The next thing you know they're gone and in the ground.''
 
Too Few Role Models
 
Some Can't Leave, But Others Plan to
 Not all of Harlem is suffering.
 A black middle- and upper-middle class has long thrived in the neighborhood's grand brownstones and modern apartment buildings. New York's Mayor, David N. Dinkins, has lived much of his life in Harlem.
For this well-off slice of Harlem, quality housing - like quality health care and education - is accessible. But for the residents of East 129th Street, these are luxuries most cannot afford.
On the block, most people live in four city-owned tenements, taken over from landlords after years of neglect. The city also owns the four abandoned buildings on the street.
The building in the worst condition is No. 51; Michael Heath and his family live there. Mr. Heath is an organizer for the Hospital and Health Care Employees Union Local 1199. His wife, Audrey, is a hospital billing clerk. They have an 8-year-old daughter who is doing well in school and is eagerly waiting for her father to connect their new computer. They are the kind of family that sociologists point to as crucial role models for the less fortunate neighbors.
But the Heaths want to leave, because even simple everyday tasks like taking a bath are often anything but simple.
Two years ago the wall between their bathroom and kitchen was removed by city workers during renovation. Sheets of rumpled plastic still hang where the wall used to be, and Mr. Heath can reach through the crumbling ceiling and chip away at the rotting joists and studs as water leaks into a green bucket perched atop the toilet.
Outside the apartment in the graffiti-smeared hallways, addicts often smoke crack, leaving a trail of vials and fear.
Rafael Perez and his family live upstairs. Mr. Perez, who is 34, said his son was returning home from the store a couple of weeks ago when two men assaulted him in the hallway. They slapped him and took the family groceries and $10 in cash.
''I'm scared of the crack heads, and I'm scared that my little daughter will put her finger in this,'' Mr. Perez said, holding up an exposed electrical outlet. ''This is no way to live.''
Mr. Perez has few alternatives. He cannot afford to move. Mr. Heath, who can, says he has stayed out of loyalty to his neighbors.
''I could have left before it got this bad,'' Mr. Heath said. ''But I think about the other people who live here and we have to stick together. I was born here. These are my roots.''
Near the end of the block and the thriving drug market is a narrow strip of blacktop -what the city calls a vest-pocket park, with two rusted and bent basketball hoops, a rickety slide and a patchy carpet of broken glass.
''Would that park exist like that on 65th and Park?'' Mr. O'Gorman asked as students burst through the door behind him and ran down the school steps to recess, their laughter echoing after them.
Mr. O'Gorman grabbed a boy and gave him a hug. ''Are you going to come to school every day and not end up a corpse in the street?'' he asked. The child mumbled a ''yes'' and ran off to play.
So far, the teen-age boys flying up and down the basketball court in the playground seem to have avoided the lure of the corner. Instead of fast money and faster cars, their dreams are about being electricians, doctors, actors and ballplayers.
Perhaps this is because they saw what happened to Robert Cole.
Robert Cole was a bright boy with an easy smile who had attended Ned O'Gorman's school for years. But his smile seemed to fade when he began hanging out on the corner, and one night last February, he apparently tried to rob a man with a broken gun. Confronted by a police officer, he refused to drop the weapon and was shot dead. He was 13..
''I don't like it around here at all,'' said Robert's older brother, Elika, who is 16. ''But I don't have no choice but to stay.''
''What's to like?'' said his friend, Earl Hunter. ''This is a super-ghetto.''
''This ain't even a ghetto,'' Elika said. ''It's a danger zone.''
''All I want,'' said 16-year-old Ronald Byas, ''is to live long enough to move off this block.''

HEADLINE: Nurses Get V.I.P. Treatment, Easing Shortage

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 2

 BODY:
Betsey Vernizzi, an orthopedic nurse at St. Anthony Medical Center here, recalled a course she took nearly 20 years ago in nursing school. ''It was called ethics,'' she said. ''I was taught to say 'Yes, sir, no sir.' If a doctor walked into the nurse's station, you gave him your chair. I called them 'Doctor.' They called me Betsey.' '' At St. Anthony now, there is a doctor whose first name is Louis. ''We call him 'Louie,' '' she said.
Nurses have also complained forever of menial chores that take them from their real business of caring for patients. But Margaret Taylor, a nurse-manager in the intensive care unit of one of Humana Inc.'s four hospitals here, can now turn to the ''green people,'' student aides in green smocks. ''They run specimens to the labs,'' she said. ''They run and Xerox things. They get prescriptions from the pharmacy. We pick up the phone, dial H-E-L-P and they're there.''
With many employers' new willingness to accommodate nurses in these and other ways, the worst of the great nursing shortage that arose in the last half of the 1980's may finally be over. The employers' accommodations of nurses, moreover, are likely to presage accommodations they will have to make to people in many other occupations as the 1990's unfold, the Bureau of Labor Statistics says. 
 
Demand for Special Skills
For years economists have been warning that the decline of the birth rate since the mid-1960's means the working-age population in the 1990's will grow at half the rate at which it grew in the 70's and 80's. Barring a long recession or a surge in immigration, businesses will be hard put to find all the people they will need.
Worse, workers with special skills will be much harder to find because of a mismatch between employers' expected needs and the ability of school systems to meet them. Those workers, especially, will have the upper hand in bargaining for pay and working conditions.
''Employers are going to market jobs the way you might market a car,'' said Audrey Freedman, a labor economist at the Conference Board, a business research organization in New York. '' 'Come to us. We'll give you what we think you want.' ''
Gene Remoff, vice president for human resources at ARA Services Inc. in Philadelphia, which operates 250 nursing homes, said, ''If you want somebody to take that job, you have to sell it.''
 
An Economic Harbinger
The expected crunch in the national labor market struck nursing hard and early for two reasons: One was the booming demand for health care, and the other was the fact that nursing combines the worst of many occupations: bad hours, difficult conditions, the emotional toll of helping the sick, low wage growth, high stress and the stigma of women's work.
But many people find great personal reward in being a nurse. ''A doctor's not there day by day,'' said Miriam Gravatte, 44, assistant manager in the pediatric intensive care unit at a Humana Hospital. ''He's in and out. We have a relationship with the patient. He has a relationship with a chart.''
Kathi Zanni, a 29-year-old colleague of Ms. Gravatte's, said: ''Nursing is taking care of people. It's a back rub.''
 
Maid Service as Incentive
To recruit such people today, hospitals and employment agencies are packing the help-wanted columns of newspapers with advertisements promising nurses high pay, more of a say in their jobs and in hospital management, bonuses of $3,000 and $4,000 for coming aboard, bonuses for staying, bounties for finding recruits, freedom to set their own schedules and free tuition for advanced courses. Some employers even offer maid service and free housing for those who are willing to shuttle from city to city to relieve demand for medical care.
Nurses in Louisville, as is true of nurses almost everywhere, talk of constant direct mail and telephone appeals from recruiters. ''Headhunters,'' said Pam Hagan, 38, a $42,000-a-year cancer specialist at the Veterans Affairs Medical Center here. ''I get calls from around the country. I get them a couple of times a month, but one day last week I got three in one day.''
''Their opening question is, 'I have a position in' and they tell me a region of the country and give a description of the job,'' she said. They usually start by asking if I know anyone who might be interested and then they say, 'Would you be interested in a position like this?' ''
In nursing's hot personnel market, more than 20 multi-city agencies do nothing but find jobs for itinerant nurses, young ones mostly who like to follow the sun. Humana, which has its headquarters here, operates an internal pool of 2,000 itinerants who circulate among the company's 83 hospitals in 19 cities on 13-week assignments. The nurses get a $450 monthly housing allowance, even if they stay with their families or friends, and they keep accruing benefits and seniority rather than start anew each time they take an assignment.
 
Pay of Up to $70,000
In cities like New York, Boston, Chicago and Los Angeles, a nurse can earn $60,000 or $70,000 a year for a full-time job, and an agency in Miami advertises a job that pays $1,000 for working two 12-hour shifts on Saturday and Sunday and taking the rest of the week off. Nationwide, the American Nurse Association says the average starting salary for a registered nurse last year was $25,261, an increase of about $5,000 in just three years.
Nurses have long complained of ''wage compression,'' that a nurse's pay rises far less from one year to the next than is the case in most other professions. By contrast, people who begin their careers as engineers or accountants, for example, can look ahead to top salaries of triple their starting pay, while a nurse can expect her salary to rise by just 40 percent. In addition, said Philip Doyle, an economist at the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the wages of 87 percent of all registered nurses are concentrated at the lower end of the pay scale.
''The market's starting to take care of that,'' said Kathryn M. Mersohn, senior vice president for nursing at Humana. The American Nursing Association says the 40 percent rise in pay that a nurse can now expect, reaching an average maximum of $35,442, compares with a rise of only 27 percent above starting pay that nurses could expect in 1980.
Where the market is not working, the unions are. Until a few years ago at St. Anthony, said Barbara Aynes, a staff nurse there, nurses could climb only five pay grades, so except for adjustments to take account of inflation, their raises stopped after five years. Under agreement with the union, the Kentucky Nurses' Association, the hospital now provides 18 grades.
Raising nurses' pay poses problems for employers under acute pressure to hold down the rise of health care costs, but the solution many are devising also serves nurses' pleas for relief from tasks unrelated to nursing. In February, Humana, which owns 83 hospitals in 19 states, established schools in Louisville, St. Petersburg, Fla., and San Antonio to train licensed practical nurses, who are paid 30 to 40 percent less than registered nurses. The licensed practical nurses can take on some of the registered nurses' work.
 
Easing of Shortage
The recruiting, the blandishments, the better wages and working conditions have begun to ease the shortage. Enrollments in nursing schools, which plunged 30 percent, have recovered a bit, and more than 80 percent of all people who have been trained to be nurses are actually working as nurses, the highest level in decades.
National statistics have yet to show it, but in Louisville and in many other communities, anecdotal evidence suggests that men, historically just 3 percent of all nurses, are moving into the profession. One is Kevin Boyd, 28, who works the 6:30 A.M. to 2:30 P.M. shift in the intensive care unit at St. Anthony and two additional shifts of voluntary overtime. He is married without children.
After three semesters at the University of Louisville, Mr. Boyd dropped out and ended up in a job transporting patients at St. Anthony. He then returned to the university to become a nurse. ''Of 80 students in my class,'' he said, ''10 were men.'' As for the stigma of women's work, he said, ''I never looked at that.'' Of the 112 students enrolled so far in Humana's new schools for licensed practical nurses, Ms. Mersohn said, 18 are men.
Because of the explosive growth in health care services, demand for nurses still far exceeds the supply. That means the nurses who are working, especially in hospitals, have to accommodate the demand by working overtime, and many complain of stress and burnout. Ms. Gravatte at Humana said that for one week in April, she recorded the overtime that the 15 nurses in her unit worked.
''We had 197 hours,'' or just about two extra eight-hour shifts per nurse, she said. Depending on the unpredictable numbers of children in her unit, Ms. Gravette said, ''One day you may need two nurses, on another day four. You're constantly on the phone calling in nurses. That alone is a source of stress.'' But even there, hospitals are finding some relief in scores of temporary nurse agencies that have formed in the last few years.
 
Impact of Competition on Pay
Some public institutions have been able to match the accommodations that private institutions are making. The Department of Veterans Affairs, the nation's biggest employer of nurses, with 37,000 in 172 hospitals, is now authorized to adjust its wages in line with that of the competition. But many states and cities struggle with even tighter budgets than the Federal Government's and have not been able to offer such terms.
Patricia Payne, a nurse practitioner in pediatrics at a Jefferson County neighborhood medical center in Louisville, does much of the work of a physician but is paid a little more than $28,000 a year, about $10,000 more than her starting pay 20 years ago. Unlike more and more private institutions, the county provides no career ladders for nurses to climb; nor does it give them a say in developing medical programs.
Turnover in the county medical centers is high. ''We're always training new nurses,'' she said. ''Before, we had a pretty stable work force.'' Ms. Payne said that she expected to stay on because she was close to retirement, but that she was taking charge of a stepped-up campaign by the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees to organize more nurses at public institutions.
