HEADLINE: TriBeCa Yawns Hello to Film Studio

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS

 BODY:
Trumpeted as Hollywood on the Hudson and organized by Robert De Niro, a former coffee warehouse in lower Manhattan opened this year as the TriBeCa Film Center, with production centers on seven floors and a stylish restaurant on the ground floor. Yet for all the attention people in the neighborhood are paying to it, it might still be the warehouse.
''He's not the first celebrity in the neighborhood,'' said Dorothea Nicholas, a resident of the Independence Plaza apartment complex across the street.
Across TriBeCa, the area's supposed leap into the limelight is mostly met with an attitude of boredom, occasionally broken by a comment about the economic opportunities of such a change. 
Mr. De Niro, the actor, ''lives in the neighborhood and has for over 10 years,'' said Jane Rosenthal, executive vice president of TriBeCa Productions, the movie company that anchors the center. ''It was really just a matter of being in the neighborhood.''
Requests for a comment from Mr. De Niro were refused.
Residents' early concerns that the center, at 375 Greenwich Street, might harm the neighborhood have largely dwindled to occasional complaints about limousines on the streets and double-parked cars, said Paul L. Goldstein, district manager for Community Board 1. Many people seem grateful that an empty building has what some call a productive use.
 
Headquarters for 2 Films
''They may be customers that rent my things for their films,'' said James Garvey, who owns a metalworking studio on Franklin Street. ''I had a whole thing set up for this week, but they passed on it.''
The film center, set up as a condominium, is the headquarters for two movies this month. One, ''Bonfire of the Vanities,'' based on the novel by Tom Wolfe, is being shot in the Bronx, on Park Avenue and elsewhere around the city.
The other film, ''New Jack City,'' has had much less publicity. Filmed entirely in the city, it highlights rap music, drugs, police officers and other features of urban life.
The other occupants of the center have been less visible. They include casting agencies and development offices in search of material for screenplays. Most were recruited by Mr. De Niro and had worked with him. Last month, a restaurant on the ground floor, the TriBeCa Grill, opened.
 
Scene at the Casting Office
Security is tight. Guards make sure that only people with legitimate reasons for being there go upstairs, where the decor is loftlike, with exposed brick, neutral colors and a skylight. On the upper floors a hushed but preoccupied atmosphere prevails.
The center was the site of some casting for ''Bonfire of the Vanities.'' ''That's what makes it feel like a film center,'' said Jill Kearney, vice president for development at Art Linson Productions, producer of films like ''The Untouchables'' and ''Scrooged.''
Ms. Kearney has an office near the rehearsal room. ''One minute there are 400 little girls, then a lot of older women in beaded jackets,'' she said. ''One day everybody was walking by swearing to themselves for some role.''
Some residents seemed pleased that Greenwich Street is considered a film capital. ''It's nice to get some more fun people in the neighborhood,'' said Sixtina Friedrich, who was wheeling her 6-month-old daughter into Washington Market Park.
 
In the Spirit
A few had complaints. ''I like them to be here, but there are always negative sides, like traffic,'' said Josee Vermette, who lives in Independence Plaza and recently ate at the TriBeCa Grill. ''There are a lot of limousines. I have seen the whole block full of limousines.''
The film motif seems to be sticking. Across the street from the center is the TriBeCa Film Studio Deli. The deli has yet to stock its refrigerator cases but it has painted its name across an awning.
The deli was named after hundreds of other possibilities were exhausted, said an owner, Joe Porco. ''I bought a book of names, you know, 'What to Name Your Baby,' '' he insisted. ''Some companies spend a lot of money trying to find the proper identity. We decided, why not call it Studio Deli?''
The connection, as well as the proximity, to De Niro territory may prove profitable. ''People who come by to see his restaurant but don't go in might stop here,'' Mr. Porco said.
 
'Didn't Believe It Was Him'
At Greenwich Street Video, where Mr. De Niro has a membership and occasionally rents his movies, the management applauded the film center. ''It used to be a bombed-out warehouse,'' said Maria Hogan, who has worked at the store five years. When Mr. De Niro, who lives a block away on Hudson Street, wanted to rent his first videocassette, she added, he did not have to produce two forms of identification and a utility bill like the average customer.
''He just gave us his American Express card,'' Mrs. Hogan said. ''We didn't believe it was him.''
Part of the local indifference to stardom may be that New Yorkers tend to recognize people more readily for their success in something other than show business, Ms. Kearney said. She added: ''In New York, you're much more likely to hear someone say, 'Hey, there's Susan Sontag,' and in L.A. it's, 'There's Danny DeVito.' There's a lot more intellectual celebrity.''
Mrs. Vermette said that she expected paparazzi to start pursuing celebrities into the neighborhood and that fans would probably start showing up too. ''But that's part of New York City,'' she said. ''When you live in New York City, you have to expect these things.''

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: With Easing of Soviet Police State, Crime Against Foreigners Is Rising

BYLINE: By ESTHER B. FEIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, May 5

 BODY:
Crime against foreigners in the Soviet Union has dramatically increased in the last year, as outsiders, long isolated from Soviet society, find that their new ability to move freely has exposed them to greater danger.
The crimes range from murder to rape to burglary and attempted kidnapping, but the vast majority involve theft. The foreigners are finding that their cars, apartments, offices, hotel rooms and even suitcases are vulnerable to thieves.
''As the shortages in our own shops grow, foreigners unfortunately become a very desirable target for criminals,'' said Vladimir Gorshkov, chief of criminal investigations in the Moscow militia department assigned to crime against foreigners. ''Our current economic problems have created a breeding ground for all kinds of undesirable elements, many of whom prey on foreigners.'' 
 
Muscovites Are Victims, Too
This rise in crime against foreigners has taken place at a time when the overall crime rate has also soared. Foreigners were once insulated from such crime waves by limits on their access to ordinary people and by the close surveillance of the authorities. But with liberalization, Soviet citizens are no longer afraid to mingle with foreigners, and Soviet criminals are no longer afraid to attack them.
Foreigners are often naive about the criminal element in the Soviet Union, Western and Soviet officials here say. Many visitors apparently feel that in a country that was long a police state, they are still safe from such harm.
The number of crimes against foreigners reported in Moscow jumped from 272 in 1988 to 779 last year, according to the city's Interior Ministry. Those crimes accounted for 2 percent of the number of crimes registered, virtually a tenfold increase over the previous two years, ministry officials say.
So although reported crimes against foreigners remain a small percentage of the total, Soviet and Western officials say they believe that the rise is the beginning of a trend that may become more violent, particularly if the Soviet economy continues to founder.
''We're seeing the front end of it,'' said Mark A. Sanna, regional security officer at the United States Embassy. ''I think the police are making an effort, but they lack the manpower and the capability.''
 
Deterrent to Enterpreneurs
A Soviet law-enforcement officer, who asked not to be identified by name, said there was ''alarm and concern among the highest authorities'' over the rise in crime against foreigners.
''The Soviet Union depends very heavily now on the Western businessmen and tourists who come here,'' the official said. ''And if this crime situation continues along its current path, many of these people will start staying home, which will have a very negative effect on our economy.''
There are more than 8,000 foreigners currently accredited to work and live in Moscow, including 6,000 diplomats, nearly 600 journalists and about 1,500 representatives of businesses. In addition, about 27,000 foreign students are studying in Moscow and, last year, 1.5 million tourists traveled to the city.
Officials at Western embassies and businesses in Moscow and directors of tour companies say they have heard a litany of stories from employees, clients and colleagues who have become victims of the crime wave.
 
Threats, and Worse
A Scandinavian airline employee who reported to the police that he had seen airport baggage handlers rifling through luggage found his car badly vandalized and a note advising him to mind his own business or suffer worse consequences.
An American Embassy employee was raped in her apartment in a foreigners' compound in northern Moscow this year, a few months after two American apartments in the same area were burglarized and the Soviet authorities failed to install a security system.
An Italian tourist taking a taxi into Moscow from Sheremetyevo Airport was run off the road by gangsters in cahoots with the driver, robbed of his money, jewelry, suitcases, overcoat and shoes and left by the side of highway, one of hundreds of foreigners victimized by this long-running scam.
The tales go on and on: about side-view mirrors on foreign cars being sawed off, hotel rooms ransacked, tourists mugged inches from hotel doorways, women's purses slashed with razor blades and the contents lifted.
 
Worse Than Reported
Although the statistics show a dramatic rise, officials say the undocumented story is worse yet. The vast majority of crimes against foreigners go unreported, Western and Soviet authorites agree. Most are committed against tourists in town for short stays and many people, including foreigners living here for several years, do not believe that their stolen property will be recovered or that the perpetrators will be caught. So they are loath to tangle with the Soviet bureaucracy.
Tour organizers in the United States and other countries say Soviet tourism officials express concern that the flood of tourists visiting the Soviet Union since Mikhail S. Gorbachev came to power will slow if the crime rate continues. The State Department has issued a warning to travelers, advising them about the rise in crime.
''The Soviet tourism people tried to reassure us that Soviet authorities were taking measures to control the situation,'' said a New York-based travel agent who would not be identified.
''But frankly the Soviet Union is not a luxury vacation. The accommodations are not first class, the food is bad. It's a rough trip, but the one consolation was always that at least the country was safe for foreign travelers. Our own experience tells us that's simply not true anymore.''
Travel agents said they had not seen a dropoff in interest in travel to the Soviet Union since the State Department advisory was issued, but many said they were advising Moscow-bound tourists to be, as a trip organizer said, ''as alert and aware as if you were visiting New York or Naples.''
 
Embassy Duty Unpopular
Officials at several Western embassies said some of their employees had requested early transfers out of Moscow because of the rise in crime. ''To be uncomfortable and unsafe was not worth it to them,'' said a diplomat at a West European embassy where several employees had asked to leave.
And there is a bonus, of sorts, from the easier association with foreigners. With more Soviet citizens able to travel to the West and to earn foreign currency, more local residents have foreign-made goods. When such items are stolen from foreigners, their new owners are no longer conspicuous.
To deal with the new crime wave, some Moscow-based foreign business people have been hiring bodyguards to accompany their employees around town, to guard their offices and to protect equipment being transported around the city or country.
''We used to think Moscow was the safest city in the world,'' said Oleg Fomin, deputy director of the Defense Service Agency, a new Soviet business that provides guards and burglar alarms. ''But now we know otherwise. And unfortunately for foreigners, they're the people here with the money and the goods that criminals want. Why rob a Muscovite for a few worthless rubles if you can get a foreigner and get some dollars or Deutsche marks?''

HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;
Shadow on Arms Talks: Threat of Soviet Turmoil

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, May 5

 BODY:
While NATO ministers meeting in Europe this week have tried to maintain a business-as-usual demeanor toward Moscow, they are privately whispering about the possibilty that the Soviet Union could collapse into political turmoil before new arms-control deals are completed.
At Thursday's meeting of NATO Foreign Ministers in Brussels, the British Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, told his colleagues that the situation in the Soviet Union was ''moving rapidly toward a state of confusion.''
''There is a serious possibility that the whole thing will crumble at the Communist Party congress'' scheduled for early July, he said.
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d was equally sober in his presentation to his fellow North Atlantic Treaty Organization ministers. According to a text of Mr. Baker's remarks, he said at the closed session in Brussels: ''In our view perestroika has entered a critical, even paradoxical stage. On the one hand, Gorbachev's formal power has never been greater as he heads for the party congress this summer. Ascending to the presidency, he is positioned to push through the radical reforms he has so often extolled in the last six months.'' 
 
Uncertain Period Predicted
''The irony,'' Mr. Baker contined, ''is that while Gorbachev may finally be able to push through radical reform, right now he may be reluctant to act, increasingly fearful that real reform could lead to a genuine implosion from below. In light of these Soviet domestic realities, I suspect we are in for an uncertain two months until the Soviet party congress can clarify perestroika's political prospects more definitively.''
The contrast between the mood among the Western allies today and their mood in February 1989, when Secretary Baker made his first tour of NATO capitals, could not be more striking. On that inaugural trip, Mr. Baker was repeatedly asked by the Western Europeans when the Bush Administration would ''engage'' with Mr. Gorbachev.
A few months later, after Washington began doing serious arms-control business with the Soviet leader, Mr. Baker was peppered with the question of when the United States was going to start to help Mr. Gorbachev succeed. At the Malta summit meeting last year, a package of technical and economic assistance programs was offered to the Soviet leader by President Bush.
Today, the only question within the alliance seems to be whether anyone or anything can ''save'' Mr. Gorbachev from being overwhelmed by the internal problems closing in on him. The Soviet leader, who a year ago was seen as a heroic figure in Europe, paving the way for the revolutions of 1989 and overshadowing every other leader on the world stage, is viewed increasingly among NATO officials with pity, as an enormously capable man devoured by the very revolution that he set in motion.
 
An Altered Perception
Joseph S. Nye, an international-affairs expert at Harvard University, said the NATO allies were recognizing that the excitement around the globe engendered by Mr. Gorbachev's initiatives had obscured the degree to which his actions at home were making the situation there steadily worse, and ultimately constricting what he could do abroad.
But the problems are no longer obscured. The upsurge in nationalist tensions, the secession efforts by the Baltic republics, estimates by the C.I.A. that the Soviet economy is in an ''abysmal'' state, and the scenes of Mr. Gorbachev being booed at this year's May Day parade, have altered NATO's perception of the Soviet leader's prospects for success, and altered in some ways NATO's own agenda.
''The key issue for the West today is how do we manage the decline of the Soviet Union in a way that insures that our interests will be protected and advanced,'' Mr. Nye said.
He said the NATO allies have not pressed Mr. Gorbachev on Lithuania and have been trying to make the prospect of German unification and of membership in NATO as politically and militarily palatable to him as possible out of concern that if they push him too far ''you could push him right over a cliff'' before he is able to complete the current round of arms control negotiations.
As the British foreign affairs analyst Lawrence Freedman wrote in the Independent newspaper of London this week: ''There is no doubt that the West wants to help Gorbachev. This is not simply gratitude for what he has allowed to happen, but that he is someone with whom deals can be struck.''
 
Doubt on Arms Issues
After Mr. Baker's three-hour talk in Bonn on Friday with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, American officials were still in doubt about whether the Kremlin would be able to overcome the obstacles in the way of a strategic arms limitation treaty and a conventional arms limitation treaty. The White House was hoping to have both treaties substantially completed by the time of the May 30 summit meeting in Washington between Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev.
A State Department official said of Mr. Gorbachev: ''If you are totally preoccupied with problems that you regard as affecting your immediate survival, how equipped are you going to be to face other issues? I mean, look what is on this guy's plate: the economy is falling apart, the Baltics are seceding, he's being booed at a May Day parade, and then someone comes into his office and says, 'What do you think we should do about the range issue on air-launched cruise missiles?' And he probably just says, 'Leave me alone.' ''
A Soviet-American dispute over what range of air-launched cruise missiles should be covered by the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty, known as Start, has been one of the major problems holding up the proposed agreement.
Yet few in NATO would write off Mr. Gorbachev.
''The nature of his problems are now more apparent,'' the State Department official said. ''But anyone who is quick to count him out would be making a big mistake. He is still Gorbachev, with everything that means. There is also no one around with the strength to replace him. I still think he will make the arms control decisions, but the push is going to have to come from us. He has not lost the ability to make decisions, it is just that the number he has to make now tend to crowd out some of those that we are most interested in.''

HEADLINE: Rush for Asian Resources Prompts A Race for Weapons and Security

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, May 2

 BODY:
With the humbling of Vietnam in Cambodia, political and ideological tensions in Southeast Asia have been significantly reduced. But an arms race in the Asian and Pacific region is eating up the potential benefits from peace.
With a growing economic competition for fish, petroleum and gas, all the countries of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations - Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore, Thailand and the Philippines - are seeking ways to extend their power to the outer reaches of their territorial waters and beyond. That includes areas like the Spratly Islands, which are the subject of conflicting claims by China, Taiwan, Malaysia and the Philippines. 
This involves heavy capital investment in ships and planes, and coincides with an expensive modernization of forces after a long period of concentration on fighting rebellions.
The countries of Asean, as well as Japan, South Korea and Taiwan, will spend about $40 billion this year on the military. Add China, India and Australia and the figure is $60 billion. By the end of this decade, analysts expect it to reach $130 billion.
The Asean countries have had to deal with leftist insurgencies, but except for the one in the Philippines, these rebellions have been smothered. This created the necessary stability for current economic development, says Kusuma Snitwongse, head of the Institute of Strategic and International Studies at Thailand's Chulalongkorn University, and also allowed a reorganization of armies to deal with external threats.
 
After Cambodia, New Trouble
That trend was accelerated by the Vietnamese occupation of Cambodia, which brought Vietnamese troops to the Thai border and gave the Soviet Union and China more excuses to involve themselves in the region.
But now that the Vietnamese have largely returned home, Mrs. Kusuma said, ''there is at the same time a demand for better and more modern arms, especially for the air force and the navy.''
Noordin Sopiee, director of Malaysia's Institute of Strategic and International Studies, said that throughout Southeast Asia, ''border concerns'' are being replaced by ''territorial concerns,'' which means an unparalleled push for naval and air power to police sovereign and potentially wealthy offshore waters. ''That's the real arms race going on, and it's not so quiet,'' he said.
The Thai military budget is a good example of what is happening. Despite severe cuts in American arms aid, which has plummeted from $102.3 million in 1985 to $5.2 million now, the Thai arms budget this year will be $2.1 billion, up 16 percent from last year.
The Malaysian military budget has grown along with the economy by 20 percent over the last two years, diplomats say. But it does not reflect a $1.6 billion memorandum of understanding, signed with Britain in September 1988, for the purchase of 8 to 12 Tornado fighters, anti-aircraft missiles, naval corvettes and possibly submarines.
 
A City With an Arsenal
Singapore continues to spend about $1.5 billion a year on arms, 23 percent of its budget and 5.5 percent of its gross national product. While it says it has only deterrence in mind on the model of Switzerland, its advanced weapons, including American F-16's, provides reach far beyond its borders.
Even Brunei is extending its armed forces to insure the security of its oilfields and territorial waters. Brunei is buying patrol boats and the country's first fixed-wing combat aircraft, 16 British Aerospace Hawks. If Vietnam and China start fighting again over the Spratlys, which most diplomats regard as inevitable, then Brunei wants to be sure there is no spillover.
In Indonesia, tight military budgets have slowed planned modernization, especially the purchase of naval patrol vessels and aircraft, to defend some of the most extensive territorial waters in the world.
For that reason, Indonesia, like other Asean countries, wants American forces to retain their bases in the Philippines.

HEADLINE: I.M.F. IS EXPECTING BIG FUND INCREASE

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 5

 BODY:
Finance ministers and central bank governors representing most countries of the world are expected shortly to approve at least a 50 percent increase in the $120 billion resources of the International Monetary Fund.
Michel Camdessus, managing director of the 152-nation agency, said at a news conference today that ''one can be reasonably certain this institution will be consolidated and significantly reinforced.''
He said the increase was ''good news'' for the world economic system.
A senior United States Treasury official confirmed Mr. Camdessus's assessment. ''We're very, very close on all the major elements of a quota increase,'' he said. 
 
Shift by the White House
Until last year, the United States opposed an increase, but the Bush Administration changed its mind in view of the efforts to cut third-world debt and the upheaval in Eastern Europe.
Mr. Camdessus spoke on the eve of the spring membership meeting of his organization and its fellow global lender, the World Bank, which together provide the bulk of economic assistance for third-world countries.
The increase for the I.M.F., which would mark the ninth time in its 45-year history that the fund has tapped members for money, is expected to be approved in the course of the meetings here early next week. The World Bank obtained an increase of nearly 100 percent in its resources last year.
The I.M.F. is seeking the money to help resolve third-world debt problems and to meet new responsibilities in Poland, Hungary, Czechoslovakia and other Eastern European nations that are moving from centrally planned autocracies to market-based democracies.
 
Details of the Loans
The I.M.F. makes short- to medium-term loans, chiefly for three to five years, to countries having trouble making ends meet. To qualify, borrowers have to take tough economic measures. The World Bank makes longer-term loans to finance large projects in poorer lands.
During the extensive negotiations over the last three years, the United States has been the least-enthusiastic backer of the increase.
The Bush Administration has now gone along, but Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady has refused back an increase well in excess of 50 percent. He will meet with finance ministers from six other leading industrial countries on Sunday to try to wrap up final details of the increase.
Most other countries, with the principal exceptions of Britain and Saudi Arabia, have pressed for increases of two-thirds or more. It is expected that the final figure will be closer to 50 percent than 67 percent.
 
U.S. Share Would Be $12 Billion
Members' quotas are based on their weighted vote in the institution. With a 20 percent vote, the United States' share of a 50 percent increase would be $12 billion.
Because of complex ways in which the monetary fund works, the money does not increase the Federal budget deficit, but the Bush Administration still faces a battle with Congress, where any form of foreign aid is unpopular. The President is unlikely to make the formal request for the money until next year.
Technically, the money represents an exchange of assets. The United States makes the dollars available on call, but increases its own rights to borrow the currencies of other countries as needed.
Not only developing countries borrow from the I.M.F. The United States has tapped the fund's resources on eight occasions, the latest in 1978 when it borrowed $2.3 billion.
 
Difficulties in 1983
But these borrowings did not prevent a major debate in 1983, the last time an Administration asked Congress for money for the I.M.F. Congress finally approved a 47 percent increase, after President Ronald Reagan became deeply involved in lobbying.
To help make the case this time, the Administration has conditioned its approval on the willingness of members to address the problem of nearly $4 billion of overdue I.M.F. loans by 11 impoverished fund members.
Working quietly with other governments since last October, the United States has devised a complicated mechanism for dealing with the arrears issue, requiring a change in the I.M.F. charter.
Under I.M.F. rules, 85 percent of the weighted votes of the members are needed in order to approve an amendment to the articles of agreement. Only two such amendments have gone through in the past. An approval to to seek the charter change is expected this week.
 
Loss of Voting Rights
Under the arrears plan, delinquent countries would lose their voting rights, but special efforts would be undertaken to help them improve their economic position, provided they are willing to impose heavily supervised economic policies.
If the delinquents fail to live up to their obligations, I.M.F. gold would be sold to make good the I.M.F. claims against them.
Another issue that still has to be resolved after months of wrangling is that of the ranking of major industrial nations in the I.M.F. voting hierarchy.
Japan has had the fifth-largest quota and vote in the organization, but insisted as part of the latest increase in money that it be allowed to move up to No. 2, after the United States, reflecting the growth of its economic power. Tokyo already has the No. 2 ranking in the World Bank.
The advance for Japan would displace Britain, but it appears that an agreement is near.

HEADLINE: U.S. Envoy Steps Into Political Firestorm in Kenya

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya, May 5

 BODY:
The United States Ambassador has found himself in the middle of a fierce political debate about whether this East African nation and ally of Washington should replace its one-party state with a multiparty system.
Smith Hempstone, the new Ambassador who as a former journalist has shown a more freewheeling style than his predecessors, told a meeting of Kenyan businessmen on Thursday that a strong political tide in Congress favored giving economic aid to countries that ''nourish democratic institutions, defend human rights and practice multiparty politics.''
Mr. Hempstone, touching on Kenya's most sensitive issue, said he was not instructing the Government on what to do but rather relating a fact of life.
But the Kenyan President, Daniel arap Moi, one of the staunchest defenders of the one-party state, took the comment as an unnecessary intrusion. 
''Kenya is a sovereign state and equal to other states and does not require any guidance from outsiders on how to run its affairs,'' Mr. Moi told a political rally on Friday in the western Kenyan city of Kisumu. Anyway, Mr. Moi said, just as ''I cannot understand a foreign society,'' it is impossible for foreigners to understand African ones.
Mr. Moi, who has called Kenyan advocates of the multiparty state ''traitors,'' has long contended that a multiparty system would form along tribal lines. In an interview today, Mr. Hempstone said he was sensitive to Mr. Moi's concerns that political pluralism would emphasize tribalism. But since other African leaders say they are planning to move away from one-party states, Mr. Hempstone said, he wanted Kenya to be ''ahead of the curve.''
The question of converting to a multiparty system, with all its implications of broader freedoms of speech and dissent, has been stewing here since the beginning of the year. The debate exploded when one of the country's most prominent and articulate church officials, the Anglican Bishop, Henry Okullu, advocated a multiparty state 10 days ago and was immediately denounced in Parliament.
In some parts of Africa - the Ivory Coast, Benin, Gabon and Zaire - there have been recent moves by the long-entrenched leaders, under pressure from street demonstrations, to allow other parties to form. Mr. Moi has been resistant, almost defiantly so, to any suggestion of change.
Kenya has long been a one-party state. In 1982, four years after Mr. Moi came to power, the constitution was amended to make the Kenya African National Union the only legal party. Two years ago, the constitution was amended again, abolishing the independence of the judiciary and allowing the police to detain suspects for 14 days without charge. The secret ballot was also abolished in favor of a system in which voters line up behind pictures of candidates in KANU party primaries.
 
'Vested Interests'
The same day that Mr. Hempstone made his remarks, two former Cabinet ministers said Kenya's political, economic and social problems were caused by the single-party system.
It is the ''vested interests'' of those in power that perpetuate the system, the former ministers said.
Kenneth Matiba, a former Minister for Transport and Communications, who recently had his passport confiscated by the Government after a trip to Britain, and Charles Rubia, a former Housing Minister, dismissed the Government's argument that political pluralism would result in a return to tribalism. Rather, they said, the potential for political parties forming along tribal lines was used as an excuse to ''sustain a system that deprives people of their rights and freedoms.''
Mr. Hempstone is the first American ambassador in Africa to express publicly what is an emerging policy in Washington - that African democracies will be favored for aid - and he said that he was only trying to do what was best for Kenya.
Kenya last year received $65 million in economic aid from Washington.
''I will continue to argue for the maintenance and, indeed, for an increase in aid,'' he said. ''But it won't make it any easier for me or for Kenya if Kenya is not ahead of the curve.''

HEADLINE: CAMPUS LIFE: BERKELEY;
For This Class On Shakespeare, Play's the Thing

DATELINE: BERKELEY, Calif.

 BODY:
Hugh Richmond gives no midterms or final exams in his ''Shakespeare in the Theater'' class at the University of California at Berkeley. For this English professor's students, all the world's a stage, and his students are the players.
Forty percent of students' grades depend on their comprehension of the play as shown in how they play their roles or perform behind-the-scenes work on makeup, costumes or lighting. Acting ability does not count. 
In three performances in April before small audiences in Wheeler Hall, Professor Richmond's students tackled ''The Famous History of the Life of King Henry VIII.'' The play is considered one of Shakespeare's weakest, and many scholars believe he wrote little of it, attributing the work instead to John Fletcher.
''It may not be 'Romeo and Juliet,' but I think it's a great play,'' said Hilary Ivancovich, a sophomore economics major from Watsonville, Calif., who played the duchess, the king's sister.
 
An Alternative to Lectures
Students are also required to write a five-page essay that shows how the performance increased their understanding of the play. That counts for 50 percent of their grade, according to the course description. The remaining 10 percent depends on class participation.
''Instead of passively being lectured at, you're actually doing things - memorizing the speeches,'' Professor Richmond said. ''If you perform it, your knowledge is enormously enriched.''
Fifty students whose majors range from English to physics are enrolled, the largest number ever, Professor Richmond said. Previously, he said, enrollment was 30 to 40.
Professor Richmond said the play's the thing that has captured the students' attention. ''People who come to see the play come back to take part in a later production,'' he said.
 
A Little Bit of the Ham
Students say the class's popularity has grown by word of mouth, and relies in part on there being a little bit of the ham in everyone. It offers the opportunity to ''act and get credit for it,'' Miss Ivancovich said.
''King Henry VIII,'' a sequel to ''Richard III,'' is Shakespeare's last play, Professor Richmond said, chosen because it is a ''neglected play'' and unfamiliar to his students.
''We are an academic institution,'' he said. ''I think we should do things that commercial theaters cannot do.''
The performances were videotaped under the direction of Paul Shepard, a staff member, who also directed the play. A copy will be placed in Moffitt Library for faculty, staff and student use, Mr. Shepard said.
 
'You Forget You're in a Class'
Because the play is rarely performed, Professor Richmond said, the tape will be a valuable addition to the university's collection. He added that he anticipates other universities will request copies.
Professor Richmond said he has been putting his students on stage and behind the scenes assisting with makeup, lighting, sound and costumes almost every year since 1977, when he produced ''Love's Labor's Lost.'' This year's program budget is $3,000, he said, financed by the university's College of Letters and Science. The class borrowed elaborate costumes from Berkeley's drama department, but there are few props and no sets.
''You forget you're in a class,'' said Robert Fulton, a senior English major from Malibu, Calif., who plays a dancer and a nobleman in ''Henry VIII.''
Miss Ivancovich said her part as the duchess has given her an appreciation of the interchangeability of male and female roles in Shakespeare's works - the subject of her class paper.
Professor Richmond's production of ''King Henry VIII'' changes the role of lord chamberlain to that of the duchess. The switch, Miss Ivancovich said, ''not only adapts well, but works better.''

GRAPHIC: photo: For ''Shakespeare in the Theater,'' a class at the University of California at Berkeley given by Prof. Hugh Richmond, left, 40 percent of a student's grade depends on their performance in a production of one of Shakespeare's works. Right, Paul Shepard directed two students in a scene from ''King Henry VIII.'' (Fred Mertz for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CAMPUS LIFE: SMITH;
Ability to Pay Becomes Factor in Admissions

DATELINE: NORTHAMPTON, Mass.

 BODY:
Smith College has ended its system of admitting students without regard to their ability to pay.
''It is the first among the most selective liberal arts colleges that we know of to have taken such action,'' said Dallas Martin, president of the National Association of Student Financial Aid Administrators. Mr. Martin noted that while several colleges have publicly re-examined their admissions policies and others are privately discussing them, none had openly abandoned them.
Smith's president, Mary Maples Dunn, said, ''The board of admissions unanimously wished to continue to guarantee the full need to students we admit.'' Other officials said the college could no longer afford the policy. 
Ms. Dunn said the change would primarily hurt students on the lower end of admission ranking who need financial aid. It will become effective in the selection of the class that will enter Smith in the fall of 1991, said Debra Bradley, the news director at the college.
The new policy calls for Smith to distribute a budgeted amount of financial aid, starting with the top-ranked students and proceeding downward through the lower-ranked but still acceptable applicants. Each student admitted will be given the full amount of money she needs. But once the financial aid budget is exhausted, students who remain on the acceptable list but need financial aid will not be admitted.
 
'Totally Outraged'
This new procedure was adopted last February, when the college's board of admissions, following a recommendation from the board of trustees to limit financial aid, voted the change. Students have charged that the college, where tuition, room and board in September will total $20,140, is moving toward elitism, and some demonstrated against the change last month.
''We were totally outraged that a policy such as this could have been implemented without telling the students,'' said an organizer of the rally, Paula Rojas, a sophomore from Houston majoring in government and Latin American studies.
Alison Friedman, a French studies major from Concord, Mass., and co-chairwoman of the Association of Low Income Students, said, ''It's unrealistic to achieve socio-economic diversity with such a policy.''
 
Increased Costs
Another organizer of the rally, Amy Loper, a junior anthropology major from Marion, Iowa, said she thought the new policy would deter students from applying to Smith. ''I know I probably wouldn't have applied if this had been the policy,'' she said. ''The assurance that my family's income wouldn't be taken into consideration was one of my prime factors for applying to this college.''
In 1983, Smith College began admitting students without regard to their financial situation and guaranteeing aid to any student admitted. The college was forced to curtail the practice because of increased costs, said Smith's treasurer, Larry Selgelid. He said that this year, for the first time in a number of years, the college ''will probably come in with a deficit.''
Since the college's admissions policy was established, aid to students has grown at a rate of 20.3 percent a year, the college said. Aid totaled $5.1 million in 1983-84, and climbed to $12.8 million by 1988-89.
The percentage of students receiving financial aid increased to 52.2 percent in 1988-89 from 38 percent in 1983-84. By 1988-89, financial aid costs represented 16.9 percent of the college's total operating expenses, up from 10.1 percent in 1983-84.
 
Spending of Savings a Concern
''The financial aid budget could sink the college budget if left uncontrolled,'' said the board of trustees chairwoman, Phoebe Lewis.
Mr. Selgelid said the college did not want to dig more deeply into the endowment because ''we don't want to spend our savings today so that it won't be there for tomorrow's student.''
Under the new policy, financial aid will continue to grow, but at a slower rate, Mr. Selgelid said. The president's office explained that the college is aiming to stabilize financial aid at 15 percent of the operating budget within four years.
Faced with a similar financial aid squeeze, Tufts University in Medford, Mass., recently discussed changing its admissions policy in the face of a projected shortfall in financial aid for next year of up to $500,000 - a figure that could double if the state reduces money for aid, which has been suggested.
In 1982, Wesleyan University in Middletown, Conn., announced - but was never forced to enact - a new policy that would have effectively ended admissions without regard to financial need.
The dean of admissions and financial aid at Wesleyan, Karl M. Furstenberg, said a number of factors -including a successful $50 million fund-raising effort of which $10 million was pegged for financial aid -rendered the new policy unnecessary.
Smith College has not yet announced its decision to change the admissions policy and, Ms. Dunn said, ''I don't know that we were really planning on announcing it at all.''
The new policy was not made public until the student newspaper, The Sophian, published an article about it on April 26. ''It was unfortunate that the information came out that way,'' Ms. Dunn said.

HEADLINE: POP VIEW;
EVEN THE MUSIC WAS RECYCLED

BYLINE: By JOHN PARELES

 BODY:
Amid the Earth Day festivities in New York's Central Park, some of the most ingenious recycling took place in the music on stage. Many of the performers made the effort to do something more than flog their latest hits; they gave at least a passing thought to the cause.
Daryl Hall and John Oates had the panache to resurrect Marvin Gaye's ''Mercy, Mercy Me (The Ecology),'' recorded in 1971 and not outdated in its despair over ''radiation underground,'' while Edie Brickell realized that Bob Dylan's ''Hard Rain's A-Gonna Fall'' (not coincidentally her most recent recording, for the soundtrack of the film ''Born on the Fourth of July'') was as appropriate to environmental apocalypse as it was to the fears of nuclear war that inspired it in the early 60's. And the rally could almost have commissioned the B-52's, whose latest songs - especially ''Roam,'' about enjoying the wilderness - gamely, campily grin through environmental worries. 
Whatever cleverness the performers showed was amplified by the sheer sense of event. Like the sun's gravity bending a light beam, the rally's size and fervor bent other songs to fit its theme.
With a million-strong audience attuned to messages about the state of the environment, songs whose meanings had long seemed settled were transformed. Love songs no longer seemed like private affairs; Ben E. King's ''Stand by Me'' became an anthem of concern and solidarity, while Hall and Oates's ''I Can't Go for That'' became a protest instead of a romantic gripe. Even the Bee Gees' morosely self-involved ''I Started a Joke,'' sung by the Roches, could be taken as a parable about unthinking consumption and disposal.
Rallies and benefits are good places to hear songs getting reinterpreted. At the series of Farm Aid concerts over the last several years, songs about home and work and land have all seemed pointed and topical; at Amnesty International shows, Sting's ''Set Them Free'' - a song that urges lovers not to be possessive - became anthemic. ''That's What Friends Are For,'' a hunk of sappy sentimentality, gained some gravity when Dionne Warwick turned it into a fund-raiser for AIDS. No harm done; context isn't everything, but it accounts for more of a song's impact than most songwriters foresee. Such flexibility is one of pop's deepest pleasures and easiest corruptions. As gospel and soul singers know, the same song can sound devotional or lusty, give or take a few pronouns and a change of venue from church to club; thus the continuing pilferage through the centuries, as pop steals from religious music and religious music steals pop tricks in return. In the vast majority of pop songs, the flexibility of interpretation makes each lover or dancer an intimate of the singer, who seems, like a fortuneteller or con artist, to know the whole story.
But the same thing that makes pop songs democratic - anybody can have their interpretive fling with a song - makes them promiscuous; they lend themselves to commercials as well as benefits, demagoguery as well as education. Movie and television soundtrack producers can make love songs ominous or political songs complacent. The meanings of songs can be grabbed just as easily by the highest bidder as well as by the most well-meaning (or farfetched) cause.
Heartwarming as the performers' show of concern was at Earth Day, the recording business has its own imperatives that could hardly be called ecological. The large companies are nettled by an organization called Ban the Box. The advocacy group, started by the independent Rykodisc label and directed against the 6-by-12-inch disposable packages called longboxes that are used for CD's in the United States, has been busily publicizing the price (do consumers really want to pay an extra dollar for it?) and wastefulness of the longbox. It would prefer no longboxes or, in a pinch, reusable display boxes designed to prevent shoplifting.
Ban the Box must be having some effect, since the American record business has launched a countercampaign. They want to keep the longbox, because the bigger package has more visual impact on a record-store shelf. As the LP disappears, the record companies want to hang on to some form of packaging that will advertise the product.
Just in time for Earth Day, a group of major and independent labels responded with their own initiative. They noted that many longboxes are now made from recycled paper, which sidesteps the fact that they still cost money to make and are still thrown away by the vast majority of CD buyers.
Even better, the record companies came up with a project that's nothing less than breathtaking in its transparent hypocrisy. To prove their green consciousness, record companies are planning to print ecological suggestions on the longboxes - presumably to be read and taken to heart in the few moments before the package hits the trash. (One prospective hint urges readers to keep car tires properly inflated, which would promote fuel economy while music fans are cruising for burgers. Pretty radical.) This is exactly the kind of gambit that could catch on in a big way. No doubt we can look forward to ecological messages on polystyrene foam containers and aerosol cans and disposable cameras, all in the name of heightened environmental consciousness. Think of it: towering landfills could be devoted exclusively to throwaways that claim good intentions.
As messages go, the ecological suggestions are nothing if not direct; unlike songs, they're supposed to be interpreted in just one way. But give me the volatile, indirect, undependable messages of pop songs any time.

GRAPHIC: Photo: edie Brickell sang Bob Dylan's ''Hard Rain's A-Gonna Fall'' as an anthem about environmental apocalypse rather than nuclear war. (Ebet Roberts)

HEADLINE: RECORDINGS;
A New Caribbean Generation Sets Listeners to Swaying

BYLINE: By DAISANN MCLANE; Daisann McLane writes about Caribbean and Latin music for The Village Voice, Rolling Stone and other publications.

 BODY:
Fusion - of rhythms, ethnic groups and cultures - has vitalized Caribbean music for hundreds of years. A generation ago, the musical import-export trade proceeded at a steady but gradual pace. A Haitian group would tour Cuba and return with Latin songs in their set. Cuban records trickled down to Trinidad, influencing the horn arrangements of the calypsos.
Things move much faster these days. Because of improved recording technology, and increased movement of Caribbean people to and from their home countries and northern media centers like New York, London and Paris, a rhythm developed in one end of the region can rip up dance floors a thousand miles away in a matter of months, even weeks. 
A soca record from Trinidad makes a splash in northern Brazil, where a local musician who likes the beat modifies it, then adds it to a popular Bolivian melody. The new sound is a hit in Bahia, where a French record company executive on vacation hears it, buys the rights and takes it to Paris. And everything comes up lambada.
A marketing coup, a pop fad, and a silly one at that. But remember, Freddie and the Dreamers paved the way for the Beatles. And perhaps lambada's hip-loosening action will have a more lasting side effect: to attract a wider audience to the much richer music being produced by a new generation of Caribbean singer-songwriters. Among them are the Dominican Republic's Juan Luis Guerra, who will be performing at Avery Fisher Hall next Sunday and whose latest album is ''Ojala que Llueva Cafe'' (Karen Records KLP-126; LP and cassette), and Joe Arroyo from Colombia, who has recently released ''En Accion'' (Fuentes 201705; LP and cassette).
Performers like these, along with Trinidad's David Rudder and Panama-born Ruben Blades, come from distinctly different places and traditions, but they have one important thing in common: they understand the sound of the Caribbean. Rooted in the abundant rhythmic and folkloric sources of their home cultures, but steeped in the music of other islands, and in Western pop and jazz, these musicians are creating irresistible Caribbean pop music that moves more than bodies. Original and modern, they are leaders of a tropical New Wave. Mr. Guerra stands out in the world of merengue, where the routine pelvic action makes Elvis Presley look arthritic, and where the lyrics would give censors heart attacks if they weren't in heavily accented Dominican Spanish. Tall and a bit nerdy in baggy slacks, with a brown fedora pulled shyly over his bearded face, Mr. Guerra stands seriously at the microphone, and hardly moves.
His songs aren't standard merengue fare either; where other popular merengueros opt for comic, sexy double-entendre and hard-driving horns (sample titles: ''My Waist,'' ''The Black Man Can't Do It''), Mr. Guerra's merengue is university-level; he goes for the delicate metaphor, the deftly told tale and sweet vocal harmony arrangements. The titles of two singles from Mr. Guerra's latest album tell the story best: ''Ojala que Llueva Cafe'' (''May It Rain Coffee'') and ''Visa para un Sueno'' (''Visa for a Dream'').
Mr. Guerra's compositions, which combine a political awareness with more downto-earth concerns like love and romance, reflect the influence of the nueva cancion (modern Latin folk music with a political edge), but Mr. Guerra is also very much in the tradition of North American folk rockers of the 70's, like James Taylor. The difference is that Mr. Guerra uses the powerful rhythms and song forms of his native Dominican Republic, and borrows styles (mainly soca and salsa) from the rest of the Caribbean.
Mr. Guerra may have arty aspirations, but on his home turf he's no cult figure; his music is accessible, and extremely popular. Each of his four albums has produced hit singles. Strong melodies and inventive arrangements keep his work at street level; his best tunes, like ''Si Tu Te Vas'' (''If You Go'') from his 1985 recording ''Mudanza y Acarreo,'' linger in the brain long after first exposure. Unlike other merengue arrangers, Mr. Guerra likes to layer voices instead of horns (Mr. Guerra's band, Grupo 440, includes three other lead singers), so that his previous album often sounds like a dizzy, tropical take on the jazz ensemble Manhattan Transfer.
But on ''Ojala que Llueva Cafe,'' Mr. Guerra has pushed the harmonies to the background and brought his own voice up front. At first listening the choice seems unwise; Mr. Guerra's tenor is earnest but thin and nasal. However, without the distraction of tricky vocal arrangements, the attention is drawn to the songs, and they are among his best, full of nostalgia for a Caribbean past, frustration with the economic and social limitations of the present and hopes for a better future.
There's no better place to look for a tropical New Wave esthetic than Cartagena, the colonial port city that faces the Caribbean from the Spanish Main. And Joe Arroyo is Cartagena's proudest pan-Caribbean export. He started singing there when he was 10 years old to help support his mother, and his first professional gig was in a whorehouse. From there he's gone on to become a national hero. Mr. Arroyo started out as a salsa singer with popular Colombian bands like the Latin Brothers and Fruko - Colombia has for years been a nation of salsa fanatics.
But since forming his own group in the mid-80's, Mr. Arroyo has expanded his music to include elements from all parts of the Caribbean, Colombia and Africa. On his groundbreaking 1988 album, ''Fuego en Mi Mente'' (''Fire in My Brain''), and its strong followup, ''En Accion,'' Mr. Arroyo skips from salsa to merengue to soca, zouk and cumbia, the African-Indian-Spanish music of his homeland. No other Caribbean artist covers so much territory.
Mr. Arroyo is a descendant of slaves imported by the Spaniards to Colombia in the 17th century, and the lyrics of his songs carry the weight of Caribbean history. ''No Le Pega la Negra'' (''Don't Hit the Black Woman'') can stand next to anything Bob Marley or the Mighty Sparrow has written about slavery and its consequences; ''En Barranquilla Me Quedo'' (''I'm Staying in Baranquilla'') is as emotional an evocation of place and home as you will find in any Caribbean singer's repertory.
But it's Mr. Arroyo's amazing voice that has caught the attention of an international audience. A powerful tenor, urgent and full of spirit, Mr. Arroyo would sound quite at home in any black church in the United States singing duets with Al Green. When he sings a capella, as he does in his signature song ''A Mi Dios Todo Le Debo'' (''I Owe Everything to God''), Mr. Arroyo lifts his listeners - quite literally. At his recent Palladium show in Manhattan, Mr. Arroyo's fans responded by tossing each other high into the air.

HEADLINE: DANCE VIEW;
Ballet Theater's Challenge: To Reclaim Its Soul

BYLINE: By ANNA KISSELGOFF

 BODY:
Paradise regained? Anyone who thinks - as many do - that American Ballet Theater misplaced its soul during the decade that Mikhail Baryshnikov was its artistic director will now be closely watching a new regime determined to redefine the company's identity. Tomorrow's opening of the troupe's 50th-anniversary season in New York at the Metropolitan Opera House begins an era in which Jane Hermann and Oliver Smith, the recently named co-directors, promise to restore certain names and policies identified with Ballet Theater's past. They must, of course, go forward without appearing to step backward.
Once again, Ballet Theater finds itself in a state of flux similar to the one that marked its 40th birthday in 1980. At that time, Mr. Baryshnikov succeeded Mr. Smith and Lucia Chase, the company's founding patron. But the issues today are different. Mr. Baryshnikov's policies blurred stylistic distinctions between Ballet Theater and other troupes, and much of the new focus is geared toward reasserting a more familiar profile. Whether modern taste can still accept the early dance-dramas of Antony Tudor, the great choreographer associated with Ballet Theater, as the company's representative symbol is another matter. Moreover, a current financial crisis may well dictate how adventuresome the repertory will be with respect to the box office. 
The company's jubilees tend to be tinged with uncertainty (it was saved from dissolution on its 25th anniversary in 1965 by a grant from the newly established National Endowment for the Arts). Yet, Ballet Theater has survived remarkably, thanks largely to the moments of glorious dancing that have consistently studded its history. Despite tumult and transformations, Ballet Theater inevitably follows a natural tendency to remain itself. It continues to be a classical ballet company distinguished from others by the widest repertory in the world; yes, a gallery of the dance.
This is how Mr. Baryshnikov found the company and that is how he left it. His shift of emphasis was a matter of degree, but it was significant.
The troupe's artistic profile is now poised between two views of what ballet should emphasize: An accent on formal classical style, as promoted by Mr. Baryshnikov, or Ballet Theater's traditional identification with dramatic values and the use of classical technique to express feeling rather than pure form.
An outsider might consider these as intramural details. But in the end, Mr. Baryshnikov's changes (especially in familiar versions of the classics) offended a public that knew its ballet and that was not eager to see Ballet Theater duplicate the artistic policies of other companies.
Mr. Baryshnikov's taste tilted toward ballets by George Balanchine and 19th-century classics derived from versions he had known at the Kirov Ballet in Leningrad. He also favored works by experimental modern-dance choreographers investigating the academic idiom. By contrast, Ms. Hermann and Mr. Smith now guarantee at least two revivals a year from two of Ballet Theater's distinguished founding choregraphers, Agnes de Mille and Tudor, who died in 1987. To those who might not find the dance-dramas within that repertory overly exciting, Ms. Hermann replies, ''Too bad, that's Ballet Theater.''
The golden mean, of course, lies in between, as the company's tentative plans indicate. Dramatically oriented choreographers who will probably turn up at Ballet Theater include Jiri Kylian, Tudor's artistic heir and director of the Netherlands Dance Theater, and Glen Tetley, a company alumnus who has recently created some of his best work at the National Ballet of Canada during his banishment from Ballet Theater in the Baryshnikov years. But that future also includes Twyla Tharp, a Baryshnikov favorite, and any innovative newcomer who emerges from the scores of videotapes that have ''inundated'' Ms. Hermann after Mr. Baryshnikov's premature departure in September. Mr. Baryshnikov, who had planned to leave in July 1990, departed early, following a clash over finances and personnel with Ballet Theater's board and Ms. Hermann.
A major expectation is that the dancers will again feel free to project the individualized stage presence that embodied Ballet Theater's signature through the 1960's.
In the 1970's, however, the company was attracting audiences through sheer dance power. Mr. Baryshnikov took this trend to its logical conclusion. He asked the public to look upon Ballet Theater as an ensemble where what was danced was more important than who was dancing.
At the same time, he narrowed the company's stylistic range. A positive result has been the giant improvement in the company's classical technique and style - achieved in part through increasing the number of ballets that require this technique, namely works by Balanchine and Kirov-derived versions of the 19th-century classics. The programming balance tipped toward plotless ballets and away from more varied fare.
Did Mr. Baryshnikov really try to turn Ballet Theater into a copy of the Kirov or to ''Balanchinize'' the company? If so, he did not get very far. But there is no doubt that he blurred the company's distinctiveness and that this issue is the focus of the new regime.
''A.B.T. should have something of its own to say, with a different profile,'' Ms. Hermann declared in an interview before the season, adding that the troupe should be ''aggressive in pursuing new works - they are what keeps the dancers fresh and alive.''
Mr. Smith, whose beginnings as a theatrical designer included creating the decor for Jerome Robbins's ''Fancy Free'' in 1944, believes that the current emphasis on classical style must be balanced with dramatic values, what he calls ''a subconscious current of understanding in the dancing, a subtext.'' Tudor's genius is above dispute: He was an innovator who introduced a new expressionism into classical ballet, as embodied in his masterpiece ''Dark Elegies.'' But there is a myth-making quality about the company's recent attempt to make him the equivalent of Balanchine in the New York City Ballet.
Richard Pleasant, the architect-turned-administrator who founded Ballet Theater in 1939, created what became the equivalent of a major acting repertory company with a plethora of choreographers. At its worst, this policy led to the manufacturing of disposable works. At its best, it fostered outstanding creative diversity.
Within this context, Ballet Theater is Tudor's company, but it is not a Tudor company. It is as a touchstone of excellence that Ballet Theater should regard his works, not as an esthetic guideline for the company's profile as a whole.
Mr. Baryshnikov was correct in his intuition that Ballet Theater should not identify only with a narrative esthetic developed in the 1930's and 40's. But he swung the other way, introducing formally oriented modern-dance choreographers, such as David Gordon, Karole Armitage, Mark Morris and Ms. Tharp, who regarded ballet technique as an alien language to be mocked or explored, rather than taken for granted.
Ballet Theater's audience, however, is familiar with the academic vocabulary as well as with the standard versions of the 19th-century and early 20th-century classics.
Mr. Baryshnikov's mistake was not that he tried to revise the classics but that his versions were less successful - less coherent, less choreographically rich - than previous Ballet Theater stagings.
Like a producer eliminating everyone's favorite aria from a favorite opera, Mr. Baryshnikov, for instance, took out the male solo traditional to Ballet Theater's staging of Michel Fokine's ''Sylphides.'' In fact, he replaced Fokine's own staging for the company with the Kirov version. One of Ms. Hermann's first acts next season will be to restore the version that has come down from Fokine's Ballet Theater production in 1940. ''It is ironic to see a Kirov version when A.B.T. had a lovely version from Fokine,'' Ms. Hermann says.
Where does Ballet Theater go from here? Mr. Smith's return to his former post as co-director is a symbol of continuity. It is obvious, nonetheless, that fresh ideas will be required.
Since the 50th-anniversary season was planned by Mr. Baryshnikov, it will not be until the 1990-91 season that audiences will have a clearer sense of the sort of repertory that will be offered under the new directors. Both warn that they are nowhere near the negotiating stage with any choreographers except for Mr. Kylian, one of whose successes with the Netherlands Dance Theater, ''Sinfonietta,'' will be danced by Ballet Theater next season. Mr. Kylian has also promised a new work in the next two years.
Mr. Robbins and Eliot Feld don't like their names bandied about as prospective prodigals returning to Ballet Theater, but the door is said to always be open to them. In addition to Mr. Tetley and Ms. Tharp, Ballet Theater would like to contact Maguy Marin, James Kudelka, Alberto Mendez of the National Ballet of Cuba and Laszlo Seregi, Hungary's leading choreographer. Ms. Hermann, impressed with one of Mr. Seregi's children's ballets, is considering asking him to restage a new version of ''Coppelia'' or ''The Nutcracker.''
As for repertory derived from other companies, Mr. Smith urges something new: Ballet Theater's first staging of ''Rouge et Noir,'' one of Massine's famous symphonic ballets of the 1930's. Ms. Hermann would like to see a Paris Opera Ballet staging of the 19th-century French ballet ''Sylvia'' and more works by Frederick Ashton.
Modern-dance choreographers, in Mr. Smith's view, ''are from another world,'' and Ms. Hermann welcomes only those who ''speak to the technique of our dancers.''
What she really wants, she says, is ''a resident choreographer who does not dominate the company but gives it a profile - Tudor was this kind of choreographer, one able to develop his work within the company.''
The difference, of course, is that Ballet Theater has doubled in size since the 1940's and is in the midst of a large-scale financial crisis. Ms. Hermann, engaged originally by Mr. Baryshnikov as Ballet Theater's executive director, clashed with him over cost-cutting when she trimmed the projected $23 million budget for 1989-90 to the present $18 million.
Ms. Hermann's stated determination to pay off current loans is bound to affect future repertory. In New York, Ballet Theater is faced with filling the Met, a 3,800-seat house. Tudor used to recall that he learned to choreograph in the intimate setting of Marie Rambert's tiny Mercury Theater in London. Today's choreographic novices are thrown upon the cavernous space of the Met stage.
It isn't difficult to discern box-office considerations in plans for staging potential crowd-pleasers with fresh versions of ''The Nutcracker'' and ''Coppelia.'' Yet, a Massine revival like ''Rouge et Noir,'' especially if its Matisse decor is properly reproduced, could be a spectacular challenge as well as a spectacular risk.
Ballet Theater will have to balance the safe with the bold. Unfortunately, it may have to follow the audience rather than lead the way in order to survive in the short run.
Ballet Theater also has the flexibility to capitalize on the public's thirst for outstanding personalities at a time when stars are downplayed in other troupes. It is no accident that the May 14 performance of ''Giselle'' with Yekaterina Maksimova and Vladimir Vasiliev, guests from the Bolshoi Ballet, is already sold out. Nor is it startling that the young Julio Bocca, invited by Mr. Baryshnikov into the company in 1987, is already a draw through his virtuosity and artistry.
Having survived largely as a showcase for magnificent dancing, Ballet Theater faces the all-American dilemma: Is it box office or is it art? The two are not mutually exclusive.
 
 
 
PARTY TIME
 American Ballet Theater is having an eight-week birthday party. Its 50th-anniversary season, filled with old works and new, opens tomorrow night with a gala at the Metropolitan Opera House.
On Tuesday evening, New Yorkers will be introduced to ''Brief Fling,'' Twyla Tharp's romp with music by Michel Colombier and Percy Grainger, which delighted audiences during the company's winter tour. Ms. Tharp will also be represented on May 15 by the complete version of ''Nine Sinatra Songs.''
Tuesday's bill concludes with a choreographic birthday cake: the company's first New York performance of ''Birthday Offering,'' which Sir Frederick Ashton devised in 1956 to honor the 25th anniversary of the Sadler's Wells Ballet (the British troupe now known as the Royal Ballet). This elegant divertissement to music of Alexander Glazunov will be led by Susan Jaffe in the role created by Dame Margot Fonteyn.
The Tuesday program also includes the late Antony Tudor's ''Jardin aux Lilas,'' a poignant ballet choreographed in 1936 about a woman who must marry a man she does not love. When staged by Ballet Theater in 1940, it immediately established Tudor as a master of the dramatic ballet. Carla Fracci, the Italian ballerina, will make the second of two guest appearances as the work's heroine. Her first comes at tomorrow's gala.
The eight-week season will also include revivals of two works by Agnes de Mille, another choreographer long associated with the company. ''Rodeo,'' her cowboy comedy that was last seen in 1982, returns to the repertory Wednesday night. ''Fall River Legend,'' a character study inspired by the life of Lizzie Borden, the shy New England spinster accused of murdering her father and stepmother, will be performed on June 8 in what will be the first production of that work since 1980.
The company has always emphasized spectacular dancing as well as eclectic choreography. The charismatic Fernando Bujones is appearing as a guest artist. Other guests, in addition to Miss Fracci, include Yekaterina Maksimova and Vladimir Vasiliev of the Bolshoi Ballet. Faruk Ruzimatov, who comes from the Kirov Ballet, has joined the troupe as a principal dancer. And, of course, the company's own roster is a distinguished one.
The birthday candles are indeed burning brightly.
 
- Jack Anderson

HEADLINE: Does Affirmative Action Work?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It is amazing how people can look at the same data and come away with completely different conclusions. In ''Affirmative Action and Competitiveness'' (April 22), Bennett Harrison and Lucy Gorham conclude that we need stronger affirmative action programs to bring up the level of African-American wages. 
I see the same data and can only conclude that affirmative action programs are not working. We have spent billions on these programs, created equal employment opportunity laws, created minority set-asides, created minority business enterprise regulations and fostered untold numbers of schemes to bring minorities into the work force and raise their level of participation in our economy.
If 20 years and billions of dollars have done little to solve the problem, why do the authors assume that still more laws, regulations and money will solve anything in the future?
Our country should stand for equality of opportunity. We cannot guarantee equality of results.
BERNARD RICHARDS
Old Westbury, N.Y., April 24

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
For G.M., The Bad News Is Pretty Good

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
When is a 54 percent cut in profits good news? When it's from General Motors.
G.M. stock managed to rise late last week on news of the sharp earnings drop, simply because that decline was less than the one Wall Street expected.
The market reaction after the profit announcement Thursday also reflected Wall Street hopes that the worst was behind the American economy, as growth begins to accelerate after a successful ''soft landing'' earlier this year. 
That happy consensus was thrown into doubt on Friday, however, when the Government stunned the financial markets with a report that far fewer people were working in April than had been expected.
Suddenly, the economic bears were crowing. ''We may be at a critical shifting point, where the markets say a recession is coming,'' said David Bostian, the chief economist of Jesup & Lamont Inc. Treasury bond prices jumped, and, after some hesitation, the stock market decided that the good news of lower rates outweighed recession fears. The Dow Jones industrial average reached 2,710.36, a weekly gain of 65.31 points.
The economic evidence now seems to point to relatively strong manufacturing, as businesses invest in new equipment, combined with a weak consumer sector that could end the party. The optimists think the Federal Reserve will assure that does not happen.
G.M. and the other auto companies were hurt by the consumer slowdown, but it wasn't the profit reports that had Wall Street tongues wagging. It was G.M.'s plan to boost pensions for 3,350 top executives, most notably the retiring chairman, Roger B. Smith, who wants to raise his pension to $1.25 million a year, from $700,000. That's about $600 per hour for each 40-hour week he won't work.
The justification is that G.M. needs higher pensions to attract better executives. Given the company's declining market share and uneven profits under Mr. Smith, a case can be made for such a need, but it is hard to understand just why the incentive is required for an executive about to retire anyway.
One legacy of Mr. Smith's regime is the promise that the company's class E and H shares, issued during the takeovers of Electronic Data Systems and Hughes Aircraft, would rise in price for a number of years. In a bear market, that guarantee could cost the company billions. Perhaps Mr. Smith would like to cut a deal giving him more money if the guarantee works out for G.M. and less if it doesn't.
Whether Mr. Smith gets his money is up to G.M.'s shareholders. They may recall that G.M. was the only one of the Big Three auto makers to pay a dividend each year of the 1980's, and that - assuming annual reinvestment of dividends - G.M. stock has outperformed the market during the Smith era, which began at the end of 1980. A $1,000 investment then in G.M. would be worth about $3,742 now, compared to $3,424 for the Standard & Poor's 500. On the other hand, G.M.'s rivals did much better. A similar investment in Chrysler would be worth $9,431, and a Ford stake $14,227.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Canada's Market Timing Puzzle

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
Canada is an opportunity waiting to happen. The opportunities center on commodities stocks, from copper to paper products, which play a major role in the economy and are expected to benefit from both an expected rebound in the Canadian economy and the recent rise in commodities prices.
The problem is deciding when to invest, given uncertainties over interest rates and the Canadian dollar. But some analysts say these may begin to clear up by this summer. 
In the 1980's, Canada was America's second-favorite foreign stock market after Britain. Of total net purchases of foreign stocks, just under 21 percent, or $5.2 billion, went North. And with Canadian interest rates at record levels, well above those in the United States, Americans have been pouring more into the bond market there recently.
But so far, 1990 has not been great to foreign or Canadian investors. The Toronto stock market has slipped sharply this year. It still doesn't compare to the Japanese slide, but the 15 percent dip in Toronto's TSE 300 index ranks it among the world's biggest losers.
Those high interest rates, combined with a slowing, maybe even declining economy, a widening trade deficit and stubborn inflation around 5 percent dragged the market down.
The Bank of Canada muffed its effort to lower interest rates in January. The Canadian dollar fell so quickly after the central bank dropped its key lending rate by one-quarter of 1 percentage point that the bank had to retreat. Interest rates went up again. The prime rate, now at 14.75 percent, is higher than it was in January.
And the looming constitutional crisis that threatens the unity of English and French-speaking Canada forms an uncomfortable backdrop for all the financial markets. June 23 is the deadline for ratification of the Meech Lake Accord, which would resolve the issue, but the outcome is in doubt.
''This is not good for any of our markets,'' said Wilfred J. Hahn of Prudential Bache Securities Inc. in Toronto, who for now is staying away from stocks and bonds.
But soon, the Bank of Canada will be forced to choose between high interest rates, which it used to fight inflation and support the Canadian dollar, and the prospect of a sharp economic decline if rates are not lowered. The economy is expected to win.
The Canadian dollar will then fall. That will be especially tough on the bond market, Mr. Hahn says, which has been propped up by large purchases from Japan and West Germany, as well as the United States. Once this hot money has fled, he said, the lower rates will make both bond and stock prices attractive again.
With the decline in the market this year, many stocks are already at a fair price in relation to earnings, which could help a small rally in the near term.
Eric S. Sprott, president of Sprott Securities in Toronto, is a close watcher of commodities and believes their recent price increases mean there are some opportunites now. ''The Canadian market, notwithstanding Meech Lake, notwithstanding interest rates, will be an extremely interesting market to be invested in,'' he said. A move by the Bank of Canada to lower interest rates has to be ''awfully, awfully near,'' he added.
He is interested in metals companies, like Cominco Ltd. and Inco Ltd., and in forest product companies like the Canfor Corporation, Crestbrook Forest Industries and Malette Inc. But he warns that the uncertainty of pulp paper prices makes paper stocks somewhat risky.
He said the decline in the Canadian dollar will help increase exports by making them cheaper, benefitting companies like Cominco that report earnings in that currency.
Many analysts think the Bank of Canada could move to ease interest rates in the next several months, especially because preliminary figures show the gross domestic product declining in the first two months of the year. But the level of inflation and the mistake the central bank made in January could lead it to hold on longer.
So Mr. Hahn is more sure of the opportunities but less certain about when to take advantage of them. ''We're heading to something that could be pretty dramatic,'' he said. ''I'm just waiting for the last kick of the cat.''
