HEADLINE: FORUM;
A Soviet Appetite for U.S. Knowhow

BYLINE: By GEORGE CAPSIS; George Capsis, a business consultant, is president of International Market Development Inc.

 BODY:
I have been doing business in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe for more than 20 years. I know the Soviet Union quite well. Last October, when I was in Moscow trying to sell American computer technology to the Soviets, the director of one of the large departments of a ministry chastised me by saying: ''You Americans are late. Two Europeans have already submitted their bids.'' 
I had been brought to this office and to Moscow by a Soviet scientist, Stanislav I. Samolyenko, vice chairman of the Council of Cybernetics of the Soviet Academy of Science, who has been a friend for 20 years. Dr. Samolyenko is the creator of an elegantly simple algorithm that could become a world standard for computer network data entry. For two years, I had been helping him sell his ideas to companies in the United States - and we had had some measure of success. Now he wanted to go further and exchange Soviet theoretical science for American hardware and software.
As I searched for a reply to the director, I realized that - yes - we Americans have been late. We have been late to recognize the need the Soviet people have for practical, workable technology and to recognize that the much-vaunted Soviet science is real.
Americans have also been late to realize something I have come to believe quite strongly: The Soviet people want to live like Americans -not like Japanese or West Germans. They admire what we have created. In my experience, given a choice, Russians would rather do business with Americans than with anyone else.
Our needs and those of the Soviet people converge in a number of areas. For 70 years, the best minds in the Soviet Union have taken refuge from political danger and bureaucratic manipulation in the international fraternity of pure science. The Soviet Academy of Science, founded by Peter the Great in 1724, has 60,000 members, and their abilities when applied gave them a lead in space. One-third of all the world's scientists live in the Soviet Union.
But while they excel in theory, they need our expertise in application. One example among many: On the black market, American personal computers and software sell for 10 times what they do in the United States. Merging Soviet and American scientific and high-technology strengths would give us both enormous rewards.
American and Soviet business and government leaders must look beyond hard currency funding, floating the ruble and weapons reduction. They must focus on something much simpler: How can we fulfill each other's most pressing needs, without further delay?

HEADLINE: FORUM;
The Thin-Mint Theory of Forecasting

BYLINE: By ROBERT GOLDMAN; Robert Goldman is manager of creative services at Young & Rubicam Inc. in San Francisco.

 BODY:
The senior vice president rested a hand on my shoulder. ''You sure don't look like a Girl Scout,'' he said. ''We're changing with the times,'' I answered. ''Now, are you going to order or not?''
The senior vice president ordered: one box of Shortbreads, one box of Peanut Butter Patties and two boxes of Thin Mints. It was not my biggest order of the day, but I wasn't discouraged. Whether you are selling door-to-door in the suburbs, or office-suite-to-office-suite in a major, multinational corporation, every sale counts. 
Of course, I am not really a Girl Scout. But I am helping out my daughter - a Brownie - a member in good standing of Troop 668, Tiburon, Calif. I also know what makes the cookie - and the customer - crumble, as you might expect from a 20-year veteran of the marketing wars. As you might not expect, in the course of peddling my wares up and down Mahogany Row, I have discovered a new and powerful economic indicator. I call it ''The Thin Mint Factor.'' Now, I am aware that economic gurus like Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, must have their own indicators. Still, it does seem to me that if you want to know what is really happening in the economic world, you should ask a man who has put his Florsheim in the door of a steely-eyed chief financial officer and asked for the order. What better way to understand what is happening than to study how people spend their discretionary income? What better benchmark than the product trademarked with the words, ''a Great American Tradition.''
The domestic cookie business is in the economic spotlight. If you have ever wondered why Henry Kravis shelled out all those billions of somebody else's money to purchase RJR Nabisco (and these days, I suppose even Mr. Kravis must have his doubts), wrap your mind around the concept of being the first kid on your block to corner the market in Fig Newtons, Lorna Doones and Oreos. Compared to this economic coup, the Hunt brothers look like, well, Boy Scouts.
But enough speculation. You don't get an invitation to hold down a club chair on ''Wall Street Week'' without hard facts at your fingertips. After two days of selling, and 191 boxes sold, here's the economic picture, as I see it:
* Consumer demand is strong. Despite the recession predictions from certain Jonahs, I find that, given the right product, consumers are ready to reach for their wallets and spend, spend, spend. I don't want to point fingers here, but if General Motors could produce a car half as good as a Thin Mint, the Japanese wouldn't stand a chance.
* Consumers today are more conservative. Although this year's Girl Scout portfolio included two newcomers, Caramel deLites and Lemon Pastry Cremes, demand for these entries was weak. Despite the high degree of novelty we Americans supposedly expect in our cars, our blenders and our spouses, traditional Shortbreads and Thin Mints were the sellers. Although many customers expressed initial interest in the new offerings, even those on the leading edge of the adoption curve (measuring how products are accepted) expressed relief when offered the old reliables. ''Just put me down for two boxes of Thin Mints,'' they said. ''Better make that three.''
* Health trends are trending down. Last year saw the introduction of the ''cholesterol-free'' concept to the world of Girl Scout cookies in the form of the Golden Yangle. Despite the fact that Yangles are made with soybean oil, in 1990 they represent only 4 percent of my sales.
* Credit purchases represent an economic time bomb. Although orders from my well-heeled customers were hardly sluggish, the news that payment was not required until delivery invariably fanned the fires. Now that my orders are totaled, I see that the incendiary combination of junk food and easy credit has resulted in the addition of $477.50 to the national debt. When you consider all the dads and moms selling Girl Scout cookies in all the Fortune 500 companies across America, one can quickly see that the potential for triggering an economic crisis is very real indeed.
As for the more detailed economic forecasting, I must leave that to Mr. Greenspan. But Mr. Kravis, I am willing to help. After all, we cookie barons must stick together. I don't expect the fat consulting fees he pays to merger and acquisition mavens like Bruce Wasserstein (who, I am given to understand, never sold more than 50 boxes of Girl Scout cookies in his entire career). All I ask is that, when I knock on Henry's office door next year, he show some real appreciation for my contributions. I'm talking one box of Caramel deLites, one box of Peanut Butter Patties and, naturally, two boxes of Thin Mints.
No doubt there is more to be learned from this year's cookie sales, but order forms must be turned into scout headquarters tomorrow and I really have no time left for further analysis.

HEADLINE: All About/Shipbuilding;
After a Long Slump, World Shipping Is Embarking on a Modest Recovery

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
As owner of one of the world's largest fleets, P. N. Tsakos, the president of a Greek shipping line that bears his name, should be relishing his industry's recovery from a decade-long depression in shipping and shipbuilding. Instead, he frets about whether to place large new orders for ships. If he hesitates, prices may rise and shipyards may be booked for years, keeping him from expanding. But if he buys, he risks taking delivery in two or three years - perhaps just as the boom collapses.
Other shipowners, chastened by the long downturn, are being just as cautious. Now, a modest recovery is crowding the shipyards for the first time in years. Many shipowners are turning to the repair yards to renovatefleets. And even in the United States, where the civilian shipbuilding industry has all but evaporated, some builders hope for a revival. Gutsy investors have already made millions buying and reselling tankers.
 
Revived Demand
A cautious response from shipbuilders 
 As recently as three years ago, many of the world's shipyards stood nearly idle, devastated by a glut in ships and a long slump in demand. Some new ships were towed straight to the scrap yards. But after cutting their capacity by almost 60 percent, the world's shipbuilders are so cautious about expanding that many are likely to be working at their production limits for years to come.
The demand for ships is growing. Oil shipments from the Middle East have increased and in the last nine months, 50 large tankers have been ordered - enough to occupy the world's major yards, in Japan and Korea, for the next two to three years. Customers are paying more for long-term ship leases and buyers are finding it easier to get financing. Some banks that suffered huge losses on ship loans during the slump are again showing interest.
But capacity cannot keep up with the rebound in demand. With employment at the Japanese yards plunging to 34,000 in 1989 from 150,000 in 1975, many of the skilled workers went to other industries. Low wages and hard work make it difficult to attract replacements. The reluctance of many nations to continue subsidizing their shipyards also retards expansion. Despite labor cutbacks and higher ship prices, countries like Japan still must subsidize its yards to make up for losses.
Shipowners like Mr. Tsakos say that producers will take the risk of adding capacity once shippers can accept the risk of placing large new orders.
Eastern Europe, especially Poland, might benefit from renewed demand. But an effort by Barbara Piasecka Johnson, the heir to the Johnson & Johnson pharmaceutical fortune, to revive the Gdansk shipyard has stalled. In Korean shipyards recently, strikers and riot police have battled with each other.
Shipowners say they will not order ships unless shippers sign long-term contracts to lease them. ''We will not order ships on speculation,'' Mr. Tsakos said at a recent conference sponsored by Cypriot officials. Shipowners are also hesitating until they learn whether Congress will require new tankers to have double hulls to lessen the damage from oil spills.
Some shipowners and builders say their caution will bring the industry more stability. Others call these hopes naive. ''That's shipping. It's always been up and down,'' said Klaus E. Oldendorff, the chairman of a Cypriot shipping company. ''There are those who hope that it will be not as bad a yesterday. Of course it will be as bad as yesterday. The only thing I can hope for is that it will not be as bad again for such along time.''
 
Safety at Risk?
A surging trade in renovations
 As many ships near retirement, some doubt whether idle capacity can be revived fast enough to build replacements. The steep increase in prices of new ships - a large tanker that cost $35 million to $40 million a decade ago now costs close to $100 million - and the reluctance of shipowners to place large bets has led to a surge in overhauls.
Like shipbuilding, profitable renovation depends heavily on low wages. Singapore's inexpensive labor has helped make it the world's ship-repair center, attracting about a quarter of the world's overhauls. But even Singapore's shipyards are seeking to cut costs by moving production offshore. Two of Singapore's major yards, Keppel and Sembawang, are attempting to expand into lower-wage countries like the Philippines.
As more shipowners turn to renovation, some acknowlege that safety and environmental risks will increase. Most large tankers are built to last about 20 years, and bulk cargo ships usually last about 25. Some shipowners believe that with proper maintenance a ship will operate for 30 years. Eric Snow, the principal investigator of the Marine Division of the Candadian Transporation Accident Investigation Safety Board, says that older ships are not necessarily more vulnerable to accidents. ''You can have an 18-year-old ship, which has been well-maintained, in much better shape than a six-year-old ship that has been poorly maintained.''
 
Awash in Woes
No safe harbor for the U.S. industry
 It will take a high tide of shipbuilding to raise up the shipyards in the United States. They have been reduced to depending on the Navy for 85 percent of their building and repair work. But some hope to share in the civilian shipbuilding boom. Shipbuilders say they can convert from military to commercial work more easily than most defense contractors. John Stocker, president of the Shipbuilders Council of America, said the yards have improved their productivity building for the Navy. They will also have surplus capacity as military spending is cut back and capacity at foreign yards is strained.
Shipbuilders already blame the Federal Government for some of their woes. The industry withered after President Reagan eliminated shipbuilding subsidies in 1981. The industry now consists of 69 companies with 72,000 workers, down from some 110 companies employing 112,000 production workers 10 years ago. The number of shipyards has shrunk to 15 from 26.
Some in the industry believe the lack of subsidies has forced the yards to become more efficient. Since the Navy has more demanding standards for its ships than private companies do, Mr. Stocker said, the United States could use its experience to win contracts for ships that need more advanced construction, like passenger ships and specialized vessels for carrying products. Some yards, he said, have already attracted repair work from overseas.
Shipbuilding executives say that for the United States to compete, Japan must be induced to curb subsidies to its yards - as American trade negotiators have asked. But the Japan Maritime Research Institute recently issued a report saying that even if shipbuilding subsidies were ended everywhere, the American industry would not be competitive. The study said that American productivity lags far behind that of Far Eastern and European competitors.
 
 
 
A MAN OF THE WORLD
Klaus E. Oldendorff founded the shipping company that bears his name in West Germany. But it is now based in Cyprus, with ships registered there, in Singapore and in Turkey, with crews of Kiribati Islanders from the western Pacific. It is a odyssey that is becoming increasingly common among shipowners as they leave their native lands to search for cheap tax rates and labor.
At a recent shipping conference in New York, Cypriot officials relied on Mr. Oldendorff to persuade more owners to register ships there. ''I see myself as a Cypriot, not a German,'' he said. He has only two Germans on his staff; most staff members are Cypriot.
Mr. Oldendorff moved his company to Cyprus in 1987 to escape German trade, tonnage and income taxes. The only major tax he pays in Cyprus is on income, and that at a ceiling of just 4.25 percent.
The move ended a transition he began 20 years ago when he first registered some ships outside Germany. He needed to compete with Greeks who also had begun to register their fleets where taxes and other costs were low. He found that foreign crews, some from the Far East, accepted lower wages than German seamen.
He has since discovered an even cheaper source of labor. With eight other shipping companies, he set up a training school on one of the Gilbert Islands in the western Pacific, where the Kiribati have a reputation as good seamen. Communications advances have allowed him to recruit his staff and manage his fleet anywhere. As he said, ''It doesn't matter where you are.''

HEADLINE: A Medical Wonder That Isn't - Yet

BYLINE: By LEAH BETH WARD; Leah Beth Ward, a reporter for the Albuquerque (New Mexico) Journal in Santa Fe, has followed the health-care industry as a Wall Street journalist.

 BODY:
A few years back, investors were flocking to a new medical technology involving microscopic bubbles called liposomes. Composed of molecules of fatty acids, liposomes promised a way to administer drugs that ordinarily are too toxic to take in heavy doses.
Experiments showed that the tiny sac-like bubbles, when injected into the bloodstream, could carry powerful anticancer agents to a tumor, yet leave surrounding normal cells unharmed. Dozens of drugs that cause harrowing side effects when taken as a free substance gained new marketing potential. And liposome technology appeared to be on its way to the pharmaceutical big leagues with predictions of a $4 billion market by 1990.
But 1990 is here and, despite some progress toward commercialization, there is no liposomal drug on the market in the United States. Although some clinical trials are progressing for liposomal formulations of drugs to combat cancer and infections, others have been canceled. 
As a result, the patience of many investors has worn thin. The stocks of the three publicly traded companies developing liposomes in the United States - Liposome Technology Inc., of Menlo Park, Calif.; the Liposome Company, of Princeton, N.J., and Vestar Inc. of San Dimas, Calif. - have been trading lately from $1 to $3 a share, down from highs of $9 to $15 a share in 1987, when enthusiasm for the technology was peaking.
What's more, some major drug houses that swooped into position for the commercial payoff have since walked away from collaborative deals with the half-dozen or so companies, some of them private, which are developing the technology.
The Upjohn Company, for example, which had been working with Liposome Technology to develop liposomal formulations of minoxidil, the baldness drug, now ''has nothing going on in that area,'' a spokeswoman said.
''The technology has been a disappointment in terms of doing all the miraculous things it was supposed to do eight or nine years ago,'' conceded Nicolaos Arvanitidis, chairman of Liposome Technology.
What happened in the budding liposome industry is a classic story of the risks that can plague any attempt to develop an untried technology, a particularly dicey endeavor when it comes to the medical field. In the case of liposomes, the promise of the early years has turned into a combination of research delays, manufacturing glitches, financing difficulties and regulatory restrictions.
But despite all the hitches, not everyone is concluding that the liposome bubble has burst.
Though hardly flush with cash, all three publicly traded liposome companies claim promising early results for a few formulations, said Don Barbeau, president of the Biomega Corporation, a consulting firm in Skokie, Ill., that follows the technology. ''These companies are persistent and they've got good science,'' Mr. Barbeau said.
Indeed, the technology is at a make-or-break point as clinical trials advance, according to David Webber, an analyst with Alex. Brown & Sons, which serves as the investment banker for Vestar. ''We are at a transition point where we're starting to see some evidence of a product,'' Mr. Webber said.
Some industry executives are contending that the big drug companies that abandoned the technology will soon be sorry. ''Some of the big companies are beginning to realize they were wrong,'' said Dr. Marc Ostro, chief science officer at the Liposome Company, which is working with one pharmaceutical giant, the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company, to develop a liposome application for an antifungal drug.
Liposomes themselves are hardly new. Fatty globules found inside living cells, they were discovered when powerful microscopes were developed in the 19th century. The membranes enclosing these tiny droplets are made of molecules called phospholipids, which resemble soap molecules in an important way - one end is attracted to water while the other end is repelled by water.
When dispersed in water, pairs of phospholipid molecules spontaneously organize themselves end to end, and then the pairs arrange themselves side by side to form a continuous spherical film. Such hollow spheres can hold small amounts of liquid, which are released when the membrane of the liposome is broken down by various natural chemicals in living organisms.
In recent years, experiments revealed that liposomes could be produced in the laboratory to carry powerful therapeutic cargo to specific parts of the body. Liposomes are transported by the blood until they are grabbed by certain organs - including the liver, spleen, lungs, bone marrow and lymph nodes - that filter out or metabolize this type of body. Upon arrival, they ''unload'' their shipment at an infection site or on a tumor. Because liposomes do not accumulate in the skin and gastrointestinal tract, they show promise in preventing the drugs they carry from causing hair loss, nausea and other side effects.
In many cases, American researchers were so enamored of the liposome's natural targeting capacity that they thought it would be a short hop from laboratory production to commercial-scale manufacturing, said Joseph Jacob, chairman and chief executive of Technology Unlimited in Wooster, Ohio, a privately held company working on liposomes.
Some American companies jumped the gun by developing a manufacturing technology to process large batches of liposomes before perfecting the raw material from which the liposomes would be made, said Biomega's Mr. Barbeau.
These companies soon found that one formulation of a liposomal product did not work with all drugs and that the impact liposomes have in the body depends on both their size and the components of the outer layer of their membranes.
Commercially produced liposomes would also have to be stable and not degrade as they sat on the shelf awaiting use. It turned out, however, that they were unstable.
European and Japanese companies have gone about the problem correctly, said Mr. Barbeau, by first attacking the development of the raw materials. Through a joint venture, for example, one Japanese concern, the Nippon Oil and Fats Company, now supplies the Liposome Company with high-purity lipids, or fatty acids, that make up the cell membranes of the liposomes.
Not only was there no universal formulation for liposomes, but directing the path of the laboratory-produced bubbles once they were inside the body turned out to be trickier than anticipated, said Mr. Jacob of Technology Unlimited.
Regulatory obstacles were also underestimated. Enclosing a drug in a liposome affects its behavior, so much so that the Government views the process as yielding essentially a new product requiring extensive scrutiny.
''It appears to be a relatively full-gauge approval process at the Food and Drug Administration,'' said Anthony Evnin, general partner in Venrock Associates, the venture capital arm of the Rockefeller family, which invested in the Liposome Company in the mid 1980's.
By now, all three publicly held liposome companies - and some of the privately owned ones, as well - claim to have solved many of the problems associated with stability and production. Liposome Technology, for example, has a freeze-dried version of a liposomal antibiotic that it says can be stored at room temperature for two to three years.
But full-scale production capability still eludes some companies, analysts say, at least as much from a dearth of financing as from technological problems that might remain.
What progress these companies have made in commercializing liposomes has come by scaling down their own early hopes for widespread applicability. (See box.) Whether liposome technology will ever develop to the point that these companies can become fully integrated and profitable pharmaceutical concerns is still unclear. They may end up as university-based research houses, some experts say, if they can't raise additional capital or sign new lucrative collaborative agreements with major drug companies.
''I'm positive on the technology, but there's a question about whether the payback will be enough to compensate these companies for their time and effort,'' Mr. Barbeau said.
For their part, liposome executives are weary after nearly a decade in the laboratory. But they are still hopeful.
''I would prefer to be a much richer man after nine years of this,'' said Liposome Technology's Mr. Arvanitidis. ''But I think things are finally going our way.''
 
STILL, THEY FIGHT ON
Buffetted by technical, financial and regulatory problems, liposome companies have dropped or suspended research in a number of areas, ranging from inhalation and ophthalmic products to cardiovascular and anti-asthmatic applications.
But despite lower expectations, including sharply reduced sales estimates of $500 million to $1 billion by 1994 or 1995, the competition to reach the marketplace first is still intense.
All three publicly held liposome companies, for example, are racing to produce a delivery system for amphotericin B, a highly toxic antibiotic developed and marketed by Squibb Inc., now part of the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company. The drug, which is no longer protected by patent, is used to treat infections in patients with compromised immune systems, including people with AIDS and those undergoing cancer chemotherapy or organ transplants.
Because it has a research and development deal with Squibb, the Liposome Company is thought by some analysts to be the front-runner in the amphotericin derby. What's more, Squibb has built manufacturing capacity for commercial production of the liposomal complex. So far, the Liposome Company's version of the drug is showing encouraging results from clinical trials, said Dr. Marc Ostro, the company's chief science officer.
But competitor Vestar Inc. has already filed for approval in Europe of its own formulation of amphotericin. Its product, called Ambisome, was developed under a joint venture with Lyphomed Inc., a pharmaceutical company based in Rosemont, Ill. Shipments to four European countries started last year under a special license that allows Ambisome to be used in potentially fatal cases.
For its part, Liposome Technology Inc. is set to start a second round of testing this summer for still another formulation of amphotericin B. All three companies are also scrambling to produce liposomal forms of various anticancer drugs. The Liposome Company is enjoying something of an edge in this area as well. That is because both Vestar and Liposome Technology recently announced the cancellation of agreements with large pharmaceutical sponsors for the development of one anticancer agent, doxorubicin.
Meanwhile, Technology Unlimited, one of the privately owned companies working on liposomes, claims ''considerable success'' in developing a liposome that looks like a red blood cell and can therefore bypass the body's immune system, where liposomes naturally congregate. If so, this type of formulation would be effective in treating diseases outside the immune system.

HEADLINE: Currency;
Surprise Figures Shake the Dollar

 BODY:
THE employment numbers for April took the market by surprise on Friday and knocked the dollar lower. The surprise was that the report showed a weaker economy than expected. Rather than declining, the unemployment rate rose two-tenths of a percentage point, to 5.4 percent. After adjusting for an influx of census workers, non-farm payroll jobs declined. Because the employment figures run counter to other recent data showing the economy to be relatively strong, the betting is now likely to change on the Federal Reserve's next move on interest rates. In recent weeks, as economic reports indicated that inflation was resisting pressure to decline, many analysts had decided that the Fed was on the verge of pushing rates slightly higher.

LENGTH: 2614 words

HEADLINE: Craig McCaw's High-Risk Phone Bet

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT

DATELINE: KIRKLAND, Wash.

 BODY:
When Craig McCaw's father died in 1969, the McCaw children and their mother discovered that the elder McCaw had so buried his media business in debt that only a single cable-television system remained when all the creditors had been paid off. John Elroy McCaw had had big dreams about building a media empire and he had taken big risks. In the end, the risks were too great and his family was left to pick up the pieces.
Now, a generation later, Craig McCaw has clearly inherited his father's vision, but also his penchant for debt and risk. From that single surviving cable system in Centralia, Wash., which he took over in 1973 when he was 24 years old, Mr. McCaw has already built McCaw Cellular Communications into the nation's largest cellular telephone company. Intent on realizing his grand vision for a cellular telephone kingdom, the softspoken executive has just taken the biggest gamble of his career: the $3.4 billion purchase of control of Lin Broadcasting, a move that will allow him to enter the lucrative and strategically important urban markets.
Essentially, Craig McCaw is betting that the public will want cellular phones. Today about 1.5 percent of the population uses car phones or portable phones. The hope is that the figure will rise to 14 percent in just a decade. 
In agreeing to buy Lin Broadcasting at a time when his own company is already loaded with debt and has never had positive earnings, Mr. McCaw has submerged his business in a sea of red ink so deep that interest payments will devour all its cash flow for at least the next several years.
More and more, Mr. McCaw's resemblance to his father is startling. The challenge is that Craig McCaw signed a quintessential 1980's deal but must see it through in the tougher environment of the 90's. Mr. McCaw acknowledges that as a result of the merger annual losses could exceed $1 billion in some of the next few years. As bankers jittery about the collapse of the ''junk bond'' market shun highly leveraged deals, the flexibility Mr. McCaw once had to sell assets to raise cash may have diminished. And Wall Street is casting a cold eye on companies - like McCaw - valued on assets rather than earning. The company's stock price has been sinking since the deal was proposed.
''He is dependent on so many 'if's' going right,'' said Martin Hyman, a consultant at Booz Allen & Hamilton who follows the cellular industry. Subscriber growth, competition, regulation and the sale of assets are among the unknowns. ''If he has to sell assets, that can weaken the national business he is trying to build,'' Mr. Hyman said. Mr. McCaw is well aware of the risks. ''The key to having dreams is to make sure they come true. Waking up in a cold sweat is not what you want,'' Mr. McCaw, said during an interview at his lakeside headquarters outside Seattle. ''Debt is clearly not a challenge we want today,'' he added, speaking in tones as earnest as any Boy Scout's.
In the meantime, however, the debt load - about 20 percent is at floating rates - is casting a long shadow over McCaw, which has nearly $800 million in revenues and holdings across the country. With 51 percent ownership of Lin, McCaw now controls 72 million ''pops'' - the number of potential customers in a cellular telephone franchise area. And although McCaw had the most pops in the industry before it bought Lin, that deal cemented its lead, giving it more than twice as many as its nearest rival, Pacific Telesis Group.
 
Taking the Lead
To get that lead, Craig McCaw paid dearly. Had McCaw and Lin been combined last year for example, their combined revenues would have been $730 million. But interest payments alone would have been $695 million. And all the cash generated by the company to pay off that interest expense would have been just $227 million. Even if cash flow soars, Mr. McCaw acknowledges it would still not cover interest payments for the next several years, which may force the company to dip further into its $3 billion credit line.
But the idea of creating a nationwide cellular telephone system run by independent companies was a more powerful image for him than a mountain of debt. And Lin was the missing piece he needed, his ''only chance,'' he said, to buy into a company with extensive urban franchises.
With franchises in many suburban areas and middle-sized cities, Mr. McCaw wanted Lin's impressive urban holdings - franchises in seven major cities, including New York, Los Angeles and Dallas. His envisions a jigsaw-puzzle-like network around the country that will enable customers to call each other without the disconnects, delays and aggravation now so common in the industry.
Equally important to him, the deal kept Lin out of the hands of Bell South, one of the telephone companies Mr. McCaw considers a key rival.
If Craig McCaw is a visionary, his vision is not always easy to understand. He has a penchant for talking in convoluted and often obscure terms and is prone to such statements as: ''Electronic highways are much more efficient than concrete highways and flyways.'' Asked why he bought Lin, he once said: ''The network is smarter than the phone and the intelligent network helps support the individual.''
But for all his arcane theorizing, several industry analysts believe Craig McCaw has a realistic chance of realizing his dream. This is, after all, the man who landed on the cover of Business Week last week as the highest paid chief executive in the country. Exercising McCaw stock options he has owned for some years, he came out with stock and salary worth $53 million last year, Over the long term, Mr. McCaw is betting that his company's cash flow can grow because of the nature of the cellular business. The most powerful potential of the industry is that as franchises mature over a five-year period, pre-tax profit margins can swing quickly from losses to highly profitable businesses. ''The operating costs rise so much more slowly than subscriber growth that when the business finally turns, it turns very fast,'' said Mr. Leibowitz.
 
Rising Revenues
 Lin's cellular operations already have profit margins of 50 percent. Lin's cellular division, for example, had 1986 revenues of $41 million and cash flow before depreciation of $2 million. By 1989, revenues had risen to $180 million and cash flow was $96 million.
Industry executives believe that cellular telephones will become as much a part of the American landscape as computers, cable television and fax machines. Cellular appears to be growing faster than fax machines did in their first five years. Paul Kagan & Associates, a media research firm based in Carmel, Calif., said it took six years for fax machines to reach an analogous position.
Not only have the number of cellular subscribers increased, but the rate at which new subscribers are signing up has accelerated. For example, at McCaw subscribers increased 68 percent from the fourth quarter of 1988 to the fourth quarter of 1989. From the the first quarter of 1988 through the comparable period in 1989, the increase was 62 percent.
 
A Speculative Business
 Barry Kaplan, who follows the cellular telephone industry for Goldman Sachs & Company, said cash flow from a combined McCaw-Lin could potentially cover interest expense by 1993. He expects Lin to be generating a positive cash flow after debt service by then. And though cellular telephone users today represent just about 1.5 percent of the population, Mr. Kaplan says that figure could rise to 8.6 percent by 1995. If so, those figures would generate a cash flow of $1.7 billion for McCaw.
But the cellular business is so new that all projections are highly speculative and serious questions remain about McCaw's debt load .
The rising interest rates expected by some economists could put a tremendous strain on cash flow. ''We don't like that, but hopefully, we have thought things through,'' Mr. McCaw said. ''We were certainly aware of the changing times. You make decisions on long-term planning, not on short-term changes in the environment.''
Analysts point out Mr. McCaw could always sell pops. Indeed, to strengthen his balance sheet before buying Lin, Craig McCaw raised $1.2 billion last February by selling some franchises to Contel, an independent telephone company. He also sold a 20 percent stake in his own company to British Telecommunications P.L.C. last year for $1.5 billion.
 
Cellular Assets
 But how much could he get for his pops? Some analysts argue that the prices of cellular properties are now at their peak, having risen dramatically in the last five years. McCaw, for example, paid a record $350 per pop for Lin. But last week, GTE Corporation agreed to pay about $200 per pop for The Providence Journal's cellular franchises.
To be sure, Steven Rattner, an investment banker at Lazard Freres & Company who represented McCaw in the McCaw-Lin transaction, and others argue that the price discrepancy is not as sharp as it seems; the Journal's franchises were not major urban franchises like Lin's. In a more competitive market, GTE might have been forced to pay more - and the general perception of cellular asset values would have been stronger.
That does not seem to have reassured Wall Street, where concern about selling assets, at any price, is worryng investors, pushing the price of cellular stocks down. McCaw is now trading at about 25, down from its 52-week high of 47 1/4, reached last June. One analyst, who asked not to be named said: ''Leveraged asset value plays are out as a concept. The question really is how much liquidity there will be in the future.''
Emanuel Gerard, a partner at Gerard, Klauer Mattison & Company, an investment firm, said that cellular stocks are down now because there are no earnings and no deals to validate the worth of the assets. As to the next five years, will they pay off? ''Cellular has the promise, and if it turns out to have high rates of penetration, the stocks could be fabulous,'' he said. ''If rates are disappointing, the stocks could be disastrous.''
If the economy soured, would customers treat portable phones as a necessary expense or a disposable indulgence? ''How the business will do in a recession is really the major uncertainty,'' Mr. Rattner said.
 
The Drag of Debt
 Will its debt load jeopardize the company's ability to invest in the future? McCaw does have a $3 billion credit line that could be applied to capital investments. Mr. McCaw maintains that a long-term commitment to the industry requires investment and the company plans to improve the New York business, which it won in the Lin deal.
Down the road, McCaw has other opportunities for growth, which it may or may not be able to afford. The company is committed to buying out the remaining Lin shareholders or seeing that the balance of the company is sold to another buyer. It also has a buy-sell agreement with Pacific Telesis for pops in the San Francisco franchise. And if Mr. McCaw is to realize his dream of a national phone service, it will require a big marketing effort. Unlike cable, which has virtually no competition, the Federal Communicatons Commission granted two licenses in each market: one to a telephone company and one a nontelephone company.
 
A National Network?
 Mr. McCaw's goal is for all the independent companies to promote ''Cellular One'' - the brand name used by many nonwire-line cellular companies - service which promotes the image of a single national celluar service. Such a marketing campaign is particularly aimed at corporate clients with nationwide offices. One advantage of Mr. McCaw's city franchises is that he now controls the markets where corporations are headquartered.
It is clear that it will take years for Craig McCaw to turn many of his dreams into reality. But, like his father, Craig McCaw has long been a dreamer. Mr. McCaw's father seems to have given his son enormous self-confidence for the task at hand. ''He trusted us and he was optimistic,'' Craig McCaw recalled. ''He would give us the keys to the car and tell us to drive it around, but not to wreck it. You come up with an optimism from that. If you challenge people and they are accountable, then they are extraordinary.''
But the son is acutely aware of the father's flaws. After the elder Mr. McCaw's death, Craig McCaw's mother spent eight years paying off debts. ''My father was a visionary who did not hire great people,'' Mr. McCaw recalled. ''The company was too dependent on one person.'' So he has hired strong executives and learned to delegate some of the heavy financial dealings. His managers, he said, keep him grounded in reality. ''If you are going to set out on a voyage, remember the Titanic,'' he said. ''The captain took risks he did not have to take, for ego.''
In the next year, the first indications of how sound his decisions were how great the risk will begin to become apparent.
 
A DEAL IN LIMBO
On Wall Street these days, no news is bad news. That explains in part why McCaw's stock has been so depressed.
McCaw may have completed the deal for Lin Broadcasting, but it has not yet announced financing of its $1.9 billion acquisition of Metromedia's stake in the New York cellular franchise.
Lin and Metromedia have jointly owned the franchise for several years. Last October, Lin agreed to buy Metromedia's stake. Now that McCaw owns Lin, it must negotiate that purchase. The initial deal called for an all-cash buyout.
Several weeks ago, without explanation, McCaw announced it was restructuring the deal. The plan was for Metromedia, the company controlled by the billionaire John Kluge, to take equity worth about $850 million in Lin. The banks would put up the balance, thus reducing McCaw's interest burden.
By choosing to sell equity and reducing his interest expenses, Mr. McCaw is seeking to give himself more flexibility if he should need additional financing. McCaw and Metromedia executives have been huddled in negotiations in Manhattan for several weeks.
It's not a done deal, however, and as the weeks drag on, rumors circulate on Wall Street about how the delay in reaching an agreement might affect the economics of the larger McCaw-Lin deal.
 
 
 
REMEDIES FOR TROUBLE IN THE CELL
Though cellular technology has liberated users from the bonds of the phone cord, the quality of service isn't always ideal.
Cellular telephone calls are transmitted from one telephone to another by radio antennas in each local area, or ''cell.'' The greatest problem for users is simply that sometimes it is difficult to get a line. Problems also arise when a cellular phone owner is trying to receive a call while traveling. The caller must know how to find the traveler via telephone, a process that can involve many different numbers unless the cellular companies involved are linked together.
One simple way to improve service and transmission quality is to invest in more cell sites. Craig McCaw's goal is a ''seamless'' telephone network with individual and corporate clients who can call each other, simply by dialing a single number. His plan includes a move into cities: he will add more cell sites in New York, where they are badly needed. The more franchises McCaw owns, the easier it is to offer smooth service. The greatest advantages come from having franchises that are contiguous. That allows the operator to move the call from cell to cell, through various cities. ''For all of the companies, the goal is to make the cellular telephone as invisible to business practices as land lines are,'' said George Blumenthal, chairman of Cellular Communications Inc., an independent cellular company.

HEADLINE: A Case for Selling N.Y.C.'s Airports

BYLINE: By Ronald S. Lauder; Ronald S. Lauder, former Ambassador to Austria, was a New York City mayoral candidate in 1989.

 BODY:
In its current economic mess, New York City can learn a lesson from the corner bodega owner. He will tell you: ''You need cash? The worst thing to do is raise prices and cut services. The best thing to do is trim inventory.'' The city should heed that advice and sell two major city-owned assets: John F. Kennedy and La Guardia airports.
A tax increase is the last thing New York City needs. The already staggering tax burden has driven out hundreds of businesses and thousands of citizens. It would be comparably self-defeating to cut back on services like police and street repairs. 
Both airports are operated by the Port Authority, which leases the land from the city. The Port Authority built and maintains the terminals, employs the staff and makes all the operating decisions, including those about the prices charged to airlines and concessionaires.
A big-city airport is what business people call a cash cow - at least it could be. In arrivals and departures, Kennedy is one of the nation's leading international airports. La Guardia, which is closer to Manhattan, specializes in short-to-medium-haul service, especially to business travelers. Neither airport generates its true potential revenue - which both could if they were operated as businesses.
How can New York City unlock the airports' full potential? Some might suggest that the city cancel its leases, take the airports back from the Port Authority and operate them itself. This approach would have two big drawbacks. City governments are notoriously poor at running businesses. And under Federal grant regulations, cities cannot take any net revenue from their airports.
But suppose, instead, that New York City were to work out a deal with the Port Authority to sell Kennedy and La Guardia to private enterprise, to be operated as profit-making businesses? Such a deal would directly benefit the city coffers in sev-eral ways.
First, there would be the one-time windfall from the sale of the airports; this profit would have to be split with the Port Authority to compensate for its investments over the years.
One recent estimate, by the Reason Foundation, puts the airports' value at $2.2 billion. The true market value may be a lot more than that. Such a windfall would make a large dent in the city's fiscal problems.
As private enterprises, the airport properties would return to the city's property tax rolls and generate $212 million a year in general fund revenue. Under profit-oriented management, it is likely that the airports' value would grow faster than under Port Authority management -meaning that property tax revenues would also keep growing. The privatization of both airports would benefit New York State. If they continued to generate the level of revenue they have in recent years, the state would receive corporate income tax revenues of $4.4 million per year. (The Federal Government would get $11.4 million per year in new corporate income tax revenues.) Besides fiscal benefits, privatizing the airports would offer improved safety and service to New York air travelers.
Because the Federal Aviation Administration owns and operates the control towers and electronic landing aids, the airports' management cannot make needed improvements.
Under privatization, if the F.A.A. yielded ownership of the control tower, La Guardia could install equipment giving it increased bad-weather landing capability. (Building a new tower at La Guardia is not an F.A.A. priority.) The airport is also short of controllers because the F.A.A. cannot pay enough to attract and keep them in this high-cost part of the U.S.
In England and Scotland, where the major airports were privatized three years ago, the airports own the control towers and invest in the equipment. The same could be true in New York if the airports were turned into investor-owned businesses.
The Port Authority's $3.2 billion modernization of Kennedy is being scaled back by as much as $1 billion, and Kennedy's proposed people-mover system may be eliminated. The result surely will be continued ground congestion and chaos.
By contrast, Heathrow Airport in London, newly privately owned, is building a high-speed rail line, to be operated by the airport company, that will whiz passengers from Heathrow to central London in just 16 minutes. This is the kind of user-friendly investment we should expect from an airport operated as a business.
The British were the first to sell their airports (for $2.5 billion in July 1987). But they aren't the only ones. Denmark has announced that the Copenhagen airport is to be privatized, with the first 25 percent of the shares to be sold this year. New Zealand plans to sell its three international airports, at Auckland, Christchurch and Wellington. And in the U.S., mu- nicipalities from Albany to Peoria to Los Angeles are considering doing likewise.
The F.A.A. and the Department of Transportation are reviewing the issue, and a policy statement is expected this spring.
Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner's emerging national policy seemed to endorse airport privatization in principle when it declared that the Government would remove barriers to the private ownership and operation of transportation facilities.
Selling both airports offers New York City a way to recover its capital and use it in other, more urgent investments. The city has been undervaluing assets far too long. It's time we started getting full value from them.

HEADLINE: 'Summit' on Balderdash Mountain

BYLINE: By Ernest F. Hollings; Ernest F. Hollings, Democrat of South Carolina, is a member of the Senate Budget Committee.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Today is shaping up to be a witches' sabbath here. The top Congressional leaders will huddle with President Bush and numbers wizard Richard Darman to attempt to spike the budget brew. If past experience is any guide, the objective of this non-summit ''summit'' conference will be to concoct the right mix of lizard's tail and newt's eye to put the American people to sleep until after the election. We must not allow that to happen.
For starters, let's be clear that these bipartisan meetings are not the cure, they're the cancer. 
Republicans and Democrats share an election-year interest in producing a slide-by budget with no new taxes and no painful spending cuts. We have had these bipartisan budget love-ins for three years running now, and each year we end up further from the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings deficit-reduction targets.
Last November, an 11th-hour ''summit'' meeting produced a budget that claimed to meet the 1990 deficit target of $100 billion. We gave ourselves the good-government award and went home. But by March, the 1990 deficit was projected at $160 billion. Now, in May, it is running at a $170 billion pace.
The deficit for 1991 is projected at $160 billion. So to reach the 1991 Gramm-Rudman-Hollings deficit target of $64 billion, we are supposed to come up with a deficit-reduction package of $96 billion - all without new taxes. Not even Mr. Darman, Director of the Office of Management and Budget, has enough fairy dust to finesse this $96 billion shortfall, and he's smart enough not to try.
My advice is: Let's keep our eye on the doughnut, not the hole. The ''hole'' - the distraction - is all the Washington chatter about peace dividends, capital gains tax cuts, etc. In the context of a $1.2 trillion budget, these things are airy nothings. The ''doughnut'' - what really matters - is the size of the undisguised budget deficit.
The true deficit for 1990 will be close to $300 billion. This figure is the sum of three components: the $158 billion deficit that the media write and talk about; the $122 billion we are ''borrowing'' (Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan aptly calls it ''thievery'') from the Social Security Trust Fund and other trust funds, plus the $20 billion-plus being spent ''off-budget'' on the savings-and-loan bailout.
This real deficit of $300 billion matters because it is driving up interest rates, paralyzing government and running up the national debt to the point where we now pay $260 billion in interest annually.
Here's a tip for judging today's meeting. You can tell if these fellows are serious if they frankly and honestly acknowledge, first, the true size of the deficit and, second, that the 1991 deficit target of $64 billion cannot realistically be met.
Grown-ups shouldn't tell lies. If we can finally 'fess up to the true size of the deficit, then we can also 'fess up to another dirty little secret: that we are already levying new taxes galore in order to bring down the deficit and that we need to raise taxes even more to finish the job.
President Bush ignored his own lips long enough to propose new revenues totaling $13.9 billion in his projected 1991 budget. They include telephone excise taxes, airline-ticket taxes and increases in stock-transaction taxes.
He ignored his own lips when he let a whopping increase in Social Security payroll taxes take effect Jan. 1. Meanwhile, he has presided over a 1 percent increase in interest rates so far this year - the price exacted by the marketplace for Washington's failure to deal honestly with the deficits and the savings-and-loan bailout.
Can you imagine a more indiscriminate, irresponsible, regressive tax than these rising interest rates? ''Read my lips,'' indeed. Here is one budget sherpa's advice to the ''summiteers'': Admit the true size of the deficit mountain - $300 billion in 1991 - and acknowledge that we can't cut enough in one year to reach the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings target. Next, embrace the Senate Budget Committee's goal of reducing the deficit by $43 billion in 1991. Finally, come up with a realistic schedule of honest tax increases and honest budget cuts to liquidate the deficits by 1994. Let's start earning those good-government awards we keep giving ourselves.

HEADLINE: ON MY MIND;
The Pleasures of Poland

BYLINE: By A. M. Rosenthal

DATELINE: WARSAW

 BODY:
Later on we'll get to the problems of Poland but for at least a few paragraphs, let's just talk about the pleasures of Poland.
Right off, the first time we set eyes on each other after six years, an old Polish friend announced the great news.
''We are a free country now!'' he exclaimed in the hotel lobby, as if he were the first to carry the word.
He knew that nobody who had lived in captive Poland in the hard, mean years of Soviet-imposed Communism, as I had, could grasp fully the joy of the news until he came to see and taste it. 
Now Poles can write, talk, print, vote, travel, invest, complain, my good friend said. He laughed at the happy shake of my head that this was happening in Poland. ''Anything!''
So, finally, this is the first real Polish springtime. Springtime, after German devastation and decades of struggle against Soviet colonialism, gray decades of uprising and defeat, hope and failure, again and again.
In this country it was not the collapse of Soviet Communism that brought freedom. It was the unrelenting Polish struggle that helped drain the ability of the Communists to rule, here, in Moscow or anywhere. Freedom was not given to the Poles; they took it. In so doing they helped all Communist-ruled nations, including the Soviet Union.
Warsaw will probably never be beautiful again. German troops went from block to block, blowing them up house by house.
But Warsaw looks just wonderful these days - trees in full leaf, students and painters taking over the squares and alleys of the lovingly rebuilt Old City. It is alive with what the Communists hated so much - the bustle and bounce of business and art.
I asked Adam Michnik, editor of Solidarity's daily newspaper and one of those chewy political intellectuals who always have been a particular Polish treasure, whether it was overly romantic to be so hopeful about Poland now.
No, not overly romantic, he said, as long as Poles understood they now had nobody to blame but themselves for any mess they make. So, on to problems. The first was created by courage.
The Government of Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki acted swiftly and bravely to pull Poland from the economic morass of Communism. That meant slashing many subsidies, letting prices rise while keeping wages down for the time being, creating unemployment by writing off some failing Government enterprises.
So far the Polish people have taken the bitter medicine to cure the economic diseases left by Communism.
But if Poles do not get some economic rewards along with freedom, there could be a second problem - a split between the Solidarity intellectuals now in office and Lech Walesa. He is in a grumpy mood, which he intends to cure by becoming President of Poland.
The unanswered question is whether he will go for the official leadership, which he merits, in alliance with the intellectuals or continue to take cracks at them about the economic situation.
Solidarity supporters in the Government are worried about the possibility that the Walesa inner circle of politicians, union officials and clerics might move him toward the unpleasant Polish right. They think that could lead to a Polish Peronist populism.
But they still count on Mr. Walesa to remember that the partnership between workers and intellectuals created the Solidarity victory and keeps the alliance strong.
Poland is in its own hands now, at last. But the U.S. can do a lot to help the country; help will be welcomed.
Much can be done - more insured investments by American business, forgiveness of crippling loans made to the Communists, moving the creaky communications system into the modern business world, bringing young Poles to the U.S. for training.
The United States can push its European allies to give Poland association with the European Community. This is important to Poland economically and politically. East Germans will get it automatically with German unification, but Poland has been denied.
Bronislaw Geremek, the Solidarity leader in Parliament, said that what Poland needed most from the U.S. was to stay involved with this country, not forgetting.
Poland has suffered as no other nation from the Germans and the Soviet Union. Therefore it would honor the United States to treat it with special attention and care.
Perhaps this time the United States will not walk away from a friend. That is the one thing about their future Poles cannot decide for themselves.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: The Stark Reality That Racial Theorists Miss

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I was saddened by your April 20 report on the ill-considered and racist remarks by Michael Levin and Leonard Jeffries Jr., tenured professors at New York City's highly respected City College.
Professor Levin makes the indefensible case that blacks are underrepresented in professional positions in society, not because of society's ''discrimination'' but because of inherent mental inferiority. Professor Jeffries makes the equally indefensible accusation that society has intentionally miseducated blacks to deprive them of any hope of success. 
They both missed the one stark reality that stands out beyond the welter of repugnant claims and charges: we are systematically undereducating blacks and crippling their chances for success in school, at work, as parents and as citizens. Despite the 25-year success of the Head Start enriched preschool program, our society pays for such an indispensable aid to learning for only one out of six impoverished American kids at severe educational risk.
This means that our society denies 84 percent of kids 3, 4 and 5 years old from educationally deprived homes of the basic education skills, nurturing, nutrition and health care that are almost certainly indispensable preconditions to educational success in their elementary and secondary schools, without which these kids are almost doomed to educational failure.
In the face of such systematic un-dereducation of low-income kids, a disproportionately high share of whom are black and Hispanic, how can Professor Levin or anyone else say these kids don't suffer discrimination, prejudice and structured disadvantage at the hands of an insensitive society?
It is a disgrace that the middle-class kids who have least needed the enriched preschool experience have benefited from it the most, while the kids from low-income, educationally and culturally deprived families who have needed it most have benefited from it least, at untold cost to the health, vitality and competitiveness of our society.
Blacks have not been deliberately ''miseducated'' as Professor Jeffries charges, but systematically undereducated. Head Start is only one example. The Reagan Administration decision to replace college minority scholarships and grants with loans is another action that has demonstrably hindered the efforts of the black community to break out of the cycle of poverty and undereducation into educational success and achievement on the job at home, and in the community.
As chairman of the Education and Health Subcommittee of the House Joint Economic Committee, I recently chaired nine days of hearings on how our society can achieve a competitive and competent work force. An impressive series of corporate chief executive officers from the Fortune 500 group testified passionately about the consensus of business leadership in our country that improving the quality of education for all young people and especially provision of a Head Start experience for deprived minority youth is imperative for our society - a moral challenge to our commitment to education equality and a productive, healthy society.
This year, I, Representative Dale Kildee and several colleagues are attempting to break this vicious cycle by sponsoring a bill to provide a Head Start experience to every American child at risk of education failure. This full-funding bill, passed in committee and now part of H.R. 4151, is our best hope to avoid perpetuating our two-tier education and class system, which provides fertile ground for the racist ideas planted by Professors Levin and Jeffries.
 
JAMES H. SCHEUER
Member of Congress, 8th Dist., N.Y.
 
Washington, May 1, 1990

LENGTH: 463 words

HEADLINE: The Maggots in Communism's Decay

 BODY:
A specter of unbridled bigotry haunts the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. Ethnic Turks face persecution in Bulgaria. So do gypsies in Hungary; so does Transylvania's Hungarian community in Romania.
Meanwhile, ancient anti-Semitic hatreds flare anew. In January, goons calling themselves Russian nationalists burst into Moscow's Central House of Writers, shouting ''Kill the Yids!'' In Poland, whose prewar Jewish population of 3.3 million has dwindled to 4,400, walls have been defaced with vile graffiti: ''Jews to the ovens, Jews for soap.'' In Budapest, some politicians speak menacingly of ''cosmopolitans,'' meaning Jews. 
A society's moral worth is rightly gauged by how it treats its most defenseless citizens. The fundamental integrity of a democracy depends on its willingness to safeguard the rights of its minorities. Thus, even as the United States applauds the rise of more open systems in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, there is reason to worry about their leaders' tepid response to a malignant legacy.
The maggots of hate cannot be eliminated by simple prohibition. Sunlight is a better weapon than suppression. Those who have pleaded for pluralism in the East cannot easily argue for abridgment of hateful speech. But what leaders say and do matters enormously; bigotry is tacitly legitimized by silence or hints of complicity. Under orthodox Communist rule, bigotry was officially condemned but unofficially tolerated - and sometimes shamelessly encouraged when useful.
It was something of a moral revolution when East Germany's newly elected Government accepted responsibility for Hitler's crimes against the Jews. Having taken the imperative first step, East Germans need now to re-examine schoolbooks and the way the past is depicted in their media. Such sunlight has worked well in West Germany and provides a beacon in other transforming societies, notably the Soviet Union.
Mikhail Gorbachev has condemned ''the spread of anti-Semitism and all the other -isms.'' But the Soviet press, still highly responsive to official guidance, has barely begun to deal openly, factually and forcefully with a surge in bigotry. It is time for Soviet leaders to drive a stake into hoary slanders like the one again making the rounds, that Jews engage in ritual murders or were responsible for the murder of the Czar and his family.
In reacting to all this, Westerners need to be wary of two mistakes. The first is to exaggerate the threat of hate groups that are loud but small; Russian nationalists captured only 10 out of 468 seats in Moscow's City Council. The other mistake is to minimize the significance of resurgent bigotry in societies struggling with failed economies and new political ideas. Unless checked by leaders, maggots can multiply.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Survivability Of Weapons Begins At Home

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
JUST in case Congress had any doubt that cutting billions of dollars from the Pentagon budget might be easier in theory than reality, some imaginative defense contractors left a little reminder at the foot of the Capitol a few weeks ago: a gleaming white aircraft, not quite plane and not quite helicopter, known as the V-22 Osprey.
The stunt was the latest effort to save the Marine Corps's $26 billion V-22 transport, a program that Defense Secretary Dick Cheney tried to kill last year only to have Congress restore research funds. This year it is one of scores of projects that hang in the balance as lawmakers struggle over how to translate the reductions they want in overall military spending into real cuts that mean lost jobs and economic dislocation back home.
''I'm from the Northeast,'' said Representative Barbara Kennelly, a Democrat from Connecticut, where one in every 15 jobs is defense-related. ''We've got a soft economy up here. I have to be careful about recession.'' Mrs. Kennelly's district is home to Pratt & Whitney, which makes engines for F-15 fighters and has a potential stake in the C-17 transport and Advanced Tactical Fighter, two more programs that may not survive. 
''I sent my constituents a survey, and 78 percent of them said cut defense,'' she said. ''I don't think they've made the translation yet.''
There was a time when the Pentagon, the defense industry and their allies in Congress could hope to make a weapons system politically damage-proof by spreading the contracts around the country. The more states or Congressional districts with a piece of the project, the more its supporters could count on the collective weight of parochial interests to overcome any opposition.
But given the amounts Congress is looking to cut from the Pentagon budget, even the most politically artful procurement arrangement is no longer a guarantee of survival for costly weapons programs. The B-2 Stealth bomber is a case in point.
With an original price tag of $75 billion, or even $61 billion, based on Mr. Cheney's latest proposal to buy fewer planes, the B-2 has become a program that many in Congress love to hate. Opposition continues to mount, even though on paper the B-2 looks like a program nearly everybody would love to have.
''The B-2 is an obvious target because of its monstrous cost,'' said an industry official, who asked not to be named. ''You have a $500 million airplane that is going to turn into an $800 million airplane in the course of saving it. You can't damage-proof a system now. The defense pie is smaller, the slices are smaller, and there is more competition. Something's got to give.''
The B-2's three lead contractors, the Northrop Corporation, the Boeing Corporation and the LTV Corporation, have 4,000 subcontractors scattered in 46 states.
One of these is the Itel Rail Corporation, recent purchasers of a tiny company in Newcastle, Pa., that is to build 18 rail cars needed to haul portions of the B-2 frame. ''Cheney's cutback shouldn't hurt us, because as far as we know they will still need all the cars,'' said Ron Giallonardo, vice president of sales and marketing for Itel. Mr. Giallonardo said that thanks to guarantees in its $7.5 million contract with Northrop, Itel expects to ''come out whole'' even if the entire program is canceled. He said Northrop had not notified the company of any need to alter production schedules but had asked him to urge his congressman and senators to support the B-2. Representative Joe Kolter, a Pennsylvania Democrat whose district includes the Newcastle plant, is one of the nearly 200 co-sponsors of a House bill to kill the B-2.
For Fenwal Safety Sytems Inc., a small company in Marlborough, Mass., that makes the electronic temperature-sensing devices used in the B-2, the cutbacks Mr. Cheney announced two weeks ago would mean a loss of several million dollars in future business and probably some layoffs after this year, said Lewis F. Clark Jr., president of the company. Fenwal split the $10 million development costs for the B-2 safety system with Northrop, and while safety systems have strong applications for commercial aviation, some of the equipment the company purchased for B-2 production could not be adapted, Mr. Clark said. ''If the whole program is canceled,'' he said, ''we would lose a great deal of money.'' Other big weapons contracts work much like the B-2. The M-1 tank, also on Mr. Cheney's chopping block, is manufactured in Michigan and Ohio, but in the effort to salvage some production, its manufacturer, General Dynamics, has reminded Congress that more than 7,000 vendors in 48 states and Puerto Rico would be hit.
The Pentagon's own efforts to damage-proof programs are also less effective than they once were. Trying to build Congressional support for a 600-ship Navy back in the early 1980's, Navy Secretary John Lehman came up with a plan for ''strategic home ports'' at 13 sites around the country.
But the number has been scaled back to six, and last week, Mr. Cheney announced that four were under review for possible cancellation, including the Staten Island port. Eleven of New York City's 14 Congressional representatives and Mayor David N. Dinkins have said they are happy to see the Staten Island project go.
Representative David Skaggs, a Democrat from Colorado, said he found the Navy's procurement politics so offensive that last year he attached a provision to the defense spending bill that prohibits use of any contracting funds to make state-by-state or district-by-district analyses of the economic effects of new procurement.
''You have to look at devices that bring out the best in Congress, not the worst,'' he said.

LENGTH: 572 words

HEADLINE: Come What May, Congress Stays True to the Critters

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IF money is the sole indication, then no animal is more adored by Congress than a cow. Congress authorized $16.2 billion in subsidies over the last 10 years to bring the supply of milk into line with demand. Nor are the rangier, more ornery beef cattle ignored. Congress has taken special care since the mid-1930's to provide them grass and water, at enormous expense to the Treasury. 
Both policies have raised a ruckus among conservative economists and environmentalists, but the reason for such largess is clear to the nation's ranchers and dairy farmers. The value of the 33 million cows, calves and steers slaughtered last year exceeded $30 billion, according to the Agriculture Department. Milk sales reached $20 billion, and cheese, butter and other dairy products would add tens of billions.
Industry executives say that no consumers in the world pay as little for meat and milk as Americans, and the principal reason, they say, is Government subsidies.
''Price supports stabilize the market,'' said James C. Barr, chief executive officer of the National Milk Producers Federation in Arlington, Va. ''If you do away with the whole deal, you have a period of time where there will be short resources and higher prices. That will attract more resources, cause surpluses and lower prices. Cyclical turnover does neither the farmer nor the consumer any good.''
It took billions of dollars and considerable pain to wring instability out of the industry in the 1980's. In 1983, spending on dairy price-support programs, under which the Government sets a minimum price and guarantees it by agreeing to buy up and store surplus dairy products, reached $2.6 billion. In 1986, 14,000 farmers were paid $1.8 billion to slaughter their herds and leave the business for five years to reduce chronic overproduction. Some 1.6 million cows, calves and heifers were sent down the road. Most of the farmers took the opportunity to retire, according to the Agriculture Department.
Cattle ranchers have not been offered the same opportunities, but Congress has been generous. More than 220 million acres of Federal range and forest land in 14 Western states is open for grazing. The fee: $1.81 a month per cow. Calves eat free. The take for the Interior and Agriculture Departments last year was just $29 million.
Four years ago, the Reagan Administration, calculating that the market value for grazing on public lands was $6.40 to $9.50 a month, tried to raise the fee to pay for restoring vast tracts degraded by grazing. A coalition of Republican and Democratic lawmakers easily defeated the proprosal.
''We've been on the range for years and the land is in better shape than it has been in 100 years,'' said Betty Munis, a range expert with the Public Lands Council, a group in Washington that represents cattle and sheep ranchers. ''Cattlemen are responsible stewards.''
Environmental groups say the fees charged the ranchers do not even pay for the manpower needed to manage the grazing programs in the Interior and Agriculture Departments. ''They are not paying their fair share,'' said Johanna Wald, a senior attorney in San Francisco for the Natural Resources Defense Council, a national environmental group. ''While some cattlemen are good stewards of the land, many of them are not. The fact is vast acreage of public lands is in unsatsifactory condition and will remain in that condition until higher fees are charged.''

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1, Column 1; Week in Review Desk
