HEADLINE: NAVIGATING THE FUTURE;
A New Europe Comes Into Focus For George Bush

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
LIKE a man running to catch a train that is accelerating out of the station, President Bush keeps falling behind the breathtaking pace of events in Europe. To catch up, he has had to keep altering his ideas on the future of that continent, and the role the United States can play there in the decades to come.
Yet little by little, in reacting to changes sweeping the continent in hopes of shaping them, the President is developing a plan for Europe - dare one call it a vision? - that would have been unthinkable for an American president of any partisan or ideological persuasion only a year or two ago. Last week, he called upon the leaders of the other 15 North Atlantic Treaty Organization nations to meet him in London this summer to rethink strategy.
If Mr. Bush has his way, the new Europe will have two salient features: a unified Germany with full membership in a transformed NATO that is as much political as military - something that will require revolutionary thinking about the alliance - and a continuing American presence, rooted in a significant residue of American military forces and nuclear weapons. 
After dragging his heels for months, the President agreed last week that there might soon be no land-based nuclear weapons left, but he clings to the idea that there must be airborne nuclear missiles in the new Europe, with some of them based in Germany.
''There are few lessons so clear in history as this,'' Mr. Bush said on Friday at Oklahoma State University. ''Only the combination of conventional forces and nuclear forces have insured this long peace in Europe.''
''Everything depends on keeping NATO,'' said the Ambassador of a major Western European country. ''You can change it, make it more political, do what you like. But it has to have Germany in it, and it has to have the United States in it. We can't afford to let either one slip into isolation.''
To achieve what they want, the Administration and its allies have already made some concessions and will probably have to make more - to Congress, to the Soviet Union and to Germany. By abandoning a new short-range nuclear missile to replace the aging, land-based Lance, Mr. Bush removed a major source of dissent in NATO, and he is said to be ready to negotiate the elimination of the Lance itself as well as nuclear artillery shells from Germany. Bonn has agreed that no NATO forces will be deployed on what is now East German territory.
But even such major decisions as those have not been sufficient to resolve the central question, the security arrangements for a united Germany, which provided the focus for the first session of the ''two plus four'' negotiations in Bonn on Saturday, involving Britain, France, the United States, the Soviet Union and the two Germanys.
The most obvious problem is the Soviet Union, which originally wanted a neutral Germany and now insists upon a Germany that belongs both to NATO and to the rapidly disintegrating Warsaw Pact, pending the creation of a pan-European security system to replace the two alliances.
There are a few signs of yet another softening in the Soviet position, including an article by a Soviet general in an East German newspaper arguing the case for Germany within NATO. But President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is being asked to institutionalize a vast erosion of Soviet power in central Europe, and the NATO allies are working on ways to make it easier for him.
The West Germans, for example, are suggesting a number of economic sweeteners, like helping to pay for Soviet troops remaining in East Germany. They and the French also favor a much-enlarged role for the 35-member Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, to which the Soviet Union belongs, and a slightly reduced role for NATO. Washington and London are less enthusiastic about C.S.C.E., seeing in it a way for France, which is not a full participant in NATO, and for Germany, which could eventually choose not to be, to coax the old alliance toward oblivion.
For similar reasons, the Americans and the British are determined to introduce into Germany new, small tactical nuclear weapons carried by aircraft - so that, in the words of a ranking United States official, ''the front-line country in NATO, which is Germany, continues to be involved in nuclear deterrence after the land-based missiles have all been pulled out.'' It would also please Mr. Bush and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher to see some of the missiles at a French air base.
Even if all or most of this works - and there have been ample indications lately, for those seeking them, that Mr. Gorbachev's flexibility may be coming to an end - it appears certain that the United States will have to find a whole new basis for its role in Europe as the continent moves toward closer economic and political integration.
Although Mr. Bush has set a floor of 225,000 for American troops there, reductions in short-range weapons, as well as Congressional pressures, will inevitably drive that figure lower soon.
With the Eastern European countries transformed almost overnight from adversaries into friends, and the Soviet Union no longer nearly as menacing, in terms of either armaments or intent, as it was for four decades, much of the rationale for the strategy of the United States and NATO is withering. But there is not, as yet, any very clear delineation of what a new NATO, focused increasingly on political and even economic questions, might look like.
 
For many reasons, the
United States is fearful of losing influence in Europe, and President Bush has been saying almost since he took office that the United States intended to remain a European power.
 
He does not want to see
American products and services blocked out of European markets by a strengthened European Community, he does not want to leave a heavily armed and still autocratic Soviet Union without a sufficient counterweight in Europe, at least in the short term, and he does not want to abandon the American role in guaranteeing that a reunited Germany will remain trustworthy.
The last item is not mentioned much publicly, either in Washington or in other European capitals, because of a reluctance to offend the Germans. But it counts for a lot; a French official said not long ago that it would be ''a catastrophe not to have the United States here to balance the Germans.''
In a sense, then, NATO is being asked to do three things at once: provide a continuing deterrent or response to any attack from a weakened Soviet Union, whether under Mr. Gorbachev or someone else; prevent Germany from rebounding for the third time this century from defeat into renewed militarism; and begin transforming itself into a different sort of entity that could provide the political and economic linkage between the new Europe and the United States.
It is a large order, and the United States may have to fight to keep NATO stronger than the European Community or some new version of C.S.C.E. that might be thought to offer a safeguard against a resurgent Soviet Union by bringing it and the newly democratic Eastern European states into Europe instead of holding them at a distance for a while more.
Many European experts, and more than a few American skeptics, suspect that NATO will not be able to adapt successfully. Even if it does, they argue, it will be rendered irrelevant or redundant within a few years as the military threat recedes further and other organizations deal with non-security questions.
''We have a difficult wire to walk,'' an American strategist said. ''The easy, dramatic part is over. Now the really hard, dangerous stuff starts.''

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY

 BODY:

Cost of Cab Ride Up 30 Percent In Chicago
Chicago, which used to be one of the least expensive cities in the country for taxi riders, has joined the mainstream. The reason: after nearly a decade of no change in fares, the City Council recently approved a series of increases averaging 30 percent. The increases, which took effect in March, will affect travelers' costs in deciding which Chicago airport to use.
Travelers will pay more no matter how long or short their trip in a cab. Under the new fare structure, they are paying a base rate - the so-called flag pull or drop - of $1.20, up from $1. And they are paying $1.20 to travel a mile, up from 90 cents. 
A three-mile trip from the residential Near North Side to the Loop costs $4.60, up from $3.60. A five-mile trip - say, from the Near North Side to the McCormick Place convention center - now costs $7, up from $5.40.
Because it has always been much more expensive to ride to O'Hare Airport from downtown than to Midway Airport, the 30 percent fare translates into a greater increase in the cost of a trip to O'Hare. Whereas there used to be a $6 difference between the cost of traveling to the two airports ($18 vs. $12), there can now be an $8 difference, depending on traffic ($24 vs. $16). Moreover, now that the cost of a cab to O'Hare, including tip, exceeds $25, many business travelers will for the first time be required to keep receipts in order to be reimbursed by their employers. Many companies do not require employees to produce receipts for expenses under $25.
The one comforting piece of news is that Chicago taxis are still relatively inexpensive. Of 13 cities surveyed by Chicago officials, Chicago ranked eighth in terms of cab costs after the new fares went into effect. Leading the list was Los Angeles, where a three-mile trip costs $6.30. The cost of such a ride in Chicago is now $4.60. The cheapest cabs found in the survey were in Denver, where a three-mile ride is $4.05.
 
Watching Yen While in Japan
One way to cut costs in Japan, according to Japanese tourist officials, is to look for restaurants in department stores, office buildings or near public transportation where inexpensive prices are posted. The best buys are often at noontime when the daily special (teishoku) costs about 700 yen, or $4.50 (based on 158 yen to $1) and includes rice, miso soup, salad, meat or fish entree and dessert.
Eating out is among topics in a free color brochure, Economical Travel in Japan, available from the Japan National Tourist Organization (630 Fifth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10111). It says that kaiten sushi restaurants serve sushi at low cost by saving on labor costs. The sushi chef places slices of raw fish and rice on a conveyor belt for customers to pick up. Don't tip in Japan, the booklet adds: it's not the custom. Other advice for saving money: buy a rail pass for unlimited rail travel; study tour-operator packages for group and independent bargains and consider staying in inns (ryokan), family-run guesthouses (minshuku) or pensions.
The average cost of a night at a ryokan, without meals, is $25 a person; at a minshuku, the rate, with two meals, is generally about $32.
The 14-page brochure includes maps, tips for taking a bath and sketches, including one showing Japanese bedding, which is laid directly on a soft matted floor.
The booklet also recommends taking the limousine bus from Narita Airport to downtown Tokyo for about $17. A taxi would cost around $125.
 
Rome Protects Marcus Aurelius
After nine years of exile in Rome's Central Institute of Restoration, the statue of Marcus Aurelius, symbol of the Eternal City's ancient civilization, has made a triumphant comeback to public domain on Capitoline Hill.
The 1,800-year-old gilded equestrian masterpiece has not returned, however, to its original pedestal at the center of the Piazza del Campidoglio, which Michelangelo designed in the 16th century. It now stands in the adjacent Capitoline Museum, sheltered from smog and acid rain.
While experts continue to debate whether to replace the twice lifesize bronze statue of the emperor-philosopher with a copy, the original pedestal stands empty at the center of the square, a symbol itself, not of past glory but of the threat of traffic pollution.
The Capitoline Museum in the Palazzo Nuovo on the Piazza del Campidoglio is open every day but Monday from 9 A.M. to 1:30 P.M. and, on Tuesday, Thursday and Saturday from 5 to 8 P.M. It is also open on Saturday from 5 to 11 P.M. from April to September. The entry fee of about $3.60 covers a visit to the museum's collection of ancient Roman sculptures.
 
Hawaii Plans 3 Boat Races
 
HONOLULU
Three interisland races mark the kayak, outrigger canoe and sailing canoe racing season in Hawaii this year. Men and women paddlers, including international Olympic champions, compete across the Kaiwi Channel, one of the world's most treacherous.
The 32-mile Kayak Challenge takes place May 20. This 14th annual single-person kayak-surf ski race starts from the beach at Papohaku Roadstead in front of the Kaluakoi Resort on Molokai Island at 10 A.M. and finishes shortly after noon at the Koko Marina ocean promenade in Hawaii Kai on Oahu. Free parking is available at the adjacent shopping center.
The 75-mile Maui-to-Oahu Ho'omana'o Challenge on May 27 is a six-man outrigger sailing canoe race. It begins at Whaler's Village, Kaanapali, on Maui at 6:30 A.M. and finishes in front of the Royal Hawaiian Hotel area of Waikiki Beach, Oahu, between 1 and 3 P.M. It is a test of strength; no midwater crew changes are allowed. Ho'omana'o means ''cause to remember.'' The race, first held last year, revives the tradition of ancient Hawaiian outrigger sailing canoes.
The 40.8-mile Molokai Hoe, the classic of interisland open ocean paddling, will be Oct. 7. The 40th annual six-man outrigger canoe event, from Molokai to Oahu, begins at 6 A.M. with the rigging of the outriggers at Hale O Lono, a barge harbor reached by dirt road seven miles east of Molokai's west end. In-the-water start is at 7:30 A.M. There will be entertainment at the finish line at approximately 12:30 P.M., at Fort DeRussy Beach, Waikiki.
The Na Wahine O Ke Kai, the women's version of the Molokai Hoe, takes place on Sept. 30, starting from Hale O Lono on Molokai at 7:30 A.M. and finishing at Duke Kahanamoku Beach in front of the Hilton Hawaiian Village Hotel in Waikiki at about 1 P.M. MOANA TREGASKIS
 
Delays on I-75
Travelers arriving at Greater Cincinnati International Airport in Boone County, Ky., can expect some delays getting into town this summer due to road construction. Work along the Cincinnati stretch of Interstate 75 is scheduled to continue through October.
An alternative route to the airport, either I-471 or I-275, is advisable. For updated traffic conditions call: 513-852-5000.

HEADLINE: Crumbling Cuba Still Loves to Rumba

BYLINE: By MATTHEW ROBBINS; MATTHEW ROBBINS is a writer and director who lives in San Francisco.

 BODY:
RECENTLY I found myself fondling a dollar bill of such limp antiquity that it called the entire concept of cash into question. This tattered, pale greenback had been in circulation since the late 60's, but were it not for its privileged isolation on the island of Cuba, it would long ago have been incinerated. Its edges were thin, its corners rounded, and George Washington had faded to near anonymity. Yet here it was, in a Havana diplotienda - a shop open only to foreigners - being passed from hand to hand and enjoying the esteem of its bearers.
Also enjoying esteem throughout the island was another American symbol, the tailfin. Cars made in Detroit, like dollars minted up north, were ubiquitous but similarly ancient. For someone like me, who grew up knowing every car make and model from 1949 to 1959, a simple drive to town was a visit to an automotive past, where half-forgotten De Sotos and Kaisers trundled by on tall, balding tires. They felt like old friends, these cars, so touching in their two-tone postwar assertiveness. I was shocked to learn that some of them have undergone transplants and are powered by Russian engines. 
It was strange to be one of the few Americans in Havana, where decaying cars, dollars and hotels stood so eloquently for the vanished American presence. (An embargo by the Treasury Department generally rules out visits by American tourists.) I met only three other gringos during my two-week stay in Cuba last October, as a teacher in a screenwriting workshop organized by Robert Redford's Sundance Institute and Gabriel Garcia Marquez's International School of Film and TV. But I found the culture, 30 years after the revolution, still touched by the United States (although there is a peculiar Russian veneer as well.) As a visiting assessor, I was housed in a two-bedroom flat with kitchen and bath, part of the student dormitory of the film school an hour southwest of Havana. The town was called San Antonio de los Banos. Here, nationwide food shortages, combined with old-fashioned institutional cooking, made the cafeteria meals a dreadful prospect. I wound up shopping for food at the diplotienda, the most visible sign of the dual economy.
There were several of these shops for foreigners around Havana; this one resembled a miniature, slightly threadbare May Company. The thoroughly unremarkable merchandise was made special by its unavailability elsewhere on the island. And who were these whey-faced customers fingering Lapidus shirts and Edwin jeans? Why, they were Russians, and their wallets are bulging with greenbacks! I asked an elegant Cuban saleswoman if she spoke any English. ''No, senor,'' she answered, ''Hungar.''
Sure enough, there were Hungarians, Romanians and Czechoslovaks snapping up watches, radios, gold chains and other vital necessities. I located the food section and laid in a good supply of Italian pasta, Romanian tomato sauce and cheese of unknown origin. Visa cards? Only if yours was issued by a non-American bank, so it was cash for everything. I donated some fresh dollar bills to the island economy. Within a matter of days, I acquired three new addictions: rum (Cuban and Nicaraguan), cigars (Havana puros, of course) and thick, sweet Cuban coffee. It is not uncommon for mainlanders to drop their inhibitions when visiting Caribbean islands, but I was startled by the eagerness with which I took to these vices. With a nervous system assaulted by alcohol, nicotine and caffeine, I set out to see something of Cuban life.
I drove a Lada, a sort of extra-tinny Fiat, made in the Soviet Union. Here, surrounded by real Detroit iron, the poor thing reeked of Soviet ersatz modernity. No matter which Lada I used (the film school has a dozen), the windows didn't work and the wipers were always intermittent. I lusted for a ride in one of the big Buicks that swept by.
THE roads themselves were in rather good shape, better in many cases than the pavement in West Marin County, where I've done a lot of driving. During heavy rain, sections of the highways resembled lap pools, but I kept my eyes on the spectacular clouds overhead, especially at sunset, when silhouetted palm trees create postcard vistas.
My newfound interest in rum and cigars could be traced to the parties that kept springing up. Even the most intellectually forbidding faculty would jump up and start executing crazy salsa steps, as if it were midnight on New Year's Eve. I too got dragged onto the dance floor, even though, officially, I don't dance. No one cared - they were too busy living it up until dawn.
Everybody, it seemed, loved to dance. One day a Colombian film maker took us to a neighborhood courtyard where hundreds of onlookers gathered every week to watch a demonstration of the rumba, a dance of the past. The dancers, dressed in white, were all past 70 years of age, and comported themselves with a gracious dignity, keepers of the flame. This was a Cuban affair, with hardly a tourist in sight. It was also an occasion for folk dancing, heavily influenced by the African music and religions that were brought to the Caribbean by slaves. The racially mixed audience was intent, thoroughly involved with every moment, and generous with laughter and applause. They were proud of their dancers, and this self-regard, I discovered, applied to the other arts as well.
At a brightly lighted serigraph workshop near old Havana, dozens of art students cranked out beautiful prints by Mendive, one of the city's best-known artists. These kids had been at it all day, and, with evening aproaching, they were munching sandwiches and downing beers, clearly intending to work all night in preparation for an exhibition and festival that would begin the next day. Although I had walked in with no warning, I was received as a special guest, handed a glass of rum and given a grand tour. The art work emerging under the serigraph frames was a lively mix of surrealism and symbolism. On the walls, other artists were on view, in styles ranging from hard edge to abstract expressionism. I spotted a Rauschenberg; he had been here a year ago. In a country struggling with government censorship (with a nervous Communist Party disallowing certain Soviet publications) the visual arts, on display in all public spaces, were bold and often abstract. No socialist realism in sight.
In New York, where anyone can buy a can of paint, the once-ubiqiutous subway graffiti became a visual symbol for the city as a whole. In Havana, where there is no paint to buy, the buildings are literally flaking and peeling away. If you rarely think about something as mundane as paint, its complete absence comes as a shock, just like the graffiti. I heard somebody say that the only paint available is made in East Germany and it's no good. So the once stately Beaux-Arts homes, now surrounded by wild, uncut grass, are slowly falling into ruin.
IF the Cubans are unable to pay the upkeep on much of the splendor that was pre-revolutonary Havana, there are, nevertheless, a few symbols, like the cars, that are not allowed to die. The Tropicana cabaret, another monument to the 50's, rolls on with unchecked flamboyance. At this socialist nightclub under the stars, where hundreds of carefully matched cafe-au-lait showgirls and boys put on a Vegas revue for goggle-eyed visitors, many of them from Eastern Europe. The Tropicana was created in 1939, and the show I saw celebrated five decades of kitsch. Maybe someone in the Government decided that the cabaret is art and thus worthy of preservation. It's certainly a source of hard currency. As dozens of girls teetered around under chandelier headdresses that actually lighted up on cue, a marimba player appeared. His blurring mallets took me back to the Ed Sullivan show. The men juggled torches, the band blared and sequins never had it this good. After an hour the acts showed no sign of abating; I needed a break. The lobby was jammed with tourists buying cigars and rum. In the men's room, a dozen bleary-eyed Russians queued up for the pissoir.
On a Sunday, in search of white sand and blue water, I wedged myself into one of the Ladas, along with a group of students, and set off for Varadero, Cuba's most famous beach resort. I'd been assured by everyone that it was no more than an hour's drive. But as we headed east out of the city, the road signs abruptly ended. We were lost in no time, something that I found quite agreeable here among citrus groves, small villages and backroads. Every few miles we encountered soldiers in personnel carriers, dragging Soviet tanks around the countryside. Maneuvers. This kept the memory of invasion fresh, I supposed, but it must be a huge drain on the scanty national resources.
The soldiers we met were all courteous and offered precise directions, but none of them ever agreed on the proper route. We drove in a large, scenic circle, arriving at Varadero in just under four hours. The beach was of the classic white sand variety, with a few very pink Germans laid out under thatched umbrellas. Most of the tourists were said to be Canadians, longing for that hot Caribbean sun. On this day, however, they must all have been home in Toronto, for the shore was almost deserted. Varadero, with its stunning lack of development, is often cited as a potential tourist mecca, Cuba's most available quick fix for a moribund economy. Yes indeed, the tourists will come, but the price will be high - the mind's eye dots the landscape with boutiques, skate and scooter rental shops, real estate offices. Just like Waikiki. Some day the American embargo will be lifted, and trade will resume. It is easy to imagine the quaint streets of Cuban cities filling quickly with all the familiar American franchises. It is easy, too, to wince at the thought of the probable success of this impending invasion (with its ironic contrast to the Bay of Pigs). But the Cubans have been forced to be ingenious; they know what it means to recycle. They are not distracted by merchandise, not the way we are: they look to their culture as a source of vitality. It is peculiar, and even a bit condescending for a comfortable American to envy an impoverished and struggling people, but in some ways, I do.
 
Rules on travel
 
Who May Go
There are four reasons why Americans are permitted to visit Cuba and none involves tourism. Under the Trading With the Enemies Act, it is illegal for Americans to visit Cuba without either a general or a specific license issued by the Treasury Department, which regulates travel to the island. The ban applies even if an American citizen arrives in Cuba from a third country that permits travel to Cuba. This ban has applied since 1962, although it was lifted from 1977 to 1982.
A violation of the ban carries a fine of up to $50,000 and a prison sentence of up to 10 years. These penalties also apply to those who arrange any such trips.
With few exceptions, the six chartered planes that leave Miami for Havana each week take Government officials on business, journalists, researchers who have a specific need to be in Cuba and people visiting close relatives. They have a general license to travel to the island and do not need a piece of paper from the Government to allow the trip. But in an interview with customs agents before leaving the country they must provide proof that they qualify. Last year 8,500 American citizens visited Cuba under the general license, most to reunite with family members, said Larry Batdorf, a spokesman for the Treasury Department. All others wishing to visit Cuba must apply to the Treasury Department for a specific licence. About 50 were granted last year. In 1984 the Reagan Administration began an investigation of some 2,000 trips to Cuba by American scholars, journalists, lawyers and others that it said may have violated the regulations by offering opportunities for tourist visits under the guise of research or attendance at meetings. Marazul Tours, which is licensed by the Treasury Department, had its records subpoenaed. The subpoena was withdrawn and no charges were brought. Bob Guild, manager of Marazul, said the investigation had a chilling effect on legitimate travel to Cuba. Marazul arranges trips for about 3,500 Americans a year.
Last month a Texas fisherman was sentenced to 90 days in jail for organizing a trip to Cuba in 1987 in violation of the act.

HEADLINE: Walking on the Trail of Lord Byron

BYLINE: By ELISE MACLAY; ELISE MACLAY is the author of ''Green Winter: Celebrations of Later Life,'' which is being published in a new edition by Henry Holt this month.

 BODY:
FROM childhood, I have loved walking and reading, ideally in close conjunction. A loaf of bread, a jug of wine? For me, a book and a backpack are enough. Especially if I can walk in the footsteps of one of my favorite authors.
Last spring I did just that, roughly approximating the itinerary of the poet George Noel Gordon Byron on his initial foray from Prevesa on the Ionian coast to the interior of northwest Greece. Lord Byron was on his way to the courts of the infamous tyrant Ali Pasha, in Albanian Tepelene. Our trek kept a prudent 10- to 15-mile distance from the Albanian border. But the territory we passed through was the same, as little known and as beautiful.
We are two Americans (a lawyer and a writer who like to hike and read history and English literature) who joined a British walking group (four Britons, two Scots, two Irish and a Yorkshireman guide). Under the auspices of Sherpa Expeditions, based in London, we were on a two-week walking tour of the Zagorian villages - a Greece so different from sun-drenched, whitewashed islands as to seem another country altogether. 
In the Pindus Mountains in the region known as Zagoria, 48 exquisitely matched yet distinctive villages are composed entirely of gray local stone - gray stone houses with gray slate roofs, gray cobbled streets with gray stone curbs. Between these villages, and above and below them, lie forests and pastures inhabited only by shepherds, wolves, wild boar and an occasional lynx. It is rugged country, but the wild scenery - awesome gorges, snow-capped peaks, tumbling trout streams, plunging waterfalls - is gentled in spring with fields of wildflowers including (I was delighted to learn) a variety that is called in Greek Wild Virgin Lily.
It is the only place on earth, Lord Byron says, that he was ever content. Like him, we left problems at home and all thought of them faded like the mist in the valleys as we climbed through groves of oak, birch and juniper, up, up to Vradeto, a village that can be reached only on foot. Here, especially in winter when the snow often blocks the windows and the mule track is impassable, life is lived very much as it was 100 years ago.
We picnicked in the town square and bought drinks from the tiny taverna fronting it. The proprietor showed us photographs of winter snows reaching to the rooftops. Both taverna and square were deserted, but before we had unpacked tomatoes, cucumbers, olives and feta cheese and bread from our knapsacks and composed our communal Greek salad (a daily ritual) an old woman in black dress and shawl arrived. A man followed, then another, and soon seven or eight villagers had gathered around us. They spoke no English and our Greek was sketchy, but the old woman made us understand that we were welcome, that she was born in Vradeto and that until she was 7 years old the Turks ruled the town. She said she had a son and daughter in Athens, but lived alone here ''because it is more beautiful.'' Flowering fruit trees and neat vegetable gardens in stone-walled courtyards argued her point.
Although the ruggedness of the Pindus range has successfully turned back conquering armies and busloads of sightseeing tourists, it is not necessary to be a mountaineer or a rock climber to explore it on foot. Trails ranging from narrow footpaths to wide, cobbled mule tracks lead to all the important sights. Chief among these is Vikos Gorge, the Grand Canyon of Greece. Its towering 1,000- to 1,500-foot limestone walls stretch eight miles to the village of Papingo - our first night's stop. To walk from one village to the next takes from three to six hours and, although there are steep places and occasionally loose rocks underfoot, it should not be beyond anyone used to a good weekend's hike. The Greek Alpine club marks and maintains many of these trails and has provided for hikers an alpine hut on the saddle between Mount Astrakas (7,900 feet) and Gamila (8,320 feet).
Our climb from Papingo to the mountain hut was the most demanding part of our trip. It took about four hours, and for the first time we had to carry our food and cook it rather than dining in tavernas. In these remote parts, villages predate automobiles and so they are almost always a day's walk apart. And in every village, no matter how small, there is - as Byron says - a taverna where the traveler could be sure of food and wine and welcome.
Accommodations on the trip were a mixture, but always modest: mostly in small rooms either in the local taverna or in guesthouses. Typically there would be a shared bath or shower down the hall. The places we stayed in were, without exception, scrupulously clean. The trip leader brought the makings of breakfast, because we would usually have an early start. We often ate out in the courtyard, with coffee made on a sterno stove, fruit and bread.
However, if you believe Hobhouse, Byron's companion (and in my opinion a big complainer) Zagorian cuisine must have improved mightily since the poet's day. In village after village, we had no complaint. Our chicken was roasted to perfection. Hobhouse says theirs was ''Done to rags.'' Our tomatoes were red-ripe and flavorful. Stuffed eggplant (which our English companions called aubergine) was delicious. Meals usually consisted of bread (no butter except at breakfast), Greek salad, soup, lamb or chicken grilled or roasted or stewed with vegetables; sometimes moussaka, sometimes stuffed tomatoes or eggplant, sometimes an omelet. We almost never had dessert. Everything we ate was fresh and unadulterated. What we did not have was variety, lavishness, opulence. This is a lean and frugal land, no place for fripperies.
David, my husband, and I booked our trip through Himalayan Travel, with offices in Greenwich, Conn., because a small ad in one of the many wildlife magazines we subscribe to said they offered trips to Greece. Inquiry revealed the fact that one of their offerings was Sherpa Expeditions walking trip, its itinerary approximating Byron's.
IT was not economical for us to join the group in London and depart with them on a charter flight to Prevesa, where we might have gazed at the Bay of Actium, where Augustus defeated Anthony and Cleopatra. As it was, we got to see the bay later and our inexpensive flight from New York to Athens rewarded us with an Acropolis not yet overrun with summer visitors.
From Athens we flew to Ionnina, which our travel agent had never heard of even after I learned to pronounce it (YAH-nee-nah, with the first syllable decisively accented). In the Grande Bretagne Hotel in Athens, a porter, his eyes glazed with boredom, sprang to attention when I mentioned Ionnina. ''If you say Ionnina like that,'' he said, ''you must love Greece.'' He was right, of course.
I suspect that Ionnina today is harder to love than it was in Byron's time. Modern buildings and industrial development, traffic jams and dust deflect the visitor from the city's treasures - a mosque, a palace, the ancient Turkish quarter, historic sites including the very house - or merely the site of the house, depending on which professor you believe - where Byron lived.
Modern Ionnina also obscures its ultimate charm, its lakeside setting. Take a taxi to the quay as we did, and Lake Pamvotis suddenly appears like a magical mirage. Shallow, dark as polished onyx, reflecting minarets and towers, Pamvotis has a dreamlike quality, unruffled by scullers in training, fishermen in long narrow boats and the purposeful little launch that took us to the small wooded island called Nissi Ioanninon. Here we were to meet our fellow hikers, and we did, but they did not arrive until evening, so we explored the island on our own.
Surrounded by reeds and marshes where water fowl nest, sheltered by huge plane trees, Nissi is a pleasant place and interesting historically and artistically. With the aid of a guideboook we bought in Ionnina we viewed the 16th-century monastery of Panteleimon, the house where Ali Pasha took refuge in 1822, the ceiling through which he was shot dead by the Turks, and the jeweled dress of his young wife Vasiliki, who may or may not have betrayed him. From the 16th-century frescoes in the 11th-century monastery of Stratigopoulos we learned some of the more exotic tortures Christians endured, contemplated a portrait of Thucydides and laughed with delight at an exuberant Adam and Eve in an animal-filled painted paradise.
Toward evening the Sherpa group arrived and got acquainted at dinner. Lake Pamvotis teems with eels, trout, crayfish and frogs and every taverna on Nisi displays a tank of live seafood. We were invited to choose what we wanted the chef to cook.
The group members ranged in age from 18 to 65. Everyone was easily able to go the daily distance. It was just a matter of pace and even that tended to average out. Where the wildflowers were lush, the youngsters dawdled and the oldsters caught up. The strongest walker, a crackerjack skier, took it easy on the downhill, sparing a bad knee. I was both tortoise and hare. More agile than strong, I toiled up steep grades and bounded gleefully down. Angus, a Scot, and David, who although American is of Scottish ancestry, were soul mates, attacking every difficulty with ferocious determination. Arthur, young and Irish, jogged around the village each evening while the rest of us collapsed in the first taverna we encountered.
David and I have taken three walking trips with English groups, and it may be that our experience is unique, but it seems to us that while our British cousins are less friendly (I can't imagine their waiters bounding up to the table to announce ''Hi, I'm Kevin'') they are also more polite - a trait highly to be desired where other amenities may be in short supply. We traveled the next day by launch to Ionnina and then by taxi to the trailhead where our trek officially began. The first day is always a little tough and the Vicos gorge trail is challenging, but we all arrived at the village of Papingo in time and with enough energy to look around.
Papingo and its twin village, Mega Papingo, are traditional but not entirely typical, for they are restored villages. Crafts have been revived, houses rebuilt in the ancient style (some serve as guest houses) and families lured back after working abroad.
The next day we made the ascent to the Astraka hut, where we spent two full days. The hut, a two-story stone building, is furnished with double-decker beds, trestle tables, wooden benches and a wood-burning stove. Except in an emergency, it is part of the hikers' code to arrive with wood and kindling to add to the hut's supply. Most hikers carry sleeping bags, though we did not, but there are 20 or 30 heavy woolen blankets stored in wooden bins for visitors to use. There is electricity and water but no indoor toilet. As evening falls and the wind roars through the pass, the hut is immensely cozy with a pot of stew bubbling on the stove and hikers speaking different languages and communicating with simple offerings - a wedge of cheese (Dutch), pistachio nuts (Greek), a Hershey bar (American).
IN the morning, we explored a landscape that was almost lunar - great fields of boulders, breathtaking views and immense silence. We walked to the Drakalimmi of Gamila, a fascinating and magical green lake, stopping along the way to photograph a great snowfield with hundreds of crocuses poking through. To descend, we took a different route, across limestone uplands, past shepherd's huts where feta cheese is made. We drank at crystal springs, where we always found a cup or glass or pitcher set close by in the name of hospitality. Toward evening we reached Tsepelovon, where Alexis Gouris, who speaks English, was our host for two days.
Alexis has a fine two-story house with an external staircase and large comfortable bedrooms with fireplaces and balconies. From this luxury we set out each day to visit another Zagorian village. Every walk is at once the same and different. Much of the difference involves weather. Mountain weather is always changeable, but in the Pindus it was as if the gods drank ouzo and began throwing the elements around - sun, mist, black clouds, rain, the bluest sky in the world - all in half a day.
One day our group went farther afield and, in order to reach Tsepelevon in time for dinner, we decided to rejoin the paved road and take a 4 o'clock bus back. (When you have climbed Gamila, you feel entitled to take it easy - and Alexis had promised us hot water if we arrived before 6:30 P.M.) But delaying 5 minutes here, 10 minutes there, to take a photo or identify a wildflower (Greece is said to support over 6,000 species) we missed the bus. There was nothing for it but to walk. No problem. After the rough trails of the day, it was pleasant to stride along a smooth road.
The sun had faded and wisps of mist floated like chiffon scarfs among the limestone crags. The day, even after 4, was warm and windless. Suddenly, as if the mountains were cracking open, there was a tremendous clap of thunder. I remembered that Byron, having lost his way enroute to Zitsa, had encountered a violent thunderstorm that terrified his English valet.
THE sky blackened and, to our astonishment, we were pelted with gigantic hailstones. Perhaps these mountains are magic, for our group, tired and hungry, was seized with laughter. We scooped up handfuls of hailstones - no easy task as they skittered and bounced on the asphalt. We threw them in the air, at each other, off the cliff. Finally, we got our ponchos out, put them on and headed for town. When a bread truck stopped to give us a lift we got in a little reluctantly. Although we didn't wish to emulate the poet to the extent of getting influenza, we were somehow loath to return to the simplicity of village life.
By the time we reached Alexis' house, we were happy enough to shower, dress and eat egg-lemon soup, lamb chops, green beans and potatoes with a bottle of local white wine we had picked up at the taverna on the village square. Alexis owns the taverna. He owns the general store. He told me that he has land on the edge of the village where he said he will build a 55-room hotel.
His eyes shone at the idea. I was almost beguiled by the picture he painted. Comfortable beds. Hot water. Window boxes with flowers. But I wondered. If people come, Tsepelovon will change, the mule tracks will be paved, new buildings will rise, and although Alexis thinks that is what he wants, he cannot know what it may mean. For now, he is his own man, a big man in a small beautiful town, a man with a taverna, a general store, a house, a wife, a daughter, a garden, a pickup truck and a dream.
The Greek Government values the Zagorian villages and, in recognition of their proud and ancient past, has designated many of them as historic preservation areas. Much of the mountainous beauty around them now comprises the Vikos-Aoos National Park. But, in the last analysis, what will protect his magical place is what always has -the wildness of the terrain and the fiercely independent spirit of its people.
From Tsepelovon we went to Parga for a few days of indolence on the beach. As we were leaving, I asked Alexis about a ruined house on the outskirts of town. The roof had fallen in, wind and rain had rotted posts and beams, wild honeysuckle climbed over the crumbling walls. Was it abandoned? No, the owner had gone away. To America, perhaps. But he would be back. Or his son would or his grandson. ''And so will you,'' Alexis added, smiling. ''How do you know?'' I asked. ''I think,'' he said, ''that when people walk, they remember.'' I think he is right.

SECTION: Section 5; Page 26, Column 6; Travel Desk

LENGTH: 388 words

HEADLINE: Travel Watch

 BODY:
To the Editor: I've found your Travel Watch section a useful guide for the business traveler, but I would like to point out an error in the $1 Equals . . . section.
Since the new year began, you've been listing the year-ago Brazilian currency exchange rate as being in cruzados. This should be given in new cruzados, a monetary unit that the Brazilian Government introduced in January (1,000 cruzados equal 1 new cruzado) as an aid to help stem the country's 2,000-plus percent per annum inflation rate. 
The Brazilian-bound traveler should be aware that three types of bank notes are in general circulation: 1. Cruziero notes, which have been printed over in black ink with a thousand-fold devaluation number that turned them into cruzado notes (a result of the December 1986 Currency Devaluation Act). 2. Cruzado notes, which have been printed over in black ink with a thousand-fold devaluation number that turned them into New Cruzado notes (a result of the January 1989 Currency Devaluation Act). 3. New cruzado bank notes.
As a precaution, when changing money, the traveler should closely examine the bank notes being received so as to avoid costly conversion errors.
 
. T. CARLOCK
 Columbus, Ohio
Eliane Freitas, director of the Brazil Tourism Office in the United States and Canada, adds: As of March 15, a number of changes in the Brazilian monetary system were enacted. Among those changes, a new currency, the cruzeiro, was created in substitution of the former new cruzado without any devaluation. Another measure was an 18-month freeze on investment accounts. As a result, there was a shortage of legal tender for a limited time following the announcement. The shortage was due to the fact that most Brazilians, who used to keep their assets in investment accounts accompanying inflation, were temporarily prevented from accessing part of them. Some tourists who were in Brazil at the time were exposed to the shortage when trying to exchange money. Because of the unavailability of cruzeios, the United States dollar rate went down to about half of its value before March 15. In some cases, transactions were made in foreign currencies. By March 30, gradual injections of Brazilian currency into the market brought the U.S. dollar back to approximately 90 percent of its value prior to the plan.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: May 6, 1990,

SECTION: Section 6; Page 48, Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 4612 words

HEADLINE: GIFTED CHILDREN'S PROGRAMS: A MATTER OF CLASS

BYLINE: By Elizabeth Stone; Elizabeth Stone teaches journalism at the Fordham University College at Lincoln Center. She is working on a book about the Hunter College Campus Schools.

 BODY:
RECENTLY, A CLASS OF kindergartners and first graders at Hunter College Elementary School for the gifted in Manhattan were discussing with their teacher what Mayor David N. Dinkins might do for the city's 5- and 6-year-olds.
''Well,'' said Allegra, ''he can spend some of the money getting kids more education. He could build new schools. Many are very, very broken down.''
''He could use the money to buy teachers that are very smart and that could teach very well,'' said Josh. ''And another thing - some kids might not feel comfortable in their schools, and he could reassure them to be comfortable.'' 
''What happens to kids,'' wondered the teacher, Darlene Freeman, ''when they don't feel comfortable in school?''
Molly raised her hand. ''They wind up not wanting to go, and then the Japanese would get ahead,'' she said.
Molly isn't the only one thinking about the Japanese. Legislators, industrialists and educators are too, and about the unpleasant possibility of America falling permanently behind as a world power. And the same awful scenario goes through their minds when they consider the prospect of Europe pooling its resources in 1992. Meanwhile, despite a decade of educational reform, each new study of American schoolchildren offers more bad news. A recent report from the National Assessment of Educational Progress found that, among other things, American schoolchildren possess the capacity to absorb information but falter when it comes to using that information to reason effectively.
As a result, attention is once again being focused on ''gifted and talented'' students - in practice, the 3 to 5 percent of the elementary-school and high-school population with the highest standardized-test scores. Twenty-six states require that gifted children be identified; some also require that they be served. Others have discretionary programs.
Even the Federal Government is watching these children - as it did in the 1950's, post-Sputnik, and again in the early 70's, following a heavy emphasis on disadvantaged children - sizing them up as a national resource to be cultivated. The clearest sign of this interest is the passage of the Jacob K. Javits Gifted and Talented Students Education Act of 1988, championed by Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey.
Under the bill, money has been appropriated to subsidize 28 educational pilot projects (many of which focus on economically disadvantaged students, who account for a disproportionately small percent of those currently identified as gifted), to establish a research center on the gifted and to re-establish an Office of Gifted and Talented Education in Washington. The bill defines gifted children as those ''who give evidence of high-performance capability in areas such as intellectual, creative, artistic or leadership capacity, or in specific academic fields, and who require services or activities not ordinarily provided by the school in order to develop such capabilities.''
No one would argue with the idea that some children are smarter than others. Smart is smart, but ''gifted'' is a word with an agenda. To decide who gets into ''gifted'' programs, which may start as early as the nursery level, schools have traditionally relied on the I.Q. test. The children who do best on these tests, say educators, are those who've had the most ''mediated'' experience - been read to, talked to, listened to, taken on car trips and had every last cow pointed out. In short, the middle-class child.
In a culture uneasy at admitting that it has a class structure, ''gifted'' can become a code word for middle class, and especially white middle class, adding a fantasy patina of merit to what is merely money, and tacitly reinforcing the most unsavory racial stereotypes. Programs for the gifted are largely a phenomenon of public education. In urban areas, gifted education at the elementary level often seems little more than a lifeboat for white middle-class children on the sinking ship of public education.
Not that there aren't occasional innovative efforts to find minority children's incipient strengths and serve them: the Program of Assessment, Diagnosis and Instruction, in Montgomery County, Md., looks for and nurtures bright minority children, a quarter of whom later come to be identified as ''gifted''; an innovative program using creative means of finding bright minority children is just beginning in Austin, Tex.; another program, in District 18 in East Flatbush, Brooklyn,(Continued on Page 68) will use a $900,000 Javits grant to identify and develop ''multiple intelligences'' in minority kindergartners over a three-year period. And Hunter College's graduate program in education has recently put an emphasis on disadvantaged gifted children, says Prof. Rena F. Subotnik. But these efforts, while promising, can hardly be called indicative of the field's general orientation.
Despite more than 70 years of educational interest in bright children, there is no consistent research that demonstrates in general how gifted children should be identified, or what or how they should be taught. (Interest in the gifted began around 1920 in the United States, thus introducing educational tiers just at the time mass education was promising educational equality.) What is clear is that those identified as gifted are not necessarily the ones who have gone on to make the most stellar contributions in life.
''It's my opinion that most gifted programs turn their backs on most of the people that history comes to designate as gifted,'' says Joseph S. Renzulli, professor of educational psychology at the University of Connecticut at Storrs and director of the National Research Center on the Gifted and Talented. He cites Woody Allen, Charles Schulz and Steven Spielberg among those overlooked as talented students.
So it's no wonder the renewed interest in gifted children has stirred up controversy. That interest is not welcomed by Deborah Meier, recipient of a MacArthur Foundation grant who established several well-regarded public-school programs in East Harlem. ''Are we saying gifted children are more valuable to society?'' she asks. ''A society which picks out some children as more valuable than others is sending a terrible message. Any time people talk about what the gifted need - problem-solving abilities, critical thinking, creative thinking - they're describing what every child needs. In fact, other children may need it even more.''
Jerome Bruner, research professor of psychology at New York University, takes a different view. ''Goodness gracious,'' he says, ''when the world's leading industrial producer has become the world's leading debtor, I would think we need as much as we can get by way of thoughtful people. If you don't have high aspirations for your gifted, you don't have them for anyone. Why does 'gifted' produce such shudders?''
THE SHUDDERS BEGIN within the field of gifted education - a collection of several thousand teachers, parents, administrators and education professors in curriculum development or research. ''We're a practice without a theory,'' says Prof. James H. Borland of Columbia University Teachers College. ''We don't have a research base, we don't have a knowledge base, we don't have a theoretical base.''
Curriculum comes in for criticism, too. ''We spend a lot of time thinking about how to get kids and less time on what to do once we get them - on content areas and program planning,'' says Patricia O'Connell Ross, new director of the Federal Government's Office of Gifted and Talented Education. She was speaking to the 2,000 conventioneers of the National Association for Gifted Children, an advocacy group made up of teachers, administrators and parents, who gathered for a breakfast meeting in Cincinnati last October.
Robert J. Sternberg, a Yale psychologist and author of ''The Triarchic Mind: A New Theory of Human Intelligence,'' says what bothers him most is that ''a lot of what passes for gifted instruction is a little on the mindless side. I see some kids doing idiot work on worksheets.''
In elementary schools, there are two common approaches to education for the gifted. The first - more common because it costs less - is instituting ''pullout'' sections, where a small group of children are taken out of their regular classroom for an hour or so of special-education goodies, usually several times a week. At an elementary school in Hazlet, N.J., last fall, bright fourth graders met for special work in literature and creative writing, oceanography, social studies and problem-solving. That meant, says one unenthusiastic parent, that four times a week her child missed her regular science and social-studies classes and was required to make up the work and get the assignments on her own.
The second approach is the ''self-contained classroom,'' putting all the smart children together for the entire school day. Children who hang out with smart children tend to turn out smarter, which is why the practice is in disrepute. Besides, it's incompatible with the newest education trend favoring ''cooperative learning'' and frowning on ''ability grouping.''
Ability grouping excludes. Abraham J. Tannenbaum, emeritus professor of education and psychology at Teachers College, is one who favors an inclusive approach. You offer every child the opportunity to write haiku, or play the clarinet, or work on the class mural, says Tannenbaum. Next you look at what they actually produce - not potential but performance. Only then might you make decisions about sifting. This is how the Westinghouse Talent Search, which can claim a few Nobel Prize winners among its alumni, proceeds. This seems to make more sense than designating children as gifted before they've even started school, as Hunter Elementary does.
Whatever the class structure, the field's ideal these days is ''differentiated'' curriculum, rather than ''acceleration'' (which may, however, be favored at the high-school level, especially in advanced-placement courses). If a bright child learns quickly, say the curriculum developers, don't just race the child through the standard curriculum. Instead, offer the same material in a more textured way. In practice, curriculum adapted to bright children often boils down to ''mots and plops,'' says Arthur I. Pober, principal of Hunter College Elementary School.
''Mots'' is More of the Same, ''and it's often followed by More of the Same Times 2,'' says Pober. ''Twice as many math problems, twice as many spelling words, twice as many book reports.'' ''Plops'' is what may happen when the curriculum is enriched. ''So you take a kid to the museum and you plop him down,'' Pober says. ''It has nothing to do with what the kid's been studying or will be studying.''
Others in the field find the abundant criticisms unfair, and point out that teachers of gifted children are among the first to pick up on innovations that later become standard. For a while now in programs for the gifted, the focus has been on reasoning ability, for which the buzzwords may be ''critical thinking,'' or ''problem solving,'' or ''higher-level thinking skills.'' Just recently, Darlene Freeman adapted her class's unit on ''health'' (required by the state) to give it appropriate depth for her kindergarten children and first graders; her differentiation included a variety of problem-solving skills.
Her focus was on how much sugar the children were eating, and it was a critical thinker's heaven. Students identified various sugars - molasses, brown sugar, honey, corn syrup or dextrose. They brought in cereal boxes and analyzed the contents. Then they classified the cereals as heavy in sugar or not. Guilty boxes - Cap'n Crunch and Fruit-e-O's - were pilloried on the wall.
Next the children collected data on their own sugar intake for a week, sorting the results as high, low or average. Then they repeated their survey, and compared and contrasted the two sets of results: sugar intake was down. The children speculated as to the cause, concluding: ''This happened because we're learning that too much sugar is not good for you.''
SOON HUNTER ELEMENTARY School will celebrate its 50th anniversary as a school for the ''gifted.'' It's harder to get into than Harvard, with 1,500 applicants applying for 48 spots in nursery and kindergarten classes. At stake is an education - at the public's expense - that feels good and is good, with excellent teachers, an interesting curriculum, and a nice bunch of children, racially mixed to reflect the city's diversity and in accord with the school's explicit policy. Hunter has tried to find qualified children who are not middle-class, but, even with its change to the Stanford-Binet 4, a less culturally biased I.Q. test than most, the school has not succeeded. An informal 1988 survey among families whose children qualified for Hunter suggested the average income was $60,000.
The process of identifying a child as gifted is a complicated and stressful one for parents, as Terry Mattei, a secretary at Hunter Elementary, well knows. It is Mattei who fields all the phone calls and sends out all the applications. Although school systems in Texas, Virginia, Maine, Iowa and elsewhere are increasingly considering ''student portfolios'' among their criteria for entrance into gifted programs, Hunter discourages it. ''We tried it one year,'' says Nancy Goldman, an educational consultant at Hunter. ''Little Jimmy sent in his tape and little Betty sent in her picture, but we couldn't figure out any way to quantify it, so we dismissed it.''
Hunter does require parent evaluations, even though such evaluations favor the middle-class applicant. Parents squinch their handwriting into the tiniest size possible to fill Hunter's one-page questionnaire with examples of their child's abstract reasoning powers and analytic ability, curiosity and self-motivation, persistence and love of learning, memory and self-direction. Eventually, some even get to take their child to Hunter's ''second round,'' to a classroom whose window is covered over with paper so no one can see in. There, testers meet groups of six or seven children at a time, and carefully plumb each child's depths for signs of problem-solving ability, verbal ability, mathematical ability, creativity and leadership, says Evelyn J. Rich, associate dean of the Hunter College Campus Schools, which, in addition to Hunter College Elementary, includes Hunter College High School.
But nobody's cramped handwriting will be read and no child will be invited to the room with the paper-covered windows unless the child first scores at or above the required percentile on the Stanford-Binet 4. (Last year, Hunter Elementary required an I.Q. score at the 98th percentile, and the year before that at the 97th.) The Stanford-Binet, first used in 1916, for years heavily emphasized verbal ability and knowledge of certain kinds of verbal information. Although the argument has been made for 40 years that such skills are indicative of cultural privilege rather than intelligence, use of the I.Q. test continues to be widespread. Even in its current less ''biased'' form, it remains controversial. Dismissing it as a ''hegemonic instrument,'' Jerome Bruner says, ''We know perfectly well it paints certain kinds of kids right out of the room - poor kids, late starters.''
Dr. Ernest L. Boyer, president of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching, agrees: ''As long as we end up using the wrong yardstick, we're going to be doing mischievously dangerous things to children. These instruments tend to screen out potential rather than to define it.''
Nevertheless, the I.Q. test still has the weight of the CAT scan. Forty states recommend or require its use in identifying a gifted child, and estimates are that it governs acceptance in close to 90 percent of all gifted programs in public schools.
JOSEPH RENZULLI WAS among the first to say the field's exclusive emphasis on high I.Q. was misguided. He suggests instead that the combination of ''well above average'' ability (translated as 120 I.Q.), creativity and persistence would yield more.
As for minorities, he says, ''We've kind of been at the lip-service level for a long time.'' At the recent convention of the National Association for Gifted Children, seminars held on ''Special Populations'' focused as much on the Learning Disabled Gifted, the Underachieving Gifted, the Rurally Isolated Gifted as on the Minority Gifted. (''Severely Gifted'' or ''Chronically Gifted,'' terms people use with a straight face, refer to those who are very, very bright.) Renzulli's approach is used in all 50 states and in every major city. His is the official approach of the Gifted and Talented Unit of the New York City Board of Education. His model, the Renzulli Enrichment Triad, is based on a step-by-step approach not unlike Tannenbaum's initial come-one-come-all approach. Type I activities expose children to new realms (say urban planning) through field trips or visits from experts. Type II activities teach students skills pertinent to the area (surveying or rudimentary map making). And Type III activities are individual or group projects (doing a study to determine the best site for a second neighborhood candy store).
The appeal of Renzulli's work is that it is easily accessible and inexpensive to implement. With his emphasis on development of specific ''gifted behaviors'' rather than on a general state of ''being gifted,'' he has offered the field a way to refute charges of ''elitism.''
Nonetheless, inequities continue. State financing for the gifted has long been largest in the South. In 1987, Florida led the nation in funding its gifted programs with $68 million and Georgia was second, with $23 million. ''Florida, Georgia and North Carolina have had mandates to serve the gifted since the early 1960's,'' says Valerie Terry Seaberg, president of the Council of State Directors of Programs for the Gifted. Asked why, she paused. ''Well, you think about why.'' Many in the field privately say the money was to perpetuate segregated classrooms, with white students filling the gifted classes.
Gifted programs have made a heavy reappearance in northern cities in the last decade. Gary Timmons, a legislative specialist for the National Education Association, speculates that in a burdened educational system, middle-class parents who might never have thought of identifying their children as gifted now hurry to do so. ''It's the politics of pressure groups,'' he explains. ''You've got to have a cause. You can't just come in and say, 'My kid isn't being served.' You've got to say, 'My gifted kid isn't being served.' '' Virtually all of New York City's school districts have gifted programs. On Manhattan's Upper West Side, in Community School District 3, seven new programs for gifted children have been instituted over the last eight years.
The district's school enrollment is currently 88 percent minority. The white enrollment is heavily concentrated in classes for the gifted and in P.S. 87, the district's most middle-class school, which uses the Renzulli Triad. One school, P.S. 9, has two gifted programs. One of them, the Anderson Program, originally requiring an I.Q. at the 99th percentile, was instituted after a campaign by parents who felt the district's gifted program - requiring an I.Q. at the 95th percentile - was ''watered down.''
It is commonplace within the field to act as if the cupboard were financially bare, but a peek into the cupboard suggests otherwise. Nationally, state financing specifically tagged for gifted children added up to $297 million in 1987, according to the most recent report of the Council of State Directors of Programs for the Gifted. Sometimes the money for gifted programs comes from dipping into resources meant for desegregation - through the Magnet School Assistance Program - thanks to a loophole in Federal legislation. Eleven of the 54 grantees for 1989-91 - including urban schools in California, Georgia, Michigan, New Jersey, New York and Wisconsin - stipulated that a gifted program would be included as a part of their overall desegregation plan.
P.S. 163, on Manhattan's Upper West Side, is one of several schools in District 3 to receive a share of $3.25 million in Federal Magnet School Assistance funds during 1989-91. These funds were designed to ''reduce minority group isolation'' by bringing in white students. These schools also qualify for special city and state financing for the gifted. Sheri Lynn Behr, who teaches a first-grade gifted class, says her class takes more trips and has more creative and advanced math programs than other first-grade classes. In the same school, the children in the gifted program have a music teacher while others do not, because the parents raised the money. In District 18 in Brooklyn, teachers of the gifted receive more instruction on how to teach than teachers in other programs. The Hunter Campus Schools cost the public $7 million to $8 million annually.
Even though some of the financing is designed to reduce ''minority group isolation,'' minority children do not have to be represented in these classes in proportion to their presence in the school community. On the national level, black children account for 16.2 percent of all school children, but only 8 percent of those are identified as gifted.
IF THE I.Q. TEST GOES the way of phrenology, how are we to find, nourish and cultivate the gifts and talents in our children? Once, when I was pressing Dean Rich of the Hunter Campus Schools about the elementary school's continued use of the I.Q. test, the dean got exasperated. ''Look,'' she said, ''do you know the work of Howard Gardner? Do you know his book 'Frames of Mind'? We're interested in his work. And do you know the work of Robert Sternberg, the Yale psychologist? Him, too.'' She held the names up as if she were brandishing a cross to ward off demons.
Today, these are indeed the names to brandish, along with Renzulli's. ''I was considered to be the screaming liberal of the business,'' Renzulli says. ''And then when people like Gardner and Sternberg started to say the same things I was saying, the fabled I.Q. guard in the field softened up, and I started to get more respect.'' Whether the regard for this triad of academics is sincere or cynical, they have been pushed to the head of the parade for offering a broader, more inclusive definition of intelligence - and hence giftedness.
Howard Gardner, a developmental psychologist and professor at the Harvard Graduate School of Education, has become well known for his view, which first grew out of his research with children and stroke victims, that there are distinct and autonomous intelligences. Gardner calls these ''multiple intelligences'' and identifies them as logical-mathematical, linguistic, musical, spatial, bodily kinesthetic, interpersonal and intrapersonal.
These days, Gardner is assured a place on every scholarly bibliography, a seat on any educational dias he chooses and a citation on every grant application. ''If we're talking about gifted,'' says a source close to the Javits bill, ''Gardner and Sternberg are the coins of the realm in the cutting-edge conversations.''
''I don't have a specific interest in giftedness,'' says Gardner. ''My theory has sort of become a buzz-thing, like 'right brain-left brain.' '' Does he believe that those who buzz it understand it? ''I think it's unrealistic to think that one administrator in one school system reading one book will fully understand the theory. But,'' he adds, ''it's not something I worry about very much. I can't afford to lose too much sleep over the uses people might make of my ideas.''
Robert Sternberg says, ''I just go where my interests lead me.'' In recent years, they've led him to his ''triarchic'' theory of intelligence. Essentially, Sternberg wants to look, first, at the ''components'' of intelligence and how they function; second, at intelligence in relation to experience, as in how quickly a novel task can become automatic, and third, at intelligence in relation to everyday life - not just how smart people are in a vacuum but how well they succeed in finding a match between their strengths and the slice of the world they inhabit.
Both men are already affecting how children are identified as gifted. One successful Javits grant applicant cited Gardner (and, for good measure, Renzulli) for a project devoted to selecting children with talent in dance and music. They have asked for $930,000 over a three-year period.
Meanwhile, a few tendrils that grow out of Sternberg's theory have already found their way into Hunter Elementary's testing. One is Sternberg's interest in context. ''Vocabulary,'' he has written, ''is such a good measure of intelligence because it measures, albeit indirectly, children's ability to acquire information in context.'' Now Hunter's test, designed by Nancy Goldman, an educational consultant, may include telling children a story with selected ''nonsense'' words in place of real words and asking them to suggest what sensible words might be substituted.
One year, Goldman treated the children to a concrete variation of a problem devised by Sternberg, an ''insight'' problem involving mathematical thinking, but not computational skill. In Sternberg's words, the question is: ''If you have black socks and brown socks in your drawer, mixed in the ratio of 4 to 5, how many socks will you have to take out to make sure of having a pair of the same color?''
In adapting this problem, Nancy Goldman got three pairs of socks - each pair respectively adorned with the face of Goofy, Donald and Mickey - and put them in a paper bag. After making sure that the children being tested understood ''pairs,'' she asked them how many dips into the bag (without looking) it would take before they could be sure of having two socks that made a matched pair.
''I can solve that easy,'' one child told Goldman. Then he took the bag and dumped all the socks out. ''Here's a matching pair'' he said. Goldman thought the child had aced the question and so, too, when he was told, did Sternberg. Some people might feel that the child had simply disregarded the rules of the question, but for Sternberg real-life creativity involves innovation, even changing the nature of the question.
Would that one could as easily ace questions about bright children. For what is the point of broadening the definition of ''giftedness'' if in the end finances are not available to nurture all these gifts? All that will happen is that there will be an increased number of children competing for a fixed amount of money. All children have strengths in need of nurture, but - with all due respect to the Congress and the ''Education President,'' George Bush - a Federal budget that allocates to primary and secondary education less than 1 percent of its resources isn't putting its money where its mouth is.
Still, Robert Sternberg is a practical man, all for reaching into the drawer while it's open. ''Interest in gifted children comes in cycles,'' he says, ''and I'll take my opportunities as they come. We're living in a time of chaotic problems. We're starting to lose the ozone layer. Where is the future of business, new products, science, technology, new computers? I really do think it's with the children we might call gifted.''
And if their parents don't sort their socks before they put them in the drawer, by the way, the children will have to pull out no more than three socks to get a matched pair. Two, if they keep their eyes open.
