HEADLINE: THE GUIDE

 BODY:

 
BURR SISTERS
Forty paintings by a pair of unknown 19th-century artists from Monroe are on exhibition to June 10 at the New Britain Museum of American Art. The show, ''The Burr Sisters,'' was assembled by Helen Fusscas of the Connecticut Gallery in Marlborough, which has acquired a substantial portion of the sisters' 700 works. The remainder is in private collections.
''The family called us about paintings in their attic,'' said Ms. Fusscas, ''and I thought they were enchanting.'' Executed from 1870 to the turn of the century, ''they tell a story about women artists of the period who had better opportunities for studying and exhibiting than we thought,'' she said. 
Fannie and Jennie Burr attended the Yale Art School, where most of the students were women before it offered a baccalaureate degree and attracted men. They studied at the Art Students League in Manhattan, where most of their fellow students were also women, and they exhibited at the American Watercolor Society, the Art Club of New York, both in Manhattan, and the Brooklyn Art Association.
Neither of them married. The fruit farm they inherited from their father flourished under their stewardship, and they they profited immensely from it and from a series of shrewd investments. ''They had the talent to become well-known artists,'' said Ms. Fusscas, ''but they were busy managing the farm and the money.''
The exhibition includes landscapes, still lifes and portraits in oils, watercolors and charcoal. ''The technique is quite contemporary and realistic with a light palette,'' she said. Prices, through the Connecticut Gallery, are $800 to $5,000. Museum hours in New Britain are 1 to 5 P.M. Tuesday to Sunday. Call 229-0257 for more information.
 
HOUSE TOUR
''By Design,'' the University of Hartford Art School Auxiliary's annual house tour, focuses on homes owned by eight interior designers living and working in the Hartford area. The tour, from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. on Saturday, includes tea and a student art show on the Bloomfield Avenue campus.
A large Colonial owned by Sharyn Haymond was built 75 years ago by the architect Walter Crabtree, modeled after George Washington's home at Mount Vernon in Virgina. Margot MacDermid's English country house has a whitewashed stone facade, an interior that carries out the theme in English chintz and a big family kitchen with a fireplace.
A tiny 19th-century cottage owned by Kathleen Marr is decorated in eclectic style with Chinese art objects, while Susan Perl's traditional family home is a Dutch Colonial. One of two contemporary houses belongs to Marjorie Aronson, who added a curved glass entrance. The other is a classic ranch on which Athena Economou has lavished her interest in fabric.
James Healy made some of the furniture for his Cape Cod and painted faux marble fireplaces and crown moldings in some of the rooms. The final house is a Georgian Colonial owned by Betsey Cotter. Tickets are $12.50 in advance or $15 on tour day. Call 243-4393.
 
DEATH WITH DIGNITY
Walter Russell, probate judge from Windsor, will talk at 10 A.M. Saturday on conservatorship and issues relating to the elderly and infirm at an open meeting of The Connecticut Hemlock Society. The year-old chapter of the nonprofit national organization based in Eugene, Ore., has a membership of 300 Connecticut households.
The society's philosophy centers on death with dignity, and its purpose is to provide information about living wills and powers of attorney and to explore the options for active and passive euthanasia.
The meeting will be held in the Farmington Public Library, 6 Monteith Drive. Admission is free and more information is available by calling 325-1869 or 673-6695.
 
HORSES AND RIDERS
A total of $130,000 in prize money will be awarded in various events at the Annual Children's Services Horse Show and Country Fair at the Polo Grounds in Farmington. More than 1,000 horses and riders will compete from Tuesday to next Sunday in events ranging from the $2,500 Jumper Futurity Class to the $35,000 Grand Prix. A $7,500 Grand Slam of Show Jumping Award will go to two horse-and-rider teams accumulating the most points during the show.
Among the riders will be Barney Ward of Brewster, N.Y., two-time champion at the National Horse Show in Manhattan; Katie Monahan Prudent of Virginia, winner of the 1989 Children's Services Grand Prix and Grand Slam; George Lindemann Jr. of Greenwich, winner of the 1989 Grand Prix in Devon, Pa., and Leslie Lenehan of Westport, Grand Prix Rider of the Year in 1983 and World Cup winner in Sweden in 1986. In addition, Greg Best, Joe Fargis, Lisa Jacquin and Anne Kursinski, members of the United States 1988 Olympic silver medal equestrian team, will demonstrate their skills.
This year's expanded Country Fair, opening Thursday and continuing to Sunday, features midway rides, children's theater, pony rides, a petting zoo, clowns, and vendors of food and merchandise. Ebony Horsewomen, the only all-black female equestrian group in the country, will perform as it has in previous years, along with the Litchfield Hunt, the First Company Governor's Horse Guard and a series of dressage demonstrations.
Ring activity begins at 8 A.M. Tuesday to Thursday and 7:30 A.M. Friday to Sunday. Events wind up between 5 P.M. and 7 P.M. daily. Tickets are $4 in advance, $6 at the gate. Call 236-4511 for more information and advance ticket locations.
 
SNUFF BOXES
An indispensable accessory for men and women of the 18th and 19th centuries was the snuff box, and the Yale Center for British Art has 300 of them on view as works of art and objects of social history. ''Powder Celestial: Snuff Boxes, 1700-1880'' may be seen to June 24, complemented by humorous prints of the period depicting the attitudes of those who used snuff.
The boxes were made of tortoise shell, silver, wood, papier-mache, agate, ivory, coquilla nut and other materials, depending upon the status of the owner. Undertakers sometimes had them made in the shape of tiny coffins; prisoners made them out of bones left from their meals. Some were enameled with landscape scenes, others were painted with portraits of royalty and not always complementary.
The center is at 1080 Chapel Street in New Haven, open free from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Tuesday to Saturday and 2 to 5 P.M. Sunday. Call 432-2850 for more information. $90ELEANOR CHARLES

LENGTH: 488 words

HEADLINE: Fiscal Woes Cut Into Tourism Advertising

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
WHILE Connecticut's faltering economy will mean that less state money will be made available to promote tourism this summer, an official says that that will not necessarily translate to a flat year for tourism.
The state will spend about $200,000 for print advertising to attract tourists from surrounding states, much less than the $600,000 peak it spent two years ago and a fraction of the estimated $50 million that all other Northeastern states spend to attract the tourist dollar.
Because of the state's fiscal difficulties, there is no money for television and radio advertisements, the Deputy Commissioner of the State Department of Economic Development, Andrew A. Brecher, said last week. 
 
Optimistic Outlook
Despite the decline in state money to promote tourism, Mr. Brecher said he was optimistic that it could be a good summer for Connecticut's tourist attractions. Last year, tourists spent about $2.1 billion in Connecticut, according to state figures.
''The slowdown in the economy will work with us, not against us,'' Mr. Brecher said, ''because more people will be looking for recreational activities closer to home.''
He said he hoped that special events this summer, like the Volvo International Tennis Tournament in New Haven, as well as such traditional tourism favorites as Mystic Seaport and the Mystic Marine Life Aquarium would attract numerous visitors.
 
Summer Attractions
The Volvo Tennis Tournament, which this year will be played in New Haven, in August, ''will cause a major infusion of new tourism spending in the state,'' Mr. Brecher said. He said the state was expecting the tournament to attract 100,000 people. Many of those people will come from outside Connecticut, he said, meaning they will stay in area hotels, eat in local restaurants, attend plays and visit museums and other attractions.
Mystic Marine Life Aquarium attracted more than 770,000 visitors in 1989 and expects about a 3 percent increase this year, said Bernadette Bode, an aquarium spokeswoman.
About 450,000 tourists visited Mystic Seaport in 1989 and the seaport expects a 25 percent increase because of new evening hours seven days a week, said Liz Gwillam, a seaport spokeswoman. Lake Compounce Festival Park, on the Bristol-Southington line, and Yale University are also major attractions.
 
Changing Tastes
Mr. Brecher said that just as difficult as estimating how many tourists will visit the state this year is predicting what they will do when they do come.
''Tastes do change,'' he said. ''The hot thing to do one year won't be the same the next. People want to do something else.''
In addition, every season seems to bring a particular problem that changes tourism patterns, he said. ''In any summer season, there is some hysteria over something,'' Mr. Brecher said. ''Last year it was Lyme disease. The previous year it was medical waste. The year before that, it was the heat.''

PUB-DATE: May 6, 1990,

SECTION: Section 12LI; Page 2, Column 1; Long Island Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1527 words

HEADLINE: LONG ISLAND INTERVIEW: WILLIAM DOWDELL DENSON;
Nuremberg Prosecutor Reflects on History's Judgment of Evil

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER

 BODY:
WHEN he was appointed in 1945 to be chief prosecutor and chief of counsel for the United States Government in war crime trials involving the operators of the Dachau concentration camp, it fell to William Dowdell Denson to prove to the court, and to the world, that nearly unimaginable atrocities were committed by people who called evil their duty.
First, Mr. Denson said in a recent interview, he had to prove to himself the truth of stories so horrible he could hardly credit them. He knew they were true, he said, when he heard the same stories over and over from victims who survived to bear witness.
Then he went on to win convictions against 40 operators of Dachau, and scores more in trials that followed in 1946 and 1947 for the operators of Mauthausen, Flossenberg and Buchenwald. As a result of his efforts, 97 were hanged. 
Mr. Denson, a graduate of West Point and Harvard Law School, thinks still of Ilse Koch, the wife of the commandant of Buchenwald, who denied all and was spared death, he said, because she was pregnant at the trial. What he knew of what she did, Mr. Denson said, was more than he cared to tell.
Born and raised in Birmingham, Ala., Mr. Denson, 76 years old, moved to Long Island in 1958 after a postwar tour as chief of litigation for the Atomic Energy Commission and several years of private law practice in Washington. He is currently senior litigator for the Mineola law firm of Meltzer, Lippe, Goldstein & Wolf. He is married with three children and five grandchildren, and resides in Lawrence.
Q. As you reflect on those days you spent prosecuting some of the worst monsters in history, what stands out most strongly in your memory?
A. It was incredible. The events that had occurred were so sadistic and so gruesome that they were almost absolutely unbelievable. And when I first started questioning potential witnesses, I'll be perfectly candid with you, I thought here were some people who had been mistreated in the concentration camps and they were seeking revenge, and that they were really doing a job drawing on fantasy rather than reality.
Q. You believed they were embellishing?
A. Absolutely. And when I questioned a number of witnesses, and they related substantially the same things, then I knew the events had occurred. Because these witnesses didn't have a chance to get together ahead of time and fabricate their stories. And I began to believe and now would believe anything.
Q. These things were not known to the world then, even in 1945?
A. Of course it was revealed first when the camps were liberated. Until then the world knew there were concentration camps, and the people in Germany knew that there were concentration camps as places to be avoided. But what went on was no more known there that what you know about what goes on in Attica [State Prison], for example. You don't know what goes on there nor do you know what goes on down in Pilgrim [State Hospital in Brentwood].
Q. Are you suggesting these kind of things are happening all the time?
A. I don't know. But not on the scale that they happened in Germany.
Q. Did you find that the people running the camps and on the staffs seemed to be predisposed to act as they did?
A. That's the thing that's disturbing. Some of those people had just as normal a background as you or I. But once they started being exposed to violence and mistreatment it was like a snowball rolling down a hill. As long as they stayed there and were exposed to it the bigger the snowball and the more unconscionable these people became.
Q. And the guards?
A. Most of the guards were men that had been recruited off the streets, the unemployed from Berlin, Frankfort, Hamburg, Munich. They were thugs picked up off the streets. They became the Death's Head units of the SS.
The Jews came after the pogroms started in 1936, 1937. In 1938, when the Nazis took over Austria, in order to get rid of opposition, they took all the leaders and carted them off to one of the concentration camps. First there was Dachau, then Mauthausen.
From 1938 on, they were just working the tails off the prisoners and they didn't feed them hardly anything. There was starvation and hard work under living conditions that prevented them from getting the rest at night to do a hard day's work the next day. All of that was calculated to destroy them physically. Then there were floggings and wrist hangings and that sort of thing.
Then, as the staff grew, they drew on units of the SS.
Q. When they were tried, did they remain totally inured to what they had done?
A. They had no remorse, none that I saw. There were some that the shock was such when they were sentenced to death that they fainted. Basically they were tough. But they died just like dogs. The highest-ranking man that I prosecuted was August Eigruber, the gauleiter of Lower Danubia, a part of Austria. That scoundrel, he had a concentration camp that he put people in of his own whim and caprice. The last thing Eigruber said when the noose was put around his neck was ''Heil Hitler.''
Q. How could it be that the brutal Ilse Koch was not executed when so many others were?
A. I tried these people for the violation of the rules of land warfare. You get the foundation for that from the Hague Convention of 1907 and the Geneva Convention of 1929. What I did was try them for participating, aiding and abetting a common design to subject allied nationals to beatings, torture, starvation and killing and for doing the same thing to prisoners of war. I tried Ilse Koch for aiding and abetting this common design. I did not try her specifically for making lampshades out of human skin. She was very fond of such objects.
When prisoners were sent around the commandant's house, if they were Jewish or Poles or Russians, those who were not supposed to be really human, when those prisoners were around there, if she saw one looking at her she would take down his number and report him and he would then be flogged. He would be given 25 lashes. And that sort of flogging to those prisoners, who were almost starved to death, was a shock the nervous system which often did result in death. And she would parade herself around in tight-fitting clothing before those poor devils.
Q. What was her demeanor during the trial?
A. That this was a big bunch of lies and that she was not guilty of any misconduct. I put on enough witnesses to make out a case to justify a sentence of death. The court sentenced her to life imprisonment because she was pregnant at the time.
And then General [Lucius D.] Clay reduced her sentence to four years. The reason given was that there was insufficient credible evidence to justify a sentence of that severity. Well the whole point was, the very nature of these camps was that what took place there was incredible.
The biggest job I had was trying to get the court to believe the witnesses that I put on the stand. She was later tried by the German people for crimes against Germans and she was again sentenced to life imprisonment and she committed suicide in prison.
Q. You were trained as a soldier and a lawyer. You tried soldiers for violations of international law, but they said they were doing their duty as soldiers trained to follow orders.
A. The point is, when an order is illegal on its face, you don't have to obey it. This business that they would be shot if they didn't obey was for the birds. We had evidence of some of the doctors who declined to participate in some of the activities. They were not taken out and shot, they were just transferred to another outfit.
Q. Were there orders that American soldiers in Vietnam should have disobeyed ?
A. I don't know what the conditions were in Vietnam. I do know that in the concentration camp cases these people were seeing assaults and batteries occurring and every kind of invasion of human rights that you can imagine. And this went on over the course of a period of time. It was nothing instantaneous, where it occurred on the spur of the moment and they had to make a decision. They had a chance for reflection and everything else. So I can't answer your Vietnam question because I don't know the circumstances.
Q. You saw from close range the depravity of a nation. As that nation moves now to reunite again, are you fearful?
A. Not at all. Justice demands that there be some sort of separation of those who voluntarily participated in these wrongful acts and that large group of the impassive and unorganized that did not participate. You cannot visit the sins of the fathers upon the sons or the children. The conditions that existed in Germany that gave rise to Hitler are certainly not present in Germany today.
Q. You are not one who believes that in Germany a propensity remains.
A. Oh no, not at all. This is 45 years later. That's two generations.
Q. What should be remembered first and foremost about the Holocaust?
A. There's got to be a recognition that everybody, everybody has got to have a concept of the importance of human rights. And if there is a recognition of the meaning of human rights, then you will never have any more holocausts.

HEADLINE: Needed: A Longer School Year

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. PASCRELL Jr.; Assemblyman William J. Pascrell Jr., Democrat of Paterson, is chairman of the Assembly Higher Education Committee and vice chairman of the Education Committee.

 BODY:
AMERICANS are now working longer and harder than at perhaps any time in this century. We have to in order to compete with Asians and Europeans in the new global economy.
But while our work force is making great changes to meet the challenges of the worldwide competition, our school system is still largely mired in the ways of the past. The result is that American students are, for the most part, faring poorly in learning competition with Asian, Russian and European counterparts. 
Unless American education improves, the economic-driven life style that we have enjoyed will continue to decline. America will lose stature in the world as a desirable place to live, and multinational corporations will desert us for areas where skilled workers are more readily available.
The link between a better educational system and better economic conditions for our country is undeniable. We need a more literate, clear-thinking and trainable population if we are to continue to enjoy one of the world's highest standards of living.
All evidence, however, shows that the people graduating from our school system and entering the work force are ill prepared to handle job requirements. A recent survey of business owners conducted by Arthur Andersen & Company shows that employers have great concern about finding qualified help.
When it comes to hiring technical workers, 47 percent of the companies in New Jersey that responded to the survey said it was extremely difficult to find qualified people, while 36 percent nationwide responded similarly.
The survey also indicated that it was not much easier for employers to find semiskilled workers. In New Jersey, one of the most industrialized states in the nation, the illiteracy rate is astounding. It is estimated that there may be as many as 800,000 adults who lack basic reading skills. It is no wonder that our state's job growth prospects are dimming.
Also noted in the survey was a great deal of dissatisfaction by corporations with the New Jersey school system; only 12 percent said it was good and 52 percent said it was poor. To make up for the gaps in public education, companies are spending more and more money on remedial training for workers. Resources that should be going into research, new products and new markets are being siphoned off to pay for the job that public education should be doing.
Historically speaking, this is an ominous change in American life. Perhaps never before have we asked so much of our education system. The American way of life that we cherish so much was born in the Industrial Revolution of the mid-19th century. It was during that time, historians tell us, that America's economic efficiency was a direct result of our nation's commitment to education. It was during that time that literacy in the United States became more widespread than in Europe.
Not coincidentally, it was also at that time that the indomitable American spirit of innovation led to new inventions and new processes that would make the American work force the best in the world.
In ''The Battle Cry of Freedom,'' a book on the Civil War, the historian James M. McPherson said that New England led the world in education facilities and literacy in the mid-19th century. More than 95 percent of New England adults could read and write in 1850. Three-fourths of the children 5 to 19 years old were enrolled in school. Nearly four-fifths of the American population was literate in the 1850's, compared with just two-thirds in Britain and northwest Europe and one-fourth in southern and eastern Europe.
Without counting slaves, the literacy rate in the United States at the time reached 90 percent - equaled only by Sweden and Denmark. It was no wonder that America became the mecca for industrialization.
Americans in the mid-19th century recognized the value of education and committed themselves to it. Now, we still value education, but we don't seem to want to commit ourselves to insure that we excel at it.
In New Jersey and throughout most of America, the school day and year are relics of our agricultural roots. Children are educated now, in the post-industrial era, as if they were still needed to do summer planting and other chores on the farm.
The school year in New Jersey is still just 180 days, a far smaller number than in Japan, where the average student attends school 240 days a year. Undoubtedly there is far more for students to learn now than 50 or 60 years ago. But the education hierarchy is not providing students with more time needed to master more information.
The average child in New Jersey spends 5 hours 29 minutes a day in elementary school and that increases to only 5 hours 55 minutes in high school, when undoubtedly the students could easily handle more learning time.
Innovation is the key to our state's and nation's economic future. If we cannot solve today's problems, we will slip and America will become an also-ran in the world economy. Once prized for its success and innovation, the American school system has slipped dramatically; innovation has been replaced by huge education bureaucracies that are resistant to change.
Since becoming a New Jersey Assemblyman, I have offered numerous pieces of legislation affecting education, but none, I think, is more important than my proposal for the Local Elementary Assistance Program, or LEAP.
LEAP is simply a challenge to school districts to develop innovative and courageous plans to upgrade education at the elementary school level. I want to see teachers and administrators stretch themselves and their students to their full potential, and to see if, for once, we can get the education bureaucracy to stop worrying about teacher contracts and start devoting energy to developing programs that will challenge students to learn faster.
At the recent New Jersey School Boards convention in Atlantic City, I laid before that group a challenge to start improving education by coming up with a workable plan to extend the school year by just 20 days. That's all.
Combined with the other guidelines of the LEAP legislation, a longer school year will, I believe, produce a bold shock wave of reform throughout the educational system in New Jersey and, it is hoped, throughout the nation.

LENGTH: 1460 words

HEADLINE: Cape May Journal;
Facing the Tourist Season With Mixed Feelings

BYLINE: By MARIA EFTIMIADES

DATELINE: CAPE MAY

 BODY:
FOR now, life in Cape May is redolent of that in a small town, not a tourist haven. Streets aren't clogged with cars, and parking is as easy to find as solitude on an oceanfront jog. Best sellers still sit on shelves at the library, and there's no waiting anywhere, not at the Ugly Mug bar and restaurant, not at the Lobster House in Cape May Harbor.
But that will end with all the grace of a mudslide in less than three weeks - the start of the Memorial Day weekend.
It isn't that Cape May residents dread that weekend, when some 50,000 tourists are expected to pour into their tiny enclave at the southernmost tip of the Jersey Shore. Indeed, many say they long for the excitement of the summer, the new faces and late night activities they bring. 
It's just that life in Cape May is so pleasant in the off-season, they say. The lazy dinners at the neighbors' and gatherings in watering holes where it's easy to find a seat are friendly and familiar and very Cape May. Sometimes, they add, that's hard to give up.
But they do, and already the pace has quickened. Sounds of refurbishing echo along roads lined with stately Victorian bed and breakfasts as windows are replaced, and fresh paint - pinks and greens, yellows and blues - is readied for visitors.
Residents hover a bit longer at Keltie News on Washington Street, where everybody, it seems, shows up each morning to buy newspapers and lottery tickets and exchange gossip with John Claypool, the manager. Come June, many residents, eager to elude the crowds, will appear just once a week, stocking up on whatever they need.
''Around here in the summer, you do what you have to do before 10 A.M.,'' said Mr. Claypool, a Cape May native. ''After that you get the tour buses, the traffic, the tourists.''
 
Tours, Boutiques and Fudge
The fulcrum of activity is right outside his door - at the tourist office at the start of the Washington Street Mall, four blocks from the beach. From there, bus and walking tours to the Victorian houses operate daily. Along the cobblestone street, clothing boutiques, art galleries, the fudge shop and the drugstore are busy all day. As Memorial Day weekend approaches, many ''closed for the season'' signs on shops have come down.
Not too soon for Jennifer Wallace, who says she has never looked forward to summer more. She grew up here, and as a teen-ager she never thought she would stay. ''I was going to be out of here,'' she said. ''It just gets too quiet for me in the winter.'' But falling in love with Jerry Wallace, a title abstractor for the Title Company of New Jersey, changed her plans. So Mrs. Wallace passes the off-season months taking care of their 1 1/2-year-old daughter, Caitlin, going to Atlantic City occasionally and working as a part-time waitresss at the Ugly Mug.
She said she enjoyed the job, but added that she was unusual; many of the young people here, she said, don't work in the off-season. ''They sit back,'' she said. ''People are screaming for help in the restaurants and shops, but they do nothing until summer. Then they come alive again. It's work hard for the summer, live off unemployment all winter.''
Not if one is an innkeeper. When Patricia Stevens, two years ago, realized a decade-old dream to own a bed and breakfast place in Cape May, she also discovered it was hard work the year round. These days she is busy sprucing up the exterior of her seven-room Colonial revival, the Fairthorne. She is tending the flowers and scrubbing the pink furniture on the wraparound veranda, which faces the ocean. ''Now's the time,'' she said. It's also the time for Sam Jordan, owner of Creative Painting and Restoration, who said he had been working seven days a week lately, along with his six employees, to get houses ready for the season.
For Frank Vogel, a front-desk attendant at the Marquis de Lafayette, a sprawling 73-room hotel facing the ocean, living in Cape May is like living in two different towns. ''The off-season, that's when we get our town back - it's quiet and relaxed,'' he said. ''Then, like the flowers coming up in spring, it's one thing you can be sure of - the vacationers will come back.''
The hotel, where he has worked for 12 years, attracts mostly families and retired couples in the winter, running at about 40 percent capacity. In the summer, it's usually close to 90 percent filled.
''You get people looking for a quick escape, or else they come down here to secure summer rentals and reservations,'' said Buddy Eager, who mans the front desk with Mr. Vogel. ''People aren't in a hurry to do much of anything this time of the year.''
Such was the mood recently at the Ugly Mug, which many young people say is an integral part of the Cape May escape. It's the place the local residents go, except in the summer when ''the yups come and ruin it,'' said Tony Oreo, a commercial fisherman.
Here, hundreds of beer mugs emblazoned with initials of sailors and Cape May residents hang from the walls. The legend, printed on every menu, says that the sailors who drank at the Ugly Mug years ago used their own mugs when returning from sea. For sailors known to be dead, the management turns their mugs backward, facing the ocean.
But mostly the Ugly Mug is renowned for its ''froth blowing contest'' every August. The rules are simple: whoever blows his or her beer froth farthest wins.
Taking a pull from his beer, Donald Swan, a chef, said the tourist season was a chance for local people to ''get a break from each other.'' In the off-season, he said, this close-knit community can go too far. ''I go to the Mug and later someone will say, 'Did you hear Swanny was at the Mug, yeah? Yeah, he was there,' '' he said. ''We all end up stepping on each other - it gets real small. Then in the summer, we're looking for each other.''
Agreeing was his friend Bettyanne Ruwell, a waitress at Water's Edge, a seafood restaurant. ''You can't lose five pounds without someone knowing it,'' she said. ''If you're pregnant, it's around before you even know, because someone works for the doctor and they got the results first.''
Mr. Swan, who was a chef at a Cape May restaurant, recently moved to Devon, Pa., but expects to make the two-hour drive to Cape May often to visit friends. On this trip, he headed straight for the Ugly Mug.
What happens to the Mug in the summer is ''unspeakable,'' said Karen Frank, a training specialist for the Frank Company, a family-owned business that runs dozens of movie theaters on the Jersey Shore. That's when the ''shoobes'' emerge. ''They're the ones who come down and disturb us,'' said Ms. Frank, who lives in nearby Margate.
The term ''shoobe,'' Cape May people say, derives from Philadelphians who come to Jersey Shore towns with everything they need - sunglasses, swimsuit, suntan lotion - fitting into a shoebox.
Ever captain of her good sense, Ms. Frank knows that the shoobes are pretty important to Cape May, especially in her business.
Indeed, at the Cape May movie theater recently, there were a few tense moments by the entrance. The off-season policy requires five tickets be sold in order to show a movie. On this evening, with five minutes to go, there were just three - and not a shoobe in sight.
A couple, arm in arm, arrived in time. The fivesome took in ''Driving Miss Daisy.''
Stopping off recently in Cape May for a night were Heinz and Bette Lenz, who were on their way home to Annapolis, Md., where Mr. Lenz is a professor of physical education for the Naval Academy. They said they paid less than $40 a night for a big room with an ocean view, plus breakfast.
''Our friends wonder why we go to the Carribean in June and places like Cape May in winter,'' Mrs. Lenz said. ''They don't understand. No crowds, no hassles, and it's cheaper.''
 
Advantages of an Uncrowded Beach
Besides, the Lenzes have a special interest in off-season resorts -they met in one. It was 20 years ago on a beach in Grenada. ''If the beach had been crowded, we never would have found each other,'' Mr. Lenz said. ''I guess that's why we like the off-season.''
At the Cape May Library, summer is ''double duty or triple duty,'' said the librarian, Linda Smith, a former teacher and Cape May resident since 1973. Several hundred visitors a day drop in, often to pore over books on Cape May's history and architecture. Local people appear less frequently. ''They come in and say, 'I guess all the good books are gone,' '' Miss Smith said.
But one stalwart can't be driven away, not even by shoobes. Summer or winter, Rusty, a marmalade-colored cat, is usually sleeping on reference books or observing the checkout process. Rusty, Miss Smith said, looks forward to summer. ''That's what he loves best, next to food,'' she said. ''People.''

PUB-DATE: May 6, 1990,

SECTION: Section 12NJ; Page 1, Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1639 words

HEADLINE: Jobs Program for Students Is Lagging

BYLINE: By PRISCILLA VAN TASSEL

 BODY:
A JOBS program that was supposed to place 10,000 urban high school graduates into upwardly mobile positions by 1992 is falling far short of its goal, prompting state officials to re-examine the program to see if it can be structured more effectively.
Although the program will continue at least through the next fiscal year, plans to expand it have been shelved, and many school districts are worried that they will no longer be able to participate.
When ''10,000 Graduates . . . 10,000 Jobs'' was first announced in 1987, it was seen as an innovative approach to increasing the supply of entry-level employees while providing a strong incentive for students to complete high school. But overly ambitious projections on participation, restrictive eligibility guidelines and a lackluster response from business and industry have made it all but impossible for the state to meet its goal. Still, state officials are hopeful that they can salvage the program. ''One of the options would be to discontinue the program, but I don't believe that's a viable one at this point,'' said Dr. Lloyd J. Newbaker Jr., an assistant commissioner with the State Department of Education, which is sponsoring the program in cooperation with the State Department of Labor. ''There's a lot of promise to the project.'' 
The program's lack of success is a setback to the urban education platform of Thomas H. Kean, the former Governor, who once described the initiative as the first step to ''a lifetime of successful employment'' for many students. Guidelines called for 1,000 seniors to be placed in full-time jobs upon graduation last year, with 2,000 more students receiving jobs this spring, 3,000 next year and 4,000 in 1992.
But of the 1,500 students to sign up for the program last year, only 534 completed the requirements and received jobs. This year 1,206 seniors have enrolled in the program, with about 800 expected to get jobs.
Although the program was originally conceived for seniors who were neither college-bound nor enrolled in a vocational or cooperative program, it was expanded this year to include students in lower grades in high school and some seniors with marginal academic records who say they intend to continue their education.
To qualify for a job, students must have completed all requirements for high school graduation, including passing the High School Proficiency Test. They must also maintain a minimum 92 percent attendance record, demonstrate good citizenship and complete a 40-hour training course to learn good work habits.
The $10 million program includes a coordinator in each of the 27 participating high schools and ''private sector coordinators'' throughout the state who find jobs for students completing the program. The Department of Education has asked schools to come up with a minimum of 50 placements each year, resulting in a placement cost of roughly $1,000 a student.
But the restrictive eligibility requirements have left a small pool of students to draw from. Last year, none of the 21 participating schools except for those in Elizabeth were able to recruit 50 students, and in some of the smaller districts, making 50 placements is a virtual impossibility.
Of the 129 seniors enrolled at New Brunswick High School this year, for example, all but 25 are excluded from the program because they are either college-bound or enrolled in vocational programs.
''I made it known that there is no way I can come up with 50 students,'' said Peggy Dulin, the program coordinator for the New Brunswick school system, who is worried that her school will be dropped from the program.
For the nearly $28,000 the state paid to cover Ms. Dulin's salary and expenses last year, five New Brunswick seniors completed the program requirements, of whom two decided to go to college and one moved out of state. One of Ms. Dulin's two students to be placed in a job has already been dismissed.
Part of the poor turnout statewide is attributed to the decision by some of New Jersey's largest school districts, including Newark, not to participate in the program because of financial reasons. State subsidies of as much as $50,000 a year for individual schools are to be eliminated over time, leaving the district to pick up the expense of operating the program.
The program's attendance requirement has been an obstacle for students and businesses alike.
''We have a hard time selling 92 percent to business and industry, to be honest,'' said Russell Betz, who runs the program at Snyder High School in Jersey City, where 30 of the school's 104 seniors to enroll in the course this year have dropped out, mostly because they have missed too many days of school. ''If you're present only 92 percent of the time on your job, you're not going to last long.''
 
Details of Finding a Job
Much of the 40-hour training course is taken up with the details of finding and maintaining a job, from learning how to write a resume to coping with criticism from supervisors and co-workers.
''For the most part, students do very well academically, but it's the social end of working - being dependable, getting to work on time or calling in when they're not going to show, or handling constructive criticism or employee conflict - that they need help on,'' said Nedra Clark, coordinator of the program for Montclair schools.
But businesses have also criticized the program's lack of technical training, and more vocational education will probably be included in the curriculum in the future.
''We've got to do a better job equipping these general students with a more vocational-type program,'' Dr. Newbaker said. ''At least that is what employers have been telling us.''
Another problem has been the inherent conflict between a lengthy in-school training program and typical hiring practices.
''The business community has been reluctant to commit jobs long term before the job opening occurs, because their need is usually more immediate,'' said Robert Guadagnino, director of the Department of Labor's Division of Employment and Training. ''This was something that might not have been identified before the program was developed.''
As a result, the Department of Labor has recommended the incorporation of an apprenticeship program into the jobs program where students could gradually make the transition from school to the workplace. The department also wants the 40 hours of training to be substantially expanded.
 
Poor Timing Cited
State officials believe that the timing of the program's announcement was in large part to blame for its slow start. Shortly after the program was announced, the Department of Education's Division of Vocational Education, which administers the program, was rocked with a scandal involving charges of misuse of state and Federal funds, leaving the division in chaos and many programs unattended. Plans are under way to enlist business and industry in the department's future efforts to market the jobs program.
The economic climate has also changed since the program was first announced. In 1987, the economy was robust, and an increasing number of unfilled openings were anticipated, but the recent downturn has meant fewer jobs and greater competition.
''When you're dealing with an expanding economy, the job opportunities are greater, but with the leveling off of the economy here in New Jersey, the preparation of those students should be more intensive so they are competitive,'' Mr. Guadagnino said. ''That's where the difficulty is and focus has to be.''
 
Not 'Just Flipping Hamburgers'
In describing the jobs graduates of the program would receive, the Commissioner of Education, Dr. Saul Cooperman, stressed that they would be upwardly mobile and not ''just flipping hamburgers.'' But some state officials are privately expressing disappointment over the quality of the jobs students have received. Sales, clerical and blue-collar positions constituted 76 percent of the jobs last year, with an average wage of $5.84 an hour.
In Holmdel, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company hired 10 students for summer internships last year, mostly in clerical positions. None were hired to a permanent position because of a hiring freeze.
''We're talking low-level positions,'' said Cynthia Prescott, A.T. & T.'s staff manager for college recruiting. ''They would need much more training to move out of those slots. They were not jobs with permanent full-time potential.''
A lack of coordination between the Departments of Education and Labor has compounded the program's difficulties. Last year, for example, the Department of Labor hired a private-sector coordinator for Jersey City schools who did not have a car or find any jobs for students by graduation day. Over the summer, school officials scrambled to find suitable employment for the students.
 
Overcoming a Poor Start
Despite the paucity of students and businesses participating in the program, state officials believe that it has value and will grow in popularity once it is better established. They point to the disappointing start of similar programs in Baltimore and Boston, which have now been revamped to include more involvement from business and have begun to turn in more promising results.
For many coordinators, the most unfortunate aspect of the program is its name.
''The worst thing they could have done was to put a number on it,'' Mr. Betz said. ''For one thing, it signifies a beginning and an end. What do you do when you reach 10,000? Do you disband it? And if you don't make it by 1992, they'll turn around and call it a failure.''
There have been reports that the program's name will be changed, but Dr. Newbaker has played down that possibility.
''I don't think renaming the project is going to make it stronger or significantly alter it,'' he said.

SECTION: Section 10; Page 9, Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1326 words

HEADLINE: FOCUS;
U.S. Trying Lease-Purchases on Its New Buildings

BYLINE: By CHERYL KENT

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
An office building under construction here is the first of a dozen Federal projects throughout the United States that will use a development method that involves long-term leases rather than outright purchases of new buildings the Government commissions for its own occupancy.
A proposal for a new Federal building is approved by Congress and the Treasury issues bonds to pay for it; the lease system - sometimes called ''lease-purchase agreements'' - also needs Congressional approval.
Private developers who compete for these projects may, depending on the circumstances, do everything from assembling the site and arranging financing to managing the completed building. The Government rents the entire building for the life of a 30-year lease with its total rent calculated to pay for the building's purchase and its construction financing. At the end of the lease, the Government gains title to the property. 
Critics say the system is more expensive than the usual technique and disguises Government property purchases.
Stein & Company, a 19-year-old Chicago concern, won the Federal office project in December 1988 and is now putting up the building, which is scheduled for completion in mid-1991. Its $153 million bid included assemblage, design, project financing, construction costs and managing the property. Stein also has developed parking garages, suburban office complexes and, more recently, the 60-story A.T. & T. Building and several other downtown Chicago office towers.
The agreement was the first of its kind signed by a developer and the Government, but others are being negotiated. Lease-purchase agreements are being used most aggressively by the General Services Administration, the Government's real estate and procurement agency, which owns about 10 percent of all Federal buildings and about 40 percent of its office space. Other Federal agencies own the rest.
Congress has approved the use of lease-purchase agreements for 10 G.S.A. buildings at sites across the country. Besides the Chicago project, these include two buildings for Foley Square in New York City, amounting to a gross area of 1.6 million square feet; one building in Atlanta and two in Chamblee, Ga.; one each in San Francisco and Oakland, Calif.; one in Tacoma, Wash., and one in the District of Columbia.
The method is being taken up by other agencies as well. Lease-purchase has been adopted by the Office of the Architect of the Capital to build a new judiciary building in Washington, and the Pennsylvania Avenue Development Corporation, a small agency created during the Kennedy Administration, is using it to develop the International Culture and Trade Center there.
''No one has a greater penchant for developing a cookie-cutter approach than the Federal Government,'' says Patrick Keogh, program director for Lease Construction, a two-year-old department within the G.S.A. that manages lease-purchase projects. ''But we have learned something different from each one and a standard could be stifling.''
In Chicago, developers proposed the site as part of the package. For the lease-purchase office project in Oakland, the site has already been chosen by the G.S.A. The selected developer will help execute the contract for the property. In the future it is unlikely that lease-purchase agreements will combine financing and building costs, as was the case in Chicago. Instead, developers will submit those costs separately.
Whether lease-purchase goes any further than the approved projects is uncertain. Lease-purchase agreements are causing a furor at the Office of Management and Budget, where there are questions about how the property acquisition should be accounted for and suspicions that the agreements are dodges to conceal acquisitions and rental payments.
Last summer, that office and the G.S.A. came to an agreement permitting the latter to proceed on an experimental basis with lease-purchase. But recent testimony by the deputy director of the Office of Management and Budget, William Diefenderfer, before a subcommittee of the Senate Committe on the Environment and Public Works, suggests that the agency has had second thoughts.
''These accounting gimmicks join the dozens of others in masking the true size of the Federal deficit, thus understating our future financial obligations,'' Mr. Diefenderfer told the subcommittee on March 20.
He said the interest rate the Government would have to pay on Treasury bonds was 8 to 10 percent less than financing rates available to developers in the public sector. But supporters of lease-purchase say the technique will prove more economical in the end.
The hope is that it will produce buildings faster and more efficiently than Government-managed procedures allow, said J. David Hood, director of the planning staff at the G.S.A. offices in Chicago. ''The theory is that the sequence of construction can be collapsed using lease-purchase,'' he said. ''The developer won't have the design executed down to the last gnat's eyelash - the way we would have to - before putting a project out for bid.''
The agency is also counting on winning bidders to complete them in less time and for less money than Government agencies would. ''The potential advantage of a developer is that he will be creative and more in touch with the industry than we can be,'' Mr. Hood said. ''As a bureaucratic organization, it's hard for us to be on the leading edge, it's hard for us to reward risk-taking.''
Using either Treasury bonds or the private market to finance construction is less expensive than short-term leasing of office space at market rates. According to the Office of Management and Budget, leasing costs 83 percent more than using direct funding.
Among the instances in which lease-purchase developers may enjoy an advantage is in the buying of property. The Government cannot get bargain prices because, to compensate for the power of eminent domain, its opening bid has to be the fair-market value as assessed by an independent appraiser.
In Chicago, Continental Bank, the former owner of Stein's one-third-block site, initially asked $32 million. After negotiations, Stein was able to buy it for $22 million.
''Public projects are not notorious for being on time and on budget,'' said Mr. Keogh of the G.S.A.. But in Chicago, he said, ''the Federal office project is going along very well'' and is ''on schedule and on budget.''
Now 35 percent complete, the 27-story building is going up on the southeast corner of Jackson and Clark Streets. It will expand the Federal Center complex just across Jackson where there are two office towers and a post office built between 1964 and 1975. The complex was designed by Ludwig Mies van der Rohe. Mies students head the Chicago firm of Fujikawa Johnson and Associates, which designed the new building to be compatible with the original ones.
The new building will add about 600,000 square feet of office space to the complex's 1.6 million. All told, the Government has six million square feet in Chicago - two-thirds owned, the rest rented.
Originally, the new building was meant to accommodate all of the Environmental Protection Agency's local offices. Now, the agency will occupy roughly 60 percent of the space while retaining 15,000 to 25,000 square feet of its current offices across the street. Other tenants will be the Departments of Agriculture and Housing and Urban Development and the Social Security Administration.
Profit margins for Stein & Company are less than they would be for a fully leased speculative office building, but so is the risk. Lease-purchase offers developers the certainty of a fully leased building in an office market that is becoming increasingly competitive nationwide. Its investment is repaid in rent over the life of a 30-year lease.
''Our only profit is if we build for less than we bid,'' says Bernard Freibaum, a senior vice president and chief financial officer for Stein & Company.

PUB-DATE: May 6, 1990,

SECTION: Section 12WC; Page 38, Column 1; Westchester Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1274 words

HEADLINE: Purchase Campus Plays Host to Broadway Stars

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN

DATELINE: PURCHASE

 BODY:
Since the middle of March, the State University of New York at Purchase has been astir with the sounds of a big, splashy musical. That was when rehearsals began for ''Kiss of the Spider Woman,'' and now the well-known theatrical names connected with the show have become familiar figures on the campus here.
Among them are the director, Harold Prince; the composer and lyricist team of John Kander and Fred Ebb; the playwright Terrence McNally, and the actor John Rubinstein.
The public performances began last Tuesday at the Performing Arts Center on the campus and are to continue through June 24. Its residency begins a projected four-year alliance between the university and a newly formed commercial producing organization called New Musicals. Three additional musicals have been scheduled for this first season, which will continue in the fall at the Performing Arts Center. 
 
Laboratory for New Work
''A college campus that has a conservatory of the arts is a sound and appropriate place - a laboratory - to test new work,'' said Christopher Beach, who took over in October as director of the Performing Arts Center. Traditional theater terms like tryouts, workshops, previews and opening nights are being avoided by the producing organization, which maintains that the question of whether ''Spider Woman'' is Broadway bound is not an issue.
''This is not, strictly speaking, a Broadway-oriented show, though it should provide the transfusion Broadway needs,'' said Mr. Prince, whose career spans ''The Pajama Game'' (as co-producer in 1954) and ''Phantom of the Opera'' (as director). ''Here is a place to work as I've always worked. It's ironic how that place used to be Broadway, but the economic pressures imposed by astronomical production and operating costs are such that we all cave in.''
Sheldon N. Grebstein, the college's president, described how he hoped the arrangement would benefit the school and its neighbors: ''This connects us to the creative process and gives us a new cultural and intellectual resource for the region. That should put SUNY Purchase more vividly and emphatically on the cultural map. There are still people who drive by here but don't visit us. We'd like to change that. We've never had anything like this before.'' A community interest in musical theater came to Mr. Beach's attention during ''coffees'' that he instituted last October. These are informal post-dinner meetings in various homes in the county. They are set up by the Prompters, the Performing Arts Center's volunteer organization and attended once a week by Mr. Beach, Rachel Thompson, the Performing Arts Center's marketing director, and Carol Saltzman, the coordinator of volunteers.
New Musicals has been in the works for five years, said its producing director, Martin J. Bell. He described it as a plan to reinvigorate the American musical theater by developing new works in proximity to Manhattan, but at a remove from the city's pressures and labor costs.
The search for a suitable theater site included visits to Astoria, Queens; Stamford and Morristown, N.J., Mr. Bell said, adding that those places were rejected, respectively, because of union problems, inadequate stage space and limited parking space. There was interest in the Purchase campus three years ago, Mr. Bell said, but it was thwarted by scheduling conflicts at the Performing Arts Center concerts and by what he felt was the university's lack of interest in ''outside groups.''
But as ''Spider Woman'' began to materialize, Mr. Bell returned in October, this time with Mr. Prince, who recalled saying, ''This is exactly what we've been wanting to build and it's here already. How can we interest them? We're not not-for-profit.''
The arts center's new director, Mr. Beach, ''found a way to work with us and schedule around events,'' Mr. Bell said. New Musicals is paying $600,000 a year for the Performing Arts Center spaces, which include newly converted offices for the staff members of the organization, which also has offices in Manhattan.
''We're providing them with a home,'' Mr. Beach said, ''but we said that we've got to tie everything into the academic environment - to our undergraduate music, dance and theater programs. And they said, 'Great.' '' Mr. Beach cited as examples the possibility of seminars, master classes and student internships, as well as open rehearsals so that the university's students could follow the developmental process.
Even though ''Spider Woman'' settled in here after mid-semester, Mr. Prince has already conducted classes in musical theater direction and certain groups attended various dress rehearsals of the musical. Next semester, the educational aspect of New Musicals will be more structured,'' Mr. Beach said.
 
A $10 Million Budget
Mr. Prince said: ''We're going to make ourselves accessible to the campus and take students through the process. That's how I learned, by observing first-hand people exercising their craft. This will be good for everybody. We're doing our damnedest to resuscitate the musical theater. I want to go back to when it was terrific.''
New Musicals is financed by investors, including four corporations: Capital Cities/ABC, Columbia Artists Management, Jujamcyn Theaters and NAC Productions. The investors have provided $2.5 million of the first season's $10 million budget; ticket sales from the four shows are expected to generate $6.4 million. Other corporate sponsorships, merchandising and concession sales are expected to make up the remainder.
''They convinced me this is not a get-rich-quick venture out to make quick bucks,'' Mr. Beach said. ''but that it's to develop new works and give them a chance to grow.
Mr. Grebstein added: ''We are not producing New Musicals; we are hosting it. They're coming in self-contained and paying their own way. We just hope we can sustain this. How are we going to deal with it? We don't know how it's going to feel, but we think we know how it's going to work.''
Anne F. Zimmerman, general manager of New Musicals, said: ''Our concern was how to develop a show and not spend $7 million. We were able to make deals for reduced costs for the SUNY engagement.'' These included, she said, arrangements with suppliers like Show/Tech of Norwalk for scenery and Pro Mix of New Rochelle for sound, as well as with local musicians and stagehands.
''Kiss of the Spider Woman,'' in the 1,372-seat Theater A, is based on the 1979 novel by Manuel Puig that became a film in 1985. It concerns two men incarcerated in the early 1970's in Buenos Aires: a homosexual window dresser convicted on a morals charge (played by Mr. Rubinstein) and a revolutionary who has incited factory workers (Kevin Gray).
Mr. Kander and Mr. Ebb, perhaps best known for ''Cabaret,'' which Mr. Prince directed, wrote the score. Mr. McNally (''The Lisbon Traviata,'' ''Frankie and Johnny in the Clair de Lune'') adapted the book. Mr. Prince described the show as ''a surreal musical with political overtones, but it's also about people reaching out over a vast distance.''
The season's other shows are to be ''The Secret Garden'' (Oct. 23 through Dec. 23); ''My Favorite Year'' (Jan. 8 through March 2) and ''Fanny Hackabout Jones'' (March 19 through May 18). ''Spider Woman'' is budgeted at $1.5 million. The other shows ''are in the neighborhood of $750,000 to $900,000,'' Ms. Zimmerman estimated.
''We're hoping a show will find itself and an audience here,'' she said. ''This is our opportunity to make mistakes and corrections, and then have an afterlife. And that way we can recover costs.'' For ticket information, call 1-800-669-1619.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Harold Prince, the director, top, and the composer and lyricist team of John Kander, far left, and Fred Ebb. Theater A, above, at the Performing Arts Center. (Rachel Thompson)

SECTION: Section 12CN; Page 1, Column 3; Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1058 words

HEADLINE: Builders Trim Bids on Public Projects

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
WHEN the State Department of Transportation sought bids earlier this year for repairs to the Saugatuck River bridge on Route 1 in Westport, officials expected to pay $11.8 million for the work. But the low bid, from the George A. Tomasso Construction Corporation in New Britain, was 24 percent lower than that, $8.9 million, said Susan Reynolds, a spokeswoman for the department.
State and municipal agencies are reaping many similar savings from Connecticut's construction slowdown. As other work dries up, contractors are scrambling for public works projects. 
''Within the last year when we had any kind of construction project, we've been getting 10 to 15 bids,'' said Danbury's purchasing agent, Warren W. Platz. ''Before, we considered ourselves lucky when we got two or three.''
''We're actually getting calls from contractors who want to know if we're putting anything out to bid,'' Mr. Platz said.
Public works projects, said Richard F. Piotrowski, Deputy Commissioner of the State Department of Public Works, ''are really the backbone of construction in Connecticut right now.''
He said that his office had expected to pay $12 million to $13 million to build 300-bed prison dormitories in Niantic and Enfield but that the bids came in at $8 million. The estimate for putting in fire-protection equipment at the State Armory in Hartford was $700,000, he said, but the bid was less than half that, $339,000.
''Those are extreme examples,'' Mr. Piotrowski said. ''But we're getting bids that are routinely 10 to 30 percent below our estimates.''
While millions of dollars are being saved on state and local capital projects, the savings will not help resolve the budget deficits that state and municipal officials have been struggling to close. Capital projects are paid for with bonds, over 20 years. Thus, while the lower capital costs will mean lower interest payments in coming years, they will have no immediate effect on budget balancing.
 
As Much Work as Possible
But because the price is right now, Mr. Piotrowski of the State Public Works Department said, his agency is putting more work out to bid. Last year, he said, his department sought bids for $85 million worth of work. In the first nine months of this fiscal year, he said, it had put $129 million worth of work out to bid.
''We want to get as much work out this year as we can,'' Mr. Piotrowski said. ''First, to keep these contractors in business, to help the economy, and second, because we're getting such good prices right now.''
Henry Fusillo, the estimates manager for Tomasso Construction, the company that is rebuilding the Saugatuck River bridge, said contractors are cutting things close to win work.
''Any company would, of course, like to get more money for a project,'' Mr. Fusillo said. ''But with 15 or 20 bidders on each job, you have to go as low as you can possibly go and hope to get through until things get better.''
Mr. Fusillo said that while contractors' bids have shrunk, ''costs never go down.''
''You just have to find more efficient ways to do the work,'' he said. ''That's the only way to survive in this market.''
One measure of Connecticut's sluggish construction market is the number of housing permits issued. For March, only 391 new housing units were authorized, a drop of more than 33 percent from last year to the lowest March level in 10 years, State Housing Department figures show.
Commercial real estate development has also ground to a halt, a result in part of financial problems at banks in the state which have largely curtailed lending.
Mr. Platz said a contract for a waste-water treatment plant in Danbury was let earlier this year for $59 million, about $2 million less than expected.
''That doesn't sound like a big savings,'' he said. ''But it wasn't too long ago that all projects were coming in over estimate. It takes so long to get a bid package together, by the time you put it out to bid, the estimates are usually low because of inflation.''
Mr. Platz said that on a contract put out last month, for a water-and-sewer project in Bethel, engineers had estimated the cost at $1.2 million, but the town received 12 bids and paid 20 percent less.
 
Bids 'From Everywhere'
State Transportation Commissioner J. William Burns said the construction slowdown could not have come at a better time for the state's 10-year, $5.5 billion repair program for roads and bridges, which began in 1984.
The program's early years were spent planning and designing hundreds of road and bridge improvements. Construction is now starting on many of them, just in time to take advantage of the savings.
''Contractors are coming from everywhere - Massachusetts, New York, New Jersey,'' Mr. Burns said. ''One of the companies that will do the Charter Oak Bridge in Hartford is from the Midwest, and they've never even tried to get work in Connecticut.''
Mr. Burns said the replacement of the Baldwin Bridge over the Connecticut River on Interstate 95, connecting Old Saybrook and Old Lyme, had been expected to cost $99 million. The low bid was $93 million, he said, and all the bids came in under the estimate. ''These firms are capable, technically and financially, to carry out the projects,'' he said.
Mr. Burns said the slowdown in the construction trades also means more workers are available for state projects. Consequently, some projects are being finished ahead of schedule, which keeps drivers happy, he said.
''We've got the time and the money to get more projects done during the program,'' Mr. Burns said. ''The timing has been just great.''
So far, 19 bridge-repair projects have been added to the infrastructure program.
Mr. Fusillo said that as a contractor, he was concerned that the sudden competition for Connecticut projects could cause companies in the state to lose work to competitors from New York and Massachusetts.
''But the amount of work that's out to bid in Connecticut is sufficient so that all these companies can get a share,'' Mr. Fusillo said.
And Mr. Piotrowski said he has his staff going over each bid to make sure there are no problems that might crop up later.
''You always run the risk, when the price is so low, that you'll have problems when you get into construction,'' he said. ''But we haven't run into it so far. And with some caution, we shouldn't.''

HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;
Soviets' Price On Germany

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, May 6

 BODY:
If the opening session of the ''two plus four'' talks made one thing clear, it was that the real bargaining would be not between the victors and losers of World War II, but between a fairly unified West - now including both a prosperous West Germany and a democratized East Germany - and a battered, weakened and troubled Soviet Union using one of its last levers of power in Europe to exact the highest possible price for its final exit from the scene.
That was clear in the blend of carrots and sticks offered by Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, who staked out a tough posture in his formal comments, which were made available only to Tass and the East German press agency, and assumed a conciliatory stance at a subsequent news conference.
But it was probably more evident in the extent to which he went in his remarks to the closed gathering of foreign ministers. In his speech, he took pains to convince the other participants that the unification of Germany had a significance for the Soviet Union beyond the technical and logistical problems that the ministers had come to Bonn to discuss. 
''We are not talking about Germany alone,'' he said at one point. ''We are not resolving only German problems. What we are talking about is the final termination of the division of Europe.''
''We are dealing here with an issue of special importance to Soviet people, to our whole society,'' Mr. Shevardnadze declared later, invoking the 20 million Soviet dead in World War II. ''Neither this nor any other Soviet leadership could disregard public opinion. The Soviet people must see that the line under the past is being drawn in a just and worthy manner.''
There was almost a plaintive character to these assertions, as if Mr. Shevardnadze wanted to impress on the West how difficult and fateful was the endorsement that Moscow was being asked to give.
 
A Bargaining Session
The venue was the opening session of the two-plus-four talks between the two Germanys and the four victorious powers of World War II - the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France - on clearing away remaining obstacles to German unification.
The process was initially intended as a way for the victorious powers to arrange for the return of a chastened and reunited Germany into the family of nations. Instead, it has evolved into bargaining over the price for Moscow's withdrawal from the scene.
It was this dimension that Mr. Shevardnadze seemed to underscore. In being asked to sign off on German unity, he seemed to say, Moscow was in effect being asked to sign off on the vast influence, power and prestige it had won through the war and maintained by military power for four decades.
In the end, the core issue, as one tired Soviet journalist put it after a long day of speeches and news conferences, was, ''What do we get for getting out?''
The price was certain to be the object of hard bargaining in coming months, involving not only the Soviets and the Germans, but all the Western powers as well. At stake were ''reliable guarantees for the stability and security for decades to come,'' as Mr. Shevardnadze put it.
 
Looming Over the Summit
The issues were likely to loom large over Mr. Gorbachev's summit meeting with President Bush beginning on May 30 and over continuing arms negotiations, most notably the Vienna talks on conventional arms and the Geneva talks on strategic weapons.
Diplomats say Moscow's concerns are of three sorts.
One is the political problem outlined by Mr. Shevardnadze: that the Soviet Union, and in particular its army, could not countenance the surrender of territory won through such sacrifice unless the Kremlin could show that it had received something worthwhile in return.
Mr. Shevardnadze's invocation of this problem, however, was not entirely guileless. Most Western diplomats discerned a thinly veiled threat that unless the West came through, the liberal forces now in power could be replaced by something considerably less favorable to Western interests.
The second area of Soviet demands is deemed to be economic. Specifically, Moscow wanted assurances from West Germany that it would provide concrete assistance to the Soviet economy.
Before the two-plus-four talks, Mr. Shevardnadze met with Chancellor Helmut Kohl, and one area reportedly under discussion was that a united Germany would fulfill the long-term contracts between the Soviet Union and East Germany. East Germany supplies 40 percent of all farm machinery to the Soviet Union, 40 percent of its cosmetics and medicine, 30 percent of imported clothing and an untold amount of military equipment.
Moscow would also like West Germany to increase scientific and technological cooperation. The Kremlin presumably would also want a united Germany to assume at least a large part of the expense of keeping whatever Soviet troops remain in Germany for a transitional period.
The third area of concern is probably the most problematic. The evaporation of the Soviet bloc has roused anew the historic Russian fear of being excluded from Europe, and in seeking a new ''security order,'' Moscow will be certain to demand a role for itself.
That is where East and West are most likely to clash, and where the Germans will come under the sharpest pressure.
The United States and other major NATO countries have made it clear that they would like a united Germany to remain in NATO. Mr. Shevardnadze made it clear today that the Soviet Union finds this intolerable, and he proposed instead a center in Berlin to control all forces in Germany.
Further on, the Soviets have spoken of a new ''European security order'' based on the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, which joins 33 European states, the United States and Canada.The West German Foreign Minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, has expressed similar proposals, but other Western leaders have been reluctant to consider any immediate attempts to supplant NATO.
The bottom line in all this is whether the Soviet Union has any real bargaining power left.
Moscow's only real weapon, diplomats believe, is to try to delay the process of unification. Mr. Shevardnadze, however, seemed to take pains to reassure the Germans that even if there were ''serious differences,'' these ''need not be dramatized.''
At the same time, he declared that the Soviet Union would agree only to a ''package approach,'' adding, ''Nothing is agreed unless all aspects of unification are agreed on.''
 
Hand Is Not a Strong One
By most accounts, Moscow's hand is not a strong one. So far, the West has found an unusual degree of solidarity on the issue of unification, and a confident Chancellor Kohl did not seem likely to panic.
But there was also the sense at the talks that nobody wanted the Soviet Union to leave humiliated. That could not only affect Mr. Gorbachev's domestic position, with unknown consequences for security and stability elsewhere, but it could also derail the broader process of disarmament and liberalization.
In any case, it was clear to everyone at the talks that the process of German unity was under way. Perhaps it could be slowed a bit, but it could not be stopped.

LENGTH: 676 words

HEADLINE: Bolivian Chief to Ask Bush for More Aid on Drugs

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 6

 BODY:
President Jaime Paz Zamora plans to appeal to President Bush in Washington this week for a major increase in financial aid to help Bolivia get out of the cocaine business.
At the same time, he is expected to resist demands from the Bush Administration to use the armed forces to help halt drug trafficking. A 600-man drug police force, advised by agents of the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration, now conducts the drug fight in Bolivia.
The Bolivian armed forces have been on the political sidelines for nearly a decade now and there is concern across the political spectrum that the financial aid and power that a role in the drug fight would bring them might tempt them to eventually stage another coup. 
Although he has not yet disclosed his decision on the armed forces, the Bolivian leader is reported by aides to have plans to tell Mr. Bush when he visits Washington on Tuesday that the more important thing is to find the financing and investment to replace the ''cocaine economy.''
Bolivian and American experts say this is the most opportune moment they have seen for reorienting the Bolivian economy because the drug crackdown in Colombia and the raids on laboratories in Bolivia have driven peasants to look for crops to replace the coca leaf.
Bolivia is the world's second leading source of coca leaf, the raw material of cocaine, and is increasingly important as a source of processed cocaine as well. Drug experts say Peru, the leading source of the leaf, produces little finished cocaine, a role filled primarily by Colombia until recently.
Officials and experts dealing with the cocaine issue here have long said that priority must be given to finding substitute crops or jobs for the tens of thousands of families that make their living by growing coca in the Chapare, the tropical rain forest east of the town of Cochabamba.
Since Mr. Paz Zamora took office last August, however, his Government has broadened that position to include the need to deal with the importance of coca and cocaine in Bolivia's overall economic picture.
''Without doubt, coca provides Bolivia's principal export,'' said Samuel Doria Medina, an economic adviser to the President. ''This is not an agricultural problem. What interests Bolivia is the substitution of jobs, income and exports.''
A report by Mr. Doria affirms that coca generates some $1.4 billion a year in economic activity in Bolivia and that it leaves $600 million in the country in balance of payment terms - about the equal of all legal exports.
Mr. Doria estimated that $627 million would be needed for crop substitution and rural development over five years, plus sums to cover the lost value of the destroyed crops and balance of payments support. This fiscal year, the United States is providing $78 million in development aid and economic support in addition to financing the operations of the drug police and the Drug Enforcement Administration.
The United States Ambassador, Robert Gelbard, said that while the Bush Administration was willing to give more development aid to Bolivia, any increase would have to be based on more concrete plans than the Paz Zamora Government had yet provided.
Mr. Gelbard and other Americans challenge Mr. Doria's figures on the importance of coca to the economy.
A State Department official who asked not to be identified said a reason for the doubts is uncertainty about how much leaf is produced per hectare and the conversion rate from coca paste to cocaine base, an intermediate stage in the production of cocaine. He also said many coca growers had food crops mixed in among the coca bushes.
''The United States also believes that much of the big money from the traffickers doesn't come into Bolivia,'' he said, ''but involves only bank-to-bank transfers in places like Panama or the Cayman Islands.''
Such money, he argued, even though transferred into the offshore bank account of a Bolivian, would have little effect on the Bolivian economy aside from the payments for the relatively modest growing and production costs.
