PUB-DATE: May 7, 1990,

SECTION: Section A; Page 14, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 459 words

HEADLINE: From Bolivia, Good News on Drugs

 BODY:
President Jaime Paz Zamora of Bolivia arrives in Washington this week with startling information: The market for raw coca leaves in his country has collapsed. He considers that a powerful reason for the U.S. to speed up economic aid to help Bolivia's antidrug campaign, and he's right.
Last year, after Colombia began fighting its big drug cartels, President Bush pledged much more military and economic aid for Colombia, Peru and Bolivia. But most of the aid package did not take final shape until the ''drug summit'' meeting in January. And $230 million in military aid, only now beginning to flow, came first. 
Events in the Andes moved faster. By late last year the Colombian campaign had managed to disrupt the channels by which coca leaves were gathered in Peru and Bolivia, then transported to Colombia for final processing. As a result, coca growers suddenly found their crops hard to sell. The price for 100 pounds of raw leaves, more than $60 last summer, fell below $20, considerably less than the cost of production.
It has been hard to exploit that decline in Peru, where Maoist guerrillas control most of the coca growing territory. But in Bolivia, the decline presents a rare opportunity. The U.S. already helps the Bolivian Government with a rudimentary crop substitution program. Farmers are paid $2,000 per hectare to tear up coca and plant other crops like oranges. As long as the coca price held up, the program languished. But with the price down, many farmers now are rushing to sign up. The number of coca hectares destroyed this year already exceeds 3,000, more than in all of last year.
Surprised and pleased, Bolivia needs more money to expand the substitution program. Yet while Bolivia will receive $34 million in new military aid, economic aid remains at last year's level.
Washington urges patience: new economic aid is due with the second phase of the Andean strategy, next fiscal year. But this could be the wrong time for patience. There's powerful reason to get as much coca land as possible into other profitable crops now. The coca price could rise again if, for instance, enforcement flags in Colombia.
In any case, economic aid for Bolivia would help ease anxieties stirred by military aid. As an article on today's Op-Ed page suggests, supporters of democracy and human rights remain wary of U.S. alliances with Latin generals.
Washington professes to recognize that the Andean strategy depends on both military and economic aid. The collapse of coca prices in Bolivia vindicates that approach, and sooner than experts had dared to hope. Granting Mr. Paz Zamora's request for new economic aid now would help him seize the moment, and give reassurance that U.S. intentions in the Andes remain honorable.

HEADLINE: Defined Pension Plan Lets Worker Worry

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Prof. Eli Schwarz's paean to defined-contributon pension plans (letter, April 13) is the truth, but not the whole truth.
''Most of all,'' he states in a sentence that leaves a hole so large you could drive a truck through it, ''there is no possible imputed liability or financial risk for the sponsoring corporation, private agency or governmental unit.'' 
Unfortunately for the toiling employees, a defined contribution plan does not make this financial risk disappear. Rather, this risk is, as the physicists would say, conserved. It is transferred from the institutions to the backs of the workers. They can diligently sock away their defined contribution savings for decades. But if, at retirement, there happens to be a bear market or a major inflation, then tough beans. It is the individual worker's pension that takes a brutal kick in the teeth.
The laudable motivation of defined-benefit pension plans is to transfer (insure) some of this inescapable risk from relatively undiversified individuals to relatively diversfied institutions. If the Senators Howard M. Metzenbaum and Nancy Kassebaum of this world are serious about protecing workers and retirees (letter, April 13), let them reverse some of the recent cumulation of legislative and regulatory excesses that have hassled thousands of employers to terminate their defined-benefit pension plans.
 
BRIAN A. KENNEDY
Vice President and Treasurer
Blue Cross-Blue Shield of Illinois
 Chicago, April 18, 1990

Make Saving Pay

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Yes, Americans will have to save more if they want their industries to be more competitive (''Blame Japan? No. Save Ourselves,'' editorial, April 24).
The way to get Americans to save more is to make it worth their while. Editorials appealing for people to save are very helpful, but structuring taxes, so people will have an incentive to save, and suppressing inflation, so that what they do save is worth saving, are also important. Until Americans find it profitable to save, they won't.

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
L.B.J.'s Great Society

BYLINE: By Tom Wicker

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex.

 BODY:
''This country,'' President Lyndon Johnson once said, ''is rich enough to do anything it has the guts to do and the vision to do and the will to do.'' You'd never catch Ronald Reagan or George Bush expressing that kind of confidence in America, despite the patriotism they so fulsomely extol.
L.B.J. not only believed it, he acted on it - so enthusiastically that his ''Great Society'' program is widely considered today to have been grandiose, extravagant and a failure.
That's certainly what the Mssrs. Reagan and Bush, plus all too many contemporary Democrats, would have you believe - mostly in order to avoid domestic spending that might run up the deficit that dominates their politics. But was the Great Society really a costly failure? 
Not in the predictable but plausible view of Joseph A. Califano, a former Johnson lieutenant who was a principal architect of the program. At a symposium observing the 25th anniversary of Mr. Johnson's inauguration in 1965, he contended that the Great Society was alive and well, ''in Medicare and Medicaid, in the air we breathe and the water we drink, in the rivers and lakes we swim in; in the colleges our students attend; in the medical miracles from the National Institutes of Health; in mass transportation and equal opportunity.''
Sargent Shriver, who directed the Johnson ''war on poverty,'' concurred. Before an enthusiastic crowd at the L.B.J. Library, he listed a number of Great Society successes ''all still in existence, all helping millions of Americans today'' - Head Start, the Job Corps, community action grants, Foster Grandparents (which Nancy Reagan once proclaimed her favorite program), Upward Bound, community health centers, legal services for the poor, Vista, college work-study programs.
Mr. Califano and Mr. Shriver, as well as other Johnson Administration veterans - Bill Moyers, Jack Valenti, Nicholas deB. Katzenbach, Douglass Cater, Lee White, Charles Haar - pointed out that Mr. Johnson was the first President to take steps to enhance the environment, and that the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (proposed by President Kennedy) and the Voting Rights Act of 1965 were the high points of the civil rights movement.
''Did we legislate too much?'' Mr. Califano was willing to ask. Were mistakes made? ''Plenty of them.'' He cited inefficient payment systems for medical care, too many narrow categorical grant programs, lack of trust in the states and the middle class, too much faith in regulation, the failure ''to recognize that government could not do it all.''
But even the mistakes, he said, ''were . . . fueled by the frustration of seeing so much poverty, ignorance and illness amidst such wealth.'' Quoting Mr. Johnson, he said such mistakes were part of asking 'not how much, but how good; not only how to create wealth, but how to use it.' ''
The economist James K. Galbraith argued that Mr. Johnson had been right that the U.S. could afford whatever it willed itself to do. For all the cost of the Great Society, he pointed out, real per capita gross national product is 60 percent greater today than in 1965; and ''publicly held national debt'' is 41 percent of G.N.P. now, 39 in 1965, ''essentially the same.'' Thus, ''we are not poor, and not broke . . . we can attempt the possible, without fear of ruin.''
Nor has experience, Mr. Galbraith insisted, borne out the arguments that ''social and environmental regulation wastes resources'' or that welfare causes the poor not to work -''to the contrary, welfare clients . . . must supplement their meager benefits with work . . . in order to survive.'' Even some conservatives, he said, now acknowledge that the evidence suggests ''better welfare, not less welfare.''
A conclave of old L.B.J. hands, most stepping gingerly around the war in Vietnam (''I wasn't involved in that''), is not the place, of course, for a final judgment on the Great Society, or on Lyndon Johnson. But the gathering here did restore a useful perspective - a number of great achievements, some lasting, were registered; many Americans were given hope, help and a chance they would not otherwise have had; government was made to function powerfully and well until a divisive war shattered the Johnson ''consensus.''
It's too bad George Bush did not sit in on the Austin symposium. He might have learned something about vision and aspiration, confidence and compassion, the capacity of a President to lead, and how constricting ''prudence'' can be if that's all there is.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Tax Rise 'on the Table' in Talks on Federal Budget

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 6

 BODY:
Top Congressional leaders and President Bush reached partial agreement today on holding formal budget talks that would include negotiations on spending and on raising taxes.
Participants at the 90-minute meeting confirmed that tax increases - which President Bush has repeatedly ruled out in ''read my lips'' responses harking back to his 1988 Presidential campaign pledge - would be discussed.
''The assumption is that everything is on the table,'' said House Speaker Thomas S. Foley of Washington.
The Senate Republican leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, echoed that view. ''I don't know you can have discussions otherwise,'' he said. Asked specifically whether that meant taxes were on the discussion table, he said, ''Everything, everything.'' 
A spokesman for an Administration official who was at the meeting, held in Mr. Bush's private White House quarters, said Mr. Foley's and Mr. Dole's remarks accurately reflected the Administration views on the discussions.
 
Another Session to Come
''We didn't discuss any specific ingredients for a budget package but how to go about future talks,'' Mr. Foley said, adding that the lawmakers would meet again with the President early this week after consulting with their colleagues on Capitol Hill.
A key concern for Democrats about formal budget negotiations has been the President's willingness to make tax increases a subject of discussion.
Before the meeting, the White House chief of staff, John H. Sununu, sought to play down expectations of any breakthrough. ''We're not doing anything,'' he said.
The rare Sunday session involved Mr. Bush and Mr. Foley; the House Republican leader, Robert M. Michel of Illinois; the Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, and Mr. Dole from Congress. In addition to Mr. Bush, those attending for the Administration were Budget Director Richard G. Darman, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and Mr. Sununu.
While Democratic leaders have said repeatedly that discussions with the Administration will be essential at some point, the party is split over whether formal bargaining should come now or later in the year, after Congress has completed work on its own version of the budget and the spending bills that flow from it.
 
Wary of Political Trap
At least part of the President's motive in summoning the Congressional leaders was concern that a weaker economy and higher interest rates than the Administration predicted in January have rendered earlier White House budget calculations obsolete.
But Democrats, wary of a political trap, also see Mr. Bush's eagerness for immediate talks as an effort to short-circuit the Congressional budget process before lawmakers adopt plans that conflict sharply with his priorities.
Last week, the full House of Representatives and the Senate Budget Committee approved budget measures for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1 that seek military spending cuts far deeper than those proposed in the budget Mr. Bush sent to Congress in January. The Congressional measures, which do not require the President's signature, serve as guidelines for the spending and tax legislation that Congress must produce before the 1991 fiscal year.
Both the House budget and the one adopted by the Senate panel were approved with virtually no Republican support, and House Republicans said the President's budget was so obsolete that it was pointless to even offer it on the floor. Democrats who oppose immediate negotiations regard Mr. Bush's invitation to their leaders as an attempt to regain some control over the budget process when their party appears to have the upper hand.
 
Looking Back in Anger
As Mr. Foley and other Democrats made clear last week, one reason they remain wary of making deals with the White House at this stage is the bitter memory of last year's attempt at budget conferences between the White House and Congressional leaders. The 1989 negotiations, conducted before Congress began its own budget work, produced only a modest reduction in the deficit and led to a protracted partisan fight over Mr. Bush's proposal to cut the capital-gains tax rate.
Nonetheless, some Democrats believe that today's meeting was a signal that the President was willing to discuss tax increases as part of a larger budget deal. Representative Leon Panetta, the California Democrat who heads the House Budget Committee, said last week that negotiations were futile unless Mr. Bush was willing to put all issues, including taxes, on the table.
Despite his campaign pledge, Mr. Bush called for about $20 billion in new revenues in his January budget, with a chunk of that money coming from ''user fees'' on everything from camping in national parks to certain stock transactions and Federal meat inspections. The two Democratic budget resolutions call for the same $13.9 billion in revenue increases and $6 billion in ''user fees'' proposed by Mr. Bush, even though a number of lawmakers in both parties believe much larger tax increases are necessary. An Even Higher Deficit? Quite apart from any political maneuvering, both Congress and the Administration increasingly think the deficit for fiscal 1991 may be as much as $20 billion higher than the White House anticipated in January. That would require deeper spending cuts, larger tax increases, or both, in order to reach the $64 billion deficit level for 1991 imposed by the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings balanced-budget law.
If Congress and the Administration cannot agree on how to close the deficit gap, the law imposes automatic spending reductions that would be equally split between domestic and military programs. Just a few months ago, the Administration seemed willing to accept the automatic spending cuts on the theory that the reductions would fall more heavily on domestic programs favored by Democrats because the military budget was declining anyway.
But if the 1991 deficit is as large as many now fear, the cuts required in military spending would reduce the Pentagon budget by far more than the Administration could accept.

HEADLINE: Black-Korean Who-Pushed-Whom Festers

BYLINE: By M. A. FARBER

 BODY:
It started over some plantains and peppers, and maybe some limes.
On the afternoon of Jan. 18, Giselaine Fetissainte, a Haitian immigrant, strolled into the Red Apple, a Korean-American-owned grocery and produce store in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, in search of those items.
When she left minutes later in an ambulance, a deep-seated dispute over civility and color and economic power - a dispute that had previously damaged relations between Koreans and blacks in the city - had erupted anew. It has led to picket lines, boycotts, epithets and, without much success, the intervention of a half-dozen public agencies, including the Police Department and the Office of the Mayor. 
''Bloodsuckers!'' demonstrators chant daily through bullhorns outside the Red Apple at 1823 Church Avenue, now virtually empty of customers. ''Don't buy! Don't buy! Don't buy!'' The immediate question was what happened to Mrs. Fetissainte at the Red Apple, which is not part of the food store chain of that name, but one of a number of Korean stores on a busy commercial strip catering mostly to the Caribbean people who have recently settled in Flatbush. Was she, as she said, pummeled by store employees without provocation? Or was she, as the Koreans said, merely restrained after refusing to pay for goods and starting an argument? The larger issue is an apparently growing antagonism between Korean food merchants and black shoppers, an issue that has led to boycotts of a half-dozen Korean stores in Harlem; Jamaica, Queens, and the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn since 1984. In some instances stores have been forced out of business. In others they have survived after losing of hundreds of thousands of dollars in expected income.
Every day all over the city, blacks shop without incident at the great majority of 1,500 Korean produce stores and 500 fish markets. But in instances like the Red Apple confrontation the start-up elements are familiar: a slight or a fight, a suspicion of shoplifting, mutual indignation, cultural and language differences, demands for respect and justice - and the entry of an organized protest group. Robert (Sonny) Carson, a black community organizer who was once convicted of kidnapping, has been active in several boycotts.
Clean resolutions to these disputes have never been easy, with truces falling apart and black or Korean representatives challenging the legitimacy of others on their own side to negotiate or deliver on agreements. On Wednesday lawyers for the Red Apple obtained a court order to temporarily restrain pickets outside that store and another Korean grocery across the street. The order is being appealed, and the demonstrations continue. A hearing on the appeal is scheduled for this morning. A Special Test for Dinkins? Korean business leaders have portrayed the Red Apple case as a special test for Mayor Dinkins, who had taken part in efforts to resolve other clashes between blacks and Koreans and who campaigned last fall on a theme of uniting the city's disparate groups - what Mr. Dinkins called the city's ''gorgeous mosaic.''
''You are looked upon by many New Yorkers as a healer,'' Bo Young Jung, president of the Korean Produce Association, wrote the Mayor on March 1. ''It was under this premise that you were elected to lead our great city. What better opportunity to show your strength and ability.''
Mrs. Fetissainte's lawyer, Colin A. Moore, described her as a 46-year-old home attendant for a private agency who ''basically speaks Creole.'' She had shopped previously at the Red Apple store, said Mr. Moore. He offered this account of the incident on Jan. 18:
Around 5:30 P.M. Mrs. Fetissainte arrived at the store carrying a shopping bag that contained meat purchased elsewhere. She placed some plantains and peppers in one of the store's portable baskets, but seeing a line at the cash register, put the basket down and started to leave. Near the door she was stopped by Bong Ok Jang, the manager, who said he wanted to look in her shopping bag. Mrs. Fetissainte said he would first have to call the police. Mr. Jang then grabbed her by the back of the neck and slapped her several times on the face before she fell to the floor.
 
Very Different Accounts
Someone called the police and Mrs. Fetissainte was taken by ambulance to nearby Caledonian Hospital, where she was treated and released. Mr. Moore said his client had suffered ''trauma of the head, neck, abdomen, some contusions and now has a limp.''
Korean merchant leaders, confronted with rumors that Mrs. Fetissainte had been comatose and, as the Amsterdam News reported, ''savagely beaten,'' say her injuries amounted to a scratch on the face.
Mr. Moore's account differs from that provided by Korean groups. In their account, Mrs. Fetissainte went to the cash register with her merchandise, possibly including some limes, was told the cost was $3 and turned over $2.
Mrs. Fetissainte responded to the request for another dollar by hurling peppers at the cashier, who threw them back at her ''like a Ping-Pong game,'' said E. Michael Kang, the executive director of the Korean Produce Association. Mr. Kang said Mrs. Fetissainte spat at the cashier and began messing up register displays. Then, he said, Mr. Jang, the manager, put his hands on her shoulders to restrain her and asked her to leave. She then dropped to the floor, screaming.
As the police arrived, Mr. Kang said, the owner of the store, Bong Ok Jang's brother, Bong Jae Jang, returned from getting a haircut. Mrs. Fetissainte accused the owner of attacking her and, after being frisked and handcuffed briefly, he was given a summons to appear in Criminal Court. No date has been set.
 
'Carson's Storm Troopers'
Mr. Carson, who has been active in black community affairs, especially in Brooklyn, for more than two decades, said he was invited to help organize the Red Apple boycott by Flatbush residents.
The boycott started almost immediately and was directed at not only Red Apple but also a Korean-owned store across the street, Church Fruits. Some of the demonstrators - ''Carson's storm troopers,'' Mr. Kang calls them - say there is a business relationship between the two stores, which the owners of both stores deny. But when the incident occurred on Jan. 18, a Red Apple employee who had missed a ride home at the close of the evening was frightened and ran into Church Fruits, Mr. Kang said. For having given ''refuge,'' he said, Church Fruits was being punished.
Both Red Apple and Church Fruits have been owned by their current proprietors for two years and together employ more than 20 people. Ordinarily, Red Apple grosses $2,000 a day and Church Fruits, $7,000, the owners say. For the last three and a half months, they say, daily receipts have been $10 to $30.
At Red Apple the other day, employees stayed near the back of the narrow store, staring at the wooden floor while one worker washed the front window. ''Do a good job,'' a stalwart demonstrator, Aton Ruh, taunted from behind a police sawhorse. ''I see a little spot.''
 
'Don't Even Think About It'
Mr. Ruh turned his attention to a woman who approached the door of Red Apple. ''You know better than that, ma'am,'' he said. ''Don't even think about it.'' She walked on.
Mr. Ruh, who was born in the Bahamas and brought to Brooklyn as an infant, put down his bullhorn long enough to say that he was associated with the Flatbush Frontline Collective, ''which started this boycott,'' not with another group that, he lamented, is wrongly given credit for it. He said there could be no resolution of the Red Apple case until employees of the store were arrested and prosecuted for assault and both Red Apple and Church Fruits were shut down.
''People say the Koreans work hard,'' Mr. Carson said, ''but they don't have a monopoly on working hard in America. Nobody's worked harder than the blacks, and we didn't get paid for it.
''We are not going to tolerate continued assaults by people who don't live in our community, don't employ people in our community, don't spend in our community and don't have our best interests at heart.'' he said. ''In the future there'll be funerals, not boycotts.''
 
Store Owner Sold Out
Closings or transfers of ownership have followed most previous boycotts of Korean stores by blacks in the city -a fact not lost on the Korean leaders in the Red Apple case. ''As first-generation immigrants, we cannot be told to pull up stakes and leave whenever altercation takes place without a fair hearing,'' Sung Soo Kim, president of the Korean-American Small Business Service Center, wrote Mr. Dinkins in late January.
The first organized boycott, Mr. Kang said, began against several stores on West 125th Street in 1984 and lasted more than a year. Efforts to negotiate a settlement were made by Mr. Dinkins, then City Clerk, and Lloyd A. Williams, president of the Uptown Chamber of Commerce. The Korean store owners eventually moved elsewhere and Korean leaders rejected a proposal for a $52,000 public relations campaign by a black company headed by Mr. Williams.
Mr. Williams, in an interview last week, stressed that the vast number of Korean stores in the city have never been boycotted. He said that cultural exchanges in Harlem had helped bring Koreans and blacks together but that many Korean store owners exhibited an attitude of misplaced ''superiority'' and that when trouble arose at a store, the response of the Korean community was merely to put up a united front and wait the situation out.
A second boycott, of a Korean fish store in Jamaica, Queens, in 1986, Mr. Kang said, was settled ''within the neighborhood.''
 
'A Life of Its Own'
In 1988, Tropic Fruits on Fulton Street in Brooklyn's Bedford-Stuyvesant section was boycotted for more than four months following an altercation with a customer. A settlement was reached, but the store owner, who now drives a taxicab, sold his business. It is not clear whether the settlement, which called for printed apologies by the Koreans, Korean deposits in black-controlled banks, Korean donations to community organizations and sensitivity training, has been carried out.
Within a week of the Red Apple boycott, Brooklyn police commanders arranged a meeting of community leaders. It went nowhere, as did similar efforts by Howard Golden, the Brooklyn Borough President; Charles J. Hynes, the Brooklyn District Attorney, and others.
The Mayor's office has been particularly involved since mid-April, after Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch met with a group of Korean leaders and, during a visit to the Red Apple site, was shouted down. The Dinkins administration is believed to be opposed to any solution that would force the closing of Red Apple and Church Fruits but is uncertain who, if anyone, deserves criminal prosecution.
Mr. Lynch said this week that the protesters had rejected a moratorium and that the boycott ''seems to have taken on a life of its own.'' He said the Mayor's office, having formed a ''fact-finding'' committee of Koreans and blacks, was still engaged in ''quiet negotiations.''

GRAPHIC: photo: Antagonism between some black shoppers and Korean merchants in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn has erupted in picket lines and boycotts. Demonstrators chanted outside the Red Apple, a Korean grocery store on Church Avenue. (Vic DeLucia/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Democrats Send Connecticut Budget to Governor

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: HARTFORD, May 5

 BODY:
Democrats in the House gave final passage today to a revenue plan that takes money from two reserve funds and changes state tax laws to raise $339 million to erase this year's budget deficit and balance next year's budget without a tax increase.
The revenue plan passed on an 84-to-65 vote and now goes to Gov. William A. O'Neill, who is expected to sign it into law. Four Democrats joined the Republican minority in voting against the budget, while a lone Republican, Representative Eugene A. Migliaro Jr. of Wolcott, voted for the budget. 
The spending portion of the state's $7.05 billion budget, a separate bill under state law, received final approval in the Senate on Friday.
Total state spending will increase by 6.1 percent over this year. It is the smallest percentage increase during the O'Neill administration's nine years.
 
'It's Fiscal Insanity'
''It's difficult times, folks,'' said the House majority leader, Robert F. Frankel, a Stratford Democrat. ''But we're delivering services, and we're doing it with the smallest growth in state spending in recent history. And with no new taxes.'' During nearly five hours of debate today, House Republicans repeatedly criticized the Democrats for relying on $300 million in one-time revenue to erase this year's budget deficit and balance next year's budget.
''We're running, as an individual would, to the bank, and hitting the cash advance,'' said Representative Robert A. Maddox Jr., a Bethlehem Republican. ''It's fiscal insanity.''
To erase this year's deficit of $246 million, the Democrats will empty two reserve funds, taking $52 million from the property tax relief fund and $102 million from the budget reserve fund.
By leaving the books from the current fiscal year open into August, the plan credits $25 million in corporation tax receipts to the current fiscal year.
With other minor tax changes raising another $9 million in the current fiscal year, the state will carry a deficit of $58 million into the fiscal year beginning July 1.
In the fiscal year 1990-91 the Democrats will increase revenues by $99 million, mostly by extending the capital gains tax to out-of-state residents selling property in Connecticut to raise $10 million, accelerating payments on corporation taxes to raise $45 million and accelerating inheritance tax payments to raise $30 million.
The plan came under criticism from some Democrats, who faulted it for not overhauling the state's tax system.
The chief author of the package, Representative William J. Cibes, a Democrat of New London, also found fault with the program. ''It meets the needs of the people of the state for this year,'' said Mr. Cibes, the House chairman of the Finance Committee. ''Our real problem is not the one-shot revenues, but our over-reliance on a static tax base that does not grow, our overreliance on the sales tax, our over-reliance on a hodgepodge of other taxes.''
In addition to criticizing the reliance on one-time revenues, the Republicans have maintained that the economic assumptions behind the budget are too optimistic.

HEADLINE: Long Honeymoon for Chicago Mayor

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, May 6

 BODY:
In a city known for bare-knuckles relations between politicians and the press, Mayor Richard M. Daley spent his first months in office getting the kind of reviews ordinarily reserved for four-star restaurants.
The favorable press attention inspired a spoof in a local political cartoon, which showed a brilliant sun ascending in the sky behind the Mayor while a gaggle of reporters warbled in unison, ''Thank you, Mayor Daley.''
More recently, there have been a few brush fires, but press coverage has been overwhelmingly positive. The Mayor, who just completed his first year in office, has offered an explanation for the good press: ''We're doing a lot of good things.''
Another explanation was put forth by Alderman Danny K. Davis: ''Rich Daley and his Administration have done an outstanding job of managing the media, getting by with rhetoric and symbols rather than substance.'' 
 
Fight Over School Board
Mr. Davis and others appeared at three protests at City Hall last week over the Mayor's delay in appointing a new school board. The issue could represent Mr. Daley's most serious test.
In the past, school board appointments have provided fodder for racially charged political battles. It was Mayor Jane Byrne's appointment of two white members to the board a decade ago that sowed the seeds for a revolt among black voters, culminating in the 1983 election of Harold Washington, the city's first black mayor.
But for the most part, even Mayor Daley's critics agree that he has considerable strength and is a strong favorite to win re-election next year.
The Mayor continues to benefit from the disunity that has characterized his opposition, which rests chiefly with the black electorate. After Mr. Washington's death in 1987, black voters were divided between the two black politicians who sought to claim his legacy, and those fissures have not healed.
 
All the Familiar Problems
For Mr. Daley, the most daunting challenges are governmental, not political. Not so distant from the gleaming skyscrapers that etch the sky over Chicago's Loop, many neighborhoods are struggling. With the exception of a handful of prosperous areas being gentrified near the business district and along the North Shore of Lake Michigan, many neighborhoods suffer from poverty, inferior schools and crime.
Two decades ago, many of these areas offered good-paying, unionized jobs, which provided the fruits of the American dream for working-class families. But in Chicago today, as in many other cities, relatively few good jobs remain for those without a skill or a college education. In Chicago, where half of all students drop out of high school, that means a huge number of people eligible for little more than welfare or minimum-wage work.
In recent years, the number of black people in Chicago has surpassed the white population. But the city's fastest-growing group is Hispanic, and many Hispanic people are poor and unable to speak English. At the same time, middle-class families of all colors flee to the suburbs.
 
Stressing Better Schools
''We have got to figure out a way to get families to stay in the city,'' said Mr. Daley, sitting in the same office that was occupied by his father, Richard J. Daley, from 1955 to 1976. ''The families won't stay if the schools are not good.''
In his election campaign, Mr. Daley made education a priority. He supported the movement for changing the local school system to shift power from a centralized bureaucracy to local schools and parent councils. And he appointed a vice mayor for education, Lourdes Monteagudo.
But Ms. Monteagudo came under fire after it was revealed that her daughter was attending a private school in the suburbs because Ms. Monteagudo deemed the public schools inadequate.
And the Mayor's critics say he has not done enough to promote control by parents and local school councils. About 50 demonstrators at City Hall on Wednesday clashed with the police in a protest aimed at forcing Mr. Daley to appoint 10 blacks to a new 15-member school board.
 
Five Are Arrested
Five people were arrested, and three black reporters complained that they were roughed up by the police. The reporters said they would file charges with the Office of Professional Standards, which investigates charges of police brutality.
Mr. Daley defended the police department. ''The police department isn't out there to conduct any brutality,'' he said. ''People who want to get arrested want the publicity; people who violate the law will get arrested.''
Mr. Daley has explained his delay in appointing school board members by saying the appointments are so important that they should not be rushed.
Political foes of Mr. Daley said the clash between demonstrators and the police will help unite black political factions against the Mayor. ''He's acting cowardly and dastardly,'' said Alderman Robert Shaw. ''Many blacks feel he is trying to manipulate the board so he can control it. He certainly does not have the best interests of school children in mind.''
But other political observers said they doubted Mr. Daley would suffer. ''These were people that would be against Daley if he were reincarnated as St. Francis of Assisi,'' said Paul Green, who has written several books on Chicago politics. ''And most people in Chicago are aware of that.'' Horizon Without Vision? Mr. Daley has said that his administration is concentrating on improving the schools, but that the social and economic problems that produce inferior schools are not easily solved.
''Chicago isn't any different than other cities,'' he said, ''and I don't have a crystal ball that I can look at to find the answers.''
While conceding that Mr. Daley faces gigantic challenges, some governmental and political experts say the Mayor should use more of his political capital addressing serious urban woes.
''Maybe it's too early to judge,'' said Gary Orfield, a political scientist at the University of Chicago, ''but nothing has emerged on the horizon yet to suggest that this is going to be an administration of big vision.''
Aside from his florid face, his flashes of temper, and his occasionally creative grammar, Mr. Daley's stewardship offers a dramatic contrast from his father's. But he does share with his father an impatience with criticism. ''What ideas do they have?'' he asks of his critics.
 
Mayor but Not Kingmaker
The fabled Democratic machine that Richard J. Daley bossed for nearly 20 years was largely disassembled years ago. Court rulings long ago abolished patronage in most city jobs, which provided the machine's muscle.
Far from being a kingmaker on the national political scene, as his father was often regarded, Mayor Daley seldom makes endorsements. Unlike his father, he is not the chairman of the Cook County Democratic Party.
The younger Mr. Daley has even discounted the importance of being a Democrat or Republican, a notion that would have brought fire into the eyes of his father, a Democrat's Democrat.
''Our generation is a lot different than our parents, who came out of the Depression, and were shaped by it,'' he said. ''We don't necessarily identify with political parties or institutions.''
 
Lists Programs He Backed
Mr. Orfield and others commend Mayor Daley for appointments that demonstrate a desire to form a racially diverse government, but they urge him to speak more directly to feelings of racial hostility.
Mr. Daley bristles at such criticism. He pointed out that he sponsored an affirmative action program for city contractors. He has backed a program in which the city would sell vacant land for $1 to developers who promise to build houses for those with moderate incomes. He has ordered stepped-up attacks on rodents in poor neighborhoods.
Mr. Daley succeeded where Mayor Washington had failed and pushed through the City Council a revision of the city's housing code, long resisted by Chicago's powerful trade unions, that would allow use of plastic pipes, rather than copper, in some new construction and thus lower the cost of housing.
Mr. Daley also argues that he has demonstrated his courage by advancing plans for a new airport on the city's Southeast Side. The airport would require the demolition of hundreds of homes and has triggered an uproar among residents of the area, a mostly white section that strongly supported Mr. Daley in the mayoral race.
''It wasn't popular,'' Mr. Daley said of the plan, ''but it's the only way that area will survive. Isn't that vision? Isn't that a long-range goal?''

HEADLINE: France Regains Economic Strength

DATELINE: PARIS, May 5

 BODY:
Although German reunification worries many Frenchmen, its approach has been welcome news for the Paris Bourse and for France's economy in general.
Unification is expected to bring brisker economic growth to West Germany as it rushes to rebuild East Germany, and this will give France, the Federal Republic's largest trading partner, a powerful tug forward.
At the same time, fears that the unification process will mean higher inflation in Germany have caused many investors to flee the Frankfurt stock market in favor of the Paris Bourse. As a result, French share prices moved steadily upward in April, reaching a record high April 20, before sliding slightly. 
 
Sudden Stability
But worries about Germany were not the only reason that April in Paris became the slogan for many globe-trotting investors. Inflation worries persist in the United States, the stock market has gone haywire in Japan and a staggering attack of stagflation has mired Britain.
''Suddenly, France looks the most stable of the major industrial countries,'' said Warren Oliver, an economist with UBS Phillips & Drew, a London brokerage.
It is a vastly different picture from that of three years ago when France was dubbed ''the slow man of Europe'' because of a protracted economic malaise characterized by a subpar growth rate of less than 2 percent, unemployment of more than 10 percent and a yawning trade deficit.
France, which is Europe's second-largest economy after West Germany, owes its turnaround to some tough policies pursued by the Socialist and conservative governments in the 1980's. These policies have included clamping down on wages and tightening credit to bring inflation under control, reducing corporate taxes and deregulating financial markets.
''The greatest success of the current Government is bringing inflation down from 12 percent in 1982 to about 3 percent at present,'' said Didier Paquot, an economist with DRI Europe, an economics consulting firm.
 
Higher Growth Estimates
As the recovery in France started to flag, German unification provided a surprise push, causing many economists to raise their forecasts. UBS Phillips & Drew predicts that France's economy will grow by a respectable 3.2 percent this year, compared with a forecast of 3.7 percent for West Germany, 2 percent for the United States and nine-tenths of a percent for Britain.
As Bonn spends tens of billions of dollars to rebuild East Germany, its spending will not only spur West Germany's economy, but will also mean that the Germans will look to France for products ranging from glass to computers. What is more, as East Germans start to climb the economic ladder, thanks in part to the exchange of West German marks for East German marks, they are more likely to buy French-made Renaults and Peugeots than the more-expensive BMW's and Mercedes made in West Germany.
At the same time, France seems to be better able to capitalize on the German opportunity now than it has been for years. Economists say the seeds of France's economic resurgence were sown several years ago. Many Socialist officials now concede that the Government fueled inflation, hurt industrial competitiveness and swelled the trade deficit in the early 1980's when it allowed wages to climb and engaged in vigorous pump priming to help overcome the effects of the 1970's oil crisis.
In 1983, the Socialists sharply changed tack. They adopted a far tighter monetary policy and made a pact with labor to hold down wages. The Government's main goal was to bring France's inflation rate down to the level of West Germany's.
 
'Finally Reaping Its Fruits'
Now French officials feel like breaking out the champagne because many economists predict that later this year France's inflation rate will fall below West Germany's for the first time in decades.
''A decade-long policy of economic reform is finally reaping its fruits,'' said Mr. Oliver, the UBS Phillips & Drew economist.
After years of being ridiculed as a soft currency, the French franc is increasingly being viewed as a hard one. Not only that, as the West German mark has sunk to its lowest point in two years against the French franc, French authorities, in a reversal of roles, are talking about intervening in the money markets to defend the once-almighty mark.
For years, whenever the Bundesbank raised its interest rates to hold down inflation, the Bank of France scurried to increase its rates to keep the franc from falling against the German mark. Recently, however, France has asserted its independence.
On April 26, the Bank of France, confident about the franc's stability, lowered its key interest rate to 9.5 percent, its second quarter-point reduction in three weeks. The franc hardly budged after the announcement.
 
Moving Money to France
The cost of rebuilding East Germany and of swapping West German marks for East German marks have made the German currency look softer and the franc harder. This outlook has encouraged many bond buyers to move their money from Germany to France. As a result, the real interest rates on French long-term Government bonds, which were 2 percentage points above those of German Government bonds late last year, are now just eight-tenths of a percentage point higher.
''This is the most tangible evidence of a new optimism about the French economy,'' said Christopher Kwiecinski, an economist with Banque Indosuez.
The drop in rates is expected to help stimulate business investment in France, which many economists were already predicting would rise by more than 10 percent this year.
French investment has boomed for several years as companies scramble to prepare for the European Community's barrier-free market at the end of 1992. Once-provincial French companies are aggressively seeking business, not only on a European scale, but also worldwide.
 
Trade Deficit Narrows
Recently, France also got some good trade news: its March trade deficit was $151 million, less than a third of what some economists had forecast. This is causing some economists to predict a far lower trade deficit than last year's $9 billion. Despite the upbeat news, there are plenty of worries in France, mainly the stubbornly high unemployment rate.
There are also fears that the trade deficit could again get out of hand. The Government is encouraging people to save more, which would help hold down interest rates and would mean the French would consume -and import - less.
And as the franc gets stronger on the currency exchange markets, it increases France's competitiveness problems by making French exports more expensive. Perversely, this newfound strength could end up making France's trade deficit worse.

HEADLINE: I.M.F. Pact On Fund Rise And Voting

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 6

 BODY:
Finance ministers of the leading industrial countries agreed today on the difficult question of rankings in the voting hierarchy of the International Monetary Fund, clearing away one of the last main obstacles to an increase in the fund's $120 billion of resources.
They also decided that the increase would be 50 percent, representing a victory for the United States, which had refused to go above that figure. Most other countries had wanted an increase of at least 67 percent. The fund's managing director, Michel Camdessus, had originally called for a doubling of the capital. Before the increase takes effect, approval will be needed from the parliaments of the member nations of the I.M.F. and its sister lending organization, the World Bank. 
The meeting was held in a room in the Senate wing of the United States Capitol, the first time that has been the site of a Group of Seven gathering. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, anxious to show the ministers where American laws are made, took them on a sight-seeing tour before the meeting began.
The officials from the Group of Seven industrial nations gathered there to thrash out global economic problems on the eve of a meeting of the 152 Governments that belong to the I.M.F. and the World Bank. The Group of Seven consists of finance ministers and central bank governors from the United States, Japan, West Germany. France, Britain, Italy and Canada. Under the agreement, Japan and West Germany will share the No. 2 ranking at the agency. According to an agreement in principle also reached today, Britain and France will share the next position, but certain technical details still remain to be worked out.
The I.M.F., like the World Bank, decides policy on the basis of a weighted vote of the membership. The rankings are determined by each country's contribution, which in turn is linked to relative economic strength.
The United States, with about 20 percent of the capital in both institutions, has the largest vote. Japan, with its stunning economic growth, rose from No. 5 to No. 2 at the World Bank and had been seeking a similar jump at the I.M.F. But the situation was complicated at the fund because of Britain's longtime reluctance to cede the No. 2 spot for reasons of national prestige.
Britain's Lord Keynes provided most of the intellectual energy for the I.M.F.'s creation during the waning days of World War II.
The Government of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher decided to yield earlier this year, but then could not agree with France on which should be No. 4 after the United States, Japan and West Germany.
''We have done this to assure that the quota increase goes through,'' said an aide to John Major, Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer.
There has been broad speculation that part of the arrangement between Britain and France involves a concession by France to allow the headquarters of the new European Bank for Reconstruction and Development to be situated in London. This bank, which will make loans to spur the economic revival of Eastern Europe, was the brainchild of President Francois Mitterand of France, who wanted the headquarters in Paris.
 
German Reunification Discussed
The Group of Seven ministers also discussed the economic implications of German reunification. They agreed that there were likely to be considerable long-term benefits for the world economy.
According to a communique released tonight, the ministers said the process of German monetary union ''would contribute to noninflationary global growth and to a reduction of external imbalances.''
The ministers also said the process would ''contribute to positive economic developments in Eastern Europe, which at the same time are supported by the international community.''
There has been anxiety about the short-term inflationary impact of the union, but the West German Finance Minister, Theo Waigel, and the Bundesbank president, Karl Otto Pohl, told the other ministers today that those fears were exaggerated.
East German citizens will be able to swap most of their marks for West German marks on a one-for-one basis when a German monetary union occurs July 2.
The Group of Seven ministers held a similar meeting in Paris on April 7. At that time the concern was the falling Japanese yen, which makes Japanese goods less expensive abroad.
Although the yen has subsequently stabilized, the ministers repeated their assertion in Paris that the yen's fall ''may have undesirable consequences,'' an indication of continued anxiety.

HEADLINE: Business Scene;
Argentina's Zest For Privatization

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES

 BODY:
PRIVATIZATION, the process of turning a state enterprise into a private one, is all the rage in Eastern Europe. But perhaps nowhere in the world is it more popular than in Argentina, where the rush to sell off state companies is producing bargain-basement deals to lure reluctant foreign buyers.
The Argentine labor movement, fearing mass layoffs, had successfully resisted earlier efforts at privatization. But the spectacular failures of state enterprises in Eastern Europe have helped to produce a sea change in Argentine public opinion, one recorded in numerous polls. 
''People have jumped from thinking that state ownership is the solution for the nation's economic woes to the view that the private sector, particularly foreign companies, will somehow solve everything,'' said Juan Luis Bour, chief economist at the Foundation for Latin American Economic Studies, an Argentine research group financed by corporations.
Even the unions that represent state workers are soft-pedaling their opposition. And in this atmosphere, Congress has authorized President Carlos Saul Menem to privatize more than 30 state operations, mostly by selling them to foreign companies or granting concessions to foreigners. The biggest projects, selling the national telephone company and the state's international airline, are to be completed by the end of the year.
With the Argentine economy in disastrous shape, foreigners have shunned investment here. The gross national product is the same $2,200 per capita that it was in 1960, and the Government budget deficit is a hugely inflationary 10 percent of G.N.P. (compared with less than 2 percent in the United States). President Menem has cut public spending sharply in recent months, and this cutback has reduced both the deficit and the inflation rate. The austral, the Argentine currency, has even strengthened. But the price of less Government spending has been a severe recession.
The hope is that privatization will come to the rescue, attracting new investment to a poor but finally stable economy. The reality is that the country's stability is only two months old, a rather short track record, and foreign companies are participating in the privatization mainly because American banks have sweetened the investment pot.
The sweetener is cancellation of at least $5 billion in foreign debt as principal payment for the phone system and the airline. The $5 billion represents 10 percent of the money that Argentina owes to foreign commercial banks, and one or two banks could become part owners of the companies.
''Privatization is the healthy way to convert debt to equity, and the banks are behind the process,'' said Manuel R. Sacerdote, head of the Bank of Boston operation here. Besides, many banks believe Argentine debt is not very collectible, so why not use it for investments that might earn profits.
The phone company, called Entel, illustrates the arrangement. Entel hired Morgan Stanley & Company as its investment banker, and the offer that was finally drafted would sell 60 percent of the company for $214 million in cash and at least $450 million worth of canceled debt. The face value of that amount of debt must be a minimum of $3.5 billion in the phone company deal (and $1.5 billion in the airline deal), but if American banks were to sell $3.5 billion of the debt on Wall Street today, they would get only 13 cents for each dollar of debt, or $450 million.
Six foreign companies qualified last week as final bidders. The bidding rules conveniently prohibit them from paying more than $214 million in cash, restricting the bidding to the cancellation of additional debt, instead. The hope is that the winning bidder will go as high as $7 billion in canceled debt, or $910 million if this much debt were sold on the Wall Street market. That would be a combined cash and debt outlay of $1.12 billion to control a company whose assets were valued by Deloitte Haskins & Sells, the American accounting firm, at more than $4 billion.
The six bidders include three in partnership with banks: Bell Atlantic with Manufacturers Hanover; the Spanish national phone company with Citibank, and Italy's national phone company with the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company. The winner among them is also required to invest $500 million a year in new phone lines and equipment to satisfy pent-up demand.
Phones now take years to obtain, but the winner does not have to bring in any of the $500 million from abroad. The goal is to earn this amount within Argentina and then reinvest it. The Menem Government is allowing leeway on rate increases to help achieve this goal. But in the event of a shortfall, the penalty is only the loss of monopoly status, essentially a slap on the wrist. Competitors would not be likely to show up quickly, leaving the privatized phone company a de facto monopoly.
The foreign company would still be free to operate the company or sell to another company, or perhaps sell back to the Government. That is what the British owners of Argentina's railroads did in the late 1940's, rather than invest in modernization. The buyer then was Juan Domingo Peron, and the purchase created the nation's first huge state enterprise. Citicorpd (Citibank) Morgan, J. P.d (Morgan Guaranty Trust)

HEADLINE: Heavy Schedule of Treasury Financings

 BODY:
Treasury financings will dominate the bond market this week, as the Government begins its quarterly refunding with the auction of new 3-year notes tomorrow, new 10-year notes on Wednesday, and 30-year bonds on Thursday. Besides the quarterly refunding, the Treasury will also hold its regular weekly Treasury bill auction of three- and six-month bills today.
By late on Friday, the 3-year notes were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 8.75 percent, while the 10-year notes were offered at a price to yield 8.80 percent. The 30-year bonds were offered at a price to yield 8.79 percent. Before today's auction, the three-month bill was bid at 7.76 percent and the six-month at 7.82 percent. 
Among new Government agency securities expected this week is a $500 million issue of short-term floating-rate notes due on Nov. 8, 1990, which the Student Loan Marketing Loan Association, known as Sallie Mae, plans to price today. The notes will be priced at a spread to the bond equivalent rate of the 91-day Treasury bill.

HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe;
GERMAN OFFICIALS SEE REUNIFICATION AS ECONOMIC BOON

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 7

 BODY:
German reunification will spur economic growth in Europe and the world, and contrary to widespread expectations, should not set off more world inflation and higher interest rates, West German officials said at a global monetary conference here today. ''The stability of the D-Mark and the soundness of public finances remain safeguarded,'' Theo Waigel, the West German Finance Minister, said at the policy-making Interim Committee meeting of the 152-nation International Monetary Fund.
When the currency union goes into effect on July 2, most East German marks will be swapped for West German marks on a one-for-one basis. The initial announcement of the union provoked a rise in long-term bond rates in West Germany, an indication that the investors in the financial markets expected inflation to rise as well. 
 
Fear About U.S. Rates
With Japanese interest rates increasing at the same time, there were fears of an upward spiral that would pull up rates in the United States.
West German officials were at pains today to assert that the expectations on inflation in Germany have been vastly overstated. Government officials of other nations are coming around to that view, as are some private economists.
Karl Otto Pohl, president of the Bundesbank, said in an interview that the increase in money supply resulting from the currency union would be about 10 percent, more or less matching the added production potential of East Germany. Prices generally rise when a nation's supply of money grows faster than the total amount of goods it produces.
He also noted that it was unrealistic to assume that everyone in East Germany receiving West German marks would immediately spend them, causing a huge demand for goods, feeding inflation.
''On balance, it is realistic to assume that this will not lead to unreasonable inflation pressures,'' the central bank chief declared.
 
Little Borrowing
And Mr. Waigel, noting that West German public-sector borrowing has been running at the lowest level in 20 years, said the remaking of the East German economy should not put too much strain on the capital markets.
The German discussion came as the members of the monetary fund debated the arrangements that will lead to a $60 billion increase in the amount the fund has available to lend to poor countries.
In the debate on the quotas, third world countries expressed unhappiness that the rise would not be greater.
They are worried that the West's new focus on Eastern Europe and the huge demands on I.M.F. credits from countries weakened by years of central planning will hurt third world development.
The seven leading industrial powers, the principal donors to the monetary fund, agreed Sunday among themselves on the $60 billion level, and there was little likelihood that this figure will change, despite complaints from the third world.
Officials of other countries were also coming around to the view that German currency union would not lift inflation. A senior French official interviewed today said the Germans were developing a sound and reasonable monetary process, and ''our opinion is that it will be on the safe side.''
 
Longer-Term Benefits
A senior American Treasury official who also spoke on condition of anonymity projected considerable benefits for the longer term, including faster economic growth and prospective improvement in American trade accounts.
He noted that German trade surpluses with the United States should decline as more German output is absorbed by domestic demand and less is sold on export markets.
The short-term adjustment ''will be reasonably well contained,'' he said. ''One can depend on responsible authorities in Germany.''
Private economists were divided on the inflationary impact. Gary C. Hufbauer, professor of international finance at Georgetown University, said the earlier fear of inflation was ''really a fear of the unknown.'' He added, ''When I did my own back of the envelope calculations, I couldn't see that big a stimulus.''
Professor Hufbauer also suggested that the Bundesbank itself might have spurred the earlier fears as part of bargaining tactics. Initially, the central bank wanted to exchange two East German marks for one West German mark, warning that more generous terms could be inflationary.
 
'A New Realism'
''Now it's a done deal,'' Professor Hufbauer said, ''and what we've got now is a new realism.''
He also noted that although long-term bond yields had increased, they have been moving down for the last two weeks, an indication that market operators feel the inflation fears have been exaggerated.
But C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics, a Washington-based policy-research group, said he still believed the inflation threat was very real.
Mr. Bergsten, a former senior American Treasury official, noted that it would take some time before the East Germans would be able to match their increased income with new production and that this timing difference could mean more inflation.
In addition, he pointed out that the German economy was already at full capacity and that any new demands on it could result in price increases.
Reacting to the quota agreement, Bernard Chidzero, Finance Minister of Zimbabwe, said, ''I hope the international community will be wiser and realize that siphoning off resources in Eastern Europe will create a very dangerous situation - explosive.''
 
No Diversion Seen
Both the I.M.F. and the World Bank insist there will be no diversion of resources by these organizations, which are the principal third world lenders,

HEADLINE: BUSH EASES STAND, SAYING NEW TAXES CAN BE DISCUSSED

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 7

 BODY:
The White House committed itself today to discuss new taxes in budget negotiations with Congress but stopped short of saying that President Bush is now prepared to accept higher taxes to reduce the deficit.
Instead of repeating Mr. Bush's ''no new taxes'' pledge, the White House shifted its stance for the first time, saying it would impose ''no preconditions'' on budget discussions. The White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said the President wanted ''an open debate that is unfettered with conclusions about positions taken in the past.''
 
Merely 'a Goal'
Although the White House has always been vague on the issue of how long Mr. Bush's campaign pledge against taxes would hold, Bush aides said today that the President really only intended the pledge to last for his first year in office. After that, a senior adviser said, it would be merely ''a goal.'' 
''His interest is in stimulating the economy and keeping strong, job-oriented growth on track,'' the adviser said. ''And he approaches that goal with the idea that taxation is not helpful in the process.''
The White House was clearly trying to walk a fine line today. Despite the offer to hold discussions without preconditions, Mr. Fitzwater said Mr. Bush was not simply abandoning his oft-repeated campaign pledge against new taxes, but merely widening his options. In any event, most recent speculation about new taxes, on Capitol Hill as well as within the Administration, has focused not on higher income taxes but on other revenue sources.
 
Democrats Are Wary
Democratic Congressional leaders indicated that they would proceed with the budget talks, but they were clearly wary. A number of Democrats said they were not interested in going into budget talks that would conclude with the public impression that the Democrats proposed new taxes that Mr. Bush reluctantly accepted. ''We have absolutely no interest in asking for taxes and having a reluctant-bride President,'' a Democratic aide said.
Mr. Bush's position on taxes has softened at least partly because of growing fears that a weaker economy and higher interest rates than the Administration predicted in January have overtaken earlier deficit projections.
In January, the Administration calculated that $36 billion would have to be cut from the budget for the fiscal year 1991 to meet the $64 billion deficit target mandated by law, and it offered recommendations that it said would accomplish that reduction. But because of the changing economic expectations, Administration officials say, a greater deficit reduction -perhaps an additional $10 billion or $20 billion - will be needed to reach the goal.
Democratic lawmakers suggest that rather than the $36 billion originally envisioned by the Administration, as much as $60 billion will have to be cut, or raised in new revenues.
 
Democrats to Meet
The Speaker of the House, Thomas S. Foley of Washington, and the Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, said today that they would meet with fellow Democrats on Tuesday to explore the President's invitation, extended Sunday night, to open discussions that would lead to a budget summit.
Mr. Foley said, ''I think we have to realize there is a process here that involves the President, there is the necessity of coming to some kind of agreement with the Administration.''
The President was scheduled to meet with Republican Congressional leaders on Tuesday to discuss the prospect of budget negotiations.
Although both parties have been careful to avoid taking the lead in proposing new taxes, most discussion has centered on increasing what the Administration likes to call ''user fees,'' like the Federal gasoline tax, rather than raising income tax rates.
 
Nothing in, Nothing Out
Asked if the White House would revive the gasoline-tax idea, which was proposed last October by Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, and rejected by the White House, an adviser said that ''all the ideas are old, and all have been rejected.''
''We're not ruling anything in or anything out,'' said the adviser.
Mr. Foley and Mr. Mitchell met late this afternoon with 15 other Democratic leaders from both chambers to discuss the meeting with the President on Sunday evening. The uncommon Sunday session, initiated by the President, included Mr. Foley, Representative Bob Michel of Illinois, the House Republican leader, Senator Mitchell and Senator Dole. On the Administration side, participants included the President; his chief of staff. John H. Sununu; Budget Director Richard G. Darman, and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady.
Immediately after the meeting Sunday, Mr. Michel said: ''I don't know how you make these figures match without doing something on revenues. I don't think we're going to be talking about a small package of doings.'' Going On Separate Tracks? Mr. Foley and Mr. Mitchell said they were not ready to respond to Mr. Bush's proposal for formal budget talks until after conferring with the rest of the Democratic membership on Tueday.
One Democratic lawmaker, who asked not to be identified, said the leadership appeared to be heading toward a situation in which talks with the Administration would proceed on one track while Congress continued with its own budget work on another. ''The truth is you can't say no when the President asks you to sit down and talk,'' the Democrat said.''
The House has already approved a $1.2 trillion budget that would cut military spending to nearly $24 billion below the level recommended by Mr. Bush in January, and that would increase domestic spending above the levels sought by the President.
The Senate Budget Committee has completed its version of the budget, which also seeks deep Pentagon cuts. That measure is now ready for consideration by the full Senate if Mr. Mitchell brings it to the floor.
If the Congressional budget process were to proceed, the House and Senate would have to work out the differences in their two budget measures in a conference. The final plan, which does not require the President's signature, would then become the blueprint for individual spending and tax bills produced by other committees.
As Democrats tried today to decode the carefully crafted White House message, the strains in their own party were clear. Mr. Foley, who has been more receptive than Mr. Mitchell to the notion of a budget summit, faces opposition from House liberals who fear that negotiations at this point can only mean one thing - more money for the Pentagon than was envisioned in the budget resolution adopted by the House last week.
 
'Out of the Process'
''When the President asks our leadership to talk, they have no choice, but I'm worried that the defense number will be jacked up too high,'' said Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat who serves on the House Budget Committee. ''The reason Bush is coming to the table is because he's been out of the process for a while and because he thinks our defense number is too low.''
Mr. Mitchell, who declined today to say whether he was prepared to recommend that his colleagues enter into negotiations, faces opposition from some of his key committee chairmen, notably Jim Sasser of Tennessee, who heads the Senate Budget Committee. Mr. Sasser has argued that the budget resolution adopted by his panel last week would slash the 1991 deficit by $43 billion without resorting to accounting gimmicks or requiring tax increases beyond those proposed in the budget Mr. Bush sent to Congress in January.
Mr. Fitzwater said today the two sides were motivated to put everything back on the table by ''the anxiety over a deficit that is fighting every reduction attempt that we can come up with.''
The savings and loan bailout is also putting pressure on the deficit. A current plan involving more than 141 ailing institutions could increase the deficit for the current fiscal year by more than $50 billion. But a measure before the Senate would exempt a large amount of the money needed in the future to close sick institutions from deficit calculations under the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget balancing law.
 
Holding to a Philosophy
Mr. Fitzwater said the President agreed to Mr. Mitchell's proposal that no preconditions be set for the talks, but he did not specifically talk about the tax issue because ''his philosophy on this issue is quite well known.''
''What they did agree to was that they would not get involved in discussions about taxation or specific issues but rather to stick to the phrase of 'no preconditions' and begin an open debate that is unfettered with conclusions about positions taken in the past,'' Mr. Fitzwater said.
In an effort to develop a budget that reflects the changing priorities in defense and domestic spending, the President and the Congressional leadership have agreed to three basic operating principles, the spokesman said.
The first is that ''anyone can bring up an issue for discussion and debate.'' The second is that they keep their negotiations private ''so that we'll try to keep a little mystery in the marriage,'' Mr. Fitzwater said, and the third is that ''they will continue the process as long as they believe that it has a chance of being productive.''
