PUB-DATE: May 8, 1990,

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 5; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1671 words

HEADLINE: Japan Builds East Asia Links, Gaining Labor and Markets

SERIES: Japan's Turn to Asia; Surging Trade and Investment 0 First of two articles.

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 7

 BODY:
After having built its economic miracle on strong links with the industrialized West, Japan is now increasing its trade and investment in the buoyant economies of East Asia, creating a highly efficient manufacturing bloc in this vital region.
The shift, economists and diplomats say, represents a challenge to American companies both trying to maintain their investments in East Asia and trying to compete with the low-cost products from joint ventures of Japanese and other Asian companies. But consumers worldwide could benefit from the lower prices.
 
Plants in Several Countries
For example, six Japanese companies are now making videocassette recorders in Malaysia. Hitachi is shifting its production of some electric motors to Thailand, from which they will be exported to Japan and other countries. Japanese auto makers are also charging ahead and have built plants in several Asian countries. 
To provide the financial fuel needed to keep the new regional operations going, Japan's ''big four'' securities houses have rushed to open offices and start funds for investing in the area. The Yasuda Trust and Banking Company just purchased 20 percent of Malaysia's Pacific Bank Berhad. The seller: the American Express Bank Ltd.
For Japan, the surge of investment in Taiwan, South Korea, Hong Kong and Singapore, known as the four tigers, and the countries of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, or Asean, Thailand, Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia, Brunei and the Philippines, offers an answer to labor shortages at home, gives it a presence in fast-growing markets and possibly a way around trade barriers in the West. For the nations in the region, Japanese investment helps to fuel economic growth and bring them advanced technology they can use to improve living conditions or to make better products themselves.
And if the trends continue, Japan's trade and investment ties to East Asia will eventually rival the country's economic links to North America.
Economists say Japan will not soon be able to replace the United States as a market or as a center for investments.
 
Potentially Faster Growth
But by strengthening its bonds with other East Asian nations, Japan is tying its fortunes to a part of the world that offers potentially faster growth than the West. In addition, Japanese success there could limit the effect on Japan of any protectionist measures taken by the United States or European countries.
Japanese companies are going beyond just pouring more capital into Asia and tapping its lower-cost labor. The Japanese are also moving to a new level of sophistication by transforming the region into a manufacturing base with the flexibility to switch among different plants and to alter products quickly to meet shifts in consumer demand. In doing so, the companies are also cultivating budding markets for advanced goods.
In short, the bonds between Japan and the other East Asian nations are no longer as simple as rich countries exploiting the natural resources and cheap labor of poor countries.
''In the Asia-Pacific region, economic relations can no longer be characterized in traditional North-South terms,'' said a report by the East-West Center in Honolulu, a Government-supported organization that studies links between the industrialized West and the economies of East Asia. ''By any measure, the explosion of intra-regional trade and investment of the 1980's is exceptional,'' and the trend of mutual technological and financial dependence ''promises to continue into the 1990's and beyond.''
 
American Influence Waning
As Japan's influence in the region gains momentum, America's is clearly waning. The East-West Center's report concluded that the United States will buy fewer products from the region and will supply less investment capital.
The East Asian economic integration promises to yield some unanticipated side effects. For example, if the United States does open Japan's domestic markets further to foreign goods, the real beneficiaries will probably be other East Asian manufacturers, many of them aligned with Japanese companies, rather than American companies.
''People may not like it, but Asian countries would benefit more from an open Japan than the United States,'' said Jun Tsunekawa, assistant director of the Asian research division at the Japan External Trade Organization, a Government body. ''That is the market they are becoming more integrated with. They will begin the real opening of Japan.''
But there is also concern in the region about Japan and its strength. The concern goes back to Japan's brutal record of repression in much of Asia during World War II, in part to support a Japanese strategy to dominate what it called the Greater East Asia Co-Prosperity Sphere.
 
'Welcomed and Feared'
''It will take some time for people to feel more secure and comfortable with us,'' acknowledged Michio Mizoguchi, who in February was named Japan's Ambassador for Asia-Pacific cooperation. ''Japan is welcomed and feared.''
Japan's direct investment into Asia - mainly to buy land, build factories and acquire companies - quadrupled since 1985, to about $5.6 billion in the year that ended in March 1989. That was more than double the direct investment from the United States. Japan's overall trade with the United States last year, $141.4 billion, just edged out its total trade with Asia, $138 billion, but the Asian trade is growing faster.
Japan imported more from the other Asian countries last year, $49 billion, than it did from the United States. The trade flows within Asia were nearly double Japan's total trade with the European Community.
 
New Range of Operations
Some of the investment is an expansion of previous operations. For example, more and more elements of semiconductor production are taking place at plants in Thailand and Malaysia.
But there are also some new twists. The Japanese car manufacturing and assembly plants can ship parts and components to one another. Engines and electrical equipment might be made in Thailand, transmissions in the Philippines, steering assemblies in Malaysia. The result is a completed car, assembled in any one of several East Asian nations.
Most of these cars are sold in East Asia, but some may be exported to the United States or Western Europe. They never pass through Japan and thus do not add to Japan's trade surpluses with the rest of the world.
 
Transforming the Region
Techniques like that are transforming the region into a highly flexible manufacturing base. Plants can quickly shift production to two-door cars from four-door models, for instance. Or a plant in one country can pick up the slack from another, while maintaining low costs. The process is regarded as a model of how investment and trade ties are pulling the region tightly into Japan's economic orbit.
It has also meant that when Asian countries do threaten to become unstable, as China and the Philippines have in the last year, it is easy to continue production elsewhere without much interruption.
One sign of the growing prosperity that regional integration is bringing is that Australia, which long resisted identifying itself with Asia because of its European roots, is now more concerned about being left out of the boom.
''We now see ourselves as part of the Asia-Pacific region, but we have to work hard to make sure we remain a part of it,'' said Jeff Scougall, counselor in the Australian Embassy here.
Yoshio Suzuki, vice chairman of the Nomura Research Institute, described an increasingly common view here about a profound shift in global economic balance. He said the postwar Pax Americana is giving way to a tripolar structure, in which American economic domination of Asia and Europe is yielding to three spheres in which a regional power will dominate - Germany in a newly opened Europe, Japan in Asia, and the United States in the Americas.
 
Clear-Sighted Policies
Mr. Suzuki said that Germany and Japan were developing clear-sighted policies on how to build up the less-developed areas in their regions -Eastern Europe for Germany and Southeast Asia for Japan - while the United States was spending more time lamenting its loss of influence than on articulating a new strategy for developing the Americas.
In a darker vein, other Japanese warn that growing protectionist pressures in the United States and the unification of the European Community in 1992 will create a ''Fortress Europe'' and a ''Fortress America'' that will block access by Japan. In this view, the cultivation of Asia is not an option for Japan, but a necessity.
Initially, the attraction of these Asian countries for both Japan and the United States was cheap labor and a source of raw materials. That is still largely the case. Wages are still just 20 percent of those in Japan and Singapore. Japan has an acute labor shortage, encouraging Japanese companies to move factories elsewhere in the region.
While the East Asian countries welcome the factories, many complain that Japanese companies are not transferring manufacturing and other technologies to the region fast enough, and that the prosperity brought by Japanese investment ends up in too few hands.
 
Effective Counterbalance
Yet despite the growth of the Japanese role, few in the region are eager to see much more erosion of American influence in Asia. Some Asian officials see the United States as an effective counterbalance to Japan, and some Japanese see the United States's presence as a means of lessening fear of Japanese domination and designs. All sides see its involvement in the region as a way of insuring that American markets remain open to Asian exporters.
''There's a danger that with the convulsions in Eastern Europe, the United States might have its attention diverted,'' said Mr. Mizoguchi, Japan's Ambassador for Asia-Pacific cooperation. ''We can only hope the United States will not lose interest in this area.''
NEXT: Thailand's remarkable boom and Southeast Asia's future.

HEADLINE: Taxes and Political Peril

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 7

 BODY:
Most people in Washington now think some kind of tax increase is inevitable, and the holdouts, President Bush included, are finding it harder and harder to hold the line as the deficit soars.
But no one wants to take the responsibility for doing the deed. In the politics of placation that prevails in the capital these days, with officeholders determined to conform to the wishes of the electorate, it is considered political poison to advocate higher taxes. That's what the opinion polls seem to counsel; that's what politicians deduced from the defeat of Walter F. Mondale, the Democratic Presidential candidate in 1984, after he discussed a tax increase. 
Hence Mr. Bush's unvarying refrain, in the 1988 campaign and ever since: ''Read my lips: no new taxes.'' Hence the Democrats' far less catchy but equally determined resolve: Never again will we give you Republicans an opening to attack us as the party that taxes and taxes, spends and spends.
Now Mr. Bush has agreed to listen to talk about higher taxes, if not to join in, and the Democrats are looking for a way to take part in that conversation without winding up as the ones who always have to raise the subject. Both sides, in other words, are more preoccupied with covering themselves politically than with solving the fiscal problem. Both would probably settle for a no-fault tax increase, if such a thing could be devised in the dead of night.
Unfortunately, virgin births are every bit as rare in Washington as they are anywhere else.
Complicating the political calculus even more is the Chicken Little problem. Every spring, people say that if serious work isn't done on the deficit the sky will fall. But it hasn't yet, and that reduces the pressure to act.
The President was driven to initiate negotiations by the growing deficit, which includes a political threat almost as severe as that posed by seeming to renege on his promise to hold the line on taxes. Instead of needing a deficit reduction of $36 billion to meet Gramm-Rudman balanced-budget targets for the fiscal year that begins this Oct. 1, as originally calculated, the White House and Congress may have to come up with $45 billion or more, Richard G. Darman, the director of the Office of Management and Budget, has said, or even $55 billion or $60 billion, in the view of some leading Democrats.
 
Campaign Considerations
Mr. Bush would shrug off that problem at his peril, not only because of the Gramm-Rudman constraints but also because of the effect of deficits on interest rates. Sustained high interest rates, some Presidential political strategists believe, could topple the economy into recession just when Mr. Bush was mounting his re-election drive in 1992. ''That frightens me more than anything else I see on the horizon,'' one White House planner commented today.
But how do you square a tax increase with the campaign pledge - indeed, the whole political ethos that George Bush has projected to the nation?
Representative Bill Frenzel of Minnesota, the ranking Republican on the House Budget Committee, suggested one ploy this afternoon: Things change, he said.
''There isn't any President who hasn't tried to make good on his promises,'' said Mr. Frenzel, who is retiring at the end of this term and can state his views in these matters with more candor than some. ''There's no President who hasn't lived through times that change, and maybe outdate some promises.''
 
Watching Out for a Duck
But most Republicans are wary of that idea. Far better, several White House tacticians have been saying in recent days, to try to raise more money through something that could be credibly labeled a ''user fee'' rather than a tax, defining the problem out of existence in order to avoid a political pitfall.
Doing that might run into trouble because of the definition supplied by Mr. Darman when asked at his confirmation hearing to explain what was a tax and what was not: ''If it looks like a duck, walks like a duck and quacks like a duck, it's a duck.'' The Democrats have developed sharp eyes for webbed feet.
If, as some Republicans were suggesting today, the President's chosen ''user tax'' was an increase in the gasoline tax, he might have difficulty beyond terminology. Gasoline taxes have never been popular on Capitol Hill, and they are especially unpopular with Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, the potent chairman of the Finance Committee.
 
Casting an Eye on California
Both at the White House and on Capitol Hill, politicians are going to be watching closely the result of a vote in California on June 5. A ballot initiative would lift the cap on state spending for transportation and permit an increase in the state's gasoline tax. The current tax is one of the lowest in the nation, the California road system is falling apart, and the state's entire political establishment, including top Republicans and Democrats, agreed to the compromise that put the initiative on the ballot.
''It's a very close fight,'' said William Schneider, a political scientist at the American Enterprise Institute, ''and it's going to send a very important signal. The big question is, 'Is it safe yet to talk about taxes?' ''
Voters in New Jersey, Illinois and Texas have signaled at the polls in various ways in recent months that it still isn't. If the California electorate confirms that judgment, the prospect of a deal in Washington that includes both spending cuts and tax increases may prove as illusory as ever.

HEADLINE: Topics of The Times;
Left High and Dry

 BODY:
It turned out to be a lovely weekend in New York, much to the astonishment of the weathermen. There was barely a trace of the three inches of rain that some thought would deluge the metropolitan area. For all the ostensible science (''barometric pressure,'' ''relative humidity''), forecasting the weather seems approximately as accurate as forecasting the economy.
Perhaps weather forecasting has gotten too scientific, what with computers and satellites and tropical depressions. What's wrong with heeding the ache in grandpa's leg or, Heaven forbid, looking out the window?

HEADLINE: 'Bonfire' Protest Recalls 'Fort Apache' Solution;
Belated Outrage

 BODY:
To the Editor:
On the day that the protest over the portrayal of the Bronx in the upcoming movie ''Bonfire of the Vanities'' reached its peak, the New York City Board of Education was making a valuable effort to address a serious and related issue.
This was the day when Schools Chancellor Joseph Fernandez led scores of authors, artists, civic leaders and other New Yorkers into school-based libraries around the city to read to children. The purpose was to strengthen literacy skills by instilling an appreciation of literature. The Read Aloud Program sponsored by the Board of Education will ultimately be a stronger voice against the perversion of the image of poor people than recent political protests. 
What makes the book and the movie versions of ''Bonfire of the Vanities'' offensive is not simply the depiction of poor black and Hispanic people. It is also the fact that the book was published and the movie is being made in a vacuum that shrouds what is largely cultural wasteland in which, despite some notable exceptions, countless literary works by nonwhites are unpublished or poorly promoted.
If published, adequately promoted and read, these works would provide a view of the inner city that is much more authentic and much less disparaging than what is to be found in Tom Wolfe's book. Another problem is that wonderful stories written by award-winning African-American authors like Walter Dean Myers and Brenda Wilkinson about young people who are not white, not economically privileged and not criminals fail to be promoted beyond the young adult market. Apparently it takes nothing less than the vision and the resources of a black superstar like Oprah Winfrey to bring a black adult novel like Gloria Naylor's ''Women of Brewster Place'' to prime-time television. But for the most part the fault lies equally with the purveyors of culture, the consumers of culture and the now avid defenders of the cultural integrity of places like the Bronx.
Where was the hue and cry against the portrayal of black and Hispanic people when ''The Bonfire of the Vanities'' was a best-selling novel? Part of the problem is, of course, that most publications have very few black and Hispanic literary critics. But aside from this, why did so few African-American and Hispanic publications even print reviews of the book? The feeling was evidently that as printed matter the negative depiction of blacks and Hispanics didn't matter. An appropriate slogan for this mind-set might be: ''If it's written down, we don't even frown. But if it reaches the screen, then we get mean.'' But of course this was wrong; the book was just the beginning. And as far as unfortunate depiction of minorities goes, the motion picture may not be the end.
Those who belatedly apply their outrage to the movie ''Bonfire of the Vanities'' are not entirely wrong for doing so. But they should be prepared to fight even more diligently on quieter fronts long after the film is forgotten. Advancing the causes of literacy and literature will first of all enhance the educational growth of black and Hispanic people. And it will also help to fill the cultural void in which stereotypes have started and flourished.
 
WILLIAM H. BANKS JR.
Director, Harlem Writers Guild
 New York, April 26, 1990

HEADLINE: Don't Judge Zaire by European Standards

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your April 21 editorial comparing President Mobutu of Zaire to Nicolae Ceausescu, the late Romanian dictator, falls into the error of judging African political culture by European standards.
The two regimes cannot be compared. Nor can President Mobutu's opposition to a multiparty system be understood without reference to the traditional African political system of consensus-building through dialogue, which some scientists call existential as distinct from the dialectics of adversarial democracy. It is a view shared by, perhaps, the majority of Africa's leaders, who fear that multi-party democracy will only lead to the resurgence of tribal divisiveness. That danger is nowhere more acute than in Zaire with its 220 ethnic groups.
It is surprising that a campaign against President Mobutu is under way at a time when the country's human rights record has shown appreciable improvement and when President Mobutu has opened a dialogue with individuals and organized groups, such as the churches, with a view to giving the country's political structures greater openness and responsiveness to public needs and desires.
As for American aid, the United States Agency for International Development closely supervises the funds allocated for projects in Zaire to make sure they are being properly expended.
 
MOSHE LESHEM
Tuckahoe, N.Y., April 23, 1990
 The writer was Israeli Ambassador to Zaire.

LENGTH: 751 words

HEADLINE: FOREIGN AFFAIRS;
The Weight of Mexico

BYLINE: By Flora Lewis

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY

 BODY:
One local paper said 10 million people had come to the capital to see the Pope, who arrived Sunday. It's conceivable. Some Mexicans say the country's population is now 90 million. Nobody can be sure.
When I lived here in the 1950's, the population of the capital was 2.5 million, and of the country 25 million. The rate of growth approached the limit but nobody was particularly worried. The country's only demographer told me that development would soon bring a balance, and he cited the U.S. as proof that rising living standards brought a lowered birth rate. 
Now at last the rate is dropping, but the population is still soaring, and standards are falling. Mexico will enter the 21st century with 100 million or more. Population is like a supertanker: it goes a long way before attempts to slow it take effect.
There have been huge efforts to expand education, health services, roads and such, but human misery is spreading much faster with the deluge of children, many abandoned.
The writer Carlos Fuentes, who refuses to live in Mexico City, has written a book called ''Christopher Unborn,'' about a child whose birth date will coincide with the 500th anniversary of Columbus's discovery in 1492. He will breathe fecal dust because only a third of the city's sewage is treated, and have a high level of toxic lead in his blood, which can cause mental retardation.
Thirty-five years ago you could ride a horse through scattered villages in the valley or up the empty hillsides, with the majestic volcanos on the horizon as the guiding landmark. Now the volcanos have disappeared into the acrid, slurpy air. These are the key problems underlying Mexican-U.S. relations. There's no place to go but north, and no matter how stringent the border controls, the human tide will overwhelm them unless this country becomes livable for more of its people.
According to an opposition politician, Mexico has to import 10 million tons of grain a year for survival, at $3 billion, consuming two-thirds of the value of its oil exports. Jesus Gonzalez Schmal, a moderate in the right-wing party PAN, argues that the country could feed itself again with proper agricultural policies and better cooperation with U.S. industry.
Like everybody else, he is indignant at the abduction for trial in the U.S. of a doctor charged with involvement in the torture-murder of an American drug enforcement agent here. But like many, he is worried about the drug traffic's impact on the society and says the doctor should have been arrested here and extradited.
Mexico is changing, with the rest of the world, but painfully, perhaps catastrophically slowly. President Carlos Salinas de Gortari is moving to liberalize the government-dominated economy and encourage investment. He is popular. But officials don't have much of an answer to the question why foreigners should have confidence to invest when Mexicans send their money abroad, more than enough to cover the whole debt.
The Pope's visit reflects some of the change. When he last came, 11 years ago, the Government refused a reception and he convoked a church conclave where he denounced liberation theology. This time President Salinas welcomed him formally at the airport, and the Pope's message was solidarity and social justice. But still nothing about population.
This country is another example of shifting perceptions about creating a society that offers its people a fair chance, and how much harder it is to repair the damage of bad government than to recognize it. The tendency to blame Yanqui imperialists is waning, but sensitivities about the weight and arrogance of gringo neighbors remain acute. The invasion of Panama reopened old wounds.
The U.S. cannot escape the fallout of Mexico's desperation. Neither can it intervene in the clumsy, shortsighted ways it has in Central America. The opposition leader on the left, Cuauhtemoc Cardenas, says the country has the resources and capacity to pull itself up if it had rule of law and honest government.
He is a nationalist who rejects U.S. hegemony, but he doesn't want to isolate Mexico or go for central planning. He hasn't quite got the message from Eastern Europe, but he does oppose authoritarian government and puts democracy first.
In this part of the world, it seems the U.S. hasn't quite got the message from Eastern Europe either. It's freedom, to be sure, but also out from under big brother. Mexico is in a bad way, too, and needs a sympathetic partner, not a neighborhood boss.

HEADLINE: Bass Family Gives Yale $20 Million for Ecology Institute

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN, May 7

 BODY:
The Bass family of Fort Worth, Tex., gave Yale University $20 million today to establish an Institute of Biospheric Studies that will greatly expand the university's research into environmental issues.
''The gift powerfully enhances Yale's capacity to meet its responsibilities for academic leadership in an area of the utmost importance to the future of humanity and of the Earth that is our home,'' Yale's president, Benno C. Schmidt Jr., said at a news conference announcing the gift.
The donation, which came from the Bass Foundation and the Philecology Trust, was presented by Edward P. Bass, who graduated from Yale in 1968 and also studied architecture at the graduate level there.
Mr. Bass, 44 years old, is a rancher and venture capitalist, and one of the heirs to the billion-dollar Bass family fortune originally made in Texas oil. He is also a director of the World Wildlife Fund, the New York Botanical Garden and the Jane Goodall Institute for Wildlife Research. He founded the Philecology Trust in 1986 to help non-profit ecological programs. 
 
Yale Improving Science Programs
''The future of life on this planet urgently requires the most sophisticated research and teaching to increase our understanding of the biosphere in all its complexity and diversity,'' Mr. Bass said.
Yale is well known for its strong undergraduate liberal arts curriculum and its law school, but in recent years Mr. Schmidt has made improving its science programs a priority. The 289-year-old school has 5,132 undergraduates and 5,643 graduate students.
''We will be the best in this area, I have no doubt,'' said Mr. Schmidt, who approached Mr. Bass a year ago to propose the creation of the institute for study of the biosphere -the zone of the earth, from the oceans and crust to the atmosphere, that supports living organisms.
 
Renovated Laboratories Planned
The Institute for Biospheric Studies will be formed principally from the university's departments of natural sciences, biology, geology and geophysics and the School of Forestry and Environmental Studies.
The gift will be used to renovate laboratories and classrooms, endow professorships and partially finance the directorship of the university's Peabody Museum of Natural History.
About $5 million will go toward the renovation of the university's Osborn Memorial Laboratories, which will house the institute's central facilities for biological sciences. Other Yale departments that will be involved in the institute include the School of Epidemiology and Public Health, its Law School, its School of Organization and Management and its Center for International and Area Studies.
Besides coordinating research and teaching on the biosphere throughout the Yale campus, the Institute will develop close ties with other institutions, like the New York Botanical Gardens, the Smithsonian Institution, the American Museum of Natural History and other universities and environmental organizations.
''In our increasingly crowded and polluted biosphere, man's future on earth depends as never before on an understanding of ecology,'' said Arthur W. Galston, the Eaton Professor of Botany.
The largest single gift to Yale was made in 1966. Paul Mellon, a 1929 graduate, contributed his $35 million art collection and $12 million to build the Yale Center for British Art.
Other large gifts to Yale include nearly $17 million in the 1920's from John W. Sterling, used for professorships, scholarships and buildings, $16 million from Edward S. Harkness in 1930 to build Yale's residential colleges and $15 million from John Hay Whitney in 1970.
The largest gift to a single institution is believed to be the $105 million that Emory University in Atlanta received in the 1970's from Robert W. Woodruff, the former chairman of the Coca-Cola Company.
 
Columbia and Spelman
Other recent large gifts include $25 million pledged to Columbia University in 1987 by John W. Kluge, the founder of the Metromedia Company, and $20 million donated to Spelman College in Atlanta in 1988 by the comedian Bill Cosby. The figures cannot be directly compared, of course, because inflation means a dollar in the 1920's was worth far more than a dollar today.
The Bass Foundation was founded by the Bass family in 1945 to support arts, cultural and conservation projects. Mr. Bass said the family expects to make several more donations to Yale over the next year.
Mr. Bass is the chairman of Space Biospheres Ventures, which is the developer of Biosphere II, a commercial research project in Tuscon, Ariz. It is a 2.5-acre closed system including a tropical rain forest, savannah, marsh, desert and marine zones, with human habitats and agricultural areas.
Mr. Bass's father, Perry Richardson Bass, graduated in 1937 from Yale's Sheffield Scientific School.

HEADLINE: Pine Barrens Lawsuit Halts L.I. Builders

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIDGE, L.I., May 7

 BODY:
A lawsuit seeking to limit development in the pine barrens of Suffolk County has halted construction in much of eastern Long Island since November.
Environmentalists say a delay in construction within the 100,000 acres covered by the suit is justified to protect Long Island's environment and fragile water supply. They want the towns of Riverhead, Brookhaven and Southampton to study the cumulative environmental impact of all projects proposed within the central pine barrens before any individual project can move forward.
Developers, already hurt by a softening housing market, say the suit has all but halted business in a large area of Suffolk County. In addition, they say the delay is driving up the price of housing in one of the few areas where moderately priced housing was being built. $3 Billion Amid Pine and Sand ''The construction industry on Long Island is already in a recession, and this is like the icing on the cake,'' said Phil Reed, president of Orr Associates, a small development company based in Miller Place. The towns are barred from granting permits to developers in the central pine barrens while the suit is pending. 
The environmental study would be a huge undertaking, encompassing 238 pending projects worth $3 billion in the pine barrens, an area of sandy soil and pine trees atop much of Long Island's underground water supply.
''The premise is to plan first and build second,'' said Carolyn Zenk, the lawyer for the Group for the South Fork, an environmental organization.
But environmentalists also hope the suit will force developers to sell their land to the county under a conservation program in which the county dedicated one-fourth of 1 percentage point of its sales tax to buy environmentally sensitive land. The total sales tax in the county is 7.5 percent.
The developers, who supported the program when it began in 1987, say the county should not buy up land just because the environmentalists tell them to. There is an orderly way to acquire land, they say; they predict dire consequences if too much land is removed from the tax rolls.
 
Water Competes With Housing
''The thing that troubles me is that you have two valid public purposes at conflict here,'' said Jim Morgo, president of the Long Island Housing Partnership, a nonprofit group that develops affordable housing. ''These are the protection of the ground water, but also the providing of housing to people who can't afford to live anywhere else.''
The Suffolk County Executive, Patrick J. Halpin, said the conflict represented a search for middle ground between the environment and the economy, between land preservation and development. He said that although he was in sympathy with the environmentalists, ''Affordable housing is a legitimate concern. We have to strike a balance.''
''We have to be concerned about the cumulative impact of development in the pine barren region,'' Mr. Halpin added, ''but whether or not the way to accomplish that is through a lawsuit is subject to a lot of debate.''
For Mr. Reed, the lawsuit means simply that his future is uncertain.
His project in this Brookhaven community is modest: 15 units of housing, each priced at about $140,000, off Exit 68 on the Long Island Expressway. He received final approval on the project just days before the suit was filed.
 
Investment Is in Limbo
But his property is within the boundary covered by the lawsuit, and Mr. Reed found, to his dismay, that the suit prevented the town from acting on his application for a building permit. Now the project, and his investment, are in limbo. He, the towns and other developers have filed motions to dismiss the suit; the next court date is Friday.
Environmentalists say a cumulative impact study is crucial to Long Island's water supply, which is drawn from aquifers beneath the pine barrens.
''You don't build first and then find out you need to save the land afterward,'' said Richard Amper, executive director of the Long Island Pine Barrens Society, which brought the lawsuit.
Developers estimate that they have spent more than half a million dollars fighting the suit, and they say they cannot estimate the damage done to people in the construction industry who were left idle this spring. They say the unintended result of the suit will be delays that drive up the price of housing. #10% Price Rise Is Predicted ''I think this has caused untold millions of dollars in damages throughout the county,'' said John N. Prudenti, a lawyer seeking to build 176 units of housing to sell for under $200,000 apiece in Manorville.
Even if the suit is thrown out, or his project is removed from it at the next court date, Mr. Prudenti said he will have lost important months, with his money tied up in the project.
''It will probably raise the cost of the overall project, and the cost of the homes, about 10 percent,'' he said. ''It was our intention to keep the cost of the homes as low as possible.''
Builders and environmentalists disagree over how important the pine barrens are to the economy's future.
Michael A. LoGrande, executive director of the Association for a Better Long Island, a developers' group, said that many of the best proposals for affordable housing involved the barrens.
 
Housing Threat Is Disputed
''Most of the projects are condominiums, and not single-family homes on sprawling acres,'' he said. Many of the homes covered in the lawsuit would sell in the $135,000 range, he said.
But environmentalists say that many of the projects include only a few units of affordable housing, and that the developers are trying to blame them for a general slowing of the market.
''Development is generally slowing down on the Eastern seaboard, and the development community wants a scapegoat,'' Ms. Zenk said.
Mr. Amper said that regardless of how small the projects were, their total impact must be considered.
''The folks that want to build four houses probably aren't hurting a thing,'' he said. ''But there are 238 projects, and it seems certain that the construction of all will have an effect.''
 
Environmentalist Blames Towns
Ms. Zenk said she was sympathetic to the small developers' problems, but that the fault lay with the towns, not the environmentalists.
''It's unfortunate that the Government didn't work earlier to have an environmental plan in place,'' she said.
But Donald G. Partrick, president of the Long Island Builders' Institute, said of the environmentalists: ''They would just as soon see grass grow over the Long Island Expressway.''
The tension between the environmentalists and the developers was evident last month when Suffolk County agreed to pay $17.8 million for Hampton Hills, a 1,400-acre parcel in the pine barrens that had been the proposed site for 307 condominiums.
Environmentalists applauded it as the county's single most important acquisition. But developers said it was a waste of money because the project would have clustered the housing on 200 acres, and the developer had promised to donate the remaining 1,200 acres to the county.
Mr. Halpin said he hoped the two sides could seek a compromise. ''The real challenge will be not to allow the whole issue to become so polarized, and dragged out in the courts so long, that the only people who benefit are the lawyers,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Historian Links Birth Order To Innovation

BYLINE: By DANIEL GOLEMAN

 BODY:
COPERNICUS, who shattered traditional cosmology by contending that the Earth revolves around the Sun, was the second of four children. His bitter opponent, Tycho Brahe, was an only child.
Charles Darwin, whose theory of natural selection overturned traditional views of the creation and evolution of life, was the fifth child of six and Alfred Russell Wallace, the co-discoverer of the theory, was the last of six children. But George Cuvier, an upholder of the creationist view, was the first child of four, as was Louis Agassiz, another opponent of Darwin.
Frank Sulloway, a historian of science who proposes that birth order makes a startling difference in the progress of science, is himself the third of four children. 
Dr. Sulloway cites the roles played by these and thousands of other scientists as prime evidence for a provocative theory: researchers who challenge established views tend to be born later in their families while those who support the status quo tend to be firstborns.
His proposal comes at a time when the idea that birth order makes any difference in behavior is under fierce attack by social scientists. Despite the attacks, the birth order concept is an idea that will not die. Dr. Sulloway's study is perhaps the most elaborate among the continuing efforts of dozens of researchers to find a link between birth order and such things as managerial ability, drug abuse, criminality, and teen-age pregnancies. In 1988 and 1989 there were 45 scientific reports on birth order, more than a third of which found it had no effect.
Dr. Sulloway, who is now a visiting scholar at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, may be living proof of his own theory. His first major work, ''Freud: The Mind of a Biologist,'' in 1979 scandalized orthodox psychoanalysts by saying that Freud borrowed much of his theory from the biological thinking of the period.
Now Dr. Sulloway has done it again. After years of research, he has proposed that firstborns are more likely to defend current theories and those born later are more likely to attack them. In the process, he is resurrecting the notion that birth order can to some degree steer personality in later life, an idea that most social scientists have come to reject.
''I'm skeptical of any reported effect for birth order,'' said Judith Blake, a sociologist at the University of California at Los Angeles. '' People get excited by the idea of birth order, but when you look at it scientifically, it evaporates.''
 
Support From Some Psychologists
But Dr. Sulloway's studies are finding support among some eminent psychologists.
''He has solid data,'' said Robert Zajonc, a psychologist at the University of Michigan. ''I can't argue with what he's found.'' Jerome Kagan, a psychologist at Harvard, called Dr. Sulloway's work ''the most extraordinary birth-order effect I've ever seen.''
Dr. Sulloway, a recipient of a MacArthur Foundation award, came to his view through the diligence of 19 years' labor and the assistance of scores of colleagues. For the last five of those years he squirreled himself away in a small, windowless office at Harvard.
There Dr. Sulloway finished his analysis of 2,784 participants in 28 major scientific controversies in the last 400 years. He included the 20 or so great revolutions of science, as well as some obscure controversies like the debate over phrenology. The main criterion was whether enough remained in the historical record about the scientific debate to evaluate the main participants.
Though he largely worked alone, he turned to nearly a hundred colleagues in the history of science, asking them to nominate the scientists to be studied. The historians judged the stands each scientist took, as well as as the scientist's political and religious views, family size and 40 other variables.
 
Birth Order and Innovation
Birth order was by far the strongest predictor of whether a scientist would accept or reject radically innovative ideas.
Of the 28 scientific revolutions, 23 were led by later borns. And in those with a firstborn as the leader - Einstein and Newton, for example - their prominent allies were for the most part later borns.
Of the 2,784 participants studied, 37 were siblings who joined in the same scientific controversy. Of the 7 firstborns among them, 6 opposed the radical new ideas being debated. And of the 30 younger siblings of these firstborns, 27 were supporters of the innovation.
''The overall probability that a firstborn will suppport a scientific revolution is 34 percent; the odds that a later born will do so are almost double: 64 percent,'' Dr. Sulloway said.
Dr. Sulloway reported the findings at the meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science in February. Since he announced his findings, they have sparked continuing controversy even though they are yet to be published.
 
Reformers Likely to Be Born Later
In studies currently underway, Dr. Sulloway is finding the same birth order effect at work among social reformers in historical movements like the abolition of slavery, civil rights, union organizing and women's rights.
''Later borns have a greater tendency to be reformers of all kinds,'' he said. ''For instance, the Protestant Reformation largely split noble families by birth order.''
Dr. Sulloway explains the conservatism of firstborns by their relationship with their parents. ''As the eldest, firstborns identify more closely with parents, and through them, with other authorities,'' he said. ''And they play the role of parental surrogate to later children. They end up more conforming, conscientious, and conventional than later siblings.''
On the other hand, he said, later siblings tend to rebel against the firstborn's authority.
''For the firstborn, it's taking over for daddy, being a responsible member of the establishment,'' said Dr. Zajonc. ''The younger ones grow up testing the limits, seeing what they can get away with.''
Despite a handful of influential defenders like Dr. Zajonc, Dr. Sulloway's theory is encountering a scientific attitude that is skeptical of any birth order studies.
 
Family Size Seen as More Important
Last July, Dr. Blake published data in Science showing that for 113,000 people, the order of birth made no difference in how far they went in school or how intelligent they were, despite earlier studies suggesting that firstborns had an advantage.
''What matters instead,'' Dr. Blake said, ''is how large a family one comes from. What had seemed to be birth order effects were artifacts. The real effect was due to parents' characteristics - the lower the social class and the less educated the parents, the bigger the family.''
Whatever small differences had been found, Dr. Blake said, were due to the statistical weight of those born seventh or later in families of poorer, less educated parents. Thus what seems to be an effect of birth order actually reflects the family's economic and educational status, Dr. Blake said.
Dr. Blake's attack on birth order theory came on the heels of a 1983 book ''Birth Order,'' written by two Swiss psychologists, Cecile Ernst and Jules Angst. A massive review of scientific studies, their work came to much the same conclusions as Dr. Blake: on closer scrutiny, virtually all the hundreds of findings about birth order are due to other factors like family size and economic status.
That includes the well-known findings, first proposed by Sir Francis Galton in 1874, that firstborns tend to rise to positions of eminence more than later borns.
But Mr. Sulloway used statistical methods that corrected for the influence of family size. He also pointed out that in their devastating critique of the birth order literature, Dr. Ernst and Dr. Angst found that one of the few ideas supported by well-done studies is that firstborns are more accepting of parental authority and identify more with their values than do those born later.
But, they noted, that has been shown only in studies with children and adolescents. Dr. Sulloway's is among the first to show it with adults.
 
Birth Order and Personality
Dr. Blake could not comment directly on Dr. Sulloway's study. ''I haven't seen his data,'' she said. But, she added that in a project now underway, she is analyzing data from almost 10,000 people to see if there is any relationship between any personality trait and birth order.
''I don't get anything for either birth order or family size on any personality variable, including conformity, sociability, anxiety and assertiveness,'' Dr. Blake said.
But some other recent findings fit well with Dr. Sulloway's theory. For instance, a study of 835 accountants published in 1988 found that firstborns scored higher than those born later on tests of dominance and leadership ability, of wanting to make a good impression and of achievement through conformity rather than through independence.
''The firstborns are more conformist because of their parents' expectations,'' said Arthur Bedeian, a professor of management at Louisiana State University and one of those who conducted the study. ''They're put in a leadership position from their early years, standing in for their parents in caring for the younger ones. The younger children, though, are freer to be independent, to define themselves by other standards.''
Some recent studies, like Dr. Sulloway's, are generally designed to overcome the objections of Dr. Blake and other critics. From some of the studies have come entirely new twists to the birth order concept.
For example, data from 7,018 children rated from birth to age seven showed that there was a direct relationship between birth position and the child's activity level. Firstborns were the most active, second children more active than third and so on.
''The finding surprised us,'' said Dr. Judith Chipperfield, a psychologist at the University of Manitoba and one of those who did the study. ''Children who are more active early in life learn more from their environment; they're more stimulated.''
Another new perspective holds that it is not birth order at play as much as the age of the child's mother. That position is taken by Stanley Coren, a neuropsychologist at St. Lawrence University in British Columbia. Noting that later born children have a greater chance than firstborns of being left-handed, Dr. Coren has proposed that is due to the mother's aging.
Children born to mothers in their early 30's are a third again more likely to be left-handed than children born to mothers between 17 and 24 years of age, while children born to mothers older than 40 are more than twice as likely to be left-handed.
The finding is of significance, Dr. Coren said, because about half of left-handed children have neurological indicators of problems in brain development, like dyslexia and other difficulties in problem-solving. Left-handed children also have more auto-immune diseases like allergies.
For her part, Dr. Blake remains skeptical of all the birth-order findings. ''I can't think of a domain where there's a genuine birth-order effect. Every time you look hard at it, it turns out to be an artifact, usually of family size.''
Other researchers feel that birth order still has effects, though not nearly so widespread as had once been thought. ''The psychology of birth order has a tiny effect, if any, on things like intelligence,'' said Dr. Zajonc. ''But it may be far more important in areas of life such as upholding traditional values and conventions or questioning them.''

HEADLINE: Huge Study Of Diet Indicts Fat And Meat

BYLINE: By JANE E. BRODY

 BODY:
EARLY findings from the most comprehensive large study ever undertaken of the relationship between diet and the risk of developing disease are challenging much of American dietary dogma. The study, being conducted in China, paints a bold portrait of a plant-based eating plan that is more likely to promote health than disease.
The study can be considered the Grand Prix of epidemiology. Sixty-five hundred Chinese have each contributed 367 facts about their eating and other habits that could ultimately help them and Americans preserve their health and prolong their lives. The data alone fill a volume of 920 pages, to be published next month by Cornell University Press. Among the first tantalizing findings are these: Obesity is related more to what people eat than how much. Adjusted for height, the Chinese consume 20 percent more calories than Americans do, but Americans are 25 percent fatter. The main dietary differences are fat and starch. The Chinese eat only a third the amount of fat Americans do, while eating twice the starch. The body readily stores fat but expends a larger proportion of the carbohydrates consumed as heat. Some of the differences may be attributable to exercise. The varying levels of physical activity among the Chinese were measured, but the data have not yet been analyzed. 
Reducing dietary fat to less than 30 percent of calories, as is currently recommended for Americans, may not be enough to curb the risk of heart disease and cancer. To make a significant impact, the Chinese data imply, a maximum of 20 percent of calories from fat - and preferably only 10 to 15 percent - should be consumed.
Eating a lot of protein, especially animal protein, is also linked to chronic disease. Americans consume a third more protein than the Chinese do, and 70 percent of American protein comes from animals, while only 7 percent of Chinese protein does. Those Chinese who eat the most protein, and especially the most animal protein, also have the highest rates of the ''diseases of affluence'' like heart disease, cancer and diabetes.
A rich diet that promotes rapid growth early in life may increase a woman's risk of developing cancer of the reproductive organs and the breast. Childhood diets high in calories, protein, calcium and fat promote growth and early menarche, which in turn is associated with high cancer rates. Chinese women, who rarely suffer these cancers, start menstruating three to six years later than Americans. Dairy calcium is not needed to prevent osteoporosis. Most Chinese consume no dairy products and instead get all their calcium from vegetables. While the Chinese consume only half the calcium Americans do, osteoporosis is uncommon in China despite an average life expectancy of about 70 years, just five few years less than the American average.
These findings are only the beginning. Dr. T. Colin Campbell, a nutritional biochemist from Cornell University and the American mastermind of the Chinese diet study, predicts that this ''living laboratory'' will continue to generate vital findings for the next 40 to 50 years.
The study, started in 1983 to explore dietary causes of cancer, has been expanded to include heart, metabolic and infectious diseases. Dr. Chen Junshi of the Chinese Institute of Nutrition and Food Hygiene organized the survey to cover locations from the semitropical south to the cold, arid north.
 
Exacting, Labor-Intensive Study
The extensive volume of raw data and its counterpart on computer tape will be available to any scientist to use as raw material for medical research.
It is an exacting, labor-intensive study, initially financed by the National Cancer Institute, that probably could not have been done anywhere except China. For nowhere else can accurate mortality statistics be combined with data from people who live the same way in the same place and eat the same foods for virtually their entire lives.
Nowhere else is there a genetically similar population with such great regional differences in disease rates, dietary habits and environmental exposures. For example, cancer rates can vary by a factor of several hundred from one region of China to another. These large regional variations in China highlight biologically important relationships between diet and disease.
And nowhere else could researchers afford to hire hundreds of trained workers to collect blood and urine samples and spend three days in each household gathering exact information on what and how much people eat, then analyzing the food samples for nutrient content.
 
'The Whole Diet Panoply'
''The total cost in U.S. dollars of this project - $2.3 million plus 600 person-years of labor contributed by the Chinese Government - is a mere fraction of what it would have cost to do the same study here,'' Dr. Campbell noted. And unlike typically circumscribed American studies that examine one characteristic as a factor in one disease, the Chinese investigation ''covers the whole diet panoply as it relates to all diseases.''
Dr. Mark Hegsted, emeritus professor of nutrition at Harvard University and former administrator of human nutrition for the United States Department of Agriculture, said: ''This is a very, very important study - unique and well done. Even if you could pay for it, you couldn't do this study in the United States because the population is too homogeneous. You get a lot more meaningful data when the differences in diet and disease are as great as they are in the various parts of China.''
In the first part of the study, 100 people from each of 65 counties throughout China each contributed 367 items of information about their diets, lives and bodies. The responses from residents of each county were then pooled to derive countywide characteristics that could be measured against the area's death rates for more than four dozen diseases.
By matching characteristics, researchers derived 135,000 correlations, about 8,000 of which are expected to have both statistical and biological significance that could shed light on the cause of some devastating disease.
In the poorer parts of China, infectious diseases remain the leading causes of death, but in the more affluent regions, heart disease, diabetes and cancer are most prominent, Dr. Campbell said.
 
Adding Taiwan to the Research
Although from an overall perspective of nutrient composition the Chinese diet is more health-promoting than ours, he said, there are some important limitations that result from a lack of economic development.
''Food quality and variety are not as good as ours,'' he explained. ''With limited refrigeration, bacteria and mold contamination is more common, large amounts of salt and nitrites are used to preserve foods and hot spices are used to mask off-flavors.''
The study is now being expanded and revised. New mortality rates are being gathered to update the original mortality data from the early 1970's and to reflect causes of death for 100 million people in the late 1980's. The original 6,500 participants are being resurveyed and people from 12 counties in Taiwan are being included in the expanded survey, which will also measure many socioeconomic characteristics.
''We want to see how economics change and health factors follow,'' Dr. Campbell explained in an interview. ''Taiwan should be interesting because it is intermediate between the United States and China in nutrient intake and plasma cholesterol levels. And since the Taiwanese gene pool is more like the Chinese, we can study the relative contributions of genetics and diet to risk of disease.''
 
Cholesterol as Disease Predictor
Dr. Campbell continued: ''So far we've seen that plasma cholesterol is a good predictor of the kinds of diseases people are going to get. Those with higher cholesterol levels are prone to the diseases of affluence - cancer, heart disease and diabetes.''
Contrary to earlier reports that linked low blood cholesterol levels to colon cancer, the Chinese study strongly suggests that low cholesterol not only protects against heart disease but also protects against cancer of the colon, the most common life-threatening cancer among Americans. In China, mortality rates from colon cancer are lowest where cholesterol levels are lowest.
Over all, cholesterol levels in China, which range from 88 to 165 milligrams per 100 milliliters of blood plasma, much lower than those in the United States, which range from 155 to 274 milligrams per 100 milliliters of plasma.
''Their high cholesterol is our low,'' Dr. Campbell noted. He said the data strongly suggest that a major influence on cholesterol levels and disease rates is the high consumption of animal foods, including dairy products, by Americans.
 
'Basically a Vegetarian Species'
''We're basically a vegetarian species and should be eating a wide variety of plant foods and minimizing our intake of animal foods,'' he said.
The Chinese have already begun to capitalize on these findings, using them to develop national food and agricultural policies that will promote health.
''Usually, the first thing a country does in the course of economic development is to introduce a lot of livestock,'' Dr. Campbell said. ''Our data are showing that this is not a very smart move, and the Chinese are listening. They're realizing that animal-based agriculture is not the way to go.''
The plant-rich Chinese diet contains three times more dietary fiber than Americans typically consume. The average intake in China is 33 grams of fiber a day, and it ranges as high as 77 grams in some regions. Dr. Campbell found no evidence to suggest that diets very high in fiber are in any way deleterious to nutritional well-being.
While American scientists worry that fiber may interfere with the absorption of essential minerals like iron, no reason for concern was found among the Chinese. Rather, those with the highest fiber intake also had the most iron-rich blood.
 
Iron From Vegetables
The study also showed that consumption of meat is not needed to prevent iron-deficiency anemia. The average Chinese adult, who shows no evidence of anemia, consumes twice the iron Americans do, but the vast majority of it comes from the iron in plants.
Nor are animal products needed to prevent osteoporosis, the study showed. ''Ironically,'' Dr. Campbell noted, ''osteoporosis tends to occur in countries where calcium intake is highest and most of it comes from protein-rich dairy products. The Chinese data indicate that people need less calcium than we think and can get adequate amounts from vegetables.''
Another common health concern that could prove to be a red herring is the fear that aflatoxin, which is produced by a mold that grows on peanuts, corn and other grains, causes liver cancer. Rather, the Chinese study strongly indicates that chronic infection with hepatitis B virus and high serum cholesterol levels are the primary culprits.
''We did not find any relationship between aflatoxin and liver cancer, and we have the largest study on this question ever done,'' Dr. Campbell said.
Among other intriguing findings are a relationship between infection with herpes simplex virus and coronary heart disease and a relationship between infection with the yeast candida and nasopharyngeal cancer.
''Lots and lots such relationships are turning up as we plot out the 367 characteristics on maps of China and try to match them up with maps of disease rates,'' Dr. Campbell said. ''The data now need to be interpreted, and six Chinese scientists are working with us on this. The amount of information gathered in this study is kind of staggering,'' he said, then proceeded to outline his interest in gathering more.

HEADLINE: Ocean Predator Is Preyed Upon; Sharks Need Help, Officials Say

 BODY:
SHARKS, the skillful and storied hunters of the deep, are being threatened by even tougher predators - people.
A dramatic rise in commercial fishing and a significant amount of recreational fishing pose problems for the survival of some species of shark in the Atlantic Ocean, the Gulf of Mexico and the Caribbean, Federal officials and scientists say.
To protect the remaining stocks, the National Marine Fisheries Service will soon propose a management plan that would limit the numbers of 38 of the 350 species of shark that could be caught by commercial and recreational fishermen. The plan covers a zone from 3 to 200 miles from the coast in the three areas. (State laws govern the area within three miles of the coast.) The plan, to be published next Tuesday in The Federal Register, is expected to take effect in September after a period for public comment and revision if any is needed. 
''If commercial fishing of sharks remains at current levels, some species may be vacant from waters within the next few years,'' said Paul Leach, an official of the fisheries service in St. Petersburg, Fla., who was also the chairman of the committee that prepared the plan.
As the predator at the top of the ocean food chain, sharks fulfill an evolutionary role by preying on fish and insuring that only the strongest survive. The sharks prey on virtually every type of fish, as well as squid, octopus, turtles, seals and whales. If the sharks were lost, the populations of prey species would explode, creating an imbalance. Dr. Samuel H. Gruber, a professor of marine biology at the University of Miami, said, ''They all live as an interwoven tapestry of life and when you pull one thread, it all unravels.''
 
A Threat From Fin Soup
The most serious threat is the practice known as finning, in which fishermen catch and slice off a shark's fins, discarding the bleeding carcass in the water. More than 35 million pounds of shark, or three times the yearly domestic catch, are discarded from finning in United States waters each year. The fins are valued in Asia, where shark fin soup is a delicacy.
In addition, shark meat has gained increasing popularity since the 1970's. At restaurants from Manhattan to Los Angeles, thresher or mako shark, both of them white, meaty fish that are grilled and served with a butter or garlic sauce, can be found on menus alongside mahi mahi and red snapper for $15 to $22. Fish markets in New York City sell shark meat for about $4.99 a pound.
''The demand from the public is increasing all the time,'' said Tom Hoff of the fisheries service. ''Since shark became a somewhat yuppie food, it's not uncommon to see two or three types of shark on a restaurant menu, and it's seriously depleting current stocks.''
In 1988, more than 14.6 million pounds of shark worth $9.5 million were sold commercially in the United States, excluding exports, more than double the 1987 level, according to fisheries service estimates.
Scientists and fishery managers are concerned about the dramatic growth in shark fishing. In 1986, reported commercial landings in the United States amounted to 1,200 metric tons. (A metric ton is about 2,204 pounds.) In 1987, that increased to 2,200 metric tons and in 1988 to 5,800 metric tons. Landings for 1989 are expected to be 10,000 to 12,000 metric tons. Recreational fishermen, who use fishing line like that of commercial shark fishermen, accounted for 3,000 metric tons in 1986, 4,000 metric tons in 1987, and 3,500 metric tons in 1988. The Federal fisheries agency warned that continued heavy fishing was likely to destroy the shark fishing industry itself.
 
'A Fascination for Humans'
Yet scientists' knowledge about sharks' habits and customs is limited, and conservation efforts must come to grips with the shark's image as a formidable predator that can prey on people.
''Sharks hold a fascination for humans, who feel obliged to kill them,'' said Dr. George Burgess, senior biologist in icthyology at the Florida Museum of Natural History. He said sharks stir up emotions of terror and dread in humans so that any brutality toward them is simply chalked up to ''evening the score.'' And environmentalists said it was unlikely that public opinion would come to the defense of such a skillful hunter.
''Sharks are just not the glamour organisms that motivate the environmentally concerned,'' said Harold Upton, the fisheries program director at the Center for Marine Conservation, an environmental group based in Washington. ''To a large degree, fish haven't been at the forefront of the conservation industry in general.''
The problem of conserving the dwindling population is compounded by sharks' low reproductive rate. A female shark typically produces 2 to 30 offspring in a lifetime, which ranges from 20 years to 30 years, depending on the species, though some have been found to be as old as 50 years.
 
Plan Sets Limits on Catches
The plan to manage sharks would set a quota of 5,800 metric tons for the commercial catch, limit the number of sharks killed as a byproduct of other fishing and limit recreational fishermen to one shark per person per day. Though the practice of finning would not be eliminated, the total weight of fins would be restricted and fishermen would be required to bring in a part of the carcasses.
The 38 species to be covered by the plan are those that are frequently caught by commercial or recreational fishermen or are particularly vulnerable because they have slow reproduction or growth rates. They include the thresher, mako, hammerhead, sharpnose, nurse, cow, angel, tiger and whale sharks.
 
Greatest Demand From Asia
By far the highest demand for shark products comes from Asia. Shark fins are dried, salted and soaked several times before the meat is extracted from them and cut into long, thin strips. Seven million pounds of shark fins worth $93 million were imported by Hong Kong last year, according to the Hong Kong Economic and Trade Office.
Sharks migrate through international waters and boundaries, making it difficult to calculate their population.
Though the most dangerous fish in the water may be in peril, commercial shark fishermen say it is their livelihood that is threatened.
 
Possible Government Limits
Chris Brannon, a commercial shark fisherman who operates 13 boats on the Gulf Coast, the East Coast and the Caribbean, said he favored some management of the shark-fishing industry but feared the Government limit would be too low.
''Shark can be taken off menus,'' said Mr. Brannon, who has been in the fishing industry for more than 20 years.''It's not like salmon or halibut, fish that have been entrenched in the market for a long time.
''The shark business right now is in its infancy and management could kill it or expand it,'' said Mr. Brannon, who switched about 10 years ago from catching tuna, shrimp and swordfish. ''They're forcing me back into already overfished industries.''
Mr. Brannon's company, Gulf Star Seafoods Inc., based in St. Elmo, Ala., typically ships about 180,000 pounds of shark steaks a week to retail fish markets in Los Angeles, Boston, Chicago, Detroit and San Francisco. Mr. Brannon recently built a new processing plant and added five new vessels to his fleet.
 
'A Benefit, Not a Hazard'
While commercial fishermen say the quota would reduce their catch, environmentalists are saying the quota is inadequate. ''The quota is probably erring on the side of exploitation,'' said Mr. Upton of the Center for Marine Conservation.
Jack Casey, a fisheries biologist at the National Marine Fisheries Laboratory in Narragansett, R.I., who has participated in a national shark tagging program for more than 20 years, said, ''It's a testimonial to the U.S. that a resource with such a sinister reputation is now being looked at as a benefit and not a hazard.''
Those like Mr. Casey in tagging programs said they were seeing fewer and fewer sharks in mid-life and only an occasional old-timer.
''The concern is that the shark population is so vulnerable,'' he said. ''Do we have to wait until the population crashes before we do something?''

HEADLINE: Spring Series of Art Auctions May Top $1 Billion in Sales

BYLINE: By RITA REIF

 BODY:
A 13-day series of auctions that may, for the first time, produce more than $1 billion in art sales got under way last night at Christie's in New York.
The high point of Christie's sale of contemporary art came when Roy Lichtenstein's ''Kiss II,'' from 1962, a wordless, larger-than-life cartoon of a couple embracing, was sold for $6 million, the highest price ever paid for a work by the artist. The buyer was the Fujii Gallery of Tokyo.
Other records were rewritten for Jean Dubuffet, whose colorful 1962 painting from his Paris circus series was bought for $5 million by the Chicago dealer Richard Gray, and for Sam Francis, whose ''Round the World,'' from 1958-59, was bought for $1.9 million by Larry Gagosian, a Madison Avenue dealer who also paid $3.7 million for Willem de Kooning's 'Untitled XII'' from 1982.
''The estimates of the paintings that did not sell were far too aggressive,'' Mr. Gagosian said. ''I think that stemmed from what has been going on for a while, with Sotheby's and Christie's bidding for properties and placing too-high estimates on them - conducting auctions before the auction.'' 
 
Strong Prices for the Best
The mood at Christie's wascheerful, but the bidding throughout the evening was selective, as 25 of the 77 works offered were not sold in an auction that totaled $40.2 million, well below the house's expectations of $50 million to $71.8 million.
Allan Stone, the New York dealer, left early. ''I think it is the healthiest thing that could happen,'' he said. ''The best things went for strong prices. The rest represents consignor greed because these auction houses allow it.''
Whether this sale was an exception or a prediction of what may happen in the next two weeks, most people did not wish to say. Leo Castelli the SoHo art dealer, expressed it this way: ''Only tomorrow will we have a true indication of a trend.''
The most intense interest in the series centers on two of the most important artworks ever to be auctioned. Vincent van Gogh's ''Portrait of Dr. Gachet'' (1890) will be presented next Tuesday at Christie's by the heirs of Siegfried Kramarsky, a New York banker and philanthropist. Two days later at Sotheby's, Pierre Auguste Renoir's renowned depiction of an open-air dance hall in Montmartre, ''Au Moulin de la Galette'' (1876), will be offered. Its owner is Betsey Cushing Whitney, the widow of John Hay Whitney, the financier, publisher, sportsman and former Ambassador to Britain.
The poignant van Gogh portrait, which was exhibited at the Metropolitan Museum of Art from 1984 until this year, depicts the artist's friend and physician Dr. Paul-Ferdinand Gachet as a troubled, introspective man. Paul Gauguin said of the painting that it captured ''the heartbroken expression of our time.''
The widely exhibited Renoir, the smaller and more atmospheric of two versions of the work painted by the artist (the mate hangs in the Musee d'Orsay in Paris) has been described by the art historian John Rewald as ''the finest work Renoir painted.''
 
Identical Estimates
The van Gogh and the Renoir each have the same presale estimate of $40 million to $50 million. This contrasts with the $53.9 million paid for van Gogh's ''Irises'' in November 1987, still the highest price ever paid at auction for a work of art. The disclosure that Sotheby's had loaned the Australian industrialist Alan Bond half the purchase price led to charges by critics that the market was artificially inflated. The painting has since been resold at an undisclosed price to the J. Paul Getty Museum in Malibu, Calif., but this development has not provoked a downturn in the auction market.
The upward spiral of art prices in recent years has attracted many extraordinary artworks to these auctions, further fueling positive expectations for these sales. The test of the market will be in whether the problems surrounding the sale of ''Irises'' deter the bidding for the major prizes, and in whether more moderate-priced artworks are as much in demand as they were six months ago.
Art specialists at Sotheby's and Christie's were optimistic before the sales when asked whether their sales may be affected by such factors as the continued slowdown in the economy, the fluctuations in foreign currencies (including the decline of the yen against the dollar), and the financial reversals experienced recently by some leading art collectors and dealers, including Charles Saatchi, the British advertising magnate, Mr. Bond, and Shigeki Kameyama, a Tokyo art dealer.
 
No Apparent Holding Back
David J. Nash, who heads fine-art sales at Sotheby's, said there was a ''puzzling contradiction'' between the positive results in the art market and the economic news of tremors in the Japanese stock market, on Wall Street and in the real estate market. ''From where I sit,'' he said, ''the world seems to be awash with money in the hands of the rich. I don't detect any holding back on the part of collectors and dealers when presented with these sales.''
Christopher Burge, president of Christie's in New York, said in assessing last night's auction:: ''We saw 75 percent of the sale sold. We saw some incredibly strong prices, and we saw some weaknesses. Contemporaary art was up 120 percent last year at Christie's. If you have a real downturn, you see greater problems than we saw tonight.''
Spurred by the boom economy of the 1980's, art-buying propelled prices to dizzying levels, bringing the 12-day series of art sales in New York last November to a record total of $930 million. Although there have been some disappointments recently at art sales in London, no major downturn has occurred in the market. The expectation for this series is sales of $933 million to $1.25 billion.
At the sale of Soviet contemporary art by Habsburg, Feldman in New York last Saturday, only 65 of the 121 offered works were sold, for a total of $1.7 million in an auction that was expected to bring $2.1 million to $2.8 million. But most New York sales have been successful thus far.
 
Auctions of Quality Works
The quality of the contemporary, Impressionist and modern art to be offered for sale in the next few days is staggering. There are five paintings at Christie's and four at Sotheby's valued at $10 million or more, and 201 artworks valued at $1 million or more - 106 at Sotheby's, 84 at Christie's and 11 at Habsburg, Feldman.
Both Sotheby's and Christie's are offering art from renowned collections, assembled by Robert Lehman, a financier who was chairman of the Metropolitan Museum of Art at his death in 1969; by Mr. Whitney; Mr. Kramarsky; Lydia Winston Malbin, daughter of the industrial architect Albert Kahn, and by Margaret Ryan, the widow of John Barry Ryan Jr., an heir to a New York fortune.
Museums have also consigned a number of major works to these auctions. Sotheby's will be the setting for the sale of three noted paintings from the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum - Kandinsky's ''Fugue'' (1914), Amedeo Modigliani's ''Boy With a Blue Shirt'' (1918) and Marc Chagall's ''Anniversaire'' (1923). The sale of the paintings, valued in all at $22 million to $31 million, is to help finance the museum's planned multi-million-dollar purchase of more than 200 Minimalist and other works from the collection of Count Giuseppe Panza di Biumo.
The Art Institute of Chicago has consigned paintings to both Sotheby's and Christie's. Sotheby's is auctioning an Edgar Degas pastel of a dancing class, a Claude Monet seascape, a Pierre Bonnard floral still life, and a 1953 oil on wood painting by Pablo Picasso, with an estimated total worth of $13.5 million to $17.7 million. The two paintings the Chicago museum sent to Christie's - a Modigliani portrait of a woman and a Maurice Utrillo street scene - are expected to bring $4.7 million to $6.9 million.
The properties from the Guggenheim and three of the four works from the Art Institute at Sotheby's are guaranteed, assuring payment of a minimum price to the consignors even if the paintings do not sell. Sotheby's has guaranteed a total of 127 works in these sales, valued at $119.5 million to $161.5 million.
These include 103 works from the Malbin collection, which is expected to total $66 million to $88 million in five different sessions. Most of the Malbin holdings of 20th-century art by Constantine Brancusi, Fernand Leger, Piet Mondrian, Joan Miro and Giacomo Balla, are to be auctioned on May 16. Eight other works are to be offered at Sotheby's contemporary sale tonight and tomorrow.
 
A Change of Policy
Christie's, long critical of Sotheby's guarantees, which were introduced about 1970, changed its policy in March and guaranteed the five works from the Lehman collection. The presale estimate for this art, to be auctioned May 15, is $40 million to $60 million.
Christie's is anticipating perhaps the most successful night in its 224-year history, the sale on May 15 of 81 Impressionist and modern works that may total or exceed $334.9 million. Some 61 of the works are valued at $1 million or more each, and five are expected to bring $10 million or more each.
Over the next two nights Sotheby's may equal or exceed those figures when it auctions 93 works from the Malbin collection, estimated to total up to $74.8 million, and 71 Impressionist and modern works from other owners valued at up to $289.5 million. In these sales, 10 works in the Malbin sale and 62 in the various owners' sale are valued at $1 million or more each, and three may exceed $10 million each.
Contemporary art comes up tonight at Sotheby's in a sale of 88 works, valued at $88 million to $114 million, in which two paintings by Mr. de Kooning are the major offerings. They are expected to bring a combined total of as much as $22 million.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST
