COMPANIES
 
Carl C. Icahn all but conceded that he had failed to win support for his plan to split USX. The votes cast at the annual meeting will not be tabulated for at least a week, but the indications are that the New York financier has come up short in his campaign. [Page D1.] 
 
Karl Eller resigned as chairman of Circle K, a week before the convenience-store company, behind on interest payments to creditors, was expected to file plans to reorganize. [D1.]
 
Chrysler is intensifying a two-month-old media blitz with new advertising based on a surprising finding that new-car buyers prefer Chrysler cars over Hondas, which had always gotten the highest quality ratings. [D1.]
 
Eviction of the Bloomingdale's store in Manhattan is being sought in a bankruptcy court battle. [D2.]
 
The Greyhound strike is over ''from all practical points of view,'' the bus company's chief executive said. [D5.]
 
Telephone caller identification can be foiled - at a price. A California company has set up a pair of 900 numbers to allow users to block transmission of their numbers. [D7.]
 
A former Bear, Stearns executive and three other men have been indicted on charges of conspiracy, perjury and obstruction of justice in a seven-year investigation into stock-lending. [D16.]
 
Playboy Enterprises announced a recapitalization plan aimed at helping it finance acquisitions and other activities without diluting the controlling stake of its founder, Hugh Hefner. [D5.]
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
German reunification will spur economic growth in Europe and the world, and should not set off more world inflation, West German officials said at a global monetary conference. [A1.]
 
Japan is increasing its trade and investment in the buoyant economies of East Asia, creating a highly efficient manufacturing bloc in this vital region. [A1.]
 
An aircraft with twice the range of the Concorde is expected to be studied by the Concorde's British and French makers. [D1.]

The White House committed itself to discuss new taxes in budget negotiations with Congress but stopped short of saying that President Bush was now prepared to accept higher taxes. [A1.]
 
U.S. business productivity fell an unexpectedly sharp 1 percent in the first quarter, despite the biggest gains in the manufacturing sector in nearly three years, the Labor Department said. [D6.]

Stocks rose for the sixth day in a row, holding on to a thin gain in light trading heavily influenced by a skittish bond market. The Dow gained 11.26, to 2,721.62. [D10.]
 
Prices of Treasury securities dipped in sluggish trading, as dealers prepared for the quarterly refunding auctions. [D16.]
 
The dollar fell against most major currencies, as the West German mark strengthened. [D17.]
 
Prices of grain and soybean futures closed higher, as expectation of additional export sales fueled buying interest. [D17.]
 
TODAY'S COLUMNS
 
California's health insurance industry is in disarray. Popular support is growing for measures that would require all employers in the state to provide coverage for employees. Milt Freudenheim: Business and Health. [D2.]
 
Wall Street seems to have reduced its expectations for corporate profits to achievable levels, and that seems to be starting to help share prices. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D10.]
 
The Martin Agency is asking, ''What's next,'' having weathered the departure of its founder, the hostile takeover of its parent company's parent company and an apparent renaissance in New York advertising. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [D23.]

PUB-DATE: May 8, 1990,

SECTION: Section D; Page 1, Column 4; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1424 words

HEADLINE: A Fervent Advocate Of the Proxy Battle

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Robert A. G. Monks has a resume that might endear him to any corporate board: a Harvard-educated lawyer who made his fortune as an industrialist; former chairman of a leading Boston investment firm; two-time Republican candidate for the United States Senate in Maine. And, he held top positions in the Reagan Administration.
In this case, appearances are deceiving. Mr. Monks is the scourge of many executive suites for his outspoken - and influential - views on corporate proxy battles. From a Georgetown office, Mr. Monks, 56 years old, heads a consulting business that for a fee advises more than 100 institutions, including the mammoth employee pension funds of New York City and California, on how to vote their proxies. And he has been a behind-the-scenes player in recent proxy contests, with victories at the Lockheed Corporation and Honeywell Inc.
For Mr. Monks, shareholder activism is a calling and he minces no words on its behalf. ''American chief executives are close to becoming the absolute monarchs that we saw in the 18th century,'' he said in an interview. ''Managements of large American corporations are only accountable to themselves. The words I use may be of governance and process, but what is really being said in a masculine, emotional way relates to power. In a psychological sense, it's like I'm gelding these guys.'' 
 
First-Hand Knowledge
What sets Mr. Monks apart from other proxy advisers is that he used to run companies himself. Nor does it hurt that he has enough wealth to pursue his interests. He took over a family coal and oil business that was eventually split and sold in 1972. He successfully speculated in oil during the energy squeeze in the mid-1970's and was chairman of the Boston Company, an investment firm, until it was taken over by American Express.
And while he has attacked corporate boards, he has sat on a few himself - not without criticism over possible conflicts of interest. Because of such questions, he recently decided to leave the board of Jefferies & Company, the Los Angeles brokerage that has advised corporate raiders. But he still holds paid advisory positions at Lambert Brussels Associates, which held a 33 percent stake in Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., and is an adviser to the American unit of Mitsubishi of Japan, though he says he may terminate these relationships.
He approaches corporate governance with a born-again fervor, gained during his years of Government service. He came to Washington in 1981 as a director of the ill-fated Synthetic Fuels Corporation and became, in 1984, head of the Labor Department's pension and welfare benefits program. Soon, he began to exhort pension fund managers to flex their power over intransigent corporate managers.
''I got the idea that stock ownership was a responsibility,'' he said. ''Before, I just wanted to trade.''
His 1984 speech ''The Institutional Investor as a Corporate Citizen'' set Labor Department policy that has encouraged proxy activism by pension funds and is considered a seminal work by shareholder activists. After leaving Government, he began, like a well-heeled Paul Revere, to travel the country, meeting pension-fund managers and spreading his views.
 
Passion Into Business
A passion turned into a business, and Mr. Monks's vehicle was Institutional Shareholders Services, a company he founded to analyze proxy questions and make recommendations - for a $10,000 annual base fee. His timing was right. Institutional funds were growing, and few had the in-house expertise, or willingness, to analyze complicated proxies, which meant that they often automatically sided with management. And, senior Labor Department officials had begun to put pressure on large institutions, which own nearly half of all corporate equities, to consider voting their proxies as a fiduciary duty.
''One of the major criticisms of institutional investors is that they own stocks but don't know enough about the companies they own to make an informed proxy vote,'' said John Wilcox, a managing director at Georgeson & Company, a New York proxy solicitor. ''It's a perfect situation for them to seek assistance, and Bob Monks has taken advantage of that.''
In running his business, Mr. Monks has walked a tightrope - between conflicts in his business activities and between promoting his own ideas and the interest of his clients.
Eyebrows were raised when Mr. Monks served as an unpaid adviser to the Dallas investor Harold C. Simmons, who led a proxy battle for control of Lockheed. Mr. Monks took pains to disclose that relationship because his firm was recommending that institutions side with Mr. Simmons. But Mr. Monks did not make similar efforts to disclose that he was a director at Jefferies, which was advising Mr. Simmons. Mr. Monks has since left the Jefferies board but still holds an equity stake in that firm. (His one remaining corporate directorship, is at Tyco Laboratories, a New Hampshire concern,) Others are concerned that Mr. Monks's zealousness for shareholder rights makes him recommend proxy-contest positions that are sometimes not in his clients' economic interests. Lilli A. Gordon, a managing director of the Analysis Group, a rival consulting firm based in Boston, pointed to the recent proxy bid by Torchmark, an insurance company with steller earnings, for American General, an insurance company with a weak stock performance. Mr. Monks recommended that his institutional clients oppose Torchmark because it has anti-takeover provisions in its own bylaws.
''When he gives advice that could potentially decrease value for the shareholders, he's ultimately not serving his clients,'' Ms. Gordon said.
To Mr. Monks, however, corporate governance leads to superior corporate performance. ''I'm not interested in having the world's most successful consulting firm, but in promoting my own agenda,'' he said.
So far, that agenda has led to major shareholder victories at Honeywell and at Lockheed. In both cases, he was instrumental in connecting with a well-known investor willing to foot the bill to wage a proxy battle -which can cost between $1 million and $5 million.
The 1989 Honeywell battle grew out of conversations Mr. Monks had with the Texas investor Richard E. Rainwater, once a financial adviser to the Bass brothers of Texas. Mr. Rainwater and other Texas investors owned 4.4 percent of Honeywell. Mr. Rainwater's group was unhappy with the company's stock performance and upset that Honeywell was asking shareholders to approve two anti-takeover measures.
If Mr. Rainwater's group would lead the proxy battle, Mr. Monks would rally the pension funds. After a one-week blitz, their side won. The effort was remarkable because the group worked without a complete list of Honeywell shareholders. They bypassed small shareholders and relied almost exclusively on institutional votes. ''This said institutions could ignore all other shareholders and still block management initiatives,'' said Mr. Wilcox, the proxy solicitor.
Another deep pocket for Mr. Monks was Mr. Simmons, chairman of NL Industries, who was willing to spend $11 million to take on Lockheed, in which NL had a $500 million stake. Even though Mr. Simmons did not succeed in ousting Lockheed's board, the company agreed to add three shareholders' representatives to its board and enacted three shareholder-rights measures that Mr. Simmons had proposed - overturning Lockheed's ''poison pill,'' opting out of anti-takeover protections provided by incorporation in Delaware, and confidential proxy votes.
 
New Plans Afoot
With these victories, Mr. Monks is plotting again. He wants to oppose management initiatives to issue ''sweetheart'' stock to thwart takeovers. He also wants corporations to create shareholders' advisory committees for their boards and opt out of Delaware's anti-takeover protection, if incorporated there.
In the current USX Corporation proxy battle, he has sided with the investor Carl C. Icahn, who wants to split the company.
Not all his clients follow his bidding, however. Paul Quirk, head of the Massachusetts Public Reserves Investment Management Board, said Mr. Monks's views are ''very refreshing'' but not always followed by his group. And Robert C. Pozen, general counsel at Fidelity Investments, terms Mr. Monks's opinions ''useful, but one of many views.''
Still, Mr. Monks thinks he's working on their behalf. ''It's difficult for many of my clients to take a high-visibility position,'' he said. ''I'm saying that I'll be the lightning rod.''
